original: 1. Nidānasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: nidāna saṃyuttam

original: 1. Buddhavaggo
analyzed: buddha vaggaḥ

original: 1. Paṭiccasamuppādasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Dependent Origination Sutta

original: 1. Evaṃ me sutanti – nidānavagge paṭhamaṃ paṭiccasamuppādasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ anupubbapadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: evam me sutam ti nidāna vagge paṭhamam paṭiccasamuppāda suttam tatra ayam anupubba pada vaṇṇanā
translated: Thus I heard. In the Nidāna Vagga, the first sutta is the Dependent Origination Sutta. Here is the commentary on the successive terms

original: – tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesīti, ettha tatrāti desakālaparidīpanaṃ. Tañhi
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi iti ettha tatra ati desa kāla paridīpanam tat hi
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus. Herein, there is a term for indicating the place and time. For

original: “yaṃ samayaṃ viharati, tatra samaye, yasmiñca jetavane viharati, tatra jetavane”ti🔽dīpeti. Bhāsitabbayutte vā desakāle dīpeti. Na hi bhagavā ayutte dese kāle ca dhammaṃ
analyzed: yam samayam viharati tatra samaye yasmin ca jetavane viharati tatra jetavana iti  dīpeti bhāsitabba yutte vā desa kāle dīpeti na hi bhagavā ayutte dese kāle ca dhammam
translated: it shows that “at the time when he was living, at that time, and in the Jeta Grove where he was living, in that Jeta Grove.”🔽Or it shows the place and time suitable for teaching. For the Blessed One does not teach Dhamma at an unsuitable place or time. Here the proof is this: “It is not the right time now, Bāhiya” .

original: bhāsati. “Akālo kho tāva bāhiyā”tiādi cettha sādhakaṃ. Khoti padapūraṇamatte, avadhāraṇe
analyzed: bhāsati akālaḥ tāva ca ittha sādhakam avadhāraṇe
translated: Kho is a particle in the sense of filling out the line or of limitation

original: ādikālatthe vā nipāto. Bhagavāti lokagarudīpanaṃ. Bhikkhūti kathāsavanayuttapuggalavacanaṃ.
analyzed: ādi kāla tthe vā nipātaḥ bhagavā ati loka garu dīpanam bhikkhū iti kathā savana yutta puggala vacanam
translated: or of the time of beginning. Blessed One is a term signifying the chief of the world. Bhikkhus is a term for persons who are suitable to hear the talk.

original: Apicettha “bhikkhakoti bhikkhu, bhikkhācariyaṃ ajjhūpagatoti bhikkhū”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: apica ittha bhikkhakaḥ iti bhikkhu bhikkhā cariyam ajjhūpagataḥ ti bhikkhu iti ādinā nayena
translated: And here the meaning of the words should be understood in this way: “He is a beggar , thus he is a bhikkhu ; he has undertaken the way of a beggar , thus he is a bhikkhu” .

original: vacanattho veditabbo. Āmantesīti ālapi, abhāsi, sambodhesi, ayamettha attho. Aññatra
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ veditabbaḥ āmantesi iti ālapi abhāsi sambodhesi ayam ettha atthaḥ aññatra
translated: He addressed : he spoke, he made them understand. This is the meaning here. But it also occurs with the meaning of “to announce”🔽as in the passage, “I announce to you, bhikkhus, I make known to you, bhikkhus” .

original: pana ñāpanepi hoti. Yathāha – “āmantayāmi vo, bhikkhave, paṭivedayāmi vo, bhikkhave”ti.
analyzed: pana ñāpane pi hoti yathā āha āmantayāmi vaḥ bhikkhave paṭivedayāmi vaḥ bhikkhave iti
translated: And it occurs with the meaning of “to summon”

original: Pakkosanepi. Yathāha – “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena sāriputtaṃ āmantehī”ti.
analyzed: pakkosane pi yathā āha ehi tvam bhikkhu mama vacanena sāriputtam āmantehi iti
translated: as in the passage, “Come, bhikkhu, in my name you can tell Sāriputta” .

original: Bhikkhavoti āmantanākāradīpanaṃ. Tañca bhikkhanasīlatādiguṇayogasiddhattā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti āmantanā ākāra dīpanam tat ca bhikkhana sīla tā ādi guṇa yoga siddhattā vuttam
translated: Bhikkhus : this is a term that indicates the way in which they were addressed. And that is said because they are so called owing to their possession of the qualities of the virtue of begging, etc.

original: Bhikkhanasīlatāguṇayuttopi hi bhikkhu, bhikkhanadhammatāguṇayuttopi bhikkhane sādhukāritāguṇayuttopīti
analyzed: bhikkhana sīla tā guṇa yuttaḥ api hi bhikkhu bhikkhana dhamma tā guṇa yuttaḥ api bhikkhane sādhukāri tā guṇa yuttaḥ api iti
translated: For a bhikkhu is so called because he possesses the quality of the virtue of begging, or because he possesses the quality of the state of a beggar, or because he possesses the quality of the proper performance of begging.

original: saddavidū maññanti. Tena ca tesaṃ bhikkhanasīlatādiguṇayogasiddhena vacanena hīnādhikajanasevitavuttiṃ
analyzed: sadda vidū maññanti tena ca tesam bhikkhana sīla tā ādi guṇa yoga siddhena vacanena hīna adhika jana sevita vuttim
translated: This is how the connoisseurs of words understand it. And by that expression, which is established by their possession of the qualities of the virtue of begging, etc.,

original: pakāsento uddhatadīnabhāvaniggahaṃ karoti. “Bhikkhavo”ti iminā ca karuṇāvipphārasommahadayanayananipātapubbaṅgamena🔽vacanena te attano abhimukhe karonto teneva kathetukamyatādīpakena nesaṃ vacanena
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ uddhata dīna bhāva niggaham karoti bhikkhavaḥ ti iminā ca karuṇā vipphāra sommahat aya nayana nipāta pubbaṅgamena  vacanena te abhimukhe karonto tena iva kathetu kamya tā dīpakena vacanena
translated: By the words “Monks,” which are the first to fall on the ear of the Blessed One, whose heart and eyes are full of compassion,

original: sotukamyataṃ janeti, teneva ca sambodhanatthena sādhukaṃ manasikārepi niyojeti. Sādhukaṃ
analyzed: jana iti tena iva ca sambodhana tthena sādhukam manasikāre pi niyoja iti sādhukam
translated: he makes them face him. And by the words, which indicate his desire to speak, he arouses in them a desire to listen. And by the very same words, which have the sense of addressing them, he enjoins them to pay close attention.

original: manasikārāyattā hi sāsanasampatti.
analyzed: manasikāra āyattā hi sāsana sampatti
translated: For the success of the Dispensation depends on close attention.🔽If it be asked why he addressed only the monks, though gods and men were present,

original: Aparesupi devamanussesu vijjamānesu kasmā bhikkhūyeva āmantesīti ce? Jeṭṭhaseṭṭhāsannasadāsannihitabhāvato.🔽Sabbaparisasādhāraṇā hi bhagavato dhammadesanā, parisāya jeṭṭhā bhikkhū paṭhamaṃ🔽uppannattā, seṭṭhā anagāriyabhāvaṃ ādiṃ katvā satthucariyānuvidhāyakattā sakalasāsanapaṭiggāhakattā
analyzed: aparesu pi deva manussesu vijjamānesu kasmai bhikkhūya iva āmantesi iti ce jeṭṭha seṭṭha āsanna sadā asannihita bhāvato  sabba parisa sādhāraṇā hi bhagavato dhamma desanā parisāya jeṭṭhāḥ bhikkhū paṭhamam  uppanna ttā seṭṭhā anagāriya bhāvam ādim katvā satthu cariyā anuvidhāyaka ttā sakala sāsana paṭiggāhaka ttā
translated: the answer is that the monks were the most venerable, the most excellent, the nearest, and the most constantly in attendance.

original: ca, āsannā tattha nisinnesu satthusantikattā, sadāsannihitā satthusantikāvacarattāti.
analyzed: ca āsannā tattha nisinnesu satthu santika ttā sadā sannihitā satthu santika avacara ttā ati
translated: For the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma is common to all the assembly. The monks are the most venerable because they are the first to come into being in each aeon. They are the most excellent because they are the followers of the Master’s way of life, which has homelessness as its distinguishing mark, and because they are the recipients of the whole dispensation. They are the nearest because they are seated near the Master. They are the most constantly in attendance because they are constantly in attendance on the Master.

original: Apica te dhammadesanāya bhājanaṃ yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipattisabbhāvato. Visesato ca
analyzed: apica te dhamma desanāya bhājanam yathā anusiṭṭham paṭipatti sabbhāvataḥ visesato ca
translated: and he addressed them because they were a vessel for the teaching of the Dhamma and because they were endowed with the practice of the training as taught.

original: ekacce bhikkhūyeva sandhāya ayaṃ desanāpīti evaṃ āmantesi.
analyzed: ekacce bhikkhūya iva sandhāya ayam desanā api iti evam āmantesi
translated: And in particular, he addressed them because this teaching was for the bhikkhus.

original: Kimatthaṃ pana bhagavā dhammaṃ desento paṭhamaṃ bhikkhū āmantesi, na dhammameva desesīti?🔽Satijananatthaṃ. Bhikkhū aññaṃ cintentāpi vikkhittacittāpi dhammaṃ paccavekkhantāpi🔽kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontāpi nisinnā honti. Te anāmantetvā dhamme desiyamāne “ayaṃ
analyzed: kimattham pana bhagavā dhammaṃ desento paṭhamam bhikkhū āmantesi na dhammam eva desesi iti  sati janana attham bhikkhū aññam cintentā api vikkhitta cittā api dhammam paccavekkhantā api  kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontā api nisinnāḥ honti te an āmantetvā dhamme desiyamāne ayaṃ
translated: But why did the Blessed One address the bhikkhus first when he was teaching the Dhamma, instead of teaching the Dhamma straight away?🔽It was in order to arouse mindfulness in them. For the bhikkhus sit down thinking of something else, with distracted minds, reviewing the Dhamma,

original: desanā kiṃnidānā kiṃpaccayā katamāya aṭṭhuppattiyā desitā”ti sallakkhetuṃ asakkontā🔽duggahitaṃ vā gaṇheyyuṃ, na vā gaṇheyyuṃ, tena nesaṃ satijananatthaṃ bhagavā paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: desanā kiṃnidānā kiṃpaccayā katamāya aṭṭhuppattiyā desitā ati sallakkhetum a sakkontā  duggahitam vā gaṇheyyum na vā gaṇheyyum tena na īsam sati janana attham bhagavā paṭhamam
translated: or giving attention to a meditation subject. If the Dhamma were taught without addressing them, they would be unable to discern, “This teaching has such and such a source, such and such a reference, such and such an origin,”

original: āmantetvā pacchā dhammaṃ deseti.

analyzed: vadamānaḥ bhagavā bhikkhū ālapati bhadanta iti vadamānā te bhagavantam paccālapanti  tathā hi bhikkhavaḥ iti bhagavā ābhāsati bhadanta iti paccābhāsanti bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: The Blessed One spoke to the monks. The monks spoke in reply to the Blessed One.🔽“Monks,” the Blessed One spoke. “Venerable sir,” the monks spoke in reply.🔽“Monks,” the Blessed One spoke. “Venerable sir,” the monks spoke in reply.

original: paṭivacanaṃ dāpeti, “bhadante”ti paṭivacanaṃ denti. Te bhikkhūti ye bhagavā āmantesi,🔽te. Bhagavato paccassosunti bhagavato āmantanaṃ patiassosuṃ, abhimukhā hutvā suṇiṃsu🔽sampaṭicchiṃsu paṭiggahesunti attho. Bhagavā etadavocāti, bhagavā etaṃ idāni vattabbaṃ
analyzed: paṭivacanam dāpeti bhadanta iti paṭivacanam denti te bhikkhū iti ye bhagavā āmantesi  te bhagavataḥ paccassosunti bhagavataḥ āmantanam abhimukhāḥ hutvā suṇiṃsu  paṭiggahesunti atthaḥ bhagavā etat avoca ati bhagavā etam idāni vattabbam

analyzed: evamādīni tesam aṭṭhuppattikaḥ nikkhepo
translated: and so on. These are the suttas that were spoken in response to a situation that had arisen.

original: Evametesu catūsu nikkhepesu imassa paṭiccasamuppādasuttassa parajjhāsayo nikkhepo.
analyzed: evam etesu catūsu nikkhepesu imassa paṭiccasamuppāda suttassa parajjhāsayaḥ nikkhepo
translated: Thus, of the four ways of introducing a sutta, this sutta on dependent origination is introduced by the Exalted One’s own thought.

original: Parapuggalajjhāsayavasena hidaṃ bhagavatā nikkhittaṃ. Katamesaṃ puggalānaṃ ajjhāsayavasenāti?
analyzed: para puggala jjhāsaya vasena hi idam bhagavatā nikkhittam katamesam puggalānam ajjhāsaya vasena ati
translated: The Exalted One has introduced this sutta in this way in order to show the nature of the person to whom it should be taught. To what kind of person should it be taught?

original: Ugghaṭitaññūnaṃ. Cattāro hi puggalā ugghaṭitaññū vipañcitaññū neyyo padaparamoti.
analyzed: ugghaṭita ññūnam cattāraḥ hi puggalāḥ ugghaṭita ññū vipañcita ññū neyyaḥ pada paramaḥ ti
translated: For there are four kinds of persons: those who understand from a brief statement, those who understand from an expanded statement, those who are guided, and those who are at the end of the list.

analyzed: tattha yassa puggalassa saha udāhaṭa velāya dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati puggalo  yassa puggalassa saṃkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthe vibhajiyamāne
translated: Herein, the person who has penetration of the Dhamma when the Thread is stated to him briefly is called🔽one who understands from a brief statement. The person who has penetration of the Dhamma when the meaning is expounded in detail of what was stated to him in brief is called

analyzed: dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati puggalo vipañcitaññū yassa puggalassa uddesato

translated: when he is taught the analysis, when he gives attention to the meaning with wisdom, when he frequents the wise, associates with the wise, honours the wise, is called🔽one who is guided. The person who has no penetration of the Dhamma in that life even though he hears much,

analyzed: bahum pi dhārayataḥ bahum pi vācayataḥ na tāya jātiyā dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati
translated: even though he bears much in mind, even though he recites much, is called

analyzed: puggalaḥ pada paramaḥ iti imesu catūsu puggalesu ugghaṭita ññū puggalānam ajjhāsaya vasena
translated: one who is at the end of the list. So of these four persons, it is for those who understand from a brief statement that the Blessed One usually states a Thread in brief.

original: idaṃ suttaṃ nikkhittaṃ.
analyzed: idam suttam nikkhittaṃ
translated: This Thread was laid down.

original: Tadā kira pañcasatā janapadavāsikā bhikkhū sabbeva ekacarā dvicarā ticarā catucarā🔽pañcacarā sabhāgavuttino dhutaṅgadharā āraddhavīriyā yuttayogā vipassakā saṇhaṃ sukhumaṃ
analyzed: tadā kira pañca satā janapada vāsikāḥ bhikkhū sabbe iva eka carā dvi carā ti carā catu carā  sa bhāga vuttinaḥ dhutaṅga dharāḥ āraddha vīriyāḥ yutta yogāḥ vipassakā saṇham su khumam
translated: At that time, it seems, five hundred bhikkhus living in the country districts, all of whom were single men, pairs, trios, fours,🔽fives, all of whom were of like disposition, all of whom were ascetics, all of whom were strenuous, all of whom were devoted to the higher consciousness, all of whom were subtle, all of whom were delicate,

original: suññataṃ paccayākāradesanaṃ patthayamānā sāyanhasamaye bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā,
analyzed: suññatam paccaya ākāra desanam patthayamānā sāyanha samaye bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā

analyzed: vanditvā ratta kambala sāṇiyā parikkhipamānā viya desanam paccāsīsamānā parivāretvā

original: nisīdiṃsu. Tesaṃ ajjhāsayavasena bhagavā idaṃ suttaṃ ārabhi. Yathā hi cheko cittakāro
analyzed: nisīdiṃsu tesam ajjhāsaya vasena bhagavā idam suttam ārabhi yathā hi chekaḥ citta kāro
translated: The Lord began this Thread in accordance with their disposition. Just as a clever painter

original: aparikammakatabhittiṃ labhitvā, na āditova rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi, mahāmattikalepādīhi
analyzed: a parikamma kata bhittim labhitvā na āditas va rūpam samuṭṭhāpesi mahā mattika lepa ādīhi

analyzed: pana bhitti parikammam tāva katvā kata parikammāya bhittiyāḥ rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti kata parikammam

original: pana bhittiṃ labhitvā, bhittiparikammabyāpāraṃ akatvā, raṅgajātāni yojetvā, vaṭṭikaṃ

translated: so too, when the Blessed One has got a clansman who has begun by taking a vow,

analyzed: tāva ācikkhati yam sandhāya vuttam  tasmāt iha tvam bhikkhu ādim eva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu kaḥ ca ādi kusalānam  dhammānam sīlam ca su visuddham diṭṭhi ca ujukā yatas kho te bhikkhu sīlam ca su visuddham
translated: according as it is said:

analyzed: bhavissati ca ujukā tatas tvam bhikkhu sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro

Right view is the beginning; right thought … right speech … right action … right livelihood … right effort … right mindfulness … right concentration is the middle; right knowledge is the end. Right concentration is the beginning; right knowledge and right deliverance are the middle; right concentration is the end. Right knowledge is the beginning; right deliverance is the middle; right concentration is the end” .

original: satipaṭṭhāne tividhena bhāveyyāsi. Katame cattāro? Idha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ajjhattaṃ

analyzed: vā kāye kāya anupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassam  bahiddhā vā kāya īpe ajjhatta bahiddhā vā kāya īpe dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharāhi  ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassam yatas kho tvam bhikkhu sīlam
translated: Or, you should live contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things, ardent, clearly knowing, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.🔽When, bhikkhu, you, depending on virtue, established on virtue,

analyzed: nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evam tividhena bhāvessasi tatas

analyzed: tuyham bhikkhu yā ratti vā divasaḥ vā āgamissati vuddhiyā iva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu

analyzed: dhammesu no parihāni iti

analyzed: evam ādikammika kula puttassa sīla kathāya parikammam kathetvā arahatta padaṭṭhānam saṇham sukhumam suññatam vipassanā lakkhaṇam ācikkhati
translated: Having spoken thus, having given this advice to the clansman who was a beginner, he explained the four Arousings of Mindfulness in detail, and after giving the advice on the four Arousings of Mindfulness, he explained the four Noble Truths, and after explaining the four Noble Truths, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Abidings, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Abidings, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Concentration, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Concentration, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Equanimity, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Equanimity, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, he explained the four Noble Truths, and after explaining the four Noble Truths, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Abidings, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Abidings, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Concentration, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Concentration, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Equanimity, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Equanimity, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, and after explaining the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, he explained the four Noble Truths, and after explaining the four Noble Truths, he explained the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, and after explaining the four Ways

original: Parisuddhasīlaṃ pana āraddhavīriyaṃ yuttayogaṃ vipassakaṃ labhitvā, nāssa pubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: parisuddha sīlam pana āraddha vīriyam yutta yogam vipassakam labhitvā na assa pubbabhāga paṭipadam
translated: But when he had found a monk of purified virtue, who was energetic and devoted to his task, and who was a meditator, he did not teach him the preliminary part of the practice.

original: ācikkhati, ujukameva pana arahattapadaṭṭhānaṃ saṇhaṃ sukhumaṃ suññataṃ vipassanālakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: ācikkhati ujukam eva pana arahatta padaṭṭhānam saṇham sukhumam suññatam vipassanā lakkhaṇam
translated: He taught him the straight way, the footing for the attainment of arahatship, which is soft, subtle, and void of self, and which is the characteristic of insight.

original: ācikkhati. Ime pañcasatā bhikkhū pubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ parisodhetvā ṭhitā sudhantasuvaṇṇasadisā
analyzed: ācikkhati ime pañcasatāḥ bhikkhū pubbabhāga paṭipadam parisodhetvā ṭhitā su dhanta suvaṇṇa sadisā
translated: These five hundred monks, who were like well-polished gold, like a heap of well-polished gems, had purified the preliminary part of the practice and were waiting for the path.

original: suparimajjitamaṇikkhandhasannibhā, eko lokuttaramaggova nesaṃ anāgato. Iti tassāgamanatthāya
analyzed: su parimajjita maṇi kkhandha sannibhāḥ ekaḥ lokuttara maggaḥ uva na īsam anāgataḥ iti tassa āgamana tthāya
translated: The only thing that was lacking was the supramundane path. Therefore the Teacher,

original: satthā tesaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ apekkhamāno idaṃ suttaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: satthā tesam ajjhāsayam apekkhamānaḥ idam suttam ārabhi
translated: looking for an opportunity to teach them, began this sutta.

original: Tattha paṭiccasamuppādanti paccayākāraṃ. Paccayākāro hi aññamaññaṃ paṭicca sahite🔽dhamme uppādeti. Tasmā paṭiccasamuppādoti vuccati. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana
analyzed: tattha paṭiccasamuppādanti paccaya ākāram paccaya ākāraḥ hi aññam aññam paṭicca sahite  dhamme uppādeti tasmā paṭiccasamuppādo ti vuccati ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana
translated: Herein, dependent origination is the principle of conditionality. For the principle of conditionality causes and conditions to arise in mutual dependence,

original: visuddhimaggato gahetabbo.
analyzed: visuddhi maggataḥ gahetabbaḥ
translated: in combination. Therefore it is called dependent origination. This is a brief explanation. The detailed explanation should be understood according to the Visuddhimagga.

original: Voti ayaṃ vo-saddo paccatta-upayogakaraṇa-sampadāna-sāmivacana-padapūraṇesu dissati.🔽“Kacci pana vo anuruddhā samaggā sammodamānā”tiādīsu hi paccatte dissati. “Gacchatha,
analyzed: vo ti ayam vo saddo paccatta upayoga karaṇa sampadāna sāmi vacana pada pūraṇesu dissati  kacci pana vaḥ anuruddhā samaggā sammodamānā iti ādīsu hi paccatte dissati gacchatha
translated: Vo is a word for the vocative case, the instrumental case, the dative case, the ablative case, and the locative case.

original: bhikkhave, paṇāmemi vo”tiādīsu upayoge. “Na vo mama santike vatthabba”ntiādīsu karaṇe.🔽“Vanapatthapariyāyaṃ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmī”tiādīsu sampadāne. “Sabbesaṃ vo, sāriputta,
analyzed: bhikkhave paṇāmemi vaḥ ti ādīsu upayoge na vaḥ mama santike vatthabba nti ādīsu karaṇe  vana pattha pariyāyam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi iti ādīsu sampadāne sabbesam vaḥ sāriputta
translated: For in such passages as “But, Anuruddha, are you all harmonious, in concord, with a common recitation?” it is the vocative case. In such passages as “Go, bhikkhus, I dismiss you” it is the instrumental case. In such passages as “You should not dwell with me” it is the dative case.

original: subhāsita”ntiādīsu sāmivacane. “Ye hi vo ariyā parisuddhakāyakammantā”tiādīsu padapūraṇamatte.
analyzed: su bhāsita nti ādīsu sāmivacane ye hi vaḥ ariyā parisuddha kāya kammantā ati ādīsu pada pūraṇa matte
translated: In such passages as “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you a discourse on what pertains to happiness” it is the ablative case. In such passages as “Sariputta, all that you have said is well said” it is the locative case. In such passages as “Those who are noble thoroughbred persons” it is merely a filler word.

original: Idha panāyaṃ sampadāne daṭṭhabbo. Bhikkhaveti patissavena abhimukhībhūtānaṃ puna🔽ālapanaṃ. Desessāmīti desanāpaṭijānanaṃ. Taṃ suṇāthāti taṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ taṃ
analyzed: idha pana ayam sampadāne daṭṭhabbaḥ bhikkhave iti patissavena abhimukhībhūtānam puna  ālapanam desessāmi iti desanā paṭijānanam tam suṇātha ati tam paṭiccasamuppādam tam
translated: But here it should be regarded as the ablative case. Bhikkhus: this is an address.🔽Desessami: this is the undertaking of the teaching.

original: desanaṃ mayā vuccamānaṃ suṇātha.
analyzed: desanam mayā vuccamānam suṇātha
translated: Sunatha: this is the exhortation to listen to the dependent origination and the teaching being given by me.

original: Sādhukaṃ manasi karothāti ettha pana sādhukaṃ sādhūti ekatthametaṃ. Ayañca sādhusaddo
analyzed: sādhukam manasi karotha ati ettha pana sādhukam sādhu iti ekattham etam ayaṃ ca sādhu saddo

analyzed: āyācana sampaṭicchana sampahaṃsana sundara daḷhī kamma ādīsu dissati sādhu me bhante
translated: This word “well” is found in the sense of entreaty, consent, approval, beauty, and emphasis.

original: bhagavā saṃkhittena dhammaṃ desetū”tiādīsu hi āyācane dissati. “Sādhu, bhanteti kho
analyzed: bhagavā saṃkhittena dhammam desetu utiādīsu hi āyācane dissati sādhu bhante iti kho
translated: In the passage beginning, “It would be good, venerable sir, if the Blessed One would teach me the Dhamma in brief” , it is found in the sense of entreaty.

original: so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā”tiādīsu sampaṭicchane. “Sādhu
analyzed: saḥ bhikkhu bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā ati ādīsu sampaṭicchane sādhu
translated: In the passage beginning, “Very well, venerable sir,” the bhikkhu delighted and rejoiced in the Blessed One’s words, and then rose from his seat and departed” , it is found in the sense of consent.

original: sādhu, sāriputtā”tiādīsu sampahaṃsane.🔽“Sādhu dhammarucī rājā, sādhu paññāṇavā naro;
analyzed: sādhu sāriputta ati ādīsu sampahaṃsane  sādhu dhammaruciḥ rājā sādhu paññāṇavā naraḥ
translated: In the passage beginning, “Good, good, Sāriputta” , it is found in the sense of approval.🔽In the passages beginning, “Good is the delight of one gone forth, good is self-control, good is the subduing of vanity, good is the stilling of all formations” ,

original: Sādhu mittānamaddubbho, pāpassa akaraṇaṃ sukha”nti. –
analyzed: sādhu pāpassa a karaṇam sukhanti
translated: and “Good is the king who delights in the Dhamma, good is the man who is wise at home, good is the friend who is hard to win over, good is the non-doing of evil” , it is found in the sense of beauty.

original: Ādīsu sundare. “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, sādhukaṃ suṇāhī”tiādīsu sādhukasaddoyeva daḷhīkamme
analyzed: ādīsu sundare tena hi brāhmaṇa sādhukam suṇāhi iti ādīsu sādhuka saddaḥ yā iva daḷhīkamme
translated: In the passage beginning, “Then, brahmin, listen and heed well” , the word “well” is itself an emphasis.

original: āṇattiyantipi vuccati. Idha panāyaṃ ettheva daḷhīkamme āṇattiyā ca attho veditabbo,
analyzed: āṇattiyam tipi vuccati idha pana ayam ettha iva daḷhīkamme āṇattiyā ca atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: It is also called an “injunction.” But here it should be understood to have the sense of both an emphasis and an injunction.

original: sundaratthepi vaṭṭati. Daḷhīkaraṇatthena hi “daḷhaṃ imaṃ dhammaṃ suṇātha, suggahitaṃ🔽gaṇhantā”, āṇattiatthena “mama āṇattiyā suṇātha” sundaratthena “sundaramimaṃ bhaddakaṃ
analyzed: sundara atthe api vaṭṭati daḷhīkaraṇa atthena hi daḷham imam dhammam suṇātha suggahitam  gaṇhantā āṇatti atthena mama āṇattiyā suṇātha sundara tthena sundaram imam bhaddakam
translated: and it is also appropriate in the case of the beautiful. For the meaning of “firm” is indicated by “Listen to this Dhamma, monks, and be very attentive,🔽bearing in mind what is said by me in the way it is said”;🔽by “Listen to this Dhamma, monks, by my injunction” in the sense of “command”;

original: dhammaṃ suṇāthā”ti etaṃ dīpitaṃ hoti. Manasi karothāti āvajjetha. Samannāharathāti
analyzed: dhammam suṇātha ati etam dīpitam hoti manasi karotha ati āvajjetha samannāharatha ati
translated: and by “Listen to this Dhamma, monks, which is beautiful in the beginning, beautiful in the middle, and beautiful in the end, with its own intrinsic meaning and expression, complete in its arguments, complete in its courses of conduct, complete in its requisites of enlightenment, a Dhamma that I have made known in all its details” in the sense of “beautiful.”🔽“Be attentive” means “make it your object.” The meaning is: “Be intent on it.”

original: attho. Avikkhittacittā hutvā nisāmetha, citte karothāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: attho a vikkhitta cittāḥ hutvā nisāmetha citte karotha ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The purport is: “Be intent on it, not distracted.”

original: Idānettha taṃ suṇāthāti sotindriyavikkhepanivāraṇametaṃ. Sādhukaṃ manasi karothāti
analyzed: tam suṇātha ati sotindriya vikkhepa nivāraṇam etam sādhukam manasi karotha ati
translated: Herein, “Listen to this” is a prevention of distraction of the ear faculty.🔽“Be attentive” is a prevention of distraction of the mind faculty by the instigation to make the attention well-established.🔽The former is a prevention of misinterpretation of the letter,

original: manasikāre daḷhīkammaniyojanena manindriyavikkhepanivāraṇaṃ. Purimañcettha byañjanavipallāsagāhanivāraṇaṃ,🔽pacchimaṃ atthavipallāsagāhanivāraṇaṃ. Purimena ca dhammassavane niyojeti, pacchimena
analyzed: manasikāre daḷhī kamma niyojanena man indriya vikkhepa nivāraṇam purimam ca itthā byañjana vipallāsa gāha nivāraṇam  pacchimam attha vipallāsa gāha nivāraṇam purimena ca dhammassavane niyojeti pacchimena
translated: the latter a prevention of misinterpretation of the meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,🔽and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,🔽and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,🔽and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,

original: sutānaṃ dhammānaṃ dhāraṇūpaparikkhāsu. Purimena ca “sabyañjano ayaṃ dhammo, tasmā
analyzed: sutānam dhammānam dhāraṇa upaparikkhāsu purimena ca sa byañjanaḥ ayam dhammaḥ tasmai
translated: and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,🔽and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,🔽and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen to the Dhamma,🔽and by the latter to the retention of the Dhamma heard and to the investigation of its meaning. And by the former he is urged to listen

original: savanīyo”ti dīpeti, pacchimena “sāttho, tasmā manasi kātabbo”ti. Sādhukapadaṃ vā
analyzed: dīpeti pacchimena tasmā manasi kātabbā iti sādhuka padam vā
translated: and the last, “it should be given attention.”

original: ubhayapadehi yojetvā, “yasmā ayaṃ dhammo dhammagambhīro ca desanāgambhīro ca, tasmā
analyzed: ubhaya padehi yojetvā yasmai ayam dhammo dhamma gambhīro ca desanā gambhīro ca tasmai
translated: Or the word “well” may be construed with each of the other two words, in which case the construction should be understood as follows: “Since this Dhamma is profound in its meaning and profound in its teaching,

original: suṇātha sādhukaṃ. Yasmā atthagambhīro ca paṭivedhagambhīro ca, tasmā sādhukaṃ manasi🔽karothā”ti evaṃ yojanā veditabbā. Bhāsissāmīti desessāmi. “Taṃ suṇāthā”ti ettha paṭiññātaṃ
analyzed: suṇātha sādhukam yasmai attha gambhīro ca paṭivedha gambhīro ca tasmai sādhukam manasi  karotha ati evam yojanā veditabbā bhāsissāmi iti desessāmi tam suṇātha ati ettha paṭiññātam
translated: listen to it well. Since it is profound in its meaning and profound in its penetration,🔽give it attention well.”

original: desanaṃ saṃkhittatova na desessāmi, apica kho vitthāratopi naṃ bhāsissāmīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: desanam saṃkhittataḥ va na desessāmi api ca kho vitthārataḥ pi nam bhāsissāmi iti vuttam
translated: “Listen to it” means “I will not teach the doctrine that you have asked for in brief only, but rather I will teach it in detail as well.”

original: hoti. Saṅkhepavitthāravācakāni hi etāni padāni. Yathāha vaṅgīsatthero –
analyzed: saṅkhepa vitthāra vācakāni hi etāni padāni yathā āha vaṅgīsattheraḥ
translated: For these words refer to a brief and detailed explanation. As the Elder Vaṅgīsa said:

original: “Saṃkhittenapi deseti, vitthārenapi bhāsati;
analyzed: deseti vitthārena api bhāsati
translated: “He teaches in brief, he speaks in detail,

original: Sāḷikāyiva nigghoso, paṭibhānaṃ udīrayī”ti. ;
analyzed: nigghosaḥ paṭibhānam
translated: His eloquence is like a cascade’s sound.”

original: Evaṃ vutte ussāhajātā hutvā evaṃ, bhanteti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ satthu vacanaṃ sampaṭicchiṃsu, paṭiggahesunti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Atha nesaṃ bhagavā etadavoca – etaṃ idāni vattabbaṃ “katamo ca, bhikkhave, paṭiccasamuppādo”tiādiṃ
analyzed: evam vutte ussāha jātāḥ hutvā evam bhante iti kho te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ paccassosum satthu vacanam sampaṭicchiṃsu paṭiggahesunti vuttam hoti  atha na īsam bhagavā etat avoca etam idāni vattabbam katamaḥ ca bhikkhave paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ti ādiṃ
translated: When this was said, the bhikkhus were inspired with zeal and said, “Yes, venerable sir,” and they listened to the Blessed One’s speech. They listened and received it respectfully, and this is what the Blessed One said:🔽“And what, bhikkhus, is dependent origination? “

original: sakalaṃ suttaṃ avoca. Tattha katamo ca, bhikkhave, paṭiccasamuppādoti kathetukamyatāpucchā.
analyzed: sakalam suttam avoca tattha katamaḥ ca bhikkhave paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ti kathā itu kamya tā pucchā
translated: Herein, “And what, bhikkhus, is dependent origination?” is a question section.

original: Pañcavidhā hi pucchā adiṭṭhajotanāpucchā diṭṭhasaṃsandanāpucchā vimaticchedanāpucchā
analyzed: pañcavidhā hi pucchāḥ a diṭṭha jotanā pucchāḥ diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchāḥ vimati chedanā pucchā
translated: For there are five kinds of questions: questions for specific location, questions for definition, questions for identification,

original: anumatipucchā kathetukamyatāpucchāti, tāsaṃ idaṃ nānattaṃ –
analyzed: anumati pucchā kathā itu kamyatā pucchā ati tāsam idam nānattam
translated: questions for discussion, and questions for teaching.

original: Katamā adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā ? Pakatiyā lakkhaṇaṃ aññātaṃ hoti adiṭṭhaṃ atulitaṃ atīritaṃ
analyzed: katamā adiṭṭha jotanā pucchā pakatiyā lakkhaṇam aññātam hoti adiṭṭham a tulitam ati īritam
translated: Herein, what is a question for specific location? The specific location of a characteristic that is not known, not seen, not recognized, not contacted, not reflected upon, not pondered, is not clear, is not evident.

original: avibhūtaṃ avibhāvitaṃ. Tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya tulanāya tīraṇāya vibhūtāya vibhāvanatthāya
analyzed: a vibhūtam a vibhāvitam tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya tulanāya tīraṇāya vibhūtāya vibhāvana tthāya
translated: For the purpose of knowing, seeing, recognizing, contacting, reflecting upon, pondering, making clear, and making evident that characteristic,

original: pañhaṃ pucchati. Ayaṃ adiṭṭhajotanāpucchā.
analyzed: pañham pucchati ayam a diṭṭha jotanā pucchā
translated: a question is asked. This is a question for specific location.🔽What is a question for definition?

original: Katamā diṭṭhasaṃsandanāpucchā? Pakatiyā lakkhaṇaṃ ñātaṃ hoti diṭṭhaṃ tulitaṃ tīritaṃ
analyzed: katamā diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchā pakatiyā lakkhaṇam ñātam hoti diṭṭham tulitam tīritam
translated: What is a question asking for a connected statement? One who knows, sees, weighs, considers,

original: vibhūtaṃ vibhāvitaṃ. So aññehi paṇḍitehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: vibhūtam vibhāvitam saḥ aññehi paṇḍitehi saddhim saṃsandana tthāya pañham pucchati
translated: examines, and judges the characteristics of a thing by nature, asks a question in order to discuss it with other wise men.

original: Ayaṃ diṭṭhasaṃsandanāpucchā.
analyzed: ayam diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchā
translated: This is a question asking for a connected statement.

original: Katamā vimaticchedanāpucchā? Pakatiyā saṃsayapakkhando hoti vimatipakkhando dveḷhakajāto
analyzed: katamā vimati chedanā pucchā pakatiyā saṃsaya pakkhando hoti vimati pakkhando dveḷhaka jāto
translated: What is a question asking for a decision? One who is naturally inclined to doubt, inclined to uncertainty, born of uncertainty,

original: – “evaṃ nu kho, na nu kho, kathaṃ nu kho”ti, so vimaticchedanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchati,
analyzed: evam nu kho na nu kho katham nu kho ti so vimati chedana tthāya pañham pucchati
translated: “Is it so? Is it not so? What is it?” asks a question in order to decide his doubt.

original: ayaṃ vimaticchedanāpucchā.🔽Katamā anumatipucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ anumatiyā pañhaṃ pucchati – “taṃ kiṃ maññatha,🔽bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti, aniccaṃ, bhante. Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: ayam vimati chedanā pucchā  katamā anumati pucchā bhagavā bhikkhūnam anumatiyā pañham pucchati tam kim maññatha  bhikkhave rūpam niccam vā aniccam vā ati aniccam bhante yam pana aniccam dukkham
translated: This is a question asking for a decision.

original: vā taṃ sukhaṃ vāti, dukkhaṃ, bhante. Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ
analyzed: vā tam sukham vāti dukkham bhante yam pana aniccam dukkham vipariṇāma dhammam kallam
translated: What is a question asking for approval? The Blessed One asks a question with the approval of the bhikkhus: “What do you think, bhikkhus, is material form permanent or impermanent?” “Impermanent, venerable sir.” “But that which is impermanent, is it painful or pleasant?” “Painful, venerable sir.” “But that which is impermanent, painful, and subject to change, is it proper to regard it thus: ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self’?” “No, venerable sir.”

original: nu taṃ samanupassituṃ – “etaṃ mama esohamasmi eso me attā”ti, no hetaṃ bhanteti. Ayaṃ anumatipucchā.
analyzed: nu tam samanupassitum etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati no ha itam bhante iti ayam anumati pucchā
translated: “Do you regard it thus: ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self’?” “No, venerable sir.” This is the question asking for assent.

original: Katamā kathetukamyatāpucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ kathetukamyatāya pañhaṃ pucchati – “cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā. Katame cattāro”ti? Ayaṃ kathetukamyatāpucchāti.🔽Tattha buddhānaṃ purimā tisso pucchā natthi. Kasmā? Buddhānañhi tīsu addhāsu kiñci
analyzed: katamā kathetu kamyatā pucchā bhagavā bhikkhūnam kathetu kamyatāya pañham pucchati cattāro me bhikkhave sati paṭṭhānā katame cattāro ti ayam kathetu kamyatā pucchā ati  tattha buddhānam purimāḥ tissaḥ pucchāḥ natthi kasmā buddhānam hi tīsu addhāsu kiñci
translated: What is the question asking for a statement? The Blessed One asks the bhikkhus a question in order to make a statement: “Bhikkhus, there are these four foundations of mindfulness. What are the four?” This is the question asking for a statement.

original: saṅkhataṃ addhāvimuttaṃ vā asaṅkhataṃ adiṭṭhaṃ ajotitaṃ atulitaṃ atīritaṃ avibhūtaṃ🔽avibhāvitaṃ nāma natthi. Tena nesaṃ adiṭṭhajotanāpucchā natthi. Yaṃ pana bhagavatā🔽attano ñāṇena paṭividdhaṃ, tassa aññena samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena
analyzed: saṅkhatam addhāvimuttam vā a saṅkhatam a diṭṭham a jotitam a tulitam a tīritam a vibhūtam  avibhāvitam nāma natthi tena nesam adiṭṭha jotanā pucchā natthi yam pana bhagavatā  attanaḥ ñāṇena paṭividdham tassa aññena samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena
translated: Herein, the first three questions do not arise for Buddhas. Why is that? Because there is nothing in the three periods of time that is formed or unformed, seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, sought after, or examined by the Buddhas and is not fully understood by them.🔽Therefore they have no question asking for a statement of what is seen or heard. But as to what is penetrated by the Blessed One’s knowledge, there is no need for him to discuss it with any recluse or brahmin or god or Mara or Brahma or with anyone else in the world.

original: vā brahmunā vā saddhiṃ saṃsandanakiccaṃ natthi. Tenassa diṭṭhasaṃsandanāpucchā natthi.
analyzed: vā brahmunā vā saddhim saṃsandana kiccam na atthi tenassa diṭṭha saṃsandana āpucchā na atthi
translated: Therefore he has no question asking for a statement of what is seen.

original: Yasmā panesa akathaṃkathī tiṇṇavicikiccho sabbadhammesu vihatasaṃsayo. Tenassa vimaticchedanāpucchā
analyzed: yasmā pana esa a kathaṃkathī tiṇṇa vicikiccho sabba dhammesu vihata saṃsayo tena assa vimati chedanā pucchā
translated: But since he is one who has no doubts, who has crossed over uncertainty, who has no perplexity about any ideas, he has no question to ask for the purpose of resolving doubt.

original: natthi. Itarā pana dve pucchā bhagavato atthi. Tāsu ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchāti veditabbā.
analyzed: natthi itarā pana dve pucchā bhagavataḥ atthi tāsu ayam kathā itu kamya tā pucchā ati veditabbā
translated: But the Blessed One has the other two kinds of questions to ask. Of these, this one should be understood as the question asked out of a desire to expound.

original: Idāni tāva pucchāya puṭṭhaṃ paccayākāraṃ vibhajanto avijjāpaccayā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārātiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tāva pucchāya puṭṭham paccaya ākāram vibhajantaḥ avijjā paccayāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārā ti ādim āha
translated: Now, in analysing the mode of conditionality, which is the subject of the question, he said, “With ignorance as condition there are formations,”

original: Ettha ca yathā nāma “pitaraṃ kathessāmī”ti āraddho “tissassa pitā soṇassa pitā”ti🔽paṭhamataraṃ puttampi katheti, evameva bhagavā paccayaṃ kathetuṃ āraddho “avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: ettha ca yathā nāma pitaram kathessāmi iti āraddhaḥ tissassa pitā soṇassa pitā ati  paṭhamataram puttam pi katheti evam eva bhagavā paccayam kathetum āraddhaḥ avijjā paccayā
translated: and here it is as follows. Just as when someone has started to tell a story and says, “I shall tell you about the father,” and then he tells you about the son first, saying, “Tissa’s father was so-and-so, Soṇa’s father was so-and-so,”

original: saṅkhārā”tiādinā nayena saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccaye avijjādidhamme kathento paccayuppannampi
analyzed: saṅkhāra ati ādinā nayena saṅkhāra ādīnam paccaye avijjā ādi dhamme kathento paccaya uppannam pi
translated: so too, the Blessed One, who had started to tell the conditionality, told you about the states of ignorance, etc., which are the conditions for the formations, etc., by saying, “With ignorance as condition there are formations,” and so on, and in doing so he told you about the conditions’ outcome as well.

original: kathesi. Āhāravaggassa pana pariyosāne “paṭiccasamuppādañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi
analyzed: kathesi āhāra vaggassa pana pariyosāne paṭiccasamuppādam ca vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi
translated: But at the end of the “Food” chapter he said, “Bhikkhus, I will teach you dependent origination.

original: paṭiccasamuppanne ca dhamme”ti ubhayaṃ ārabhitvā ubhayampi kathesi. Idāni avijjāpaccayā🔽saṅkhārātiādīsu pana avijjā ca sā paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo. Tasmā avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: paṭicca samuppanne ca dhamme ti ubhayam ārabhitvā ubhayam pi kathesi idāni avijjā paccayā  saṅkhāra ati ādīsu pana avijjā ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayaḥ tasmai avijjā paccayā
translated: and in dependent origination.🔽Now, as to the clause “With ignorance as condition there are formations,” etc., here ignorance is a condition and it is a cause too, thus it is a condition as cause.

original: saṅkhārā sambhavantīti iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārena
analyzed: saṅkhārā sambhavanti iti iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārena
translated: So the meaning should be understood in this way: “With ignorance as condition as cause there are formations.” This is the brief treatment here.

original: pana sabbākārasampannā anulomapaṭiccasamuppādakathā visuddhimagge kathitā, tasmā
analyzed: pana sabba ākāra sampannā anuloma paṭiccasamuppāda kathā visuddhi magge kathitā tasmā
translated: But the treatment in detail of the dependent origination in forward and reverse order, which is complete in all its aspects,

original: sā tattha kathitavaseneva gahetabbā.
analyzed: sā tattha kathita vasena iva gahetabbā
translated: is given in the Path of Purity. So it should be taken as given there.

original: Paṭilomakathāyaṃ pana avijjāya tvevāti avijjāya tu eva. Asesavirāganirodhāti virāgasaṅkhātena
analyzed: paṭiloma kathā ayam pana avijjāya tu eva ati avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā ati virāga saṅkhātena
translated: But in the reverse order the words “With the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of formations” should be understood as follows. “With the cessation of ignorance as condition comes the cessation of formations”: with the cessation of ignorance as condition the cessation, the non- arising, of formations comes about.🔽“With the cessation of formations comes the cessation of consciousness”: with the cessation of formations as condition the cessation of consciousness comes about.🔽“With the cessation of consciousness comes the cessation of mentality-materiality”: with the cessation of consciousness as condition the cessation of mentality-materiality comes about.🔽“With the cessation of mentality-materiality comes the cessation of the sixfold base”: with the cessation of mentality-materiality as condition the cessation of the sixfold base comes about.🔽“With the cessation of the sixfold base comes the cessation of contact”: with the cessation of the sixfold base as condition the cessation of contact comes about.🔽“With the cessation of contact comes the cessation of feeling”: with the cessation of contact as condition the cessation of feeling comes about.🔽“With the cessation of feeling comes the cessation of craving”: with the cessation of feeling as condition the cessation of craving comes about.🔽“With the cessation of craving comes the cessation of clinging”: with the cessation of craving as condition the cessation of clinging comes about.

original: maggena asesanirodhā. Saṅkhāranirodhoti saṅkhārānaṃ anuppādanirodho hoti. Evaṃnirodhānaṃ
analyzed: maggena asesa nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho ti saṅkhārānam anuppāda nirodhaḥ hoti evaṃnirodhānam
translated: “With the cessation of clinging comes the cessation of being”: with the cessation of clinging as condition the cessation of being comes about.🔽“With the cessation of being comes the cessation of birth”: with the cessation of being as condition the cessation of birth comes about.🔽“With the cessation of birth comes the cessation of ageing and death”: with the cessation of birth as condition the cessation of ageing and death comes about.🔽“With the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of formations”: with the cessation of ignorance as condition the cessation of formations comes about.

original: pana saṅkhārānaṃ nirodhā viññāṇādīnañca nirodhā nāmarūpādīni niruddhāniyeva hontīti
analyzed: pana saṅkhārānam nirodhāḥ viññāṇa ādīnam ca nirodhāḥ nāma rūpa ādīni honti iti
translated: “With the cessation of ignorance comes the cessation of

original: dassetuṃ saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodhotiādīni vatvā, evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa
analyzed: dassetum saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho ti ādīni vatvā evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa
translated: To show this, he said, “With the cessation of formations, the cessation of consciousness,” and so on, and concluded, “This is the cessation of the entire mass of suffering.”

original: nirodho hotīti āha. Tattha kevalassāti sakalassa, suddhassa vā, sattavirahitassāti
analyzed: nirodhaḥ hoti iti āha tattha kevalassa ati sakalassa suddhassa vā satta virahitassa ati

analyzed: cavanaka vasena vuccati eka catu pañca kkhandha sāmañña vacanam etam cavana tā ati bhāva vacanena  lakkhaṇa nidassanam bhedaḥ ti cuti kkhandhānam bhaṅgu patti paridīpanam antaradhānan ti
translated: The rest should be understood in the way already stated. As regards the words death, decease, etc., death is said in the sense of decease; it is a term for the five aggregates, one, four, or five. Decease is said in the sense of the state of being ;

original: ghaṭasseva bhinnassa bhinnānaṃ cutikkhandhānaṃ yena kenaci pariyāyena ṭhānābhāvaparidīpanaṃ.🔽Maccu maraṇanti maccusaṅkhātaṃ maraṇaṃ, tena samucchedamaraṇādīni nisedheti. Kālo
analyzed: ghaṭassa iva bhinnassa bhinnānam cuti kkhandhānam yena kenacid pariyāyena ṭhāna abhāva paridīpanam  maccu saṅkhātam maraṇam tena samuccheda maraṇa ādīni kālo
translated: it is a term for the characteristic of that . Dissolution is the manifestation of the breaking up of the aggregates at death. Disappearance is the manifestation of the non-existence of the aggregates that have been broken up by any means whatsoever, like a broken pot.

original: nāma antako, tassa kiriyā kālakiriyā. Evaṃ tena lokasammutiyā maraṇaṃ dīpeti.🔽Idāni paramatthena dīpetuṃ khandhānaṃ bhedotiādimāha. Paramatthena hi khandhāyeva
analyzed: nāma antako tassa kiriyā kāla kiriyā evam tena loka sammutiyā maraṇam dīpeti  idāni paramatthena dīpetum khandhānam bheda uti ādim āha paramatthena hi khandhāya iva
translated: Death is the decease called “death”; it rejects the severance-death, etc. Time is the destroyer; its action is the action of time. Thus he shows death by the world’s conventional usage.

original: bhijjanti, na satto nāma koci marati. Khandhesu pana bhijjamānesu satto marati, bhinnesu
analyzed: bhijjanti na sattaḥ nāma koci marati khandhesu pana bhijjamānesu sattaḥ marati bhinnesu
translated: Now, in order to show it by the ultimate meaning, he says, “The dissolution of the aggregates,” etc. For it is the aggregates that break up by the ultimate meaning, not some being called “a person.” But when the aggregates are breaking up, a being dies; when they have broken up,🔽he is dead.

original: matoti vohāro hoti. Ettha ca catupañcavokāravasena khandhānaṃ bhedo, ekavokāravasena
analyzed: vohāro hoti ettha ca catu pañca vokāra vasena khandhānam bhedaḥ eka vokāra vasena
translated: And here the breakup of the aggregates is by way of the four and five aggregates,🔽while the casting aside of the body is by way of the single aggregate.

original: kaḷevarassa nikkhepo. Catuvokāravasena ca khandhānaṃ bhedo, sesadvayavasena kaḷevarassa
analyzed: kaḷevarassa nikkhepo catuvokāra vasena ca khandhānam bhedo sesa dvaya vasena kaḷevarassa
translated: Or the breakup of the aggregates is by way of the four aggregates, while the casting aside of the body is by way of the remaining two aggregates.

original: nikkhepo veditabbo. Kasmā? Bhavadvayepi rūpakāyasaṅkhātassa kaḷevarassa sabbhāvato.
analyzed: nikkhepaḥ veditabbo kasmā bhava dvaye pi rūpa kāya saṅkhātassa kaḷevarassa sabbhāvato
translated: Why? Because in both cases the body, which is called the material form aggregate, is cast aside in its entirety.

original: Atha vā yasmā cātumahārājikādīsu khandhā bhijjanteva, na kiñci nikkhipati, tasmā
analyzed: atha vā yasmai cātumahārājika ādīsu khandhāḥ bhijjantā iva na kiñci nikkhipati tasmai
translated: Or else, since in the realms of the four great kings, etc., the aggregates break up but nothing is cast aside,

original: tesaṃ vasena khandhānaṃ bhedo, manussādīsu kaḷevarassa nikkhepo. Ettha ca kaḷevarassa
analyzed: tesam vasena khandhānam bhedaḥ manussa ādīsu kaḷevarassa nikkhepaḥ ettha ca kaḷevarassa
translated: the breakup of the aggregates is by way of those realms, while the casting aside of the body is by way of the human realm, etc.

original: nikkhepakāraṇato maraṇaṃ “kaḷevarassa nikkhepo”ti vuttanti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Iti🔽ayañca jarā idañca maraṇaṃ, idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhaveti idaṃ ubhayampi ekato katvā
analyzed: nikkhepa kāraṇataḥ maraṇam kaḷevarassa nikkhepaḥ ti vuttan ti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ iti  ayam ca jarā idam ca maraṇam idam vuccati bhikkhave ti idam ubhayam pi ekatas katvā
translated: And here the meaning should be regarded thus: “Death is called the casting aside of the body because it is the cause of the casting aside of the body.”

original: jarāmaraṇanti kathīyati.
analyzed: kathīyati
translated: Thus this aging and this death are called aging and death.

original: Jātiniddese jāti sañjātītiādīsu jāyanaṭṭhena jāti, sā aparipuṇṇāyatanavasena yuttā.
analyzed: jāti niddese jāti sañjāti itiādīsu jāyana ṭṭhena sā aparipuṇṇa āyatana vasena yuttā
translated: In the description of birth, in the passage beginning “birth, being born, generation, arising,” birth is the act of being born, which is associated with the incomplete bases.

original: Sañjāyanaṭṭhena sañjāti, sā paripuṇṇāyatanavasena yuttā. Okkamanaṭṭhena okkanti,🔽sā aṇḍajajalābujavasena yuttā. Te hi aṇḍakosañca vatthikosañca okkamantā pavisantā
analyzed: sañjāyana ṭṭhena sañjāti sā paripuṇṇa āyatana vasena yuttā okkamana ṭṭhena okkanti  sā aṇḍa ja jalābu ja vasena yuttā te hi aṇḍa kosam ca vatthi kosam ca okkamantā pavisantā
translated: Birth is in the sense of being born. It is classed according to the complete sense bases.🔽Entry is in the sense of entering.🔽It is classed according to the egg-born and womb-born. For these take rebirth-linking as they enter the egg and the womb respectively,

original: viya paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhanti. Abhinibbattanaṭṭhena abhinibbatti, sā saṃsedajaopapātikavasena
analyzed: viya paṭisandhim gaṇhanti abhinibbattana ṭṭhena abhinibbatti sā saṃseda ja opapātika vasena
translated: as if entering a house. Appearance is in the sense of appearing. It is classed according to the moisture-born and the spontaneously born.

original: yuttā. Te hi pākaṭāyeva hutvā nibbattanti. Ayaṃ tāva vohāradesanā.
analyzed: yuttā te hi pākaṭāya iva hutvā nibbattanti ayam tāva vohāra desanā
translated: For these appear openly. This, firstly, is the teaching of the terms.

original: Idāni paramatthadesanā hoti. Khandhāyeva hi paramatthato pātubhavanti, na satto.
analyzed: idāni paramattha desanā hoti khandhāya iva hi paramatthataḥ pātubhavanti na satto
translated: Now there is the teaching of the ultimate. For it is only the aggregates that appear in the ultimate sense, not a being.

original: Tattha ca khandhānanti ekavokārabhave ekassa, catuvokārabhave catunnaṃ, pañcavokārabhave🔽pañcannampi gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Pātubhāvoti uppatti. Āyatanānanti ettha tatra tatra
analyzed: tattha ca khandhānam ti ekavokāra bhave ekassa catuvokāra bhave catunnam pañcavokāra bhave  pañcannam pi gahaṇam veditabbam ettha tatra tatra
translated: And here the aggregates should be understood as the taking of one in a single-door occurrence, of four in a four-door occurrence,🔽and of five in a five-door occurrence. Appearance is origination.🔽As to the bases, the inclusion should be understood according to the bases that arise here and there.

original: uppajjamānāyatanavasena saṅgaho veditabbo. Paṭilābhoti santatiyaṃ pātubhāvoyeva.
analyzed: uppajjamāna āyatana vasena saṅgahaḥ veditabbo paṭilābhaḥ ti santatiyam
translated: Occurrence is the appearance in a continuity.

original: Pātubhavantāneva hi tāni paṭiladdhāni nāma honti. Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, jātīti
analyzed: pātubhavantāna iva hi tāni paṭiladdhāni nāma honti ayam vuccati bhikkhave jātī iti
translated: for they are only manifested when they are acquired. This is called birth.

original: iminā padena vohārato paramatthato ca desitāya jātiyā nigamanaṃ karotīti.
analyzed: iminā padena vohārato paramatthato ca desitāya jātiyāḥ nigamanam karoti iti
translated: By this word he concludes the teaching of birth as a term and as the ultimate reality.

original: Bhavaniddese kāmabhavoti kammabhavo ca upapattibhavo ca. Tattha kammabhavo nāma kāmabhavūpagakammameva.🔽Tañhi tattha upapattibhavassa kāraṇattā “sukho buddhānaṃ uppādo dukkho pāpassa uccayo”tiādīni
analyzed: bhava niddese kāma bhavo ti kamma bhavo ca upapatti bhavo ca tattha kamma bhavaḥ nāma kāma bhava upaga kammam eva  tat hi tattha upapatti bhavassa kāraṇa ttā sukhaḥ buddhānaṃ uppādaḥ dukkhaḥ pāpassa uccayaḥ ti ādīni
translated: In the description of becoming, sense-desire becoming is kamma-process becoming and rebirth-process becoming. Herein, kamma-process becoming is kamma that leads to sense-desire becoming.

original: viya phalavohārena bhavoti vuttaṃ. Upapattibhavo nāma tena kammena nibbattaṃ upādiṇṇakkhandhapañcakaṃ.
analyzed: viya phala vohārena bhavaḥ ti vuttam upapatti bhavaḥ nāma tena kammena nibbattam upādiṇṇa kkhandha pañcakam
translated: For that is called becoming by a figurative use of the word fruit for a cause, as in the passage “The arising of Buddhas is bliss, the arising of the bad is woeful” . Rebirth-process becoming is the five aggregates that have been generated by that kamma.

original: Tañhi tattha bhavatīti katvā bhavoti vuttaṃ. Sabbathāpi idaṃ kammañca upapattiñca
analyzed: tat hi tattha bhavati iti katvā bhavaḥ ti vuttam sabbathā api idam kammañca upapattiñca
translated: For that is called becoming because it becomes there. And all this kamma and rebirth-process becoming

original: ubhayampetamidha “kāmabhavo”ti vuttaṃ. Esa nayo rūpārūpabhavesūti.
analyzed: vuttam esa nayaḥ rūpa arūpa bhavesu iti
translated: is called here “sense-desire becoming.” So too with fine-material and immaterial becoming.

original: Upādānaniddese kāmupādānantiādīsu vatthukāmaṃ upādiyanti etena, sayaṃ vā taṃ upādiyatīti
analyzed: upādāna niddese kāma upādāna nti ādīsu vatthu kāmam upādiyanti etena sayam vā tam upādiyati iti
translated: In the description of clinging, sense-desire clinging, etc., are so called either because they cling to sense desires, etc., or because they themselves are clung to as sense desires, etc.

original: kāmupādānaṃ, kāmo ca so upādānañcāti kāmupādānaṃ. Upādānanti daḷhaggahaṇaṃ vuccati.
analyzed: kāma upādānam kāmo ca saḥ upādānam ca ati kāma upādānam upādānam ti daḷha ggahaṇam vuccati
translated: “Sensual-desire clinging” is either sensual desire itself or clinging that is sensual desire. Clinging is said to be firm grasping.

original: Daḷhattho hi ettha upasaddo upāyāsaupakaṭṭhādīsu viya. Pañcakāmaguṇikarāgassetaṃ
analyzed: daḷha atthaḥ hi ettha upasaddaḥ upāyāsa aupakaṭṭha ādīsu viya pañca kāmaguṇika rāgassa etam
translated: For the prefix upa has the sense of firmness, as in upayása “worry” and upakaṭṭha “near” . This is a term for the defilement consisting of the five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārato panetaṃ, “tattha katamaṃ kāmupādānaṃ?
analyzed: adhivacanam ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana itam tattha katamam kāma upādānam
translated: This is the brief treatment here. But it should be understood in detail in the way given in the description of sensual-desire clinging in the Paṭisambhidā: “Herein, what is sensual-desire clinging?

original: Yo kāmesu kāmacchando”ti vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ kāmesu kāmacchandaḥ iti vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: It is will and lust in regard to the five cords of sensual pleasure” .

original: Tathā diṭṭhi ca sā upādānañcāti diṭṭhupādānaṃ. Atha vā diṭṭhiṃ upādiyati, upādiyanti🔽vā etena diṭṭhinti diṭṭhupādānaṃ. Upādiyati hi purimadiṭṭhiṃ uttaradiṭṭhi, upādiyanti
analyzed: tathā diṭṭhi ca sā upādānam ca ati diṭṭhupādānam atha vā diṭṭhim upādiyati upādiyanti  va etena diṭṭhin ti diṭṭh upādānam upādiyati hi purima diṭṭhim uttara diṭṭhi upādiyanti
translated: Likewise, “view clinging” is either a view itself or clinging that is a view. Or alternatively, it is clinging to a view, or clinging is to be clung to by a view.

original: ca tāya diṭṭhiṃ. Yathāha – “sassato attā ca loko ca idameva saccaṃ moghamañña”ntiādi.
analyzed: ca tāya diṭṭhim yathā āha sassataḥ attā ca loko ca idam eva saccam mogham aññan ti ādi
translated: For a later view clings to an earlier view, and the view is clung to by that. As it is said: “The self and the world are eternal—this alone is the truth, (all) else is foolish” , and so on.

original: Sīlabbatupādānaattavādupādānavajjassa sabbadiṭṭhigatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Ayamettha
analyzed: sabba diṭṭhi gatassa itam adhivacanam ayam ettha
translated: This is a term for all the views that are to be abandoned by the path of arahantship, which is free from the clinging of mere rules and rituals and from the clinging of personality view.

original: saṅkhepo, vitthārato panetaṃ, “tattha katamaṃ diṭṭhupādānaṃ? Natthi dinna”nti vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana itam tattha katamam diṭṭhupādānam natthi dinnan ti vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: In brief, but in detail it should be understood in the way stated thus: “Herein, what is clinging to (wrong) views? ‘There is nothing given’ … and so on.

original: Tathā sīlabbatamupādiyanti etena, sayaṃ vā taṃ upādiyati, sīlabbatañca taṃ upādānañcāti
analyzed: tathā sīlabbatam upādiyanti etena sayam vā tam upādiyati sīlabbatam ca tam upādānam ca ati
translated: So too, they cling to rules and vows, or he himself clings to them, and that clinging is to rules and vows,

original: vā sīlabbatupādānaṃ. Gosīlagovatādīni hi “evaṃ suddhī”ti abhinivesato sayameva upādānānīti.
analyzed: vā sīlabbata upādānam go sīla govata ādīni hi evam suddhi iti abhinivesato sayam eva upādānāni iti
translated: or it is rules and vows and clinging, thus it is clinging to rules and vows. For the cow-duty, the dog-duty, and so on, are clingings because of the adherence to them as purity.

original: Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato panetaṃ, “tattha katamaṃ sīlabbatupādānaṃ? Ito bahiddhā
analyzed: ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana itam tattha katamam sīlabbata upādānam itas bahiddhā
translated: This is in brief, but in detail it should be understood in the way stated thus: “Herein, what is clinging to rules and vows? Outside this Dispensation

original: samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sīlena suddhī”ti vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: samaṇa brāhmaṇānam sīlena suddhi iti vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: the purity of recluses and brahmans is by means of rules and vows” and so on.

original: Idāni vadanti etenāti vādo, upādiyanti etenāti upādānaṃ, kiṃ vadanti upādiyanti vā?
analyzed: idāni vadanti etena ati upādiyanti etena ati upādānam kim vadanti upādiyanti vā
translated: Now, they are called by this, thus it is a view, they cling by means of this, thus it is clinging, what do they call and cling to?

original: Attānaṃ. Attano vādupādānaṃ attavādupādānaṃ. Attavādamattameva vā attāti upādiyanti
analyzed: attānam attanaḥ vāda upādānam attavād upādānam atta vādam attam eva vā attā ati upādiyanti
translated: The self. Or it is the self and the view, thus it is clinging to a doctrine of self. Or they cling to the self by means of the mere doctrine of self,

original: etenāti attavādupādānaṃ. Vīsativatthukāya sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Ayamettha
analyzed: etena ati attavāt upādānam vīsati vatthukāya sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā etam adhivacanam ayam ettha
translated: thus it is clinging to a doctrine of self. This is a designation for the embodiment-view with its twenty cases. This is in brief,

original: saṅkhepo, vitthārato panetaṃ, “tattha katamaṃ attavādupādānaṃ? Idha assutavā puthujjano
analyzed: saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana itam tattha katamam attavāt upādānam idha assutavā puthujjanaḥ
translated: In brief, but in detail it should be understood in the way stated thus: “Herein, what is self-theory assuming? Here an untaught ordinary man …

original: ariyānaṃ adassāvī”ti vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ariyānam adassāvi iti vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: … who has no regard for the ariyans … “ .

original: Taṇhāniddese rūpataṇhā…pe… dhammataṇhāti etaṃ cakkhudvārādīsu javanavīthiyā pavattāya
analyzed: taṇhā niddese dhamma taṇhā ti etam cakkhu dvāra ādīsu javana vīthiyā pavattāya
translated: In the description of craving, “craving for visible forms … craving for ideas” is craving that occurs in the impulsions in the eye door, etc.,

original: taṇhāya “seṭṭhiputto brāhmaṇaputto”ti evamādīsu pitito nāmaṃ viya pitisadisārammaṇato🔽nāmaṃ. Ettha ca rūpārammaṇā taṇhā, rūpe taṇhāti rūpataṇhā. Sā kāmarāgabhāvena rūpaṃ🔽assādentī pavattamānā kāmataṇhā, sassatadiṭṭhisahagatarāgabhāvena “rūpaṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ🔽sassata”nti evaṃ assādentī pavattamānā bhavataṇhā, ucchedadiṭṭhisahagatarāgabhāvena
analyzed: taṇhāya seṭṭhi putto brāhmaṇa putto ti evamādīsu pititaḥ nāmam viya piti sadisa ārammaṇato  nāma ettha ca rūpa ārammaṇā taṇhā rūpe taṇhā ati rūpa taṇhā sā kāma rāga bhāvena rūpam  assādentī pavattamānā kāma taṇhā sassata diṭṭhi sahagata rāga bhāvena rūpam niccam dhuvam  evam assādentī pavattamānā bhava taṇhā uccheda diṭṭhi sahagata rāga bhāvena
translated: and it is called “by association” because it is similar to the associated object, as in the case of the names “son of the money-lender” and “son of the brahmin” .

original: “rūpaṃ ucchijjati vinassati pecca na bhavatī”ti evaṃ assādentī pavattamānā vibhavataṇhāti
analyzed: rūpam ucchijjati vinassati pecca na bhavati iti evam assādentī pavattamānā vibhava taṇhāti
translated: And here craving for the visible-form object is “craving for visible forms” . That occurs enjoying visible form as the state of lust for sense desires; it occurs enjoying visible form as “permanent, lasting, eternal” as the state of lust associated with the eternalist view; and it occurs enjoying visible form as “destroyed, annihilated, done away with, not destined to arise again” as the state of lust associated with the annihilationist view.

original: rūpataṇhā evaṃ tividhā hoti. Yathā ca rūpataṇhā, tathā saddataṇhādayopīti evaṃ tāni
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā evam tividhā yathā ca rūpa taṇhā tathā sadda taṇhā ādayaḥ api iti evam tāni
translated: So craving for materiality is threefold. And as craving for materiality is, so are craving for sound, etc.,🔽Thus there are eighteen kinds of occurrence of craving. There are eighteen kinds of occurrence of craving in respect of internal materiality, etc.,

original: aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni honti. Tāni ajjhattarūpādīsu aṭṭhārasa, bahiddhārūpādīsu
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni honti tāni ajjhatta rūpa ādīsu aṭṭhārasa bahiddhā rūpa ādīsu
translated: and eighteen kinds in respect of external materiality, etc.,

original: aṭṭhārasāti chattiṃsa. Iti atītāni chattiṃsa, anāgatāni chattiṃsa, paccuppannāni🔽chattiṃsāti evaṃ aṭṭhasataṃ taṇhāvicaritāni honti. “Ajjhattikassa upādāya asmīti
analyzed: aṭṭhārasā ati chattiṃsa iti atītāni chattiṃsa anāgatāni chattiṃsa paccuppannāni  chattiṃsa ati evam aṭṭhasatam taṇhā vicaritāni honti ajjhattikassa upādāya asmi iti
translated: making thirty-six. So there are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present,

original: hoti, itthasmīti hotī”ti vā evamādīni ajjhattikarūpādinissitāni aṭṭhārasa, “bāhirassa🔽upādāya iminā asmīti hoti, iminā itthasmīti hotī”ti vā evamādīni bāhirarūpādinissitāni
analyzed: hoti itthasmi iti hoti iti vā evamādīni ajjhattika rūpa ādi nissitāni aṭṭhārasa bāhirassa  upādāya iminā asmi iti hoti iminā itthasmi iti hoti iti vā evamādīni bāhira rūpa ādi nissitāni
translated: making one hundred and eight kinds of occurrence of craving. Or again, there are eighteen kinds of occurrence of craving in respect of internal materiality, etc., based on the phrases “because of the internal he is, he is called; because of the internal he is not, he is called” ,🔽and eighteen kinds in respect of external materiality, etc., based on the phrases “because of the external he is, he is called; because of the external he is not, he is called” ,

original: aṭṭhārasāti chattiṃsa, iti atītāni chattiṃsa, anāgatāni chattiṃsa, paccuppannāni
analyzed: aṭṭhārasā ati chattiṃsa iti atītāni chattiṃsa anāgatāni chattiṃsa paccuppannāni
translated: making thirty-six. So there are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present,

original: chattiṃsāti evampi aṭṭhasataṃ taṇhāvicaritāni honti. Puna saṅgahe kariyamāne rūpādīsu
analyzed: chattiṃsa ati evam pi aṭṭhasatam taṇhā vicaritāni honti puna saṅgahe kariyamāne rūpa ādīsu
translated: making one hundred and eight kinds of occurrence of craving. But when they are again combined, there are thirty-six kinds of occurrence of craving in respect of materiality, etc.,

original: ārammaṇesu chaḷeva taṇhākāyā tissoyeva kāmataṇhādayo hontīti. Evaṃ –
analyzed: ārammaṇesu chaḷ eva taṇhā kāyā tisso yeva kāma taṇhā ādayo honti iti evam
translated: and in the case of the objects of craving, there are only six kinds of craving, namely, the three kinds of sense-desire craving, etc.,”

original: “Niddesatthena niddesa, vitthārā vitthārassa ca;
analyzed: niddesa atthena niddesa vitthārāḥ vitthārassa ca
translated: “The exposition is the meaning of the exposition, and the elaboration is the meaning of the elaboration.

original: Puna saṅgahato taṇhā, viññātabbā vibhāvinā”ti.
analyzed: puna saṅgahato taṇhā viññātabbā vibhāvinā ti
translated: Again, by the method of inclusion, craving should be known by the expositor.”

original: Vedanāniddese vedanākāyāti vedanāsamūhā. Cakkhusamphassajā vedanā…pe… manosamphassajāvedanāti
analyzed: vedanā niddese vedanā kāyā ati vedanā samūhā cakkhu samphassa jā vedanā pe manaḥ samphassa jā vedanā ti
translated: In the Description of Feeling, “feeling groups” are the groups of feelings. “Feeling born of eye-contact” … “feeling born of mind-contact”

original: etaṃ “cakkhusamphassajāvedanā atthi kusalā, atthi akusalā, atthi abyākatā”ti evaṃ🔽vibhaṅge āgatattā cakkhudvārādīsu pavattānaṃ kusalākusalābyākatavedanānaṃ “sāriputto
analyzed: etam cakkhu samphassa jā vedanā atthi kusalā atthi akusalā atthi abyākatā ati evam  vibhaṅge āgata ttā cakkhu dvāra ādīsu pavattānam kusala akusala abyākata vedanānam sāriputto
translated: are so called because they are stated in the Vibhaṅga thus: “There is feeling born of eye-contact that is wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate” ,

original: mantāṇiputto”ti evamādīsu mātito nāmaṃ viya mātisadisato vatthuto nāmaṃ. Vacanattho
analyzed: mantāṇiputto ti evamādīsu mātitaḥ nāmam viya māti sadisataḥ vatthutaḥ nāmam vacana atthaḥ
translated: and so on. Just as the name of a mother’s brother is given to a man similar to a mother’s brother, so these feelings born of eye-contact, etc., are called by the name of their respective bases, the eye, etc.

original: panettha – cakkhusamphassahetu jātā vedanā cakkhusamphassajā vedanāti. Eseva nayo
analyzed: pana ittha cakkhu samphassa hetu jātā vedanā cakkhu samphassa jā vedanā ti esa iva nayo
translated: The meaning of the words is this: Feeling that has arisen with eye-contact as its condition is feeling born of eye-contact. The same method applies in the case of the other kinds of feeling.

original: sabbattha. Ayaṃ tāvettha sabbasaṅgāhikā kathā. Vipākavasena pana cakkhudvāre dve
analyzed: sabbattha ayam tāva ettha sabba saṅgāhikā kathā vipāka vasena pana cakkhu dvāre dve
translated: This, firstly, is the general discussion. But in the eye door, two kinds of feeling arise with resultant consciousness,

original: cakkhuviññāṇāni, dve manodhātuyo, tisso manoviññāṇadhātuyoti etāhi sampayuttavasena
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇāni dve manaḥ dhātuyo tisso manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo ti etāhi sampayutta vasena
translated: and the two kinds of mind element and the three kinds of mind-consciousness element.

original: vedanā veditabbā. Eseva nayo sotadvārādīsu. Manodvāre manoviññāṇadhātusampayuttāva.
analyzed: vedanā veditabbā esā iva nayo sota dvāra ādīsu manaḥ dvāre manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu sampayuttā ava
translated: Feeling should be understood as associated with these. The same method applies in the case of the ear door, etc. In the mind door the associated feeling is that of the mind-consciousness element.

original: Phassaniddese cakkhusamphassoti cakkhumhi samphasso. Esa nayo sabbattha. Cakkhusamphasso…pe…
analyzed: phassa niddese cakkhu samphasso ti cakkhumhi samphasso esa nayo sabbattha
translated: In the description of contact, “Eye-contact” is contact in the eye. The same method applies in all cases. “Eye-contact” …

original: kāyasamphassoti ettāvatā ca kusalākusalavipākā pañcavatthukā dasa phassā vuttā honti.
analyzed: kāya samphassaḥ ti ettāvatā ca kusala akusala vipākā pañca vatthukā dasa phassā vuttāḥ honti
translated: … “body-contact”: thus far ten kinds of contact have been mentioned, namely, the five profitable, five unprofitable resultants having the five sense bases as their respective physical bases.

original: Manosamphassoti iminā sesabāvīsatilokiyavipākamanasampayuttā phassā.
analyzed: manaḥ samphasso ti iminā sesa bāvīsati lokiya vipāka mana sampayuttā phassā
translated: “Mind-contact”: by this the remaining twenty-two kinds of resultant mind-contact belonging to the sense sphere are included.

original: Saḷāyatananiddese cakkhāyatanantiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ visuddhimagge khandhaniddese ceva āyatananiddese ca vuttameva.
analyzed: saḷāyatana niddese cakkha āyatana nti ādīsu yam vattabbam tam visuddhi magge khandha niddese ca iva āyatana niddese ca vuttam eva
translated: In the description of the sixfold base, as regards the eye base, etc., what should be said has already been said in the Description of the Aggregates and in the Description of the Bases.

original: Nāmarūpaniddese namanalakkhaṇaṃ nāmaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ. Vibhajane panassa
analyzed: nāma rūpa niddese namana lakkhaṇam nāmam ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam vibhajane panassa
translated: In the description of mentality-materiality, mentality has the characteristic of bending ; materiality has the characteristic of being molested . In the analysis of it:

original: vedanāti vedanākkhandho, saññāti saññākkhandho, cetanā phasso manasikāroti saṅkhārakkhandho
analyzed: vedanā ati vedanā khandho saññā ati saññā kkhandho cetanā phassaḥ manasikāraḥ iti saṅkhāra kkhandho
translated: Feeling is the feeling aggregate, perception is the perception aggregate, and volition, contact, and attention are the formations aggregate.

original: veditabbo. Kāmañca aññepi saṅkhārakkhandhasaṅgahitā dhammā santi, ime pana tayo sabbadubbalesupi
analyzed: veditabbo kāmañca aññe pi saṅkhāra kkhandha saṅgahitāḥ dhammāḥ santi ime pana tayo sabba dubbalesu pi
translated: There are other states included in the formations aggregate, but these three are found in all the weakest types of consciousness too.🔽That is why the formations aggregate is shown here by way of these three.

original: cittesu santi, tasmā etesaṃyeva vasenettha saṅkhārakkhandho dassito. Cattāro ca mahābhūtāti
analyzed: cittesu santi tasmai etesam yeva vasena ittha saṅkhāra kkhandho dassito cattāro ca mahābhūtā ti
translated: The four great entities:

original: ettha cattāroti gaṇanaparicchedo. Mahābhūtāti pathavīāpatejavāyānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: ettha cattāro ti gaṇana paricchedaḥ adhivacanam
translated: Herein, the four is a delimitation of number. Great entities is a term for the earth, water, fire, and air element.

original: Yena pana kāraṇena tāni mahābhūtānīti vuccanti, yo cettha añño vinicchayanayo, so
analyzed: yena pana kāraṇena tāni mahābhūtāni iti vuccanti yaḥ ca ittha aññaḥ so
translated: But as to why they are called “great entities” and the exposition of the other terms here,🔽all that has been given in the Description of the Form Aggregate in the Path of Purity.

original: sabbo visuddhimagge rūpakkhandhaniddese vutto. Catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāyāti
analyzed: sabbaḥ visuddhi magge rūpa khandha niddese vuttaḥ catunnam ca mahābhūtānam upādāya ati
translated: Derived from the four great entities:

original: ettha pana catunnanti upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ, cattāri mahābhūtānīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ettha pana catunnam ti upayoga atthe sāmivacanam cattāri mahābhūtāni iti vuttam hoti
translated: Herein, the four is a possessive form in the sense of instrument. The meaning is: the four great entities.

original: Upādāyāti upādiyitvā, gahetvāti attho. Nissāyātipi eke. “Vattamāna”nti ayañcettha
analyzed: upādāya ati upādiyitvā gahetvā iti atthaḥ nissāya atipi eke vattamānanti ayam ca ittha
translated: Derived: taken, grasped, is the meaning. Some say “relied on.”

original: pāṭhaseso. Samūhatthe vā etaṃ sāmivacanaṃ, catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ samūhaṃ upādāya🔽vattamānaṃ rūpanti ettha attho veditabbo. Evaṃ sabbathāpi yāni ca cattāri pathavīādīni
analyzed: samūha atthe vai etam sāmi vacanam catunnam mahābhūtānam samūham upādāya  vattamānam rūpan ti ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ evam sabbathā api yāni ca cattāri pathavī ādīni
translated: So in all ways, the four great primaries beginning with earth,🔽and the twenty-three kinds of materiality classed as the eye base, etc.,

original: mahābhūtāni, yañca catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya vattamānaṃ cakkhāyatanādibhedena
analyzed: mahābhūtāni yat ca catunnam mahābhūtānam upādāya vattamānam cakkhā āyatana ādi bhedena
translated: which occur in dependence on the four great primaries and are mentioned in the Abhidhamma as follows:🔽“Twenty-three kinds of materiality: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, visible datum, sound, odour, flavour, materiality as tangible property, femininity faculty, masculinity faculty, life faculty, heart- basis, space element, bodily intimation, verbal intimation, lightness of matter, malleability of matter, wieldiness of matter, growth of matter, continuity of matter, ageing of matter, dissolution of matter” ,

original: abhidhammapāḷiyameva vuttaṃ tevīsatividhaṃ rūpaṃ, taṃ sabbampi rūpanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: abhidhamma pāḷiyam eva vuttam tevīsatividham rūpam tat sabbam pi rūpan ti veditabbam
translated: all this should be understood as “materiality.”

original: Viññāṇaniddese cakkhuviññāṇanti cakkhumhi viññāṇaṃ, cakkhuto vā jātaṃ viññāṇanti
analyzed: viññāṇa niddese cakkhu viññāṇanti cakkhumhi viññāṇam cakkhutaḥ vā jātam viññāṇanti
translated: In the description of consciousness: Eye-consciousness is consciousness in the eye, or it is consciousness arisen from eye,

original: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Evaṃ sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇāni. Itaraṃ pana manoyeva viññāṇanti
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇam evam sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇāni itaram pana manoyeva viññāṇanti
translated: thus it is eye-consciousness. So too with ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-consciousness. But mind-consciousness is consciousness arisen from mind,

original: manoviññāṇaṃ. Dvipañcaviññāṇavajjitatebhūmakavipākacittassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇam adhivacanam
translated: or it is consciousness in the mind, thus it is mind-consciousness. This is a term for resultant consciousness of the sense sphere, except for the five consciousnesses.

original: Saṅkhāraniddese abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇo saṅkhāro. Vibhajane panassa kāyasaṅkhāroti
analyzed: saṅkhāra niddese abhisaṅkharaṇa lakkhaṇaḥ saṅkhāraḥ vibhajane pana assa kāya saṅkhāro ti
translated: In the description of formations: a formation has the characteristic of forming. But in the analysis it is said “bodily formation” ,

original: kāyato pavattasaṅkhāro. Kāyadvāre copanavasena pavattānaṃ kāmāvacarakusalato aṭṭhannaṃ,
analyzed: kāyato pavatta saṅkhāro kāya dvāre copana vasena pavattānam kāmāvacara kusalato aṭṭhannam
translated: the formation that occurs in the body. And of the eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable consciousness that occurs by way of the body door,

original: akusalato dvādasannanti vīsatiyā kāyasañcetanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vacīsaṅkhāroti
analyzed: adhivacanam
translated: It is the formation that occurs by means of the body. It is a term for the twenty kinds of bodily volition, namely, the eight kinds of profitable volition and the twelve kinds of unprofitable volition that occur in the sense sphere.🔽Verbal formation:

original: vacanato pavattasaṅkhāro, vacīdvāre vacanabhedavasena pavattānaṃ vīsatiyā eva vacīsañcetanānametaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Cittasaṅkhāroti cittato pavattasaṅkhāro, kāyavacīdvāre copanaṃ akatvā
analyzed: vacanato pavatta saṅkhāraḥ vacī dvāre vacana bheda vasena pavattānam vīsatiyāḥ eva  adhivacanam citta saṅkhāro ti cittataḥ pavatta saṅkhāro kāya vacī dvāre copanam a katvā
translated: It is the formation that occurs by means of speech. It is a term for the twenty kinds of verbal volition that occur in the sense sphere by way of the division of speech in the speech door.🔽Mental formation:

original: raho nisīditvā cintentassa pavattānaṃ lokiyakusalākusalavasena ekūnatiṃsamanosañcetanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Avijjāniddese dukkhe aññāṇanti dukkhasacce aññāṇaṃ, mohassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Esa nayo
analyzed: rahaḥ nisīditvā cintentassa pavattānam lokiya kusala akusala vasena adhivacanam  avijjā niddese dukkhe aññāṇan ti dukkha sacce aññāṇam mohassa itam adhivacanam esa nayo
translated: It is the formation that occurs by means of cognizance.
