It is a term for the twenty-nine kinds of mental volition, namely, the twenty-two kinds of sense-sphere profitable and unprofitable volition and the seven kinds of fine-material and immaterial profitable volition that occur in one who, without making bodily or verbal effort, sits alone and thinks.🔽In the Description of Ignorance, ignorance about suffering is the unknowing of the truth of suffering. It is a term for delusion. So too in the case of ignorance about the origin of suffering, etc. Herein, ignorance about suffering should be understood in four ways: as to inclusion,

original: dukkhasamudaye aññāṇantiādīsu. Tattha catūhi kāraṇehi dukkhe aññāṇaṃ veditabbaṃ antogadhato
analyzed: dukkha samudaye aññāṇa nti ādīsu tattha catūhi kāraṇehi dukkhe aññāṇam veditabbam antogadhato
translated: as to condition, as to non-penetration, and as to wrong penetration.

original: vatthuto ārammaṇato paṭicchādanato ca. Tathā hi taṃ dukkhasaccapariyāpannattā dukkhe🔽antogadhaṃ, dukkhasaccañcassa nissayapaccayabhāvena vatthu, ārammaṇapaccayabhāvena
analyzed: vatthutaḥ ārammaṇataḥ paṭicchādanataḥ ca tathā hi tam dukkha sacca pariyāpanna ttā dukkhe  antogadham dukkha saccañcassa nissaya paccaya bhāvena vatthu ārammaṇa paccaya bhāvena
translated: As to physical basis, object, and concealment. For it is included in the truth of suffering because it is included in the truth of suffering,🔽and the truth of suffering is its physical basis as decisive-support condition,

original: ārammaṇaṃ, dukkhasaccaṃ etaṃ paṭicchādeti tassa yāthāvalakkhaṇapaṭivedhanivāraṇena
analyzed: ārammaṇam dukkha saccam etam paṭicchādeti tassa yāthāva lakkhaṇa paṭivedha nivāraṇena
translated: and it is its object as object condition, and it conceals the truth of suffering by preventing the knowledge of its specific characteristics from arising

original: ñāṇappavattiyā cettha appadānena.
analyzed: ñāṇa pavattiyā ca ittha appadānena
translated: by not giving it an opportunity to arise.

original: Dukkhasamudaye aññāṇaṃ tīhi kāraṇehi veditabbaṃ vatthuto ārammaṇato paṭicchādanato🔽ca. Nirodhe paṭipadāya ca aññāṇaṃ ekeneva kāraṇena veditabbaṃ paṭicchādanato. Nirodhapaṭipadānañhi
analyzed: dukkha samudaye aññāṇam tīhi kāraṇehi veditabbam vatthutaḥ ārammaṇataḥ paṭicchādanataḥ  ca nirodhe paṭipadāya ca aññāṇam ekena iva kāraṇena veditabbam paṭicchādanataḥ nirodha paṭipadānam hi
translated: Ignorance of the origin of suffering should be understood as to physical basis, object, and concealment.🔽Ignorance of cessation and of the path should be understood as to concealment only. For ignorance conceals cessation and the path by preventing the knowledge of their specific characteristics from arising

original: paṭicchādakameva aññāṇaṃ tesaṃ yāthāvalakkhaṇapaṭivedhanivāraṇena tesu ca ñāṇappavattiyā
analyzed: paṭicchādakam eva aññāṇam tesam yāthāva lakkhaṇa paṭivedha nivāraṇena tesu ca ñāṇa ppavattiyā
translated: and by not giving an opportunity for the knowledge of them to arise.

original: appadānena. Na pana taṃ tattha antogadhaṃ tasmiṃ saccadvaye apariyāpannattā, na tassa
analyzed: appadānena na pana tam tattha antogadham tasmim sacca dvaye a pariyāpanna ttā na tassa
translated: But it is not included in those two truths, because it is not included in them.

original: taṃ saccadvayaṃ vatthu asahajātattā, nārammaṇaṃ, tadārabbha appavattanato. Pacchimañhi
analyzed: tam sacca dvayam vatthu asahajāta ttā na ārammaṇam tat ārabbha a pavattanato pacchiman hi
translated: and the two Truths are not the object of the former, because they are not conascent with it, and because it does not occur contingent upon them. For the latter

original: saccadvayaṃ gambhīrattā duddasaṃ, na tattha andhabhūtaṃ aññāṇaṃ pavattati. Purimaṃ
analyzed: sacca dvayam gambhīra ttā duddasam na tattha andha bhūtam aññāṇam pavattati purimam
translated: The first two Truths are not objects of ignorance because they are not conascent with it, and because ignorance does not occur contingent upon them. But the last two Truths are hard to see because of their profundity, and so ignorance is not blind to them.

original: pana vacanīyattena sabhāvalakkhaṇassa duddasattā gambhīraṃ, tattha vipallāsagāhavasena pavattati.
analyzed: pana vacanīya ttena sabhāva lakkhaṇassa duddasa ttā gambhīram tattha vipallāsa gāha vasena pavattati
translated: The first two Truths are profound because of the difficulty of seeing the specific characteristic of their individual essences.

original: Apica “dukkhe”ti ettāvatā saṅgahato vatthuto ārammaṇato kiccato ca avijjā dīpitā.🔽“Dukkhasamudaye”ti ettāvatā vatthuto ārammaṇato kiccato ca. “Dukkhanirodhe dukkhanirodhagāminiyā
analyzed: apica dukkha iti ettāvatā saṅgahataḥ vatthutaḥ ārammaṇataḥ kiccataḥ ca avijjā dīpitā  dukkha samudaya iti ettāvatā vatthutaḥ ārammaṇato kiccato ca dukkha nirodhe dukkha nirodha gāminiyā
translated: Moreover, by the words “in suffering” ignorance is shown as to inclusion, as to the basis, as to object, and as to function.

original: paṭipadāyā”ti ettāvatā kiccato. Avisesato pana “aññāṇa”nti etena sabhāvato niddiṭṭhāti ñātabbā.
analyzed: paṭipadāya iti ettāvatā kiccataḥ avisesataḥ pana aññāṇanti etena sabhāvataḥ niddiṭṭhā ati ñātabbā
translated: By the words “in the origin of suffering” it is shown as to the basis, as to object, and as to function. By the words “in the cessation of suffering” and “in the way leading to the cessation of suffering” it is shown as to function only. But by the words “ignorance” it should be understood as to individual essence without distinction.

original: Iti kho, bhikkhaveti evaṃ kho, bhikkhave. Nirodho hotīti anuppādo hoti. Apicettha
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave iti evam kho bhikkhave nirodhaḥ hoti iti anuppādaḥ hoti apica ittha
translated: Thus, bhikkhus: thus, bhikkhus. Comes to be: arises. Herein,

original: sabbeheva tehi nirodhapadehi nibbānaṃ desitaṃ. Nibbānañhi āgamma te te dhammā nirujjhanti,🔽tasmā taṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ nirodhoti vuccati. Iti bhagavā imasmiṃ sutte dvādasahi padehi
analyzed: sabbehi eva tehi nirodha padehi nibbānam desitam nibbānam hi āgamma te te dhammāḥ nirujjhanti  tasmā tam tesam tesam nirodho ti vuccati iti bhagavā imasmim sutte dvādasahi padehi
translated: All these terms of cessation teach Nibbāna. For Nibbāna is the cessation of these things,🔽and therefore it is called the cessation of each one. Thus the Blessed One, teaching the round and the cessation of the round by means of these twelve terms,

original: vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ desento arahattanikūṭeneva desanaṃ niṭṭhapesi. Desanāpariyosāne vuttanayeneva
analyzed: vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam desentaḥ arahatta nikūṭena iva desanam niṭṭhapesi desanā pariyosāne vutta nayena iva
translated: brought his teaching to a conclusion with the peak of the arahants. At the conclusion of the teaching,

original: pañcasatā bhikkhū arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsūti.
analyzed: pañcasatā bhikkhū arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu iti
translated: five hundred bhikkhus were established in arahatship, as stated in the text.

original: Vibhaṅgasuttaṃ dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: vibhaṅga suttam dutiyam
translated: The Vibhaṅga Sutta is finished.

original: 3. Paṭipadāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽3. Tatiye micchāpaṭipadanti ayaṃ tāva aniyyānikapaṭipadā. Nanu ca avijjāpaccayā puññābhisaṅkhāropi
analyzed: tatiye micchā paṭipadam ti ayam tāva aniyyānika paṭipadā nanu ca avijjā paccayā puñña abhisaṅkhāraḥ api
translated: The Path of Purification

original: atthi āneñjābhisaṅkhāropi, so kathaṃ micchāpaṭipadā hotīti. Vaṭṭasīsattā. Yañhi kiñci
analyzed: atthi āneñja abhisaṅkhāraḥ api saḥ katham micchā paṭipadā hoti iti vaṭṭa sīsa ttā yat hi kiñci
translated: In the third sutta, the wrong way is the way that does not lead to deliverance. But is not the formation of merit and the formation of the imperturbable also a condition for ignorance? How then can it be the wrong way? It is the round of rebirths,

original: bhavattayasaṅkhātaṃ vaṭṭaṃ patthetvā pavattitaṃ, antamaso pañcābhiññā aṭṭha vā pana
analyzed: bhavattaya saṅkhātam vaṭṭam patthetvā pavattitam antamasaḥ pañca abhiññāḥ aṭṭha vā pana
translated: for whatever occurs in the round of rebirths, which is called the triple round , is so called because it occurs seeking the round of rebirths, even down to the five kinds of direct-knowledge or the eight attainments.

original: samāpattiyo, sabbaṃ taṃ vaṭṭapakkhiyaṃ vaṭṭasīsanti vaṭṭasīsattā micchāpaṭipadāva🔽hoti. Yaṃ pana kiñci vivaṭṭaṃ nibbānaṃ patthetvā pavattitaṃ, antamaso uḷuṅkayāgumattadānampi
analyzed: samāpattiyo sabbam tat vaṭṭa pakkhiyam vaṭṭa sīsanti vaṭṭa sīsa ttā micchā paṭipadā ava  hoti yam pana kiñci vivaṭṭam nibbānam patthetvā pavattitam antamasaḥ uḷuṅka yāgu matta dānam pi
translated: All that is on the side of the round, is the head of the round, is the head of the round’s being, is the wrong way.

original: paṇṇamuṭṭhidānamattampi, sabbaṃ taṃ vivaṭṭapakkhiyaṃ vivaṭṭanissitaṃ, vivaṭṭapakkhikattā🔽sammāpaṭipadāva hoti. Appamattakampi hi paṇṇamuṭṭhimattadānakusalaṃ vā hotu mahantaṃ
analyzed: paṇṇa muṭṭhi dāna mattam pi sabbam tat vivaṭṭa pakkhiyam vivaṭṭa nissitam vivaṭṭa pakkhika ttā  sammā paṭipadā ava hoti appamattakam pi hi paṇṇa muṭṭhi matta dāna kusalam vā hotu mahantam
translated: But whatever is on the side of the unrolling, is on the side of the unrolling, is dependent on the unrolling, is the right way.🔽For even though the profitable consisting in giving a mere handful of food or a mere cluster of flowers,

original: velāmadānādikusalaṃ vā, sace vaṭṭasampattiṃ patthetvā vaṭṭanissitavasena micchā ṭhapitaṃ
analyzed: velā madāna ādi kusalam vā sace vaṭṭa sampattim patthetvā vaṭṭa nissita vasena micchā ṭhapitam
translated: is slight, if it is wrongly placed by being dependent on the round and aiming at the round’s success,

original: hoti, vaṭṭameva āharituṃ sakkoti, no vivaṭṭaṃ. “Idaṃ me dānaṃ āsavakkhayāvahaṃ hotū”ti
analyzed: hoti vaṭṭam eva āharitum sakkoti no vivaṭṭam idam me dānam āsava khaya āvaham hotu uti
translated: it can only bring about the round, not the unrolling.

original: evaṃ pana vivaṭṭaṃ patthentena vivaṭṭavasena sammā ṭhapitaṃ arahattampi paccekabodhiñāṇampi
analyzed: evam pana vivaṭṭam patthentena vivaṭṭa vasena sammā ṭhapitam arahattam pi pacceka bodhi ñāṇam pi
translated: But when it is rightly placed by being dependent on the unrolling and aiming at the unrolling, it can bring about even the state of Arahantship, the knowledge of a Paccekabuddha’s enlightenment,

original: sabbaññutaññāṇampi dātuṃ sakkotiyeva, na arahattaṃ appatvā pariyosānaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: sabbaññu ta ññāṇam pi dātum sakkotiyā iva na arahattam ap patvā pariyosānam gacchati
translated: or the knowledge of omniscience, and it does not stop short of that.

original: Iti anulomavasena micchāpaṭipadā, paṭilomavasena sammāpaṭipadā desitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: iti anuloma vasena micchā paṭipadā paṭiloma vasena sammā paṭipadā desitā ati veditabbā
translated: So it should be understood that the wrong way is taught by the forward order and the right way by the reverse order.

original: Nanu cettha paṭipadā pucchitā, nibbānaṃ bhājitaṃ, niyyātanepi paṭipadāva niyyātitā.
analyzed: nanu ca ittha paṭipadā pucchitā nibbānam bhājitam niyyātane pi paṭipadā ava niyyātitā
translated: But was not the way asked for in the question, and is not Nibbāna demonstrated here, and is not the way demonstrated in the answer too?

original: Na ca nibbānassa paṭipadāti nāmaṃ, savipassanānaṃ pana catunnaṃ maggānametaṃ nāmaṃ,🔽tasmā pucchāniyyātanehi padabhājanaṃ na sametīti. No na sameti, kasmā? Phalena paṭipadāya
analyzed: na ca nibbānassa paṭipadā ti nāmam sa vipassanānam pana catunnam maggānam etam nāmam  tasmā pucchā niyyātanehi pada bhājanam na sameti iti no na sameti kasmā phalena paṭipadāya
translated: And the name of the way is not Nibbāna, but it is the four paths with insight.🔽So the demonstration of the answer does not agree with the question.

original: dassitattā. Phalena hettha paṭipadā dassitā. “Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho”ti🔽etaṃ nirodhasaṅkhātaṃ nibbānaṃ yassā paṭipadāya phalaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave,
analyzed: dassita ttā phalena ha ittha paṭipadā dassitā avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodhā ti  etam nirodha saṅkhātam nibbānam yassā paṭipadāya phalam ayam vuccati bhikkhave
translated: —No, it does not not agree. And why not? Because the way is demonstrated by its fruit. For the way is demonstrated here by its fruit. With the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance comes cessation of formations.🔽This Nibbāna, which is called cessation, is the fruit of a way, and this is what is called “the right way” here.

original: sammāpaṭipadāti ayamettha attho. Imasmiñca atthe asesavirāganirodhāti ettha virāgo
analyzed: sammā paṭipadā ti ayam ettha atthaḥ imasmin ca atthe asesa virāga nirodhā ati ettha virāgo
translated: And in this meaning the words “with the remainderless fading away and cessation” are a synonym for cessation, and the meaning is that it is with the remainderless cessation of that.

original: nirodhasseva vevacanaṃ, asesavirāgā asesanirodhāti ayañhettha adhippāyo. Yena vā
analyzed: nirodhassa iva vevacanam asesa virāgāḥ asesa nirodhā ti ayan ha ittha adhippāyaḥ yena vā
translated: Or alternatively, the words “with the remainderless fading away and cessation” are a synonym for Nibbāna, and the meaning is that it is with the remainderless cessation of that.

original: virāgasaṅkhātena maggena asesanirodho hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ etaṃ padabhājanaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Evañhi sati sānubhāvā paṭipadā vibhattā hoti. Iti imasmimpi sutte vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva
analyzed: virāga saṅkhātena maggena asesa nirodhaḥ hoti tam dassetum etam pada bhājanam vuttam  evam hi sati sa anubhāvā paṭipadā vibhattā hoti iti imasmim pi sutte vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam eva
translated: The cessation is the complete cessation of the round by means of the path called “fading away” . The words of the text are given in order to show this.

original: kathitanti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: kathitanti tatiyam
translated: For when this is so, the way with its potency is shown. So in this sutta too it is the round of the dependent origination that is taught. This is the commentary on the third sutta.

original: 4. Vipassīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vipassī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The fourth sutta

original: 4. Catutthe vipassissāti tassa kira bodhisattassa yathā lokiyamanussānaṃ kiñcideva
analyzed: catutthe vipassissa ti tassa kira bodhisattassa yathā lokiya manussānam kiñcid eva
translated: In the fourth sutta, Vipassī means that his eyes did not wink as he looked, it seems.

original: passantānaṃ parittakammābhinibbattassa kammajapasādassa dubbalattā akkhīni vipphandanti,🔽na evaṃ vipphandiṃsu. Balavakammanibbattassa pana kammajapasādassa balavattā avipphandantehi
analyzed: passantānam paritta kamma abhinibbattassa kamma ja pasādassa dubbala ttā akkhīni vipphandanti  na evam vipphandiṃsu balava kamma nibbattassa pana kamma ja pasādassa balavat tā a vipphandantehi
translated: For when ordinary people look at something, their eyes wink because the eye-sensitivity produced by kamma is weak.

original: animisehi eva akkhīhi passi seyyathāpi devā tāvatiṃsā. Tena vuttaṃ – “animisanto
analyzed: animisehi eva akkhīhi passi seyyathā api devā tāvatiṃsā tena vuttam a nimisanto
translated: But his eyes did not wink because the eye-sensitivity produced by kamma was strong. He looked with unwinking eyes like the Thirty-three Gods. Hence it was said: “The prince looked without winking” .

original: kumāro pekkhatīti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa ‘vipassī vipassī’tveva samaññā
analyzed: kumāraḥ pekkhati iti kho bhikkhave vipassissa kumārassa vipassī vipassī tu eva samaññā
translated: “The prince looked without winking” : the prince Vipassī was called Vipassī because he looked with unwinking eyes.

original: udapādī”ti. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – antarantarā nimisajanitandhakāravirahena visuddhaṃ
analyzed: udapādi iti ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ antar antarā nimisa janita ndhakāra virahena visuddham
translated: This is the meaning here: He sees with eyes free from the darkness caused by the winking of the eyelids,

original: passati, vivaṭehi vā akkhīhi passatīti vipassī. Ettha ca kiñcāpi pacchimabhavikānaṃ
analyzed: passati vivaṭehi vā akkhīhi passati iti vipassī ettha ca kiñcā api pacchimabhavikānam
translated: or he sees with eyes that are open. And here, although the eyes of all Bodhisattas in their last existence

original: sabbabodhisattānaṃ balavakammanibbattassa kammajapasādassa balavattā akkhīni na vipphandanti,
analyzed: sabba bodhisattānam balava kamma nibbattassa kamma ja pasādassa balavattā akkhīni na vipphandanti
translated: do not wink because of the strength of the eye-sensitivity produced by powerful kamma,

original: so pana bodhisatto eteneva nāmaṃ labhi.
analyzed: saḥ pana bodhisattaḥ etena iva nāmam labhi
translated: that Bodhisatta received this name because of this.

original: Apica viceyya viceyya passatīti vipassī, vicinitvā vicinitvā passatīti attho. Ekadivasaṃ🔽kira vinicchayaṭṭhāne nisīditvā atthe anusāsantassa rañño alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ mahāpurisaṃ
analyzed: apica viceyya viceyya passati iti vipassī vicinitvā vicinitvā passati iti attho eka divasam  kira vinicchaya ṭṭhāne nisīditvā atthe anusāsantassa raññaḥ alaṅkata paṭiyattam mahā purisam
translated: Moreover, he sees after examining again and again; the meaning is, he sees after investigating.🔽One day, it seems, they brought the Great Man, who was adorned and decorated,🔽and placed him on the king’s lap while the king was sitting in the judgment hall and giving judgment.

original: āharitvā aṅke ṭhapayiṃsu. Tassa taṃ aṅke katvā palāḷayamānasseva amaccā sāmikaṃ assāmikaṃ
analyzed: āharitvā aṅke ṭhapayiṃsu tassa tam aṅke katvā palāḷayamānassa iva amaccā sāmikam a sāmikam
translated: While the king was fondling him, his ministers made the king’s master a non-master.

original: akaṃsu. Bodhisatto anattamanasaddaṃ nicchāresi. Rājā “kimetaṃ upadhārethā”ti āha.
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ anattamana saddam nicchāresi rājā kim etam upadhāretha iti āha
translated: The Bodhisatta uttered a cry of distress. The king said, “Find out what this means.”

original: Upadhārayamānā aññaṃ adisvā “aṭṭassa dubbinicchitattā evaṃ kataṃ bhavissatī”ti puna
analyzed: upadhārayamānāḥ aññam a disvā aṭṭassa dubbinicchita ttā evam katam bhavissati iti puna
translated: Not seeing any other reason, they thought, “It must be that the prince has done this because of his bad training.”

original: sāmikameva sāmikaṃ katvā “ñatvā nu kho kumāro evaṃ karotī”ti? Vīmaṃsantā puna sāmikaṃ
analyzed: sāmikam eva sāmikam katvā ñatvā nu khalu kumāraḥ evam karoti iti vīmaṃsantā punar sāmikam
translated: So they made him a husband again, thinking, “Let us see if he will do the same thing when he knows.”

original: assāmikamakaṃsu. Puna bodhisatto tatheva saddaṃ nicchāresi. Atha rājā “jānāti mahāpuriso”ti
analyzed: puna bodhisatto tathā iva saddam nicchāresi atha rājā jānāti mahā purisaḥ ti
translated: But the Bodhisatta made the same noise as before. Then the king thought, “The great man knows what is going on.”

original: tato paṭṭhāya appamatto ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ “viceyya viceyya kumāro atthe panāyati
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya appamattaḥ ahosi tena vuttam viceyya viceyya kumāraḥ atthe panāyati
translated: From that time forth he was on his guard. That is why it was said above, “The prince, after due investigation,

original: ñāyenāti kho, bhikkhave, vipassissa kumārassa bhiyyosomattāya ‘vipassī vipassī’tveva samaññā udapādī”ti.🔽Bhagavatoti bhāgyasampannassa. Arahatoti rāgādiarīnaṃ hatattā, saṃsāracakkassa vā
analyzed: ñāyena ati kho bhikkhave vipassissa kumārassa bhiyyosomattāya vipassī vipassī tvā iva samaññā udapādi iti  bhagavato ti bhāgya sampannassa arahato ti rāga ādi arīnam hata ttā saṃsāra cakkassa vā
translated: ‘By reason of his knowledge’: the name Vipassī came to be applied to the prince Vipassī because of his knowledge.

original: arānaṃ hatattā, paccayānaṃ vā arahattā arahāti evaṃ guṇato uppannanāmadheyyassa.
analyzed: arānam hatattā paccayānam vā arahattā arahāti evam guṇataḥ uppanna nāmadheyyassa
translated: The Blessed One: he who possesses fortune . The Arahant: he who has destroyed the enemies such as greed, etc., or he who has destroyed the spokes of the wheel of the round of rebirths , or he who is worthy of offerings because of his being a fit recipient of offerings.

original: Sammāsambuddhassāti sammā nayena hetunā sāmaṃ paccattapurisakārena cattāri saccāni
analyzed: sammāsambuddhassa ati sammā nayena hetunā sāmam paccatta purisakārena cattāri saccāni
translated: The Fully Enlightened One: he who has fully and rightly awakened to the four truths by himself and has realized them by his own efforts.

original: buddhassa. Pubbeva sambodhāti sambodho vuccati catūsu maggesu ñāṇaṃ, tato pubbeva.
analyzed: buddhassa pubbā iva sambodhā ti sambodho vuccati catūsu maggesu ñāṇam tatas pubbā eva
translated: “Before the Buddha”: the knowledge in the four paths is called “awakening”; before that.

original: Bodhisattasseva satoti ettha bodhīti ñāṇaṃ, bodhimā satto bodhisatto, ñāṇavā paññavā
analyzed: bodhisattassa iva sato ti ettha bodhi iti ñāṇam bodhimā sattaḥ bodhisatto ñāṇavā paññavā
translated: “Of the Bodhisatta”: here, “awakening” is knowledge; the being who has awakened is a “bodhisatta” . He is wise, discerning,

original: paṇḍitoti attho. Purimabuddhānañhi pādamūle abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya paṇḍitova so satto,
analyzed: paṇḍito ti attho purima buddhānam hi pāda mūle abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya paṇḍitaḥ uva so satto
translated: intelligent, is the meaning. For from the time of his resolution at the feet of previous Buddhas, that being is wise,

original: na andhabāloti bodhisatto. Yathā vā udakato uggantvā ṭhitaṃ paripākagataṃ padumaṃ
analyzed: na andha bālaḥ iti bodhisattaḥ yathā vā udakataḥ uggantvā ṭhitam paripāka gatam padumam
translated: not blind and foolish, thus he is a “bodhisatta.” Or just as a lotus that has emerged from the water and is fully developed

original: sūriyarasmisamphassena avassaṃ bujjhissatīti bujjhanakapadumanti vuccati, evaṃ buddhānaṃ
analyzed: sūriya rasmi samphassena avassam bujjhissati iti bujjhanakapadumanti vuccati evam buddhānam
translated: is called a “lotus that will open” because it will certainly open by the touch of the sun’s rays, so too this being

original: santike byākaraṇassa laddhattā avassaṃ anantarāyena pāramiyo pūretvā bujjhissatīti🔽bujjhanakasattotipi bodhisatto. Yā ca esā catumaggañāṇasaṅkhātā bodhi, taṃ patthayamāno
analyzed: santike byākaraṇassa laddha ttā avassam anantarāyena pāramiyaḥ pūretvā bujjhissati iti  bujjhanakasatto tipi bodhisattaḥ yā ca esā catu magga ñāṇa saṅkhātā bodhi tam patthayamānaḥ
translated: will certainly awaken by fulfilling the pāramīs without hindrance because he has received the prophecy in the presence of the Buddhas, thus he is called a “bodhisatta” .🔽And just as a lotus that is attached to the place where it grows is called a “lotus in the water,” so too this being,

original: pavattatīti bodhiyaṃ satto āsattotipi bodhisatto. Evaṃ guṇato uppannanāmavasena bodhisattasseva
analyzed: pavattati iti bodhiyam satto āsattaḥ iti pi bodhisatto evam guṇataḥ uppanna nāma vasena bodhisattassa iva
translated: who is attached to the awakening, who proceeds with the desire for that awakening which is called the four paths, thus he is a “bodhisatta” . Thus, by way of the name that has arisen from the quality, he is a “bodhisatta” .

original: sato. Kicchanti dukkhaṃ. Āpannoti anuppatto. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – aho ayaṃ sattaloko🔽dukkhaṃ anuppattoti. Cavati ca upapajjati cāti idaṃ aparāparaṃ cutipaṭisandhivasena
analyzed: sataḥ kicchanti dukkham āpannaḥ ti anuppattaḥ idam vuttam hoti aho ayam satta loko  dukkham anuppatto ti cavati ca upapajjati ca ati idam apara aparam cuti paṭisandhi vasena
translated: He is mindful. They strive for suffering. He has reached: he has attained. This is what is said: “Oh, this world of beings🔽has reached suffering.” He passes away and is reborn: this is said in terms of death and rebirth-linking.

original: vuttaṃ. Nissaraṇanti nibbānaṃ. Tañhi jarāmaraṇadukkhato nissaṭattā tassa nissaraṇanti
analyzed: vuttam nissaraṇanti nibbānam tat hi jarā maraṇa dukkhataḥ nissaṭa ttā tassa nissaraṇan ti
translated: An escape: Nibbāna. For that is called “an escape” because it has escaped from the suffering of ageing and death.

original: vuccati. Kudāssu nāmāti katarasmiṃ nu kho kāle.
analyzed: vuccati kudāssu nāma ati katarasmin nu kho kāle
translated: When will there be: in what time?

original: Yoniso manasikārāti upāyamanasikārena pathamanasikārena. Ahu paññāya abhisamayoti🔽paññāya saddhiṃ jarāmaraṇakāraṇassa abhisamayo samavāyo samāyogo ahosi, “jātipaccayā🔽jarāmaraṇa”nti idaṃ tena diṭṭhanti attho. Atha vā yoniso manasikārā ahu paññāyāti
analyzed: yonisaḥ manasikārā ati upāya manasikārena patha manasikārena ahu paññāya abhisamayo ti  paññāya saddhim jarā maraṇa kāraṇassa abhisamayaḥ samavāyaḥ samāyogaḥ ahosi jāti paccayā  jarā maraṇanti idam tena diṭṭhanti attho atha vā yonisas manasikārāḥ ahu paññāyāti
translated: Proper attention: by means of the right kind of attention, by means of the right way of directing the mind. He had direct knowledge with understanding:🔽there was direct knowledge, direct seeing, direct encounter, on his part with understanding, of the cause of ageing and death. The meaning is: “This was seen by him: ‘With birth as condition ageing and death come to be.’” Or alternatively, he had direct knowledge with understanding:

original: yoniso manasikārena ca paññāya ca abhisamayo ahu. “Jātiyā kho sati jarāmaraṇa”nti,
analyzed: yonisas manasikārena ca paññāya ca abhisamayaḥ ahu jātiyā kho sati jarā maraṇanti
translated: there was direct knowledge, direct seeing, direct encounter, on his part with understanding and by means of proper attention. “With the existence of birth ageing and death come to be,”

original: evaṃ jarāmaraṇakāraṇassa paṭivedho ahosīti attho. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: evam jarā maraṇa kāraṇassa paṭivedhaḥ ahosi iti attho esa nayo sabbattha
translated: The meaning is that he penetrated the cause of aging-and-death. The same method applies in all cases.

original: Iti hidanti evamidaṃ. Samudayo samudayoti ekādasasu ṭhānesu saṅkhārādīnaṃ samudayaṃ🔽sampiṇḍetvā niddisati. Pubbe ananussutesūti “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo hotī”ti.🔽Evaṃ ito pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu, catūsu vā ariyasaccadhammesu. Cakkhuntiādīni
analyzed: iti evam idam ekādasasu ṭhānesu saṅkhāra ādīnam samudayam  sampiṇḍetvā niddisati pubbe an anussutesu ti avijjā paccayā saṅkhārānam samudayaḥ hoti iti  evam itas pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu catūsu vā ariya sacca dhammesu cakkhu nti ādīni
translated: “Thus, bhikkhus, this was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus, it is by way of elements that beings come together and unite. When their bodily activities, verbal activities, and mental activities coincide and agree, then owing to the similarity, likeness, and conformity of their bodily, verbal, and mental activities, they come together and unite.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus, it is by way of elements that beings come together and unite. When their bodily activities, verbal activities, and mental activities coincide and agree, then owing to the similarity, likeness, and conformity of their bodily, verbal, and mental activities, they come together and unite.’

original: ñāṇavevacanāneva. Ñāṇameva hettha dassanaṭṭhena cakkhu, ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṃ, pajānanaṭṭhena🔽paññā, paṭivedhanaṭṭhena vijjā, obhāsanaṭṭhena ālokoti vuttaṃ. Taṃ panetaṃ catūsu
analyzed: ñāṇa vevacanāni iva ñāṇam eva ha ittha dassana ṭṭhena cakkhu ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇam pajānana ṭṭhena  paññā paṭivedhana ṭṭhena vijjā obhāsana ṭṭhena āloko ti vuttam tam pana etam catūsu
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus, it is by way of elements that beings come together and unite. When their bodily activities, verbal activities, and mental activities coincide and agree, then owing to the similarity, likeness, and conformity of their bodily, verbal, and mental activities, they come together and unite.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus, it is by way of elements that beings come together and unite. When their bodily activities, verbal activities, and mental activities coincide and agree, then owing to the similarity, likeness, and conformity of their bodily, verbal, and mental activities, they come together and unite.’

original: saccesu lokiyalokuttaramissakaṃ niddiṭṭhanti veditabbaṃ. Nirodhavārepi imināva nayena🔽attho veditabbo. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: saccesu lokiya lokuttara missakam niddiṭṭhanti veditabbam nirodha vāre pi iminā ava nayena  atthaḥ veditabbaḥ catuttham
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus, it is by way of elements that beings come together and unite. When their bodily activities, verbal activities, and mental activities coincide and agree, then owing to the similarity, likeness, and conformity of their bodily, verbal, and mental activities, they come together and unite.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus, it is by way of elements that beings come together and unite. When their bodily activities, verbal activities, and mental activities coincide and agree, then owing to the similarity, likeness, and conformity of their bodily, verbal, and mental activities, they come together and unite.’

original: 5-10. Sikhīsuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: sikhī sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: ‘Bhikkhus

original: 5-10. Pañcamādīsu sikhissa, bhikkhavetiādīnaṃ padānaṃ “sikhissapi, bhikkhave”ti na
analyzed: pañcama ādīsu sikhissa bhikkhave iti ādīnam padānam sikhissa api bhikkhave iti na
translated: In the case of the fifth and following questions, the meaning of the passages beginning “Bhikkhus, to a disciple in higher training” should not be understood as follows: “Bhikkhus, even to a disciple in higher training” .

original: evaṃ yojetvā attho veditabbo. Kasmā? Ekāsane adesitattā. Nānāṭhānesu hi etāni desitāni,🔽attho pana sabbattha sadisoyeva. Sabbabodhisattānañhi bodhipallaṅke nisinnānaṃ na
analyzed: evam yojetvā atthaḥ veditabbo kasmā eka āsane a desita ttā nānā ṭhānesu hi etāni desitāni  atthaḥ pana sabbattha sadisaḥ yeva sabba bodhisattānam hi bodhi pallaṅke nisinnānam na
translated: Why not? Because they were not taught at the same session. For these were taught on different occasions.

original: añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā ācikkhati – “atīte bodhisattā🔽paccayākāraṃ sammasitvā buddhā jātā”ti. Yathā pana paṭhamakappikakāle deve vuṭṭhe🔽udakassa gatamaggeneva aparāparaṃ vuṭṭhiudakaṃ gacchati, evaṃ tehi tehi purimabuddhehi
analyzed: aññaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā devaḥ vā māraḥ vā brahmā vā ācikkhati atīte bodhisattā  paccaya ākāram sammasitvā buddhā jātā ati yathā pana paṭhama kappika kāle deve vuṭṭhe  udakassa gata maggena iva apara aparam vuṭṭhi udakam gacchati evam tehi tehi purimabuddhehi
translated: But the meaning is the same in all cases. For no other ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or anyone else in the world can point out to all bodhisattas seated at the foot of the Bodhi Tree the way in which the Buddhas of the past became enlightened by comprehending the principles of conditionality.🔽But just as the water of a river flows on by a certain channel, and when the channel breaks away the water still flows on by the new channel, so too the bodhisattas flow on by the channel opened up by the Buddhas of the past.

original: gatamaggeneva pacchimā pacchimā gacchanti. Sabbabodhisattā hi ānāpānacatutthajjhānato
analyzed: gata maggena iva pacchimā pacchimā gacchanti sabba bodhisattāḥ hi āna apāna catuttha jjhānato
translated: For all bodhisattas emerge from the fourth jhāna of in-breaths and out-breaths,

original: vuṭṭhāya paccayākāre ñāṇaṃ otāretvā taṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ sammasitvā buddhā hontīti
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya paccaya ākāre ñāṇam otāretvā tam anuloma paṭilomam sammasitvā buddhāḥ honti iti
translated: and after that they become Buddhas by comprehending the principles of conditionality in forward and reverse order.

original: paṭipāṭiyā sattasu suttesu buddhavipassanā nāma kathitāti.
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā sattasu suttesu buddhavipassanā nāma kathitā ati
translated: In the seven Suttas in the Paṭipāṭi, the Buddha’s insight is called “Buddhavipassanā.”

original: Buddhavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: buddha vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first sub-chapter on the Buddha is concluded.

original: 2. Āhāravaggo
analyzed: āhāra vaggo
translated: The chapter on food

original: 1. Āhārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āhāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the first sutta in the chapter on food

original: 11. Āhāravaggassa paṭhame āhārāti paccayā. Paccayā hi āharanti attano phalaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: āhāra vaggassa paṭhame paccayā paccayā hi āharanti attanaḥ phalam tasmā
translated: In the first sutta in the chapter on food, “food” means conditions. Conditions are called “food” because they bring in their own fruit.

original: āhārāti vuccanti. Bhūtānaṃ vā sattānantiādīsu bhūtāti jātā nibbattā. Sambhavesinoti🔽ye sambhavaṃ jātiṃ nibbattiṃ esanti gavesanti. Tattha catūsu yonīsu aṇḍajajalābujā
analyzed: āhārā ti vuccanti bhūtānam vā sattānam ti ādīsu bhūtā ati jātāḥ nibbattā sambhavesinaḥ ti  ye sambhavam jātim nibbattim esanti gavesanti tattha catūsu yonīsu aṇḍa ja jalābu jā
translated: In the phrases “of beings that have come to be” and so on, “beings that have come to be” are those that have been born, have come into existence.🔽“Those seeking becoming” are those who seek, who search for, rebirth, birth, coming into existence.

original: sattā yāva aṇḍakosaṃ vatthikosañca na bhindanti, tāva sambhavesino nāma, aṇḍakosaṃ🔽vatthikosañca bhinditvā bahi nikkhantā bhūtā nāma. Saṃsedajā opapātikā ca paṭhamacittakkhaṇe
analyzed: sattāḥ yāva aṇḍa kosam vatthi kosam ca na bhindanti tāva sambhavesinaḥ nāma aṇḍa kosam  vatthi kosam ca bhinditvā bahi nikkhantā bhūtāḥ nāma saṃseda jā opapātikā ca paṭhama cittakkhaṇe
translated: Herein, beings born in the four modes of generation are called “those seeking becoming” as long as they do not break the egg shell or the caul,🔽but once they have broken the egg shell or the caul and have come out, they are called “those that have come to be.”🔽Beings born supernaturally and spontaneously are called “those seeking becoming” in the first moment of their consciousness,🔽but from the second moment of consciousness onward they are called “those that have come to be.”

original: sambhavesino nāma, dutiyacittakkhaṇato pabhuti bhūtā nāma. Yena vā iriyāpathena jāyanti,
analyzed: sambhavesinaḥ nāma dutiya cittakkhaṇato pabhuti bhūtāḥ nāma yena vā iriyāpathena jāyanti
translated: By whatever posture they are born,

original: yāva tato aññaṃ na pāpuṇanti, tāva sambhavesino nāma, tato paraṃ bhūtā nāma. Atha🔽vā bhūtāti jātā abhinibbattā, ye bhūtā abhinibbattāyeva, na puna bhavissantīti saṅkhaṃ🔽gacchanti, tesaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sambhavamesantīti sambhavesino. Appahīnabhavasaṃyojanattā
analyzed: yāva tatas aññam na pāpuṇanti tāva sambhavesinaḥ nāma tato param bhūtāḥ nāma atha  vā bhūtā ati jātāḥ abhinibbattāḥ ye bhūtāḥ abhinibbattāya iva na punar bhavissanti iti saṅkham  gacchanti tesam khīṇāsavānam etam adhivacanam sambhavam esanti iti sambhavesinaḥ appahīna bhava saṃyojana ttā
translated: as long as they do not reach another birth, they are called “those who are being born” . After that they are called “beings” .

original: āyatimpi sambhavaṃ esantānaṃ sekkhaputhujjanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Evaṃ sabbathāpi🔽imehi dvīhi padehi sabbasatte pariyādiyati. Vāsaddo cettha sampiṇḍanattho, tasmā
analyzed: āyatim pi sambhavam sekkha puthujjanānam etam adhivacanam evam sabbathā api  imehi dvīhi padehi sabba satte pariyādiyati vā saddaḥ ca ittha sampiṇḍana atthaḥ tasmā
translated: Or alternatively, “beings” are those who have been born, who have come to birth. Those who have been born and come to birth and who will not come to birth again are called “those whose cankers are destroyed” . “Those who are being born” are those who are seeking to be born. Those who are seeking to be born because they have not abandoned the fetter of being are called “those in training and ordinary men” . Thus in every way

original: bhūtānañca sambhavesīnañcāti ayamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: bhūtānam ca sambhavesīnam ca ati ayam atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: he includes all beings with these two terms. And the word “and” has the meaning of “together with” . So the meaning should be understood as “beings and those who are being born” .

original: Ṭhitiyāti ṭhitatthaṃ. Anuggahāyāti anuggahatthaṃ. Vacanabhedoyeva cesa, attho pana
analyzed: ṭhitiyā ati ṭhita attham anuggahāya ati anuggaha attham ca idam atthaḥ pana
translated: “For the sake of continuance” means for the sake of steadiness. “For the sake of maintenance” means for the sake of support. The difference is merely verbal;

original: dvinnampi padānaṃ ekoyeva. Atha vā ṭhitiyāti tassa tassa sattassa uppannadhammānaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam pi padānam eko yā iva atha vā ṭhitiyā ti tassa tassa sattassa uppanna dhammānam
translated: the meaning of both terms is the same. Or alternatively, “for the sake of continuance” means for the sake of the arising of the states of a particular being

original: anuppabandhavasena avicchedāya. Anuggahāyāti anuppannānaṃ uppādāya. Ubhopi cetāni🔽“bhūtānaṃ vā ṭhitiyā ceva anuggahāya ca, sambhavesīnaṃ vā ṭhitiyā ceva anuggahāya
analyzed: an uppabandha vasena a vicchedāya anuggahāya ati an uppannānam uppādāya ubho pi  bhūtānam vā ṭhitiyā ca iva anuggahāya ca sambhavesīnam vā ṭhitiyā ca iva anuggahāya
translated: for the purpose of non-disruption by way of continuity. For the purpose of assistance: for the purpose of the arising of those that have not arisen. Both of these

original: cā”ti evaṃ ubhayattha daṭṭhabbānīti.
analyzed: ca ati evam ubhayattha daṭṭhabbāni iti
translated: should be regarded as follows: “for the purpose of the maintenance and assistance of those that have come to be, and for the purpose of the maintenance and assistance of those that are seeking to be” .

original: Kabaḷīkāro āhāroti kabaḷaṃ katvā ajjhoharitabbako āhāro, odanakummāsādivatthukāya🔽ojāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Oḷāriko vā sukhumo vāti vatthuoḷārikatāya oḷāriko, sukhumatāya🔽sukhumo. Sabhāvena pana sukhumarūpapariyāpannattā kabaḷīkāro āhāro sukhumova hoti.🔽Sāpi cassa vatthuto oḷārikatā sukhumatā ca upādāyupādāya veditabbā. Kumbhīlānañhi
analyzed: kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ ti kabaḷam katvā ajjhoharitabbakaḥ āhāraḥ odana kummāsa ādi vatthukāya  adhivacanam oḷārikaḥ vā sukhumaḥ vāti vatthu oḷārika tāya oḷārikaḥ sukhuma tāya  sukhumaḥ sa bhāvena pana sukhuma rūpa pariyāpanna ttā kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ uva hoti  sā api ca ssa vatthutaḥ oḷārika tā sukhuma tā ca upādāya upādāya veditabbā kumbhīlānam hi
translated: “Physical nutriment” is nutriment that is to be consumed by being made into morsels. It is a term for the essence that has as its basis rice, cakes, etc.,🔽or it is gross or subtle according to the grossness or subtlety of its basis. But in its own individual essence physical nutriment is subtle, being included in the subtle materiality .

original: āhāraṃ upādāya morānaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Kumbhīlā kira pāsāṇe gilanti, te ca nesaṃ kucchippattā
analyzed: āhāram upādāya āhāro su khumaḥ kumbhīlā kira pāsāṇe gilanti te ca na īsam kucchippattā
translated: And its grossness or subtlety according to the basis should be understood according to the kind of being. For compared with the nutriment of the peacock, the nutriment of the crocodile is subtle. The peacock swallows clay, and that helps it to digest its nutriment. The crocodile swallows sand, and that helps it to digest its nutriment.

original: vilīyanti. Morā sappavicchikādipāṇe khādanti. Morānaṃ pana āhāraṃ upādāya taracchānaṃ🔽āhāro sukhumo. Te kira tivassachaḍḍitāni visāṇāni ceva aṭṭhīni ca khādanti, tāni🔽ca nesaṃ kheḷena temitamattāneva kandamūlaṃ viya mudukāni honti. Taracchānaṃ āhāraṃ🔽upādāya hatthīnaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Te hi nānārukkhasākhādayo khādanti. Hatthīnaṃ āhārato🔽gavayagokaṇṇamigādīnaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Te kira nissārāni nānārukkhapaṇṇādīni khādanti.
analyzed: vilīyanti morā khādanti pana āhāram upādāya taracchānam  āhāro su khumaḥ te kira ti vassa chaḍḍitāni visāṇāni ca iva aṭṭhīni ca khādanti tāni  ca kheḷena kanda mūlam kanda mūlam mudukāni honti āhāram  upādāya hatthīnam āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ te hi nānā rukkha sākhā ādayaḥ khādanti hatthīnam āhārato  gavaya gokaṇṇa miga ādīnaṃ āhāro sukhumaḥ te kira nissārāni nānā rukkha paṇṇa ādīni khādanti
translated: and they dissolve. The cocks are eaten by snakes, scorpions, etc.,🔽but the food of the taraccas is finer than that of the cocks. They eat, it seems, the horns and bones of cattle that have died in the wilderness and been left for three years or more.🔽But the food of the elephants is finer than that of the taraccas. They eat various kinds of tree shoots, etc.🔽The food of the gopiya deer, etc., is finer than that of the elephants. They eat, it seems, the sapless leaves, etc., of various trees.🔽

original: Tesampi āhārato gunnaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Te allasukkhatiṇāni khādanti. Tesaṃ āhārato🔽sasānaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Sasānaṃ āhārato sakuṇānaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Sakuṇānaṃ āhārato🔽paccantavāsīnaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Paccantavāsīnaṃ āhārato gāmabhojakānaṃ āhāro sukhumo.
analyzed: tesam pi āhārataḥ gunnam āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ te alla sukkha tiṇāni khādanti tesam āhārataḥ 🔽āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ sasānam āhārataḥ sakuṇānam āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ sakuṇānam āhārataḥ 🔽paccantavāsīnam āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ paccantavāsīnam āhārataḥ gāmabhojakānam āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ
translated: and they dissolve. The birds eat the snakes, lizards, etc. But compared with the birds’ food, the food of the water animals is finer. They eat the horns and bones of the animals that have died after three years, which are then soft like tubers, having become so by being soaked in their spittle. Compared with the water animals’ food, the elephants’ food is finer. They eat the branches, etc., of various trees. Compared with the elephants’ food, the food of the wild oxen, gayals, deer, etc., is finer. They eat the leaves, etc., of various trees that have no sap. Compared with their food, the food of the goats is finer. They eat soft green grass. Compared with their food, the food of the rabbits is finer. Compared with the rabbits’ food, the food of the birds is finer. Compared with the birds’ food, the food of the borderers is finer. Compared with the borderers’ food, the food of the town-dwellers is finer.

original: Gāmabhojakānaṃ āhārato rājarājamahāmattānaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Tesampi āhārato cakkavattino🔽āhāro sukhumo. Cakkavattino āhārato bhummānaṃ devānaṃ āhāro sukhumo. Bhummānaṃ devānaṃ
analyzed: gāma bhojakānaṃ āhārataḥ rāja rāja mahāmattānaṃ āhāro sukhumaḥ tesam pi āhārato cakkavattino  āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ cakkavattinaḥ āhārataḥ bhummānam devānam āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ bhummānam devānam
translated: The food of the Wheel-turning Monarch is finer than that of the king and his ministers.🔽The food of the gods of the Earthly Realm is finer than that of the Wheel-turning Monarch.🔽The food of the gods of the Realm of the Four Great Kings is finer than that of the gods of the Earthly Realm.🔽In this way the food of the gods of the Highest Realm of the Gods is finer than that of the gods of the Realm of the Creator of Worlds.

original: āhārato cātumahārājikānaṃ. Evaṃ yāva paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ āhārā vitthāretabbā.🔽Tesaṃ panāhāro sukhumotveva niṭṭhaṃ patto.
analyzed: āhārataḥ cātumahārājikānam evam yāva paranimmita vasavattīnam āhārāḥ vitthāretabbā  tesam pana āhāraḥ sukhumaḥ tvā eva niṭṭham patto
translated: But the food of the gods of the Highest Realm of the Gods has reached the limit of fineness.

original: Ettha ca oḷārike vatthusmiṃ ojā parittā hoti dubbalā, sukhume balavatī. Tathā hi
analyzed: ettha ca oḷārike vatthusmiṃ ojā parittā hoti dubbalā sukhume balavatī tathā hi
translated: And here the nutriment in a gross physical basis is slight and weak, while in a fine one it is strong.

original: ekapattapūrampi yāguṃ pīto muhutteneva jighacchito hoti yaṃkiñcideva khāditukāmo,
analyzed: eka patta pūram pi yāgum pītaḥ muhuttena iva jighacchitaḥ hoti yaṃ kiñcid eva khāditu kāmo
translated: For instance, after drinking a bowl of rice gruel one is hungry again in a short time and wants to eat something or other,

original: sappiṃ pana pasatamattaṃ pivitvā divasaṃ abhottukāmo hoti. Tattha vatthu kammajatejasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: sappim pana pasata mattam pivitvā divasam a bhottu kāmo hoti tattha vatthu kamma ja teja saṅkhātam
translated: but after drinking a cup of ghee one does not want to eat for a day. Herein, the physical basis removes the affliction called “the heat of kamma,”

original: parissayaṃ vinodeti, na pana sakkoti pāletuṃ. Ojā pana pāleti, na sakkoti parissayaṃ
analyzed: parissayam vinodeti na pana sakkoti pāletum ojā pana pāleti na sakkoti parissayam
translated: but it cannot preserve ; it is nutriment that preserves, but it cannot remove the affliction.

original: vinodetuṃ. Dve pana ekato hutvā parissayañceva vinodenti pālenti cāti.
analyzed: vinodetum dve pana ekatas hutvā parissayam ca iva vinodenti pālenti ca ati
translated: and the other two together both remove and guard against the danger.

original: Phasso dutiyoti cakkhusamphassādi chabbidhopi phasso etesu catūsu āhāresu dutiyo
analyzed: phassaḥ dutiyaḥ ti cakkhu samphassa ādi chabbidhaḥ pi phassaḥ etesu catūsu āhāresu dutiyaḥ
translated: Contact is the second nutriment: contact is of six kinds, namely, eye-contact, etc., and it should be understood as the second nutriment among these four.

original: āhāroti veditabbo. Desanānayo eva cesa, tasmā iminā nāma kāraṇena dutiyo tatiyo cāti
analyzed: āhāraḥ ti veditabbaḥ desanā nayaḥ eva ca isa tasmai iminā nāma kāraṇena dutiyo tatiyo ca ati
translated: This is only a method of teaching. Therefore it should not be sought here why it is the second and the third.

original: idamettha na gavesitabbaṃ. Manosañcetanāti cetanāva vuccati. Viññāṇanti cittaṃ. Iti🔽bhagavā imasmiṃ ṭhāne upādiṇṇakaanupādiṇṇakavasena ekarāsiṃ katvā cattāro āhāre dassesi.🔽Kabaḷīkārāhāro hi upādiṇṇakopi atthi anupādiṇṇakopi, tathā phassādayo. Tattha sappādīhi
analyzed: idam ettha na gavesitabbam manaḥ sañcetanā ati cetanā ava vuccati viññāṇan ti cittam iti  bhagavā imasmim ṭhāne upādiṇṇaka anupādiṇṇaka vasena eka rāsim katvā cattāraḥ āhāre dassesi  kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ hi upādiṇṇakaḥ api atthi anupādiṇṇakaḥ api tathā phassa ādayo tattha sappa ādīhi
translated: Mental volition is called volition itself. Consciousness is mind.

original: gilitānaṃ maṇḍūkādīnaṃ vasena upādiṇṇakakabaḷīkārāhāro daṭṭhabbo. Maṇḍūkādayo hi🔽sappādīhi gilitā antokucchigatāpi kiñci kālaṃ jīvantiyeva. Te yāva upādiṇṇakapakkhe
analyzed: gilitānam maṇḍūka ādīnam vasena upādiṇṇaka kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ maṇḍūka ādayaḥ hi 🔽sappa ādīhi gilitāḥ anto kucchi gatāḥ api kiñci kālam jīvantiyā iva te yāva upādiṇṇaka pakkhe
translated: Thus the Blessed One has shown the four nutriments in this section by making one aggregate, namely, the aggregate of mental formations, into two nutriments, namely, mental volition and consciousness, and by making the remaining four aggregates into one nutriment, namely, physical nutriment.

original: tiṭṭhanti, tāva āhāratthaṃ na sādhenti. Bhijjitvā pana anupādiṇṇakapakkhe ṭhitā sādhenti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti tāva āhāra attham na sādhenti bhijjitvā pana anupādiṇṇaka pakkhe ṭhitā sādhenti
translated: and they do not serve the purpose of nutriment as long as they remain in that state. But when they have disintegrated and are in the state of undeclaredness, they serve the purpose of nutriment.🔽And even then they are called “nutriment that is clung to.” But this is not approved by the teachers.

original: Tadāpi upādiṇṇakāhāroti vuccantīti. Idaṃ pana ācariyānaṃ na ruccatīti aṭṭhakathāyameva🔽paṭikkhipitvā idaṃ vuttaṃ – imesaṃ sattānaṃ khādantānampi akhādantānampi bhuñjantānampi
analyzed: tadā api upādiṇṇaka āhāraḥ ti vuccanti iti idam pana ācariyānam na ruccati iti aṭṭhakathā ayam eva  paṭikkhipitvā idam vuttam imesam sattānam khādantānam pi a khādantānam pi bhuñjantānam pi
translated: For this is said in the commentary, after rejecting it:

original: abhuñjantānampi paṭisandhicitteneva sahajātā kammajā ojā nāma atthi, sā yāvapi sattamā
analyzed: abhuñjantānam pi paṭisandhi cittena iva sahajātā kamma jā ojā nāma atthi sā yau api sattamā
translated: “Whether these beings eat or do not eat, whether they enjoy or do not enjoy, there is a nutriment called ‘nutriment consisting of physical nutriment’ that is born together with the rebirth-linking consciousness and is kamma-born. It lasts for seven days.

original: divasā pāleti, ayameva upādiṇṇakakabaḷīkārāhāroti veditabbo. Tebhūmakavipākavasena
analyzed: divasā pāla iti ayam eva tebhūmaka vipāka vasena
translated: This should be understood as the nutriment consisting of physical nutriment that is clung to.🔽But the nutriments consisting of contact, mental volition, and consciousness that occur in the three planes of existence should be understood as ‘nutriment that is clung to’ in the sense of being clung to by the defilements of the three planes of existence.

original: pana upādiṇṇakaphassādayo veditabbā, tebhūmakakusalākusalakiriyavasena anupādiṇṇakā.
analyzed: pana upādiṇṇaka phassa ādayaḥ veditabbā tebhūmaka kusala akusala kiriya vasena anupādiṇṇakā
translated: And those that occur in the three planes of existence in profitable and functional consciousness should be understood as ‘nutriment that is not clung to.’

original: Lokuttarā pana ruḷhīvasena kathitāti.
analyzed: lokuttarā pana ruḷhī vasena kathitā iti
translated: But the supramundane are called ‘nutriment’ by extension” .

original: Etthāha – “yadi paccayaṭṭho āhāraṭṭho, atha kasmā aññesupi sattānaṃ paccayesu vijjamānesu
analyzed: ettha āha yadi paccaya ṭṭhaḥ āhāra ṭṭhaḥ atha kasmai aññesu pi sattānam paccayesu vijjamānesu
translated: Here it may be asked: “If the meaning of ‘nutriment’ is the meaning of condition, then why is it said in the Paṭṭhāna that ‘nutriment is a condition for these states’ ?

original: imeyeva cattāro vuttā”ti? Vuccate – ajjhattikasantatiyā visesapaccayattā. Visesapaccayo🔽hi kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ sattānaṃ rūpakāyassa kabaḷīkāro āhāro, nāmakāye vedanāya🔽phasso, viññāṇassa manosañcetanā, nāmarūpassa viññāṇaṃ. Yathāha – “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave,
analyzed: imeye eva cattāro vuttā ti vuccate ajjhattika santatiyāḥ visesa paccaya ttā visesa paccayo  hi kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkhānam sattānam rūpa kāyassa kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ nāmakāye vedanāya  phassaḥ viññāṇassa manaḥ sañcetanā nāma rūpassa viññāṇam yathā āha seyyathā api bhikkhave
translated: It is said: because it is a condition for the distinction in the internal continuity.

original: ayaṃ kāyo āhāraṭṭhitiko āhāraṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhati, anāhāro no tiṭṭhati, tathā phassapaccayā
analyzed: ayam kāyaḥ āhāra ṭṭhitiko āhāram paṭicca tiṭṭhati anāhāraḥ no tiṭṭhati tathā phassa paccayā
translated: For material food is a condition for the material body of beings who eat material food, contact is a condition for the three kinds of feeling in the mental body, mental volition is a condition for the three kinds of becoming, and consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality. As it is said: “Bhikkhus, just as this body subsists and endures with material food as the basis, with material food as the foundation, not without material food,

original: vedanā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti.
analyzed: vedanā saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpanti
translated: so too feeling is conditioned by contact … consciousness is conditioned by formations, mentality-materiality is conditioned by consciousness” .

original: Ko panettha āhāro kiṃ āharatīti? Kabaḷīkārāhāro ojaṭṭhamakarūpāni āharati phassāhāro tisso vedanā, manosañcetanāhāro tayo bhave, viññāṇāhāro paṭisandhināmarūpanti.
analyzed: kaḥ pana ittha āhāro kim āharati iti kabaḷīkāra āhāro oja ṭhamaka rūpāni āharati phassa āhāro tissaḥ vedanā manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro tayo bhave viññāṇa āhāro paṭisandhi nāma rūpanti
translated: But what is food here and what does it nourish? Material food nourishes the material body, contact nourishes the three kinds of feeling, mental volition nourishes the three kinds of becoming, and consciousness nourishes mentality-materiality.

original: Kathaṃ? Kabaḷīkārāhāro tāva mukhe ṭhapitamatteyeva aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti, dantavicuṇṇitaṃ
analyzed: katham mukhe aṭṭha rūpāni samuṭṭhāpeti danta vicuṇṇitam
translated: How? Firstly, material food, as soon as it is placed in the mouth, produces eight kinds of materiality:

original: pana ajjhohariyamānaṃ ekekaṃ sitthaṃ aṭṭhaṭṭharūpāni samuṭṭhāpetiyeva. Evaṃ kabaḷīkārāhāro🔽ojaṭṭhamakarūpāni āharati. Phassāhāro pana sukhavedanīyo phasso uppajjamānoyeva sukhaṃ
analyzed: pana ajjhohariyamānam ekekam sittham aṭṭha ṭharūpāni evam kabaḷīkāra āhāro  āharati phassa āhāraḥ pana sukha vedanīyaḥ phassaḥ uppajjamānaḥ yeva sukham
translated: But when it is swallowed, each morsel produces eight kinds of materiality. Thus the material-food nutritive essence🔽supplies the materiality of the octad of the heart-basis. The contact-food nutritive essence supplies pleasure and pain.

original: vedanaṃ āharati, dukkhavedanīyo dukkhaṃ, adukkhamasukhavedanīyo adukkhamasukhanti
analyzed: vedanam āharati dukkha vedanīyaḥ dukkham adukkham asukha vedanīyaḥ adukkham asukhanti
translated: When a contact productive of pleasant feeling arises, it supplies pleasant feeling; when one productive of painful feeling arises, it supplies painful feeling; when one productive of neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling arises, it supplies neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: evaṃ sabbathāpi phassāhāro tisso vedanā āharati.🔽Manosañcetanāhāro kāmabhavūpagaṃ kammaṃ kāmabhavaṃ āharati, rūpārūpabhavūpagāni taṃ
analyzed: evam sabbathā api phassāhāraḥ tissaḥ vedanāḥ āharati  manaḥ sañcetanā āhāraḥ kāma bhava upagam kammam kāma bhavam āharati rūpa arūpa bhava upagāni tam
translated: Thus in all ways the contact-food nutritive essence supplies the three kinds of feeling.

original: taṃ bhavaṃ. Evaṃ sabbathāpi manosañcetanāhāro tayo bhave āharati. Viññāṇāhāro pana🔽ye ca paṭisandhikkhaṇe taṃsampayuttakā tayo khandhā, yāni ca tisantativasena tiṃsa
analyzed: tam bhavam evam sabbathā api manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro tayaḥ bhave āharati viññāṇa āhāro pana  ye ca paṭisandhi kkhaṇe tad sampayuttakā tayo khandhāḥ yāni ca ti santati vasena tiṃsa
translated: The mental volition-food nutritive essence supplies sensual becoming when the kamma that generates sensual becoming is volition; it supplies fine-material and immaterial becoming when the kamma that generates fine-material and immaterial becoming is volition. Thus in all ways the mental volition-food nutritive essence supplies the three kinds of becoming. The consciousness-food nutritive essence

original: rūpāni uppajjanti, sahajātādipaccayanayena tāni āharatīti vuccati. Evaṃ viññāṇāhāro
analyzed: rūpāni uppajjanti sahajāta ādi paccaya nayena tāni āharati iti vuccati evam viññāṇa āhāraḥ
translated: is said to supply the three aggregates associated with it and the thirty kinds of materiality that arise in the course of an existence by way of the condition consisting in co-nascence, etc. Thus the consciousness-food nutritive essence🔽supplies

original: paṭisandhināmarūpaṃ āharatīti. Ettha ca “manosañcetanā tayo bhave āharatī”ti sāsavakusalākusalacetanāva🔽vuttā. “Viññāṇaṃ paṭisandhināmarūpaṃ āharatī”ti paṭisandhiviññāṇameva vuttaṃ. Avisesena
analyzed: paṭisandhi nāma rūpam āharati iti ettha ca manaḥ sañcetanā bhave āharati iti  vuttā viññāṇam paṭisandhi nāma rūpam āharati iti paṭisandhi viññāṇam eva vuttam avisesena
translated: and consciousness brings about rebirth-linking and the mentality-materiality of the next existence. And here only the wholesome and the unwholesome volition that is subject to cankers is meant by the words, “Mental volition brings about the three kinds of becoming,”

original: pana taṃsampayuttataṃsamuṭṭhānadhammānaṃ āharaṇatopete “āhārā”ti veditabbā.
analyzed: pana tad sampayutta tad samuṭṭhāna dhammānam āharaṇa tā upete āhārā ti veditabbā
translated: and only rebirth-linking consciousness is meant by the words, “Consciousness brings about rebirth-linking and the mentality-materiality of the next existence.” But they should be understood as nutriment in the sense that they bring about the states associated with them and originated by them.

original: Etesu catūsu āhāresu kabaḷīkārāhāro upatthambhento āhārakiccaṃ sādheti, phasso phusantoyeva
analyzed: etesu catūsu āhāresu kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ upatthambhentaḥ āhāra kiccam sādheti phassaḥ phusantaḥ yā iva
translated: Of these four kinds of nutriment, physical nutriment accomplishes the function of nutriment by nourishing. Contact does so by touching.

original: manosañcetanā āyūhamānāva, viññāṇaṃ vijānantameva. Kathaṃ? Kabaḷīkārāhāro hi upatthambhentoyeva🔽kāyaṭṭhapanena sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā hoti. Kammajanitopi hi ayaṃ kāyo kabaḷīkārāhārena
analyzed: manaḥ sañcetanā āyūhamānā ava viññāṇam vijānantam eva katham kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ hi upatthambhentaḥ yā iva  kāya ṭṭhapanena sattānam ṭhitiyā hoti kamma janitaḥ api hi ayam kāyo kabaḷīkāra āhārena
translated: Mental volition does so by accumulating. Consciousness does so by cognizing.🔽How? Physical nutriment is for the maintenance of beings by consolidating the body. For this body generated by kamma is maintained for ten years, a hundred years, or even longer,🔽according to the amount of physical nutriment.

original: upatthaddho dasapi vassāni vassasatampi yāva āyuparimāṇā tiṭṭhati. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā
analyzed: upatthaddhaḥ dasa pi vassāni vassa satam pi yāva āyu parimāṇā tiṭṭhati yathā kim yathā
translated: How?

original: mātuyā janitopi dārako dhātiyā thaññādīni pāyetvā posiyamāno ciraṃ tiṭṭhati, yathā
analyzed: mātuyā janitaḥ api dārakaḥ dhātiyā thañña ādīni pāyetvā posiyamāno ciram tiṭṭhati yathā
translated: A child born of a mother is kept alive for a long time by being fed with milk, etc., from a wet-nurse,

original: ca upatthambhena upatthambhitaṃ gehaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: ca upatthambhena upatthambhitam geham
translated: just as a house that is falling down is kept from collapsing by a prop. And this is said:

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, gehe papatante aññena dārunā upatthambhitaṃ santaṃ eva taṃ gehaṃ na patati. Evameva kho, mahārāja, ayaṃ kāyo āhāraṭṭhitiko āhāraṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhatī”ti.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja gehe papatante aññena dārunā upatthambhitam santam eva tam geham na patati evam eva kho mahā rāja ayam kāyaḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikaḥ āhāram paṭicca tiṭṭhati iti
translated: “As, sire, a house that is falling down is kept from collapsing by a prop, even so, sire, this body, which is subject to the perishing of formations, is kept from collapsing by nutriment.”

original: Evaṃ kabaḷīkāro āhāro upatthambhento āhārakiccaṃ sādheti.
analyzed: evam kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ upatthambhento āhāra kiccam sādheti
translated: So the material food, by propping up, accomplishes its function as nutriment.

original: Evaṃ sādhentopi ca kabaḷīkāro āhāro dvinnaṃ rūpasantatīnaṃ paccayo hoti āhārasamuṭṭhānassa
analyzed: evam sādhentaḥ api ca kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ dvinnam rūpa santatīnam paccayaḥ hoti āhāra samuṭṭhānassa
translated: And although it accomplishes it in this way, material food is a condition for two kinds of continuity of materiality,

original: ca upādiṇṇakassa ca. Kammajānaṃ anupālako hutvā paccayo hoti, āhārasamuṭṭhānānaṃ
analyzed: ca upādiṇṇakassa ca kamma jānam anupālakaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ hoti āhāra samuṭṭhānānam
translated: that originated by nutriment and that due to kamma-formation. It is a condition for the former by acting as its support, and for the latter by acting as its instigation.

original: janako hutvāti. Phasso pana sukhādivatthubhūtaṃ ārammaṇaṃ phusantoyeva sukhādivedanāpavattanena
analyzed: janakaḥ hutvā iti phassaḥ pana sukha ādi vatthu bhūtam ārammaṇam phusantaḥ yā iva sukha ādi vedanā apavattanena
translated: Contact, by merely contacting the object that is the basis for pleasure, etc., accomplishes its function as nutriment by causing the occurrence of the feeling of pleasure, etc.,

original: sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā hoti. Manosañcetanā kusalākusalakammavasena āyūhamānāyeva bhavamūlanipphādanato
analyzed: sattānam ṭhitiyā hoti manaḥ sañcetanā kusala akusala kamma vasena āyūhamānāya iva bhava mūla nipphādanato
translated: It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.

original: sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā hoti. Viññāṇaṃ vijānantameva nāmarūpappavattanena sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā hotīti.🔽Evaṃ upatthambhanādivasena āhārakiccaṃ sādhayamānesu panetesu cattāri bhayāni daṭṭhabbāni.
analyzed: sattānam ṭhitiyā hoti viññāṇam vijānantam eva nāma rūpa ppavattanena sattānam ṭhitiyā hoti iti  evam upatthambhana ādi vasena āhāra kiccam sādhayamānesu pana etesu cattāri bhayāni daṭṭhabbāni
translated: It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.

original: Seyyathidaṃ – kabaḷīkārāhāre nikantiyeva bhayaṃ, phasse upagamanameva, manosañcetanāya🔽āyūhanameva, viññāṇe abhinipātoyeva bhayanti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Kabaḷīkārāhāre hi nikantiṃ
analyzed: seyyathidam kabaḷīkāra āhāre nikantiyā iva bhayam phasse upagamanam eva manaḥ sañcetanāya  āyūhanam eva viññāṇe abhinipāto yā iva bhayanti kim kāraṇā kabaḷīkāra āhāre hi nikantim
translated: It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.🔽It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation of profitable and unprofitable kamma.

original: katvā sītādīnaṃ purakkhatā sattā āhāratthāya muddāgaṇanādikammāni karontā anappakaṃ🔽dukkhaṃ nigacchanti. Ekacce ca imasmiṃ sāsane pabbajitvāpi vejjakammādikāya anesanāya
analyzed: katvā sītā ādīnam purakkhatā sattā āhāra atthāya muddā gaṇanā ādi kammāni karontā anappakam 🔽dukkham nigacchanti ekacce ca imasmim sāsane pabbajitvā api vejja kamma ādikāya an esanāya
translated: It is the condition for the presence of beings by producing the root of existence through the accumulation

original: āhāraṃ pariyesantā diṭṭheva dhamme gārayhā honti, samparāyepi, “tassa saṅghāṭipi
analyzed: āhāram pariyesantā diṭṭhe iva dhamme gārayhāḥ honti samparāye pi tassa
translated: while seeking food, they are blameworthy in the present life and in the next.

original: ādittā sampajjalitā”tiādinā lakkhaṇasaṃyutte vuttanayena samaṇapetā honti. Iminā
analyzed: ādittā sampajjalitā ati ādinā lakkhaṇa saṃyutte vutta nayena samaṇa petāḥ honti iminā
translated: and while seeking food they are blameworthy in the very eyes of others, and in the other world they are called “ascetic ghosts” in the way described in the Lakkhaṇa Sutta with the words “His outer robe and bowl Are burning, ablaze, a single flame” .

original: tāva kāraṇena kabaḷīkāre āhāre nikanti eva bhayanti veditabbā.
analyzed: tāva kāraṇena kabaḷīkāre āhāre nikanti eva veditabbā
translated: So it should be understood that attachment to the material-food is itself a danger for this reason.

original: Phassaṃ upagacchantāpi phassassādino paresaṃ rakkhitagopitesu dārādīsu bhaṇḍesu aparajjhanti,🔽te saha bhaṇḍena bhaṇḍasāmikā gahetvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ vā chinditvā saṅkārakūṭe chaḍḍenti,
analyzed: phassam upagacchantā api phassassa ādino paresam rakkhita gopitesu dāra ādīsu bhaṇḍesu aparajjhanti  te saha bhaṇḍena bhaṇḍa sāmikāḥ gahetvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam vā chinditvā saṅkārakūṭe chaḍḍenti
translated: And when they go to experience contact, they steal the goods of others, such as wives, that are guarded and protected, and they are addicted to the enjoyment of contact.🔽The owners of the goods seize them together with the goods and cut them to pieces limb by limb, or they hand them over to the king.

original: rañño vā niyyādenti. Tato te rājā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārāpeti. Kāyassa ca bhedā🔽duggati tesaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā hoti. Iti phassassādamūlakaṃ diṭṭhadhammikampi samparāyikampi
analyzed: raññaḥ vā niyyādenti tatas te rājā vividhā kamma kāraṇā kārāpeti kāyassa ca bhedā  duggati tesam pāṭikaṅkhā hoti iti phassa ssāda mūlakam diṭṭhadhammikam pi samparāyikam pi
translated: Then the king has various punishments inflicted on them. And when their bodies break up,🔽they are doomed to states of loss. So all the danger that arises from the enjoyment of contact, whether in the present life or in the life to come, comes from the enjoyment of the taste of contact.

original: bhayaṃ sabbamāgatameva hoti. Iminā kāraṇena phassāhāre upagamanameva bhayanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhayam sabbam āgatam eva hoti iminā kāraṇena phassāhāre upagamanam eva bhayanti veditabbaṃ
translated: It should be understood that the going to experience contact is itself a danger for this reason.

original: Kusalākusalakammāyūhane pana tammūlakaṃ tīsu bhavesu bhayaṃ sabbaṃ āgatameva hoti. Iminā kāraṇena manosañcetanāhāre āyūhanameva bhayanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: kusala akusala kamma āyūhane pana tad mūlakam tīsu bhavesu bhayam sabbam āgatam eva hoti iminā kāraṇena manaḥ sañcetanā āhāre āyūhanam eva bhayanti veditabbam
translated: That is why nutriment consisting of mental volition should be understood as danger in the accumulating.

original: Paṭisandhiviññāṇañca yasmiṃ yasmiṃ ṭhāne abhinipatati, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne paṭisandhināmarūpaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi viññāṇam ca yasmim yasmim ṭhāne abhinipatati tasmim tasmim ṭhāne paṭisandhi nāmarūpam
translated: And the rebirth-linking consciousness, wherever it occurs, does so taking rebirth-linking mentality-materiality

original: gahetvāva nibbattati. Tasmiñca nibbatte sabbabhayāni nibbattāniyeva honti tammūlakattāti
analyzed: gahetvā ava nibbattati tasmin ca nibbatte sabba bhayāni nibbattāniya iva honti tad mūlakattā ati
translated: and when that has occurred all the dangers have occurred that have their root in that.

original: iminā kāraṇena viññāṇāhāre abhinipātoyeva bhayanti veditabboti.
analyzed: iminā kāraṇena viññāṇa āhāre abhinipāto yā iva bhayanti veditabbo ti
translated: That is why nutriment consisting of consciousness should be understood as danger in occurrence.

original: Kiṃnidānātiādīsu nidānādīni sabbāneva kāraṇavevacanāni. Kāraṇañhi yasmā phalaṃ nideti,
