analyzed: pacchiyam pakkhipati evam eva diṭṭhi gatikaḥ yuttam pi ayuttam pi pucchati saḥ kasmā
translated: he puts the wrong one in. In the same way, the one who has views asks questions that are both correct and incorrect.

original: imaṃ pucchasī”ti na niggahetabbo, pucchitapucchitaṭṭhāne pana gahaṇameva nisedhetabbaṃ.🔽Teneva naṃ bhagavā “kasmā evaṃ pucchasī”ti avatvā gahitagāhameva tassa mocetuṃ no
analyzed: imam pucchasi iti na niggahetabbaḥ pucchita pucchita ṭṭhāne pana gahaṇam eva nisedhetabbam  tena iva nam bhagavā kasmai evam pucchasi iti avatvā gahita gāham eva tassa mocetum no
translated: and he puts it in the back. So too, the theorist asks questions whether they are proper or improper. He should not be stopped by saying, “Why do you ask that? ” but his taking up of the question as he asks it should be stopped.

original: kallo pañhotiādimāha.🔽Tattha no kalloti ayutto. Āhāretīti ahaṃ na vadāmīti ahaṃ koci satto vā puggalo vā
analyzed: kallo pañhaḥ tiādim āha  tattha no kallo ayuttaḥ āhāreti iti aham na vadāmi iti aham koci sattaḥ vā puggalo vā
translated: That is why, instead of saying, “Why do you ask that? ” the Blessed One said, “The question you ask is improper” , and so on, in order to make him give up the question.

original: āhāretīti na vadāmi. Āhāretīti cāhaṃ vadeyyanti yadi ahaṃ āhāretīti vadeyyaṃ. Tatrassa🔽kallo pañhoti tasmiṃ mayā evaṃ vutte ayaṃ pañho yutto bhaveyya. Kissa nu kho, bhante,🔽viññāṇāhāroti, bhante, ayaṃ viññāṇāhāro katamassa dhammassa paccayoti attho. Tatra
analyzed: āhāra iti iti na vadāmi āhāra iti iti ca aham vadeyyanti yadi aham āhāra iti iti vadeyyam  kallaḥ pañhaḥ ti tasmin mayā evam vutte ayam pañho yuttaḥ bhaveyya kissa nu kho bhante  viññāṇa āhāro ti bhante ayam viññāṇa āhāro katamassa dhammassa paccayaḥ ti attho tatra
translated: Herein, improper is unfitting. I do not say that anyone … takes it is what is said. I do not say that anyone, whether a being or a person, takes it. And if I were to say that anyone takes it, then🔽the question would be proper is what is said. If I were to say that anyone takes it, then this question would be fitting: “What is the nutriment consciousness for, venerable sir? ”

original: kallaṃ veyyākaraṇanti tasmiṃ evaṃ pucchite pañhe imaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ yuttaṃ “viññāṇāhāro
analyzed: kallam veyyākaraṇanti tasmin evam pucchite pañhe imam veyyākaraṇam yuttam viññāṇa āhāro
translated: The answer would be fitting too: “The nutriment consciousness is for the satisfaction of the element of consciousness” .

original: āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattiyā paccayo”ti. Ettha ca viññāṇāhāroti paṭisandhicittaṃ.🔽Āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattīti teneva viññāṇena sahuppannanāmarūpaṃ. Tasmiṃ bhūte
analyzed: āyatim punabbhava abhinibbattiyā paccayaḥ ti ettha ca viññāṇa āhāro ti paṭisandhi cittam  āyatim punabbhava abhinibbattī iti tena iva viññāṇena saha uppanna nāma rūpam tasmim bhūte
translated: and a condition for the arising of future renewed existence.”🔽Herein, the “consciousness” is the rebirth-linking consciousness.🔽“The arising of future renewed existence”: the mentality-materiality that arises together with that consciousness.

original: sati saḷāyatananti tasmiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattisaṅkhāte nāmarūpe jāte sati saḷāyatanaṃ hotīti attho.
analyzed: sati saḷāyatanam ti tasmin punabbhava abhinibbatti saṅkhāte nāma rūpe jāte sati saḷāyatanam hoti iti attho
translated: When that being is, there is the sixfold base. The meaning is that when that mentality-materiality that is called the arising of future renewed existence has arisen, there is the sixfold base.

original: Saḷāyatanapaccayā phassoti idhāpi bhagavā uttari pañhassa okāsaṃ dento desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti idha api bhagavā uttari pañhassa okāsam dentaḥ desanam niṭṭhāpesi
translated: With the sixfold base as condition, contact. Here too the Blessed One concluded the teaching by giving an opportunity for further questioning.

original: Diṭṭhigatiko hi navapucchaṃ uppādetuṃ na sakkoti, niddiṭṭhaṃ niddiṭṭhaṃyeva pana
analyzed: diṭṭhi gatikaḥ hi nava puccham uppādetum na sakkoti niddiṭṭham niddiṭṭham yeva pana
translated: For one who has views cannot raise a further question, but he only grasps what is pointed out to him.

original: gaṇhitvā pucchati, tenassa bhagavā okāsaṃ adāsi. Attho panassa sabbapadesu vuttanayeneva
analyzed: gaṇhitvā pucchati tena assa bhagavā okāsam adāsi attho pana assa sabba padesu vutta nayena iva
translated: So the Blessed One gave him the opportunity. But the meaning should be taken in the way already stated in all instances.

original: gahetabbo. “Ko nu kho, bhante, bhavatī”ti kasmā na pucchati? Diṭṭhigatikassa hi satto
analyzed: gahetabbaḥ kaḥ nu kho bhante bhavati iti kasmā na pucchati diṭṭhi gatikassa hi satto
translated: Why does he not ask, “Who becomes, venerable sir”? For one who has views has the opinion that a being is born,

original: nāma bhūto nibbattoyevāti laddhi, tasmā attano laddhiviruddhaṃ idanti na pucchati.
analyzed: nāma bhūtaḥ nibbattaḥ yā iva ati laddhi tasmai attanaḥ laddhi viruddham idam ti na pucchati
translated: so he does not ask about “becoming” because that is contrary to his opinion.

original: Apica idappaccayā idaṃ idappaccayā idanti bahūsu ṭhānesu kathitattā saññattiṃ upagato,
analyzed: apica ida paccayāḥ idam ida paccayāḥ idam ti bahūsu ṭhānesu kathita ttā saññattim upagataḥ
translated: Moreover, since it is stated in many places thus: “This is conditioned by that, this is conditioned by that,” it has come to be a mere convention.

original: tenāpi na pucchati. Satthāpi “imassa bahuṃ pucchantassāpi titti natthi, tucchapucchameva🔽pucchatī”ti ito paṭṭhāya desanaṃ ekābaddhaṃ katvā desesi. Channaṃ tvevāti yato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: tena api na pucchati satthā api imassa bahum pucchantassa api natthi tuccha puccham eva  pucchati iti itas paṭṭhāya desanam eka ābaddham katvā desesi channam tu eva ati yatas paṭṭhāya
translated: Therefore he does not ask. The Teacher thought: “He will never be satisfied with so much questioning. He is just asking questions at random.

original: desanāruḷhaṃ, tameva gahetvā desanaṃ vivaṭṭento evamāha. Imasmiṃ pana sutte viññāṇanāmarūpānaṃ🔽antare eko sandhi, vedanātaṇhānaṃ antare eko, bhavajātīnaṃ antare ekoti. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: desanā āruḷham tam eva gahetvā desanam vivaṭṭentaḥ evam āha imasmin pana sutte viññāṇa nāma rūpānam  antare ekaḥ vedanā taṇhānam antare ekaḥ bhava jātīnam antare ekaḥ iti dutiyam
translated: From this point on, the Teacher gave his discourse in a connected form. “Of these six,” he said, taking up the last of the six internal bases mentioned in the sutta.

original: 3. Samaṇabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā🔽13. Tatiye samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vāti saccāni paṭivijjhituṃ asamatthā bāhirakasamaṇabrāhmaṇā.🔽Jarāmaraṇaṃ nappajānantītiādīsu jarāmaraṇaṃ na jānanti dukkhasaccavasena, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ
analyzed: samaṇa brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽tatiye samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā ati saccāni paṭivijjhitum asamatthāḥ bāhiraka samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ 🔽jarā maraṇam na ppajānanti iti ādīsu jarā maraṇam na jānanti dukkha sacca vasena jarā maraṇa samudayam
translated: In this sutta there is one junction between consciousness and mentality-materiality, one between feeling and craving, and one between becoming and birth.

original: na jānanti saha taṇhāya jāti jarāmaraṇassa samudayoti samudayasaccavasena, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ🔽na jānanti nirodhasaccavasena, paṭipadaṃ na jānanti maggasaccavasena. Jātiṃ na jānanti
analyzed: na jānanti saha taṇhāya jāti jarā maraṇassa samudayo ti samudaya sacca vasena jarā maraṇa nirodham  na jānanti nirodha sacca vasena paṭipadam na jānanti magga sacca vasena jātim na jānanti
translated: They do not know the origin of aging-and-death together with craving as the truth of origin.🔽They do not know the cessation of aging-and-death as the truth of cessation. They do not know the way as the truth of the path. They do not know birth as the truth of suffering.

original: dukkhasaccavasena, jātisamudayaṃ na jānanti saha taṇhāya bhavo jātisamudayoti samudayasaccavasena.
analyzed: dukkha sacca vasena jāti samudayam na jānanti saha taṇhāya bhavaḥ jāti samudayaḥ ti samudaya sacca vasena
translated: They do not know the origin of birth together with craving as the truth of origin.

original: Evaṃ saha taṇhāya samudayaṃ yojetvā sabbapadesu catusaccavasena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: evam saha taṇhāya samudayam yojetvā sabba padesu catu sacca vasena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Having thus combined the origin with craving, the meaning should be understood in all passages according to the four truths.

original: Sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vāti ettha ariyamaggo sāmaññañceva brahmaññañca. Ubhayatthāpi🔽pana attho nāma ariyaphalaṃ veditabbaṃ. Iti bhagavā imasmiṃ sutte ekādasasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: sāmañña ttham vā brahmañña ttham vā ati ettha ariya maggo sāmaññam ca iva brahmaññam ca ubhayattha api  pana atthaḥ nāma ariya phalam veditabbam iti bhagavā imasmim sutte ekādasasu ṭhānesu
translated: The meaning of the common and the divine: here the noble path is both the common and the divine. But in both cases

original: cattāri saccāni kathesīti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: cattāri saccāni kathesi iti tatiyam
translated: the meaning should be understood as the noble fruit. Thus the Blessed One spoke about the four truths in eleven places in this sutta. The third.

original: 4. Dutiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya samaṇa brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary to the Second Discourse on the Ascetic and the Brahmin🔽In the fourth, it is said by way of the elaboration “What are these things?”

original: 14. Catutthe ime dhamme katame dhammeti ettakaṃ papañcaṃ katvā kathitaṃ, desanaṃ
analyzed: catutthe ime dhamme katame dhammā iti ettakam papañcam katvā kathitam desanam
translated: . The Teaching

original: paṭivijjhituṃ samatthānaṃ puggalānaṃ ajjhāsayena ime dhamme nappajānantītiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paṭivijjhitum samatthānam puggalānam ajjhāsayena ime dhamme na pajānanti itiādi vuttaṃ
translated: The meaning is that they do not understand these ideas in accordance with the inclination of those who are able to penetrate to the truth.

original: Sesaṃ purimasadisameva. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: sesam purima sadisam eva catuttham
translated: The rest is as above. The fourth .

original: 5. Kaccānagottasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kaccānagotta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The fifth .

original: 15. Pañcame sammādiṭṭhi sammādiṭṭhīti yaṃ paṇḍitā devamanussā tesu tesu ṭhānesu sammādassanaṃ
analyzed: pañcame sammādiṭṭhi sammādiṭṭhi iti yam paṇḍitāḥ deva manussā tesu tesu ṭhānesu sammādassanaṃ
translated: Right view is what the wise, the noble disciples, call right seeing in such and such instances.

original: vadanti, sabbampi taṃ dvīhi padehi saṅkhipitvā pucchati. Dvayanissitoti dve koṭṭhāse
analyzed: vadanti sabbam pi tam dvīhi padehi saṅkhipitvā pucchati dvaya nissito ti dve koṭṭhāse
translated: He asks about all that by abbreviating it to two terms. “Based on duality”: based on two sections.

original: nissito. Yebhuyyenāti iminā ṭhapetvā ariyapuggale sesamahājanaṃ dasseti. Atthitanti
analyzed: nissitaḥ yebhuyyena āti iminā ṭhapetvā ariya puggale sesa mahājanam dasseti atthita nti
translated: “For the most part”: by this he shows the great multitude, leaving out the noble persons. “Existence”:

original: sassataṃ. Natthitanti ucchedaṃ. Lokasamudayanti loko nāma saṅkhāraloko, tassa nibbatti.🔽Sammappaññāya passatoti sammāpaññā nāma savipassanā maggapaññā, tāya passantassāti
analyzed: sassatam natthitanti ucchedam loka samudayanti lokaḥ nāma saṅkhāra loko tassa nibbatti  sammappaññāya passatoti sammāpaññā nāma sa vipassanā magga paññā tāya passantassa ati
translated: eternalism. “Non-existence”: annihilationism. “The origin of the world”: the world is the formed world; its generation.

original: attho. Yā loke natthitāti saṅkhāraloke nibbattesu dhammesu paññāyantesveva yā natthīti
analyzed: atthaḥ yā loke natthitā ti saṅkhāra loke nibbattesu dhammesu paññāyantesu eva yā natthi iti
translated: “One who sees rightly”: right understanding is path understanding with insight; the meaning is, one who sees with that. “What does not exist in the world”: among the things that are generated in the formed world, what is non-existent is

original: ucchedadiṭṭhi uppajjeyya, sā na hotīti attho. Lokanirodhanti saṅkhārānaṃ bhaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: uccheda diṭṭhi uppajjeyya sā na hoti iti attho loka nirodham ti saṅkhārānam bhaṅgam
translated: As to cessation of the world: as to the dissolution of formations.

original: Yā loke atthitāti saṅkhāraloke bhijjamānesu dhammesu paññāyantesveva yā atthīti sassatadiṭṭhi
analyzed: yā loke atthitā ti saṅkhāra loke bhijjamānesu dhammesu paññāyantesu eva yā atthi iti
translated: As to what exists in the world: when states are breaking up and becoming evident in the formed world, the eternalist view would arise that “What exists in the world is permanent,”

original: uppajjeyya, sā na hotīti attho.
analyzed: uppajjeyya sā na hoti iti attho
translated: but it does not.

original: Apica lokasamudayanti anulomapaccayākāraṃ. Lokanirodhanti paṭilomapaccayākāraṃ. Lokanissaye🔽passantassāpi hi paccayānaṃ anucchedena paccayuppannassa anucchedaṃ passato yā natthīti🔽ucchedadiṭṭhi uppajjeyya, sā na hoti. Paccayanirodhaṃ passantassāpi paccayanirodhena
analyzed: apica loka samudayanti anuloma paccaya ākāram loka nirodhanti paṭiloma paccaya ākāram loka nissaye  passantassa api hi paccayānam an ucchedena paccaya uppannassa an ucchedam passataḥ yā natthi iti  uccheda diṭṭhi uppajjeyya sā na hoti paccaya nirodham passantassa api paccaya nirodhena
translated: Moreover, as to the origin of the world: as to the mode of conditionality in forward order. As to the cessation of the world: as to the mode of conditionality in reverse order.🔽For even when one sees the conditionality of the occurrence of formations, the annihilationist view would arise that “What exists in the world is annihilated,”🔽but it does not. And even when one sees the cessation of conditions, the eternalist view would arise that “What exists in the world is permanent,”

original: paccayuppannanirodhaṃ passato yā atthīti sassatadiṭṭhi uppajjeyya, sā na hotīti ayampettha attho.
analyzed: paccaya uppanna nirodham passataḥ yā atthi iti sassata diṭṭhi uppajjeyya sā na hoti iti ayam pa ittha attho
translated: but it does not. This is the meaning here.

original: Upayupādānābhinivesavinibandhoti upayehi ca upādānehi ca abhinivesehi ca vinibandho.
analyzed: upaya upādāna abhinivesa vinibandho ti upayehi ca upādānehi ca abhinivesehi ca vinibandhaḥ
translated: “By means of the means, the assuming, and the misinterpreting”: by means of the means, the assuming, and the misinterpreting.

original: Tattha upayāti dve upayā taṇhupayo ca diṭṭhupayo ca. Upādānādīsupi eseva nayo. Taṇhādiṭṭhiyo
analyzed: tattha upayā ti dve upayā taṇhupayo ca diṭṭhupayo ca upādāna ādīsu pi esa iva nayo taṇhā diṭṭhiyo
translated: for craving and views are called “approach”

original: hi yasmā ahaṃ mamantiādīhi ākārehi tebhūmakadhamme upenti upagacchanti, tasmā upayāti🔽vuccanti. Yasmā pana te dhamme upādiyanti ceva abhinivisanti ca, tasmā upādānāti
analyzed: hi yasmai aham ākārehi tebhūmaka dhamme upenti upagacchanti tasmai upayāti  vuccanti yasmai pana te dhamme upādiyanti ca iva abhinivisanti ca tasmai
translated: because they approach, come near, the states of the three planes by way of the modes of “I” and “mine.”🔽But they are called “clinging”🔽and “misapprehension” because they cling to and misapprehend those states. And by them this world is fettered. Thus it is said: “Fettered by misapprehension and clinging, by approach and clinging, he is fettered.”

original: ca abhinivesāti ca vuccanti. Tāhi cāyaṃ loko vinibandho. Tenāha “upayupādānābhinivesavinibandho”ti.
analyzed: ca abhinivesā ati ca vuccanti tāhi ca ayam lokaḥ vinibandho tena āha upayupādāna abhinivesa vinibandho ti
translated: “And that”: and that approach and clinging,🔽“this noble disciple”: this disciple of the noble ones.

original: Tañcāyanti tañca upayupādānaṃ ayaṃ ariyasāvako. Cetaso adhiṭṭhānanti cittassa patiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: tat ca ayanti tat ca ayam ariya sāvako cetasaḥ adhiṭṭhānam ti cittassa patiṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: “By the resolution of his mind”: by the states that serve as the basis for his mind.🔽“The underlying tendency to misapprehension”: the underlying tendency that is misapprehension. For unwholesome consciousness

original: Abhinivesānusayanti abhinivesabhūtañca anusayabhūtañca. Taṇhādiṭṭhīsu hi akusalacittaṃ
analyzed: abhinivesa anusayanti abhinivesa bhūtañca anusaya bhūtañca taṇhā diṭṭhīsu hi akusala cittam
translated: is based on craving and views,

original: patiṭṭhāti, tā ca tasmiṃ abhinivisanti ceva anusenti ca, tasmā tadubhayaṃ cetaso
analyzed: tā ca tasmin abhinivisanti ca iva anusenti ca tasmai tat ubhayam cetasaḥ
translated: and they misapprehend and underlie that consciousness. Therefore both are called “the underlying tendency to misapprehension.”

original: adhiṭṭhānaṃ abhinivesānusayanti ca āha. Na upetīti na upagacchati. Na upādiyatīti
analyzed: adhiṭṭhānam ca āha na upeti iti na upagacchati na upādiyati iti
translated: “Does not come” : does not go. “Does not take up” :

original: na gaṇhāti. Nādhiṭṭhātīti na adhiṭṭhāti, kinti? Attā meti. Dukkhamevāti pañcupādānakkhandhamattameva.🔽Na kaṅkhatīti “dukkhameva uppajjati, dukkhaṃ nirujjhati, na añño ettha satto nāma
analyzed: na gaṇhāti na adhiṭṭhāti iti na adhiṭṭhāti kinti attā mā iti dukkham eva ati pañca upādānakkhandha mattam eva  na kaṅkhati iti dukkham eva uppajjati dukkham nirujjhati na aññaḥ ettha satto nāma
translated: does not grasp. “Does not adhere” : does not adhere to the view “This is my self.” “Only suffering” : the mere five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: atthī”ti kaṅkhaṃ na karoti. Na vicikicchatīti na vicikicchaṃ uppādeti.
analyzed: atthi iti kaṅkham na karoti na vicikicchati iti na vicikiccham uppādeti
translated: “Does not doubt” : he does not doubt that only suffering arises and only suffering ceases, that there is no being here apart from the aggregates. “Does not waver” : he does not arouse wavering.

original: Aparappaccayāti na parappaccayena, aññassa apattiyāyetvā attapaccakkhañāṇamevassa🔽ettha hotīti. Ettāvatā kho, kaccāna, sammādiṭṭhi hotīti evaṃ sattasaññāya pahīnattā🔽ettakena sammādassanaṃ nāma hotīti missakasammādiṭṭhiṃ āha. Ayameko antoti esa eko
analyzed: apara paccayā ti na para paccayena aññassa a pattiyā āyetvā atta paccakkha ñāṇa mevassa  ettha hoti iti ettāvatā kho kaccāna sammādiṭṭhi hoti iti evam satta saññāya pahīna ttā  ettakena sammādassanam nāma hoti iti missaka sammādiṭṭhim āha ayam ekaḥ anto ti esaḥ ekaḥ
translated: “Not dependent on another” : not dependent on another’s attainment, but his own knowledge is independent of the attainment of another.

original: nikūṭanto lāmakanto paṭhamakaṃ sassataṃ. Ayaṃ dutiyoti esa dutiyo sabbaṃ natthīti
analyzed: paṭhamakam sassatam ayam dutiyaḥ ti esa dutiyaḥ sabbam na atthi iti
translated: “To this extent there is right view” : to this extent there is right seeing, he says, referring to right view mixed with speculation, since the perception of a being has been abandoned. This is one extreme : this is the first extreme, the first corner, the first limit, the first end, eternalism. This is the second : this is the second extreme, the second corner, the second limit, the second end, annihilationism.

original: uppajjanakadiṭṭhisaṅkhāto nikūṭanto lāmakanto dutiyako ucchedoti attho. Sesamettha
analyzed: uppajjanaka diṭṭhi saṅkhātaḥ nikūṭa antaḥ lāmaka antaḥ dutiyakaḥ ucchedaḥ ti attho sesam ettha
translated: The end of the view called “arising” is the end of the view called “vanishing.” The meaning is: the second annihilation. The rest here is clear.

original: uttānamevāti. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Dhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uttānam eva ati pañcamam  dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The fifth.

original: 16. Chaṭṭhe nibbidāyāti nibbindanatthāya. Virāgāyāti virajjanatthāya. Nirodhāyāti🔽nirujjhanatthāya. Paṭipanno hotīti ettha sīlato paṭṭhāya yāva arahattamaggā paṭipannoti

original: Āraddhacittāti aṭṭhavattapūraṇena tuṭṭhacittā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato panesa
analyzed: āraddha cittā ati aṭṭhavatta pūraṇena tuṭṭha cittā ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana īsa
translated: ‘With his mind inclined’ : with his mind satisfied by fulfilling the eight duties. This is in brief. But in detail it is given in the Khandhaka on the Probationer for Former Sectarians .

original: titthiyaparivāso samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāya pabbajjakkhandhakavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: titthiya parivāso samantapāsādikāya vinaya aṭṭhakathāya pabbajja khandhaka vaṇṇanāyaṃ
translated: The probation for schism-makers is finished.🔽In the commentary on the chapter on going forth in the very helpful Vinaya commentary.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo.🔽Apica mayāti ayamettha pāṭho, aññattha pana “apica metthā”ti. Puggalavemattatā viditāti
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ  apica mayā iti ayam ettha pāṭhaḥ aññattha pana apica mā itthā ati puggala vematta tā viditā ati
translated: The probationer’s life is to be understood in the way stated in the commentary on the chapter on going forth in the Vinaya commentary called Samantapāsādikā.🔽Moreover, “I know the difference in individuals” means

original: puggalanānattaṃ viditaṃ. “Ayaṃ puggalo parivāsāraho, ayaṃ na parivāsāraho”ti idaṃ
analyzed: puggala nānattam viditam ayam puggalo parivāsa arahaḥ ayam na parivāsa arahaḥ iti idam
translated: I know the diversity of individuals. I make it clear that “This individual is worthy of probation, this is not worthy of probation.”

original: mayhaṃ pākaṭanti dasseti. Tato kassapo cintesi – “aho acchariyaṃ buddhasāsanaṃ, yattha🔽evaṃ ghaṃsitvā koṭṭetvā yuttameva gaṇhanti, ayuttaṃ chaḍḍentī”ti. Tato suṭṭhutaraṃ
analyzed: mayham pākaṭanti dasseti tatas kassapaḥ cintesi aho acchariyam buddha sāsanam yattha  evam ghaṃsitvā koṭṭetvā yuttam eva gaṇhanti ayuttam chaḍḍenti iti tato suṭṭhutaram
translated: Then Kassapa thought, “How wonderful is the Buddha’s Dispensation,

original: pabbajjāya sañjātussāho sace, bhantetiādimāha. Atha bhagavā tassa tibbacchandataṃ
analyzed: pabbajjāya sañjātussāhaḥ sace bhante tiādim āha atha bhagavā tassa tibbacchandatam

original: viditvā “na kassapo parivāsaṃ arahatī”ti aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi – “gaccha, bhikkhu,
analyzed: viditvā na kassapaḥ parivāsam arahati iti aññataram bhikkhum āmantesi gaccha bhikkhu
translated: said to a certain monk, “Go, monk, and give the going forth to Kassapa.”

original: kassapaṃ nahāpetvā pabbājetvā ānehī”ti. So tathā katvā taṃ pabbājetvā bhagavato santikaṃ🔽agamāsi. Bhagavā gaṇe nisīditvā upasampādesi. Tena vuttaṃ alattha kho acelo kassapo🔽bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadanti. Acirūpasampannotiādi sesaṃ brāhmaṇasaṃyutte
analyzed: kassapam nahāpetvā pabbājetvā ānehi iti saḥ tathā katvā tam pabbājetvā bhagavato santikam  agamāsi bhagavā gaṇe nisīditvā upasampādesi tena vuttam alattha kho acelaḥ kassapo  bhagavato santike pabbajjam alattha upasampadanti acira upasampannaḥ iti ādi sesam brāhmaṇasaṃyutte
translated: and after bathing Kassapa, let him go forth and bring him here.” He did so, and after going forth he came into the presence of the Fortunate One. The Fortunate One, after sitting down, gave him the Acceptance. Therefore it is said: “Then the Independent Seer Kassapa obtained the going-forth in the presence of the Fortunate One, he obtained Acceptance.” Not long after his Acceptance: etc. as in the Discourse in the Chapter on the Brahmins

original: vuttamevāti. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam eva ati sattamam
translated: and after bathing him, to bring him back after giving him the going-forth.” He did so, gave him the going-forth, and came to the Blessed One. The Blessed One, sitting down in the midst of the Community of monks, gave him the Acceptance. Therefore it was said: “The naked ascetic Kassapa obtained the going-forth in the Blessed One’s presence, he obtained the Acceptance.” “Not long after his Acceptance”: the rest is as in the Brahmana Sela Sutta. The seventh .

original: 8. Timbarukasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: timbaruka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Timbaruka Sutta Commentary

original: 18. Aṭṭhame sā vedanātiādi “sayaṃkataṃ sukhadukkha”nti laddhiyā nisedhanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Etthāpi satoti bhummattheyeva sāmivacanaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ atthadīpanā – “sā vedanā, so
analyzed: aṭṭhame sā vedanā ti ādi sayaṃkatam sukha dukkham ti laddhiyāḥ nisedhana attham vuttam  ettha api satī iti sāmi vacanam tatra ayam attha dīpanā sā vedanā
translated: . “That feeling is his” and so on was said in order to refute the assumption that pleasure and pain are self-made.

original: vediyatī”ti kho, timbaruka, ādimhiyeva evaṃ sati “sayaṃkataṃ sukhadukkha”nti ayaṃ
analyzed: vediyati iti kho timbarukaḥ evam sati sayaṃkatam sukha dukkham ti ayam
translated: Here too the word “his” is used in the sense of the state . The explanation of the meaning here is this: “That feeling, he feels” — if this is so, Timbaruka, then this assumption is made: “Pleasure and pain are self-made.”

original: laddhi hoti. Evañhi sati vedanāya eva vedanā katā hoti. Evañca vadanto imissā vedanāya
analyzed: laddhi hoti evañhi sati vedanāya eva vedanā katā hoti evañca vadantaḥ imissā vedanāya
translated: For if this is so, then feeling is made by feeling. And one who speaks thus makes this statement:

original: pubbepi atthitaṃ anujānāti, sassataṃ dīpeti sassataṃ gaṇhāti. Kasmā? Tassa hi taṃ🔽dassanaṃ etaṃ pareti, etaṃ sassataṃ upagacchatīti attho. Purimañhi atthaṃ sandhāyevetaṃ
analyzed: pubbe api atthitam anujānāti sassatam dīpeti sassatam gaṇhāti kasmā tassa hi tam  dassanam etam pareti etam sassatam upagacchati iti attho purimam hi attham sandhāya iva etam
translated: He allows that it existed in the past and proclaims the eternal. Why? Because

original: bhagavatā vuttaṃ bhavissati, tasmā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ taṃ yojetvāvassa attho dīpito. Evampāhaṃ🔽na vadāmīti ahaṃ “sā vedanā, so vediyatī”ti evampi na vadāmi. “Sayaṃkataṃ sukhadukkha”nti
analyzed: bhagavatā vuttam bhavissati tasmai aṭṭhakathāyam tam attho dīpito evam pa aham  na vadāmi iti aham sā vedanā saḥ vediyati iti evam pi na vadāmi sayaṃkatam sukha dukkham
translated: that view of his is “this,” i.e. it is eternal. The Blessed One said this with reference to the first meaning, and so the commentator has interpreted it in that way.🔽I do not say thus: I do not say that “that is the feeling, he feels.”

original: evampi na vadāmīti attho.🔽Aññā vedanātiādi “paraṃkataṃ sukhadukkha”nti laddhiyā paṭisedhanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Idhāpi🔽ayaṃ atthayojanā –“aññā vedanā añño vediyatī”ti kho, timbaruka, ādimhiyeva evaṃ sati
analyzed: evam pi na vadāmi iti attho  aññā vedanā ti ādi paraṃkatam sukha dukkham ti laddhiyā paṭisedhana attham vuttam idha api  ayam attha yojanā aññā vedanā aññaḥ vediyati iti kho timbarukaḥ evam sati
translated: I do not say thus: I do not say that “pleasure and pain are self-made.”🔽Another feels: this is said in order to refute the doctrine that “pleasure and pain are made by another.” Here is the interpretation of the meaning.🔽If it were so, Timbaruka, that “another feels,”

original: pacchā yā purimapakkhe kārakavedanā, sā ucchinnā. Tāya pana kataṃ añño vediyatīti
analyzed: pacchā yā purima pakkhe kāraka vedanā sā ucchinnā tāya pana katam aññaḥ vediyati iti
translated: then in the first place the feeling would be one thing and the feeler another.🔽But since that is not so, the feeling that was the doer in the past has ceased.

original: evaṃ uppannāya ucchedadiṭṭhiyā saddhiṃ sampayuttāya vedanāya abhitunnassa sato “paraṃkataṃ
analyzed: evam uppannāya uccheda diṭṭhiyā saddhim sampayuttāya vedanāya abhitunnassa sataḥ paraṃkatam
translated: When the view of annihilation has arisen in this way, and the feeling associated with it has overwhelmed him, he thinks: “It is done by another,🔽

original: sukhadukkha”nti ayaṃ laddhi hoti. Evañca vadanto kārako ucchinno, aññena paṭisandhi
analyzed: sukha dukkha nti ayam hoti evam ca vadantaḥ kārako ucchinnaḥ aññena paṭisandhi
translated: When feeling associated with the view of annihilation arises in one who is obsessed by it, he comes to the conclusion that “Pleasure and pain are created by another.”🔽By saying this he proclaims annihilation of the doer and the taking up of rebirth by another. He grasps at annihilation.

original: gahitāti ucchedaṃ dīpeti, ucchedaṃ gaṇhāti. Kasmā? Tassa hi taṃ dassanaṃ etaṃ pareti,
analyzed: gahitā ati ucchedam dīpeti ucchedam gaṇhāti kasmā tassa hi tam dassanam etam pareti
translated: Why? Because his view is that “This is the end of me.”

original: etaṃ ucchedaṃ upagacchatīti attho. Idhāpi hi imāni padāni aṭṭhakathāyaṃ āharitvā
analyzed: etam ucchedam upagacchati iti attho idha api hi imāni padāni aṭṭhakathāyam āharitvā
translated: Here too the passages from the commentary have been incorporated in the sutta itself.

original: yojitāneva. Imasmiṃ sutte vedanāsukhadukkhaṃ kathitaṃ. Tañca kho vipākasukhadukkhameva
analyzed: imasmim sutte vedanā sukha dukkham kathitam tat ca kho vipāka sukha dukkham eva

analyzed: vaṭṭati iti vuttam aṭṭhamam
translated: The eighth sutta is finished.

original: Bhagavaṃmūlakāti bhagavā mūlaṃ etesanti bhagavaṃmūlakā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ime, bhante,
analyzed: bhagavaṃmūlakā ati bhagavā mūlam etesan ti bhagavaṃmūlakā idam vuttam hoti ime bhante
translated: “Rooted in the Blessed One”: they have the Blessed One as their root. This is what is meant.

original: amhākaṃ dhammā pubbe kassapasammāsambuddhena uppāditā, tasmiṃ parinibbute ekaṃ buddhantaraṃ🔽añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ime dhamme uppādetuṃ samattho nāma nāhosi, bhagavatā pana
analyzed: amhākam dhammā pubbe kassapa sammāsambuddhena uppāditā tasmin parinibbute ekam buddha antaram  aññaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā ime dhamme uppādetum samatthaḥ nāma na ahosi bhagavatā pana
translated: “Formerly, venerable sir, these ideas were produced by the Perfectly Enlightened One Kassapa. When he had finally attained nibbana,🔽for one whole aeon no ascetic or brahmin anywhere was able to produce them. But now, venerable sir,

original: no ime dhammā uppāditā. Bhagavantañhi nissāya mayaṃ ime dhamme ājānāma paṭivijjhāmāti
analyzed: no ime dhammāḥ uppāditāḥ bhagavantam hi nissāya mayam ime dhamme ājānāma paṭivijjhāma ati
translated: these ideas have been produced by the Blessed One. For it is by depending on the Blessed One that we understand and penetrate these ideas.”🔽So they are rooted in the Blessed One.

original: evaṃ bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammāti. Bhagavaṃnettikāti bhagavā hi dhammānaṃ
analyzed: evam bhagavaṃmūlakāḥ naḥ bhante dhammā ati bhagavaṃnettikā ati bhagavā hi dhammānam
translated: “Guided by the Blessed One”: the Blessed One is the guide, the leader, the expounder of the goal, the giver of the Deathless, the lord of the Dhamma, the Tathāgata.

original: netā vinetā anunetā, yathāsabhāvato pāṭiyekkaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ nāmaṃ gahetvā dassetāti🔽dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā nāma honti. Bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇāti catubhūmakadhammā sabbaññutaññāṇassa
analyzed: netā vinetā anunetā yathā sabhāvataḥ pāṭiyekkam pāṭiyekkam nāmam gahetvā dasseta ati  dhammā bhagavaṃnettikāḥ nāma honti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇāḥ ti catu bhūmaka dhammāḥ sabbaññuta ññāṇassa
translated: Having taken up each idea according to its individual characteristics, he shows it.🔽So the ideas are guided by the Blessed One.🔽“Take refuge in the Blessed One”: the ideas of the four planes of existence come to be called “taking refuge in the Blessed One”

original: āpāthaṃ āgacchamānā bhagavati paṭisaranti nāmāti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Paṭisarantīti
analyzed: āpātham āgacchamānāḥ bhagavati paṭisaranti nāma ati bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā paṭisaranti iti
translated: when they come into the range of the knowledge of omniscience.

original: samosaranti. Apica mahābodhimaṇḍe nisinnassa bhagavato paṭivedhavasena phasso āgacchati
analyzed: samosaranti apica mahā bodhimaṇḍe nisinnassa bhagavato paṭivedha vasena phassaḥ āgacchati
translated: Again, when the Blessed One was sitting in the Great Bodhi-grove, the contact that came to him by way of penetration was as follows:

original: “ahaṃ bhagavā kinnāmo”ti? Tvaṃ phusanaṭṭhena phasso nāma. Vedanā, saññā, saṅkhārā,
analyzed: aham bhagavā kinnāma uti tvam phusana ṭṭhena phassaḥ nāma vedanā saññā saṅkhārā
translated: “What is my name, Lord?” “You are contact in the sense of touching.”

original: viññāṇaṃ āgacchati “ahaṃ bhagavā kinnāma”nti, tvaṃ vijānanaṭṭhena viññāṇaṃ nāmāti
analyzed: viññāṇam āgacchati aham bhagavā kinnāman ti tvam vijānana ṭṭhena viññāṇam nāma ati
translated: “What is my name, Lord?” “You are consciousness in the sense of cognizing.”

original: evaṃ catubhūmakadhammānaṃ yathāsabhāvato pāṭiyekkaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ nāmaṃ gaṇhanto bhagavā
analyzed: evam catu bhūmaka dhammānam yathā sabhāvataḥ pāṭiyekkam pāṭiyekkam nāmam gaṇhantaḥ bhagavā
translated: Thus the Blessed One, taking the name of each of the states of the four planes of existence separately according to their individual essences,🔽“The Blessed One is the refuge” means that he is the refuge for the Dhamma.

original: dhamme paṭisaratīti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātūti bhagavatova etassa
analyzed: dhamme paṭisarati iti bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā bhagavantam yā iva paṭibhātu uti bhagavataḥ uva etassa
translated: “May it occur to the Blessed One” means that the meaning of this statement should occur to the Blessed One himself.

original: bhāsitassa attho upaṭṭhātu, tumheyeva no kathetvā dethāti attho.
analyzed: bhāsitassa attho upaṭṭhātu no kathetvā detha ati attho
translated: “Give it to us” means “Teach it to us after explaining it to us.”

original: Sā ceva avijjāti ettha kiñcāpi sā avijjā ca taṇhā ca kammaṃ javāpetvā paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: sā ca iva avijjā ati ettha kiñca api sā avijjā ca taṇhā ca kammam paṭisandhim
translated: “That is ignorance” : although that ignorance and craving, having caused kamma to run,🔽have ceased after dragging along rebirth-linking,

original: ākaḍḍhitvā niruddhā, yathā pana ajjāpi yaṃ hiyyo bhesajjaṃ pītaṃ, tadeva bhojanaṃ
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitvā niruddhā yathā pana ajjā api yam hiyyas bhesajjam pītam tat eva bhojanam
translated: just as the medicine drunk yesterday and the food eaten yesterday

original: bhuñjāti sarikkhakattena tadevāti vuccati, evamidhāpi sā ceva avijjā sā ca taṇhāti
analyzed: bhuñjāti sa rikkhaka ttena tat eva ati vuccati evam idha api sā ca iva avijjā sā ca taṇhā ati
translated: “He eats” is said figuratively, and so too here “ignorance” and “craving” are said figuratively.🔽The life of purity: the life of purity consisting in the path.

original: idampi sarikkhakattena vuttaṃ. Brahmacariyanti maggabrahmacariyaṃ. Dukkhakkhayāyāti
analyzed: idam pi sa rikkhaka ttena vuttam brahmacariyanti magga brahmacariyam dukkha kkhayāya ati
translated: For the destruction of suffering: for the destruction of the suffering of the round.

original: vaṭṭadukkhassa khayatthāya. Kāyūpago hotīti aññaṃ paṭisandhikāyaṃ upagantā hoti.
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhassa khaya tthāya kāya upagaḥ hoti iti aññam paṭisandhi kāyam upagantā hoti
translated: He becomes one who has entered the body: he becomes one who has entered another rebirth-linking.🔽This life of purity: this life of purity consisting in the path.

original: Yadidaṃ brahmacariyavāsoti yo ayaṃ maggabrahmacariyavāso, ayaṃ bālato paṇḍitassa
analyzed: yat idam brahmacariya vāsaḥ ti yaḥ ayam magga brahmacariya vāsaḥ ayam bālataḥ paṇḍitassa
translated: This shows the difference between the fool and the wise man.

original: visesoti dasseti. Iti imasmiṃ sutte sabbopi sapaṭisandhiko puthujjano “bālo”ti, appaṭisandhiko🔽khīṇāsavo “paṇḍito”ti vutto. Sotāpannasakadāgāmianāgāmino pana “paṇḍitā”ti vā “bālā”ti
analyzed: visesaḥ ti dasseti iti imasmin sutte sabbaḥ api sa paṭisandhikaḥ puthujjanaḥ bālaḥ ti appaṭisandhikaḥ  khīṇa āsavo paṇḍito ti vutto sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmino pana paṇḍitā ati vā bālā ati
translated: So in this sutta all ordinary men with rebirth-linking are called “fools,” and the one free from cankers is called “wise.”

original: vā na vattabbā, bhajamānā pana paṇḍitapakkhaṃ bhajanti. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: vā na vattabbā bhajamānā pana paṇḍita pakkham bhajanti navamam
translated: But stream-enterers, once-returners, and non-returners cannot be called either “fools” or “wise,” but they belong to the side of the wise as they are progressing.🔽The ninth chapter.

original: 10. Paccayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paccaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The tenth chapter

original: 20. Dasame paṭiccasamuppādañca vo bhikkhave, desessāmi paṭiccasamuppanne ca dhammeti
analyzed: dasame paṭiccasamuppādam ca vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi paṭicca samuppanne ca dhamme ti
translated: In the tenth chapter, in the first sutta, “dependent origination” is the dependent origination of the round, and “phenomena originated dependently” are the states of the round.

original: satthā imasmiṃ sutte paccaye ca paccayanibbatte ca sabhāvadhamme desessāmīti ubhayaṃ
analyzed: satthā imasmin sutte paccaye ca paccaya nibbatte ca sabhāva dhamme desessāmi iti ubhayam
translated: The Master, in this Thread, is teaching conditions and the things that are produced by conditions, both of which are in the nature of things.

original: ārabhi. Uppādā vā tathāgatānanti tathāgatānaṃ uppādepi, buddhesu uppannesu anuppannesupi
analyzed: uppādāḥ vā tathāgatānam ti tathāgatānam uppāde pi buddhesu uppannesu anuppannesu pi
translated: He begins with both of them thus: “With the arising of Tathagatas” : with the arising of Tathagatas, with Buddhas arisen, and with Buddhas not arisen,

original: jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ, jātiyeva jarāmaraṇassa paccayo. Ṭhitāva sā dhātūti ṭhitova
analyzed: jāti paccayā jarā maraṇam jātiyā iva jarā maraṇassa paccayaḥ ṭhitā ava sā dhātu uti ṭhitā uva
translated: Ageing-and-death has birth as its condition, and birth is the condition for ageing-and-death. That element is still there :

original: so paccayasabhāvo, na kadāci jāti jarāmaraṇassa paccayo na hoti. Dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatāti
analyzed: so paccaya sabhāvaḥ na kadāci jāti jarā maraṇassa paccayaḥ na hoti dhamma ṭṭhita tā dhamma niyāma tā ati
translated: that condition is still there, and never is birth not a condition for ageing-and-death. The stability of the Dhamma, the regularity of the Dhamma :

original: imehipi dvīhi paccayameva katheti. Paccayena hi paccayuppannā dhammā tiṭṭhanti, tasmā
analyzed: imehi pi dvīhi paccayam eva kathā iti paccayena hi paccaya uppannāḥ dhammāḥ tiṭṭhanti tasmā
translated: with these two terms he teaches only the condition. For it is by means of a condition that things that are produced by a condition stand,

original: paccayova “dhammaṭṭhitatā”ti vuccati. Paccayo dhamme niyameti, tasmā “dhammaniyāmatā”ti
analyzed: paccayaḥ uva dhamma ṭṭhita tā ati vuccati paccayaḥ dhamme niyameti tasmā dhamma niyāma tā ti
translated: and that is why the condition is called “ the stability of the Dhamma “. The condition determines the Dhamma, and that is why it is called “ the regularity of the Dhamma “. This is a case of conditionality :🔽these ageing-and-death, etc., have conditions, and they are the conditions here,

original: vuccati. Idappaccayatāti imesaṃ jarāmaraṇādīnaṃ paccayā idappaccayā, idappaccayāva
analyzed: vuccati idappaccaya tā ati imesam jarā maraṇa ādīnam paccayāḥ idappaccayāḥ idappaccayā ava
translated: and they are only the conditions here,

original: idappaccayatā. Tanti taṃ paccayaṃ. Abhisambujjhatīti ñāṇena abhisambujjhati. Abhisametīti
analyzed: idappaccaya tā tanti tam paccayam abhisambujjhati iti ñāṇena abhisambujjhati abhisameti iti
translated: This is the way of conditionality. Tanti: that condition. Abhisambujjhati: he penetrates by means of knowledge. Abhisametīti:

original: ñāṇena abhisamāgacchati. Ācikkhatīti katheti. Desetīti dasseti. Paññāpetīti jānāpeti.
analyzed: ñāṇena abhisamāgacchati ācikkhati iti katheti deseti iti dasseti paññāpeti iti jānāpeti
translated: he comes to the conclusion by means of knowledge. Ācikkhati: he explains. Deseti: he shows. Paññāpeti: he makes known.

original: Paṭṭhapetīti ñāṇamukhe ṭhapeti. Vivaratīti vivaritvā dasseti. Vibhajatīti vibhāgato
analyzed: paṭṭhapeti iti ñāṇa mukhe ṭhapeti vivarati iti vivaritvā dasseti vibhajati iti vibhāgato
translated: Paṭṭhapeti: he establishes in the door of knowledge. Vivaratīti: he shows by opening up. Vibhajatīti: he shows by analysis.

original: dasseti. Uttānīkarotīti pākaṭaṃ karoti. Passathāti cāhāti passatha iti ca vadati.
analyzed: dassa iti uttānīkaroti iti pākaṭam karoti passatha ati ca āha ati passatha iti ca vadati
translated: Uttānīkarotīti: he makes clear. Passathāti cāhāti: he says “See” and “Look.”

original: Kinti? Jātipaccayā, bhikkhave, jarāmaraṇantiādi.
analyzed: kinti jāti paccayā bhikkhave jarā maraṇa ntiādi
translated: Kinti? “With birth as condition, bhikkhus, there is aging and death” , and so on.

original: Iti kho, bhikkhaveti evaṃ kho, bhikkhave. Yā tatrāti yā tesu “jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇa”ntiādīsu.
analyzed: iti kho bhikkhave iti evam kho bhikkhave yā tatra ati yā tesu jāti paccayā jarā maraṇa nti ādīsu
translated: Iti kho, bhikkhave: thus, bhikkhus. Yā tatrāti: that which is there among the statements beginning with “With birth as condition, bhikkhus, there is aging and death” .

original: Tathatātiādīni paccayākārasseva vevacanāni. So tehi tehi paccayehi anūnādhikeheva
analyzed: tathatā ati ādīni paccaya ākārassa iva vevacanāni saḥ tehi tehi paccayehi anūna adhikehi iva
translated: Tathatā, etc., are synonyms for the mode of conditionality. Because of the occurrence of each state by means of the respective conditions, neither less nor more,

original: tassa tassa dhammassa sambhavato tathatāti, sāmaggiṃ upagatesu paccayesu muhuttampi
analyzed: tassa tassa dhammassa sambhavato tathatā ati sāmaggiṃ upagatesu paccayesu muhuttam pi
translated: it is tathatā . When the conditions come together, the state occurs even for a moment.

original: tato nibbattānaṃ dhammānaṃ asambhavābhāvato avitathatāti, aññadhammapaccayehi aññadhammānuppattito
analyzed: tatas nibbattānam dhammānam asambhava abhāvataḥ avitatha tā ati añña dhamma paccayehi añña dhamma anuppattito
translated: And because of the non-occurrence of one kind of dhamma with the conditions of another kind of dhamma,🔽it is not the same .

original: anaññathatāti, jarāmaraṇādīnaṃ paccayato vā paccayasamūhato vā idappaccayatāti vutto.
analyzed: anaññathatā ti jarā maraṇa ādīnam paccayataḥ vā paccaya samūhataḥ vā idappaccaya tā ati vutto
translated: Or it is called “this condition” because of the conditions such as aging-and-death, or because of the collection of conditions.

original: Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho – imesaṃ paccayā idappaccayā, idappaccayā eva idappaccayatā,
analyzed: tatra ayam vacana atthaḥ imesam paccayāḥ idappaccayāḥ idappaccayāḥ eva idappaccaya tā
translated: Here is the word-meaning: these are the conditions of this, thus they are this-conditioned ; this-conditioned only is this-condition ;

original: idappaccayānaṃ vā samūho idappaccayatā. Lakkhaṇaṃ panettha saddasatthato veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vā samūhaḥ idappaccaya tā lakkhaṇam pana ittha sadda satthataḥ veditabbam
translated: or the collection of this-conditions is this-condition . But the characteristic should be understood according to the etymological interpretation of the words.

original: Aniccanti hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccaṃ. Ettha ca aniccanti na jarāmaraṇaṃ aniccaṃ,
analyzed: aniccanti hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccam ettha ca aniccanti na jarā maraṇam aniccam
translated: Impermanent : impermanent in the sense of non-existence after having been . Herein, aging-and-death is not impermanent,

original: aniccasabhāvānaṃ pana khandhānaṃ jarāmaraṇattā aniccaṃ nāma jātaṃ. Saṅkhatādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Ettha ca saṅkhatanti paccayehi samāgantvā kataṃ. Paṭiccasamuppannanti
analyzed: anicca sabhāvānam pana khandhānam jarā maraṇa ttā aniccam nāma jātam  esa iva nayaḥ ettha ca paccayehi samāgantvā katam paṭiccasamuppannam ti
translated: but because of the aging-and-death of the aggregates that have the nature of impermanence, what is called “impermanence” has come into being. And so too with the formed, etc.,

original: paccaye nissāya uppannaṃ. Khayadhammanti khayasabhāvaṃ. Vayadhammanti vigacchanakasabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: paccaye nissāya uppannam khaya dhammanti khaya sabhāvam vaya dhammanti vigacchanaka sabhāvam
translated: the same method applies. And here the formed is that which is made by coming together through conditions. Dependent on conditions : arisen by support of conditions. Subject to destruction : having the nature of destruction. Subject to vanishing : having the nature of vanishing.

original: Virāgadhammanti virajjanakasabhāvaṃ. Nirodhadhammanti nirujjhanakasabhāvaṃ. Jātiyāpi
analyzed: virāga dhammanti virajjanaka sabhāvam nirodha dhammanti nirujjhanaka sabhāvam jātiyā api
translated: The state of dispassion: the state of the kind that causes dispassion. The state of cessation: the state of the kind that causes cessation. Impermanence should be understood in the way already stated under Ignorance .

original: vuttanayeneva aniccatā veditabbā. Janakapaccayānaṃ vā kiccānubhāvakkhaṇe diṭṭhattā
analyzed: vutta nayena iva anicca tā veditabbā janaka paccayānam vā kicca anubhāva kkhaṇe diṭṭha ttā
translated: Or alternatively, since the characteristic of impermanence is seen in the moment of the effective operation of the conditions that generate ,

original: ekena pariyāyenettha aniccātiādīni yujjantiyeva. Bhavādayo aniccādisabhāvāyeva.
analyzed: ekena pariyāyena itthā anicca ati ādīni bhava ādayaḥ anicca ādi sabhāvāya iva
translated: the words “impermanent,” etc., are appropriate here in one way or the other. Existence, etc., are of the nature of impermanence, etc.

original: Sammappaññāyāti savipassanāya maggapaññāya. Pubbantanti purimaṃ atītanti attho. Ahosiṃ
analyzed: sammappaññāya āti sa vipassanāya magga paññāya pubbantam ti purimam atītam ti atthaḥ ahosim
translated: By right understanding: by the understanding of the path, which is accompanied by insight. The past: the past time.

original: nu khotiādīsu “ahosiṃ nu kho nanu kho”ti sassatākārañca adhiccasamuppattiākārañca
analyzed: nu kho tiādīsu ahosim nu kho nanu kho ti sassata ākāram ca adhicca samuppatti ākāram ca
translated: “Was I in the past?” etc.: here, depending on the mode of eternalism and the mode of fortuitous origination,

original: nissāya atīte attano vijjamānatañca avijjamānatañca kaṅkhati. Kiṃ kāraṇanti na vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: nissāya atīte attanaḥ vijjamāna tañca a vijjamāna tañca kaṅkhati kim kāraṇam ti na vattabbam
translated: he is doubtful whether he existed or did not exist in the past. He should not be asked the reason,

original: ummattako viya bālaputhujjano yathā vā tathā vā pavattati. Kiṃ nu kho ahosinti jātiliṅgupapattiyo
analyzed: ummattakaḥ viya bāla puthujjanaḥ yathā vā tathā vā pavattati kim nu kho jāti liṅga upapattiyaḥ
translated: for he proceeds in one way or another like a madman, a foolish worldling. “What was I in the past?” etc.: depending on birth, sex, and mode of existence,

original: nissāya “khattiyo nu kho ahosiṃ, brāhmaṇavessasuddagahaṭṭhapabbajitadevamanussānaṃ
analyzed: nissāya khattiyaḥ nu kho ahosim brāhmaṇa vessa sudda gahaṭṭha pabbajita deva manussānam
translated: he is doubtful whether he was a noble, a brahmin, a merchant, a worker, a deity, or a human being.

original: aññataro”ti kaṅkhati. Kathaṃ nu khoti saṇṭhānākāraṃ nissāya “dīgho nu kho ahosiṃ🔽rassaodātakaṇhapamāṇikaappamāṇikādīnaṃ aññataro”ti kaṅkhati. Keci pana “issaranimmānādīni🔽nissāya ‘kena nu kho kāraṇena ahosi’nti hetuto kaṅkhatī”ti vadanti. Kiṃ hutvā kiṃ🔽ahosinti jātiādīni nissāya “khattiyo hutvā nu kho brāhmaṇo ahosiṃ…pe… devo hutvā
analyzed: aññataro ti kaṅkhati katham nu kha iti saṇṭhāna ākāram nissāya dīghaḥ nu khalu ahosiṃ  rassa odāta kaṇha pamāṇika appamāṇika ādīnam aññataro ti kaṅkhati keci pana issara nimmāna ādīni  nissāya kena nu kho kāraṇena ahosinti hetutaḥ kaṅkhati iti vadanti kim hutvā kim  ahosinti jāti ādīni nissāya khattiyaḥ hutvā nu kho brāhmaṇaḥ devaḥ hutvā
translated: He is in doubt as to whether he was this or that. How was I? He is in doubt as to his shape and appearance, wondering whether he was tall or short, dark or fair, and so on. Some, however, say that he is in doubt as to the reason, wondering by what action he became such and such, and they say that he is in doubt as to the cause, wondering whether he was created by God, etc. Having been what, what did I become? He is in doubt as to his past births, wondering whether he was a warrior-noble, a brāhmaṇa, a merchant, a worker, a deity, or a human being.

original: manusso”ti attano paramparaṃ kaṅkhati. Sabbattheva pana addhānanti kālādhivacanametaṃ.🔽Aparantanti anāgataṃ antaṃ. Bhavissāmi nu kho nanu khoti sassatākārañca ucchedākārañca
analyzed: manusso ti attanaḥ paramparam kaṅkhati sabbattha iva pana addhānam ti kāla adhivacanam etam  aparantanti anāgatam antam bhavissāmi nu kho nanu kho ti sassata ākāram ca uccheda ākāram ca
translated: He is in doubt as to whether he was any of the others. How was I? - he is in doubt as to whether he was long, short, dark, fair, etc., taking the shape as the sign. Some say that he is in doubt as to the reason, asking: “For what reason was I? ” taking the divine creator, etc., as the reason. Having been what, what shall I be? - he is in doubt as to his own continuity, asking: “Having been a noble, shall I be a brahmin? … a god? a human being? ” taking birth, etc., as the sign. But addha is a word for time in all instances.

original: nissāya anāgate attano vijjamānatañca avijjamānatañca kaṅkhati. Sesamettha vuttanayameva.🔽Etarahi vā paccuppannaṃ addhānanti idāni vā paṭisandhimādiṃ katvā cutipariyantaṃ
analyzed: nissāya anāgate attanaḥ vijjamāna tañca a vijjamāna tañca kaṅkhati sesam ettha vutta nayam eva 🔽etarahi vā paccuppannam idāni vā paṭisandhim ādim katvā cuti pariyantam
translated: The future is the end of the future. Shall I be? - he is in doubt as to whether he will exist in the future, taking the eternity view as the sign. Shall I not be? - he is in doubt as to whether he will exist, taking the annihilation view as the sign. The rest is as already stated.🔽The present is the present birth, beginning with descent into the womb and ending with the appearance of the faculties.

original: sabbampi vattamānakālaṃ gahetvā. Ajjhattaṃ kathaṃkathī bhavissatīti attano khandhesu🔽vicikicchī bhavissati. Ahaṃ nu khosmīti attano atthibhāvaṃ kaṅkhati. Yuttaṃ panetanti?
analyzed: sabbam pi vattamāna kālam gahetvā ajjhattam kathaṃkathī bhavissati iti attanaḥ khandhesu  vicikicchī bhavissati aham nu kho asmi iti attanaḥ atthi bhāvam kaṅkhati yuttam pana itanti
translated: and all of them are taken as occurring in the present. He will be doubtful about what is internal: he will be doubtful about his own aggregates.🔽But is it proper to say this?

original: Yuttaṃ ayuttanti kā ettha cintā. Apicettha idaṃ vatthumpi udāharanti – cūḷamātāya
analyzed: yuttam ayuttam ti kā ettha cintā api ca ittha idam vatthum pi udāharanti cūḷamātāya
translated: What is there to think about here? It is proper or improper. Moreover, they cite this instance here:

original: kira putto muṇḍo, mahāmātāya putto amuṇḍo, taṃ puttaṃ muṇḍesuṃ, so uṭṭhāya “ahaṃ
analyzed: kira puttaḥ muṇḍaḥ mahāmātāya puttaḥ amuṇḍaḥ tam puttam muṇḍesum saḥ uṭṭhāya aham
translated: the son of the younger mother was shaven, and the son of the elder mother was not shaven. They shaved the son’s head. He got up and thought,

original: nu kho cūḷamātāya putto”ti cintesi. Evaṃ ahaṃ nu khosmīti kaṅkhā hoti. No nu khosmīti
analyzed: nu kho cūḷa mātāya putto ti cintesi evam aham nu kho asmi iti kaṅkhā hoti no nu kho asmi iti
translated: “Am I the son of the younger mother?” Thus there is doubt as to whether he is. As to whether he is not,

original: attano natthibhāvaṃ kaṅkhati. Tatrāpi idaṃ vatthu – eko kira macche gaṇhanto udake
analyzed: attanaḥ natthi bhāvam kaṅkhati tatra api idam vatthu ekaḥ kira macche gaṇhantaḥ udake
translated: he doubts his non-existence. Here too they cite this instance: a man, it seems, was catching fish in a river.

original: ciraṭṭhānena sītibhūtaṃ attano ūruṃ macchoti cintetvā pahari. Aparo susānapasse khettaṃ
analyzed: cira ṭṭhānena sīti bhūtam attano ūrum maccha uti cintetvā aparaḥ susāna passe khettam
translated: Because of his long stay in the water his leg became numb. He thought it was a fish and struck it. Another man, guarding a field in a charnel ground,

original: rakkhanto bhīto saṅkuṭito sayi, so paṭibujjhitvā attano jaṇṇukāni dve yakkhāti cintetvā
analyzed: rakkhantaḥ bhītaḥ saṅkuṭitaḥ sayi saḥ paṭibujjhitvā attanaḥ jaṇṇukāni dve yakkha ati cintetvā
translated: lay down frightened and trembling. He woke up and thought his two knees were two ghosts.

original: pahari. Evaṃ no nu khosmīti kaṅkhati.
analyzed: evam naḥ nu khalu asmi iti kaṅkhati
translated: He hesitates, thinking, “Shall I strike? Shall I not?”

original: Kiṃ nu khosmīti khattiyova samāno attano khattiyabhāvaṃ kaṅkhati. Eseva nayo sesesupi.🔽Devo pana samāno devabhāvaṃ ajānanto nāma natthi, sopi pana “ahaṃ rūpī nu kho arūpī
analyzed: kim nu kha asmi iti khattiyaḥ iva samānaḥ attanaḥ khattiya bhāvam kaṅkhati esa iva nayaḥ sesesu pi  devaḥ pana samānaḥ deva bhāvam a jānantaḥ nāma natthi saḥ api pana aham rūpī nu kho arūpī
translated: “What am I?”: a noble, though he is, hesitates, thinking, “Am I a noble?” The same method applies in the case of the rest.🔽But there is no god who does not know that he is a god. Still, he hesitates, thinking, “Am I material or immaterial? Am I percipient or non-percipient? Am I neither percipient nor non-percipient?”

original: nu kho”tiādinā nayena kaṅkhati. Khattiyādayo kasmā na jānantīti ce? Apaccakkhā tesaṃ🔽tattha tattha kule uppatti. Gahaṭṭhāpi ca potthalikādayo pabbajitasaññino, pabbajitāpi
analyzed: nu kha uti ādinā nayena kaṅkhati khattiya ādayaḥ kasmā na jānanti iti ce apaccakkhā tesam  tattha tattha kule uppatti gahaṭṭhā api ca potthalika ādayaḥ pabbajita saññinaḥ pabbajitā api
translated: Why do the nobles, etc., not know?🔽Because they are not born in the corresponding class. And householders such as Potthapāda, etc., think they are recluses, and recluses think they are householders, wondering, “Is my action defective?”

original: “kuppaṃ nu kho me kamma”ntiādinā nayena gahaṭṭhasaññino. Manussāpi ca rājāno viya🔽attani devasaññino honti. Kathaṃ nu khosmīti vuttanayameva. Kevalañhettha abbhantare
analyzed: kuppam nu kho me kamman ti ādinā nayena gahaṭṭha saññinaḥ manussāḥ api ca rājānaḥ viya  attani deva saññinaḥ honti katham nu kho smi iti vutta nayam eva kevalam ha ittha abbhantare
translated: And men think they are gods, like kings.

original: jīvo nāma atthīti gahetvā tassa saṇṭhānākāraṃ nissāya “dīgho nu khosmi rassacaturassachaḷaṃsaaṭṭhaṃsasoḷasaṃsādīnaṃ
analyzed: jīvaḥ nāma atthi iti gahetvā tassa saṇṭhāna ākāram nissāya dīghaḥ nu kho asmi rassa caturassa chaḷaṃsa aṭṭhaṃsa soḷasaṃsa ādīnam
translated: “How am I?”: in the same way as stated above. But here, taking the jīva to be something internal, he hesitates, thinking, “Am I long or short, square or round, thick or thin, sixteen cubits long, a hundred cubits long, a thousand cubits long?”

original: aññatarappakāro”ti kaṅkhanto kathaṃ nu khosmīti? Kaṅkhatīti veditabbo. Sarīrasaṇṭhānaṃ🔽pana paccuppannaṃ ajānanto nāma natthi. Kuto āgato so kuhiṃ gāmī bhavissatīti attabhāvassa
analyzed: aññatara ppakāro ti kaṅkhanto katham nu kho asmi iti kaṅkhati iti veditabbo sarīra saṇṭhānam  pana paccuppannam a jānantaḥ nāma natthi kutas āgataḥ so kuhim gāmī bhavissati iti atta bhāvassa
translated: “What sort of being is it?” and he wonders, “How shall I describe it?” He should be understood as wondering thus.🔽But there is no one who does not know the shape of the body in the present.🔽Wondering about the coming and going and standing of the self, he wonders thus: “Where did it come from? Where will it go?”

original: āgatigatiṭṭhānaṃ kaṅkhanto evaṃ kaṅkhati. Ariyasāvakassāti idha sotāpanno adhippeto,
analyzed: āgati gati ṭṭhānam kaṅkhantaḥ evam kaṅkhati ariyasāvakassa ati idha sotāpannaḥ adhippeto
translated: “A noble disciple”: here an “stream-enterer” is intended.🔽But the other three are also included.

original: itarepi pana tayo avāritāyevāti. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: itare pi pana tayaḥ a vāritāya iva ati dasamam
translated: The tenth.

original: Āhāravaggo dutiyo.🔽3. Dasabalavaggo

original: 2. Dutiyadasabalasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya dasabala sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second Ten Powers Discourse

original: 22. Dutiyaṃ bhagavatā attano ajjhāsayassa vasena vuttaṃ. Tattha dasabalasamannāgatoti
analyzed: dutiyam bhagavatā attano ajjhāsayassa vasena vuttam tattha dasa bala samannāgataḥ ti
translated: The second was spoken by the Blessed One according to his own intention. Herein, “endowed with the ten powers” means endowed with the ten powers.

original: dasahi balehi samannāgato. Balañca nāmetaṃ duvidhaṃ kāyabalañca ñāṇabalañca. Tesu
analyzed: dasahi balehi samannāgataḥ balañca nāma etam duvidham kāya balañca ñāṇa balañca tesu
translated: And this power is twofold: physical power and the power of knowledge.

original: tathāgatassa kāyabalaṃ hatthikulānusārena veditabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ porāṇehi –
analyzed: tathāgatassa kāya balam hatthi kula anusārena veditabbam vuttam ha etam porāṇehi
translated: Among them, the Tathāgata’s physical power should be understood according to the lineage of the elephants. For this is said by the ancients:

original: “Kāḷāvakañca gaṅgeyyaṃ, paṇḍaraṃ tambapiṅgalaṃ;🔽Gandhamaṅgalahemañca, uposathachaddantime dasā”ti.; –
analyzed: kāḷāvakam ca gaṅgeyyam paṇḍaram tamba piṅgalam  gandha maṅgala hemañcaḥ uposatha chaddantime dasāti
translated: “The black, the Ganges-born, the white, the copper-red, the tawny,

original: Imāni dasa hatthikulāni. Tattha kāḷāvakanti pakatihatthikulaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yaṃ dasannaṃ🔽purisānaṃ kāyabalaṃ, taṃ ekassa kāḷāvakassa hatthino. Yaṃ dasannaṃ kāḷāvakānaṃ balaṃ,🔽taṃ ekassa gaṅgeyyassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ gaṅgeyyānaṃ, taṃ ekassa paṇḍarassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ🔽paṇḍarānaṃ, taṃ ekassa tambassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ tambānaṃ, taṃ ekassa piṅgalassa. Yaṃ🔽dasannaṃ piṅgalānaṃ, taṃ ekassa gandhahatthino. Yaṃ dasannaṃ gandhahatthīnaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: imāni dasa hatthi kulāni tattha kāḷāvakanti pakati hatthi kulam daṭṭhabbam yam dasannam  purisānam kāya balam tam ekassa kāḷāvakassa hatthinaḥ yam dasannam kāḷāvakānam balam  tam ekassa gaṅgeyyassa yam dasannam gaṅgeyyānam tam ekassa paṇḍarassa yam dasannam  paṇḍarānam tam ekassa tambassa yam dasannam tambānam tam ekassa piṅgalassa yam  dasannam piṅgalānam tam ekassa gandhahatthinaḥ yam dasannam gandhahatthīnam tam
translated: The fragrant, the mangala, the golden, the Uposatha, and the six-tusked: these are the ten families of elephants.”

original: ekassa maṅgalassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ maṅgalānaṃ, taṃ ekassa hemavatassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ🔽hemavatānaṃ, taṃ ekassa uposathassa. Yaṃ dasannaṃ uposathānaṃ, taṃ ekassa chaddantassa.
analyzed: ekassa maṅgalassa yam dasannam maṅgalānam tam ekassa hemavatassa yam dasannam 🔽hemavatānam tam ekassa uposathassa yam dasannam uposathānam tam ekassa chaddantassa
translated: Herein, the black should be regarded as the ordinary family of elephants. The physical strength of ten men is the same as that of one black elephant. The strength of ten blacks is the same as that of one Ganges-born. The strength of ten Ganges-born is the same as that of one white. The strength of ten whites is the same as that of one copper-red. The strength of ten copper-reds is the same as that of one tawny. The strength of ten tawneys is the same as that of one fragrant elephant. The strength of ten fragrant elephants is the same as that of one mangala. The strength of ten mangalas is the same as that of one golden. The strength of ten goldens is the same as that of one Uposatha. The strength of ten Uposathas is the same as that of one six-tusked elephant.

original: Yaṃ dasannaṃ chaddantānaṃ, taṃ ekassa tathāgatassa. Nārāyanasaṅghātabalantipi idameva🔽vuccati. Tadetaṃ pakatihatthigaṇanāya hatthīnaṃ koṭisahassānaṃ, purisagaṇanāya dasannaṃ
analyzed: yam dasannam chaddantānam tam ekassa tathāgatassa idam eva  vuccati tat etam pakati hatthi gaṇanāya hatthīnam koṭi sahassānam purisa gaṇanāya dasannam
translated: The strength of ten of these is the strength of one of the Tathāgata’s tusk-like teeth. This is also called the strength of Nārāyaṇa.

original: purisakoṭisahassānaṃ balaṃ hoti. Idaṃ tāva tathāgatassa kāyabalaṃ. “Dasabalasamannāgato”ti
analyzed: purisa koṭi sahassānam balam hoti idam tāva tathāgatassa kāya balam dasa bala samannāgataḥ ti
translated: This strength is the strength of a hundred thousand of the largest of the largest elephants according to the calculation of the normal human body. It is the strength of ten thousand of the largest of the largest men according to the calculation of the normal human body. This is the strength of the Tathāgata’s body.

original: ettha pana etaṃ saṅgahaṃ na gacchati. Etañhi bāhirakaṃ lāmakaṃ tiracchānagatānaṃ
analyzed: ettha pana etam saṅgaham na gacchati etat hi bāhirakam lāmakam
translated: But this does not come under the ten powers. For this is external, inferior, animal, and belongs to such animals as lions, etc., as well.

original: sīhādīnampi hoti. Etañhi nissāya dukkhapariññā vā samudayappahānaṃ vā maggabhāvanā🔽vā phalasacchikiriyā vā natthi. Aññaṃ pana dasasu ṭhānesu akampanatthena upatthambhanatthena
analyzed: sīha ādīnam pi hoti etat hi nissāya dukkha pariññā vā samudaya ppahānam vā magga bhāvanā  vā phala sacchikiriyā vā natthi aññam pana dasasu ṭhānesu akampana tthena upatthambhana tthena
translated: For there is no full understanding of suffering, abandoning of origination, development of the path, or realization of cessation on the basis of this.

original: ca dasavidhaṃ ñāṇabalaṃ nāma atthi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “dasabalasamannāgato”ti.
analyzed: ca dasavidham ñāṇa balam nāma atthi tam sandhāya vuttam dasa bala samannāgataḥ ti
translated: But there is another kind of power called the tenfold knowledge power, which is unshakable in ten instances and is supportive of the ten powers. It is with reference to this that it is said, “endowed with the ten powers.”

original: Katamaṃ pana tanti? Ṭhānāṭṭhānādīnaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānanaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ – ṭhānañca
analyzed: katamam pana tanti ṭhānāt ṭhāna ādīnam yathābhūtam jānanam seyyathidam ṭhānam ca
translated: But what is this? It is the knowledge of the way things are in regard to the possible and the impossible, etc. That is to say:

original: ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato jānanaṃ ekaṃ, atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ🔽ṭhānaso hetuso yathābhūtaṃ vipākajānanaṃ ekaṃ, sabbatthagāminipaṭipadājānanaṃ ekaṃ,
analyzed: ṭhānataḥ a ṭhānañca a ṭhānataḥ jānanaṃ ekam atīta anāgata paccuppannānam kamma samādānānam  ṭhānasaḥ hetusaḥ yathābhūtam vipāka jānanaṃ ekam sabbattha gāmini paṭipadā jānanaṃ ekam
translated: The knowledge of what is possible and impossible is one. The knowledge of the result of the action of the past, future and present is one.

original: anekadhātunānādhātulokajānanaṃ ekaṃ, parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ nānādhimuttikatājānanaṃ
analyzed: aneka dhātu nānā dhātu loka jānanam ekam para sattānam para puggalānam nānā adhimuttika tā jānanam
translated: The knowledge of the path leading to all destinations is one. The knowledge of the world with its manifold elements and diverse elements is one. The knowledge of the various inclinations of other beings and other persons is one.

original: ekaṃ, tesaṃyeva indriyaparopariyattajānanaṃ ekaṃ, jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ
analyzed: ekam tesam yeva indriya para upari yatta jānanam ekam jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnam
translated: The knowledge of the degree of spiritual maturity and spiritual immaturity of other beings and other persons is one. The knowledge of the defilement, cleansing and emergence in regard to the jhānas, liberations, concentrations and attainments is one.

original: saṃkilesavodānavuṭṭhānajānanaṃ ekaṃ, pubbenivāsajānanaṃ ekaṃ, sattānaṃ cutūpapātajānanaṃ
analyzed: saṃkilesa vodāna vuṭṭhāna jānanaṃ ekam pubbenivāsa jānanaṃ ekam sattānam cutūpapāta jānanaṃ
translated: The knowledge of the recollection of past lives is one. The knowledge of the passing away and rebirth of beings is one.

original: ekaṃ, āsavakkhayajānanaṃ ekanti. Abhidhamme pana –
analyzed: ekam āsava khaya jānanam ekam ti abhidhamme pana
translated: The knowledge of the destruction of the taints is one.

original: “Idha tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Yampi🔽tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Idampi tathāgatassa
analyzed: tathāgataḥ ṭhānañca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti yaḥ pi 🔽tathāgataḥ ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānam ca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti idam pi tathāgatassa
translated: “Here, the Tathagata understands as it really is what is possible as possible and what is impossible as impossible.🔽This is another power of the Tathagata that the Tathagata has, by virtue of which he claims the herd-leader’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and sets rolling the Wheel of Brahmā.

original: tathāgatabalaṃ hoti, yaṃ balaṃ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu
analyzed: tathāgata balam hoti yam balam āgamma tathāgataḥ āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti parisāsu
translated: by depending on which he claims the place of the chief bull,

original: sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavattetī”ti.
analyzed: sīha nādam nadati brahma cakkam pavatta iti iti
translated: and he roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies and sets rolling the Wheel of Brahmā’s True Idea.”

original: Ādinā nayena vitthārato āgatāneva. Atthavaṇṇanāpi nesaṃ vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyañceva papañcasūdaniyā ca majjhimaṭṭhakathāya sabbākārato vuttā. Sā tattha vuttanayeneva gahetabbā.🔽Catūhi ca vesārajjehīti ettha sārajjapaṭipakkhaṃ vesārajjaṃ, catūsu ṭhānesu vesārajjabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ādinā nayena vitthārataḥ āgatāna eva attha vaṇṇanā api nesam vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāyam ca iva papañcasūdaniyā ca majjhima ṭṭhakathāya sabba ākārataḥ vuttā sā tattha vutta nayena iva gahetabbā  catūhi ca vesārajjehi iti ettha sārajja paṭipakkham vesārajjam catūsu ṭhānesu vesārajja bhāvam
translated: The rest is as given in detail in the same way in the first part of the sutta. And the commentary on the meaning is given in all its aspects in the Vibhaṅga commentary and in the Majjhima commentary on the Papañcasūdani . It can be understood there in the way given there.🔽As to the four grounds of self-confidence : the opposite of timidity is self-confidence . This is a term for the knowledge accompanied by joy that arises in one who reviews the fact that he has self-confidence in four instances.

original: paccavekkhantassa uppannasomanassamayañāṇassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Katamesu catūsu? “Sammāsambuddhassa🔽te paṭijānato ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā”tiādīsu codanāvatthūsu. Tatrāyaṃ pāḷi –
analyzed: paccavekkhantassa uppanna somanassa maya ñāṇassa itam nāmam katamesu catūsu sammāsambuddhassa  te paṭijānataḥ ime dhammāḥ anabhisambuddhā ati ādīsu codanā vatthūsu tatra ayam
translated: In what four instances? In the instances stated thus: ‘ When a Perfect One, bhikkhus, is describing a Perfect One’s states, describing a Perfect One’s qualities, a Perfect One’s self-confidence, a Perfect One’s range, he speaks only what is true, he speaks only what is factual, he speaks only in accordance with the rule of nature, he speaks only what is relevant’ .

original: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa vesārajjāni…pe…. Katamāni cattāri? ‘Sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: cattārimāni bhikkhave tathāgatassa vesārajjānipe katamāni cattāri sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Here is the text: ‘Bhikkhus, there are these four grounds of a Perfect One’s self-confidence. What are the four? Here, bhikkhus, the Tathāgata understands as it actually is the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible. Understanding this as it actually is, the Tathāgata, in regard to the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible, claims the place of the chief bull, he roars his lion’s roar among devas and humans, and he sets rolling the Wheel of Brahmā.

original: te paṭijānato ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā’ti tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā🔽devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ saha dhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṃ,
analyzed: te paṭijānataḥ ime dhammāḥ an abhisambuddhāḥ ati tatra vata mam samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā  devaḥ vā māraḥ vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmim saha dhammena paṭicodessati iti nimittam etam
translated: If he were to say that, he would be misrepresenting me as his teacher.

analyzed: bhikkhave na samanupassāmi etam aham bhikkhave nimittam a samanupassantaḥ khema ppatto  abhaya ppattaḥ vesārajja ppattaḥ viharāmi khīṇa āsavassa te paṭijānataḥ ime āsavāḥ a parikkhīṇā ti  tatra vata maṃpe ye kho pana te antarāyikāḥ dhammāḥ vuttā te paṭisevataḥ na alam antarāyāya ati  tatra vata maṃpe yassa kho pana te atthāya dhammo desito so na niyyāti takkarassa
translated: But I see no such reason. I am confident that I am not subject to the slanders of ascetics, brahmins, gods, Māras, Brahmās, or anyone in the world.
