translated: By what is witnessed: by what gives its fruit immediately after penetration without letting any time elapse.🔽By what is attained: by what is reached.

original: Pariyogāḷhenāti pariyogāhitena paññāya anupaviṭṭhena. Atītānāgate nayaṃ netīti “ye
analyzed: pariyogāḷhena ati pariyogāhitena paññāya an upaviṭṭhena atīta anāgate nayam neti iti ye
translated: By what is reflected upon: by what is reflected upon with understanding that has taken it as its object.🔽By inference from the general rule: by what infers the future by the example of the present.

original: kho kecī”tiādinā nayena atīte ca anāgate ca nayaṃ neti. Ettha ca na catusaccadhammena
analyzed: kho keci iti ādinā nayena atīte ca anāgate ca nayam na iti ettha ca na catu sacca dhammena
translated: and some in the future.’ And he leads the way in the past and in the future by the method of the four truths.

original: vā maggañāṇadhammena vā sakkā atītānāgate nayaṃ netuṃ, catusacce pana maggañāṇena
analyzed: vā magga ñāṇa dhammena vā sakkā atīta anāgate nayam netum catu sacce pana magga ñāṇena
translated: And here it is not possible to lead the way in the past and in the future by the state of the four truths or by the state of the path knowledge,

original: paṭividdhe parato paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ nāma hoti. Tena nayaṃ netīti veditabbā. Abbhaññaṃsūti🔽abhiaññaṃsu jāniṃsu. Seyyathāpāhaṃ, etarahīti yathā ahaṃ etarahi catusaccavasena
analyzed: paṭividdhe paratas paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam nāma hoti tena nayam neti iti veditabbā abbhaññaṃsu iti  abhiaññaṃsu jāniṃsu sā iyyathā apa aham etarahi iti yathā aham etarahi catu sacca vasena
translated: but when the four truths have been penetrated by the path knowledge, there comes to be what is called reviewing knowledge. It should be understood that he leads the way by that.🔽They have known : they have come to know, they have recognized. As if face to face with : just as I now know

original: jānāmi. Anvaye ñāṇanti anuaye ñāṇaṃ, dhammañāṇassa anugamane ñāṇaṃ, paccavekkhaṇañāṇassetaṃ
analyzed: jānāmi anvaye ñāṇan ti anuaye ñāṇam dhamma ñāṇassa anugamane ñāṇam paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇassa etam
translated: by means of the four truths. Conformity knowledge : conformity knowledge is knowledge that conforms to the knowledge of the way things are . This is a name for reviewing knowledge.

original: nāmaṃ. Dhamme ñāṇanti maggañāṇaṃ. Imasmiṃ sutte khīṇāsavassa sekkhabhūmi kathitā hoti. Tatiyaṃ.🔽4. Dutiyañāṇavatthusuttavaṇṇanā🔽34. Catutthe sattasattarīti satta ca sattari ca. Byañjanabhāṇakā kira te bhikkhū,
analyzed: nāmam dhamme ñāṇanti magga ñāṇam imasmin sutte khīṇāsavassa sekkha bhūmi kathitā hoti tatiyam 🔽dutiya ñāṇa vatthu sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽catutthe satta sattari iti satta ca sattari ca byañjana bhāṇakā kira te bhikkhū
translated: Knowledge of ideas : path knowledge. In this sutta the stage of the disciple with lusts destroyed is stated.

original: bahubyañjanaṃ katvā vuccamāne paṭivijjhituṃ sakkonti, tasmā tesaṃ ajjhāsayena idaṃ
analyzed: bahu byañjanam katvā vuccamāne paṭivijjhitum sakkonti tasmā tesam ajjhāsayena idam
translated: and they are able to penetrate it when it is being taught with many terms, therefore, in accordance with their aspirations,

original: suttaṃ vuttaṃ. Dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇanti paccayākāre ñāṇaṃ. Paccayākāro hi dhammānaṃ pavattiṭṭhitikāraṇattā🔽dhammaṭṭhitīti vuccati, ettha ñāṇaṃ dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ, etasseva chabbidhassa ñāṇassetaṃ
analyzed: suttam vuttam dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇan ti paccaya ākāre ñāṇam paccaya ākāraḥ hi dhammānam pavatti ṭṭhiti kāraṇa ttā  dhamma ṭṭhiti iti vuccati ettha ñāṇam dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇam etassa eva chabbidhassa ñāṇassa etam
translated: They can penetrate it when it is spoken with many synonyms. Therefore this sutta was spoken according to their inclination. Knowledge of the stability of dhammas is knowledge of the modes of conditionality. For the modes of conditionality are called the stability of dhammas because they are the cause of the occurrence and stability of dhammas.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Khayadhammanti khayagamanasabhāvaṃ. Vayadhammanti vayagamanasabhāvaṃ.🔽Virāgadhammanti virajjanasabhāvaṃ. Nirodhadhammanti nirujjhanasabhāvaṃ. Sattasattarīti
analyzed: adhivacanam khaya dhammanti khaya gamana sabhāvam vaya dhammanti vaya gamana sabhāvam  virāga dhammanti virajjana sabhāvam nirodha dhammanti nirujjhana sabhāvam
translated: Knowledge of that is knowledge of the stability of dhammas. This is a designation for this sixfold knowledge. Subject to destruction: having the nature of going to destruction. Subject to passing away: having the nature of going to passing away.

original: ekekasmiṃ satta satta katvā ekādasasu padesu sattasattari. Imasmiṃ sutte vipassanāpaṭivipassanā kathitā. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: ekekasmin satta satta katvā ekādasasu padesu satta sattari imasmim sutte vipassanā paṭivipassanā kathitā catuttham
translated: Subject to fading away: having the nature of fading away. Subject to cessation: having the nature of cessation. Seventy-seven: seven times seven in eleven places. In this sutta insight and full-understanding are taught. The fourth .

original: 5. Avijjāpaccayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: avijjā paccaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The fifth .

original: 35. Pañcame samudayo hotīti satthā idheva desanaṃ osāpesi. Kiṃkāraṇāti? Diṭṭhigatikassa
analyzed: pañcame samudayaḥ hoti iti satthā idha iva desanam osāpesi kiṃkāraṇā ati diṭṭhigatikassa
translated: The Teacher concluded the teaching right there. Why? Because for one who has views

original: okāsadānatthaṃ. Tassañhi parisati upārambhacitto diṭṭhigatiko atthi, so pañhaṃ pucchissati,
analyzed: okāsa dāna attham tassa hi parisati upārambha cittaḥ diṭṭhi gatiko atthi so pañham pucchissati
translated: for the purpose of giving an opportunity. For there was in his assembly a person who was angry and who held a view; he would ask a question,

original: athassāhaṃ vissajjessāmīti tassa okāsadānatthaṃ desanaṃ osāpesi. No kallo pañhoti
analyzed: athassa aham vissajjessāmi iti tassa okāsa dāna attham desanam osāpesi no kallaḥ pañho ti
translated: and then I would answer it.” For the purpose of giving him an opportunity he concluded the teaching. No kallo pañho:

original: ayutto pañho. Duppañho esoti attho. Nanu ca “katamaṃ nu kho, bhante, jarāmaraṇa”nti?🔽Idaṃ supucchitanti. Kiñcāpi supucchitaṃ, yathā pana satasahassagghanike suvaṇṇathāle
analyzed: ayuttaḥ pañhaḥ duppañhaḥ eso ti atthaḥ nanu ca katamam nu kho bhante jarā maraṇanti  idam su pucchitanti kiñca api su pucchitam yathā pana sata sahassa gghanike suvaṇṇa thāle
translated: an appropriate question. The meaning is: this is a bad question. But was not “What, venerable sir, is ageing-and-death?”🔽a good question? Although it was a good question, just as when a lump of excrement the size of a jujube-fruit is put on a plate of gold

original: vaḍḍhitassa subhojanassa matthake āmalakamattepi gūthapiṇḍe ṭhapite sabbaṃ bhojanaṃ
analyzed: vaḍḍhitassa su bhojanassa matthake āmalaka matte api gūtha piṇḍe ṭhapite sabbam bhojanam
translated: weighing a hundred thousand kahāpaṇas, all the food on the plate

original: dubbhojanaṃ hoti chaḍḍetabbaṃ, evameva “kassa ca panidaṃ jarāmaraṇa”nti? Iminā sattūpaladdhivādapadena
analyzed: dubbhojanam hoti chaḍḍetabbam evam eva kassa ca panidam jarā maraṇa nti iminā sattu upaladdhi vāda padena
translated: becomes foul-smelling and disgusting and has to be thrown away, so too, with the statement “Whose, then, is this ageing-and-death?”

original: gūthapiṇḍena taṃ bhojanaṃ dubbhojanaṃ viya ayampi sabbo duppañhova jātoti.
analyzed: gūtha piṇḍena tam bhojanam dubbhojanam viya ayam pi sabbaḥ duppañhaḥ uva jātaḥ ti
translated: by the statement of the doctrine of self, this whole bad question became as foul-smelling and disgusting as the food on the plate of gold.

original: Brahmacariyavāsoti ariyamaggavāso. Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti yassa hi ayaṃ diṭṭhi,
analyzed: brahmacariya vāso ti ariya magga vāso tam jīvam tam sarīram ti yassa hi ayam
translated: Brahmacariyavāso : the life of purity, i.e. the life of the path. The view that the soul is the same as the body

original: so “jīve ucchijjamāne sarīraṃ ucchijjati, sarīre ucchijjante jīvitaṃ ucchijjatī”ti
analyzed: saḥ jīve ucchijjamāne sarīram ucchijjati sarīre ucchijjante jīvitam ucchijjati iti
translated: He grasps it thus: “When life is destroyed, the body is destroyed; when the body is destroyed, life is destroyed.”

original: gaṇhāti. Evaṃ gaṇhato sā diṭṭhi “satto ucchijjatī”ti gahitattā ucchedadiṭṭhi nāma🔽hoti. Sace pana saṅkhārāva uppajjanti ceva nirujjhanti cāti gaṇheyya, sāsanāvacarā🔽sammādiṭṭhi nāma bhaveyya. Ariyamaggo ca nāmeso vaṭṭaṃ nirodhento vaṭṭaṃ samucchindanto
analyzed: gaṇhāti evam gaṇhataḥ sā diṭṭhi sattaḥ ucchijjati iti gahita ttā ucchedadiṭṭhi nāma  hoti sace pana saṅkhārau uppajjanti ca iva nirujjhanti ca ati gaṇheyya sāsanāvacarā  sammādiṭṭhi nāma bhaveyya ariya maggo ca nāma iso vaṭṭam nirodhentaḥ vaṭṭam samucchindantaḥ
translated: When he grasps it thus, that view is called annihilationism because it grasps the annihilation of a living being.🔽But if he were to grasp it thus: “Only formations arise and cease,” it would be a right view belonging to the Dispensation.🔽And this noble path arises in order to stop the round of existence, to cut off the round of existence;

original: uppajjati, tadeva taṃ vaṭṭaṃ ucchedadiṭṭhiyā gahitākārassa sambhave sati vināva maggabhāvanāya
analyzed: uppajjati tat eva tam vaṭṭam uccheda diṭṭhiyā gahita ākārassa sambhave sati vinā uva magga bhāvanāya
translated: but if the form of the round of existence that is grasped by annihilationism were to exist, then the development of the path would be pointless,

original: nirujjhatīti maggabhāvanā niratthakā hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “brahmacariyavāso na hotī”ti.
analyzed: nirujjhati iti magga bhāvanā niratthakā hoti tena vuttam brahmacariya vāsaḥ na hoti iti
translated: since the round of existence would cease without the development of the path. Hence it is said: “There is no living of the spiritual life.”

original: Dutiyanaye aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti yassa ayaṃ diṭṭhi, so “sarīraṃ idheva ucchijjati,
analyzed: dutiya naye aññam jīvam aññam sarīranti yassa ayam so sarīram idha iva ucchijjati
translated: In the second method, the person who holds the view that the soul is one thing and the body another grasps it thus: “The body is destroyed here,

original: na jīvitaṃ, jīvitaṃ pana pañjarato sakuṇo viya yathāsukhaṃ gacchatī”ti gaṇhāti. Evaṃ
analyzed: na jīvitam jīvitam pana pañjarataḥ sakuṇaḥ viya yathāsukham gacchati iti gaṇhāti evam
translated: but not life; life goes away as it pleases, like a bird from a cage.”

original: gaṇhato sā diṭṭhi “imasmā lokā jīvitaṃ paralokaṃ gata”nti gahitattā sassatadiṭṭhi🔽nāma hoti. Ayañca ariyamaggo tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ vivaṭṭento uppajjati, so ekasaṅkhārepi
analyzed: gaṇhato sā diṭṭhi imasmai lokāḥ jīvitam para lokam gatanti gahita ttā sassata diṭṭhi  nāma hoti ayam ca ariya maggo tebhūmaka vaṭṭam vivaṭṭentaḥ uppajjati saḥ eka saṅkhāre pi
translated: The view that he holds is the eternalist view, since it is held that “life in this world has gone to the next world.”🔽And this Noble Path arises in order to break the round of existence in the three planes. It cannot break the round even of a single formation that is eternal, stable, and permanent.

original: nicce dhuve sassate sati uppannopi vaṭṭaṃ vivaṭṭetuṃ na sakkotīti maggabhāvanā niratthakā
analyzed: nicce dhuve sassate sati uppannaḥ api vaṭṭam vivaṭṭetum na sakkoti iti magga bhāvanā niratthakā
translated: Therefore the development of the path is pointless.

original: hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā bhikkhu diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso na hotī”ti.🔽Visūkāyikānītiādi sabbaṃ micchādiṭṭhivevacanameva. Sā hi sammādiṭṭhiyā vinivijjhanaṭṭhena
analyzed: hoti tena vuttam aññam jīvam aññam sarīranti vā bhikkhu diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariya vāso na hoti iti  visūkāyikāni itiādi sabbam micchādiṭṭhi vevacanam eva sā hi sammādiṭṭhiyā vinivijjhan aṭṭhena
translated: Hence it is said: “When there is the view ‘the world is the self’ or ‘the world and the self are different,’ there is no living of the spiritual life” .🔽All the terms beginning with “atomistic” are synonyms for wrong view.

original: visūkamiva attānaṃ āvaraṇato visūkāyikaṃ, sammādiṭṭhiṃ ananuvattitvā tassā virodhena
analyzed: visūkam iva attānam āvaraṇataḥ visūkāyikam sammādiṭṭhim an anuvattitvā tassā virodhena
translated: That is, wrong view is “atomistic” in the sense of dissecting the self, since it dissects the self by way of the breakup of the aggregates.🔽It is “dispersed” because it is scattered by way of the various doctrines of annihilationism.

original: pavattanato visevitaṃ, kadāci ucchedassa kadāci sassatassa gahaṇato virūpaṃ phanditaṃ
analyzed: pavattanataḥ visevitam kadāci ucchedassa kadāci sassatassa gahaṇataḥ virūpam phanditam
translated: It is “dispersedly diffused” because it is diffused by way of the various doctrines of eternalism.

original: vipphanditanti vuccati. Tālāvatthukatānīti tālavatthu viya katāni, puna aviruhaṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: vipphanditanti vuccati tālāvatthukatāni iti tāla vatthu viya katāni puna a viruhaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: is called “tossing about.”🔽“Cut down at the root”: made like a palm stump,

original: matthakacchinnatālo viya samūlaṃ tālaṃ uddharitvā tassa patiṭṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ viya ca
analyzed: matthaka chinna tālaḥ viya sa mūlam tālam uddharitvā tassa patiṭṭhita ṭṭhānam viya ca
translated: like a palm tree cut down at the top which does not grow again.

original: katānīti attho. Anabhāvaṃkatānīti anuabhāvaṃ katānīti. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: katāni iti anu abhāvam katāni iti katāni iti pañcamam
translated: The meaning is: made to be non-existent.

original: 6. Dutiyaavijjāpaccayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya avijjā paccaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The second sutta on ignorance as condition

original: 36. Chaṭṭhe iti vā, bhikkhave, yo vadeyyāti tassaṃ parisati diṭṭhigatiko pañhaṃ pucchitukāmo
analyzed: chaṭṭhe iti vā bhikkhave yaḥ vadeyya ati tassam parisati diṭṭhi gatikaḥ pañham pucchitu kāmo
translated: In the sixth sutta, “If anyone should say this, bhikkhus” means that there was someone in the assembly who was a theorist and wanted to ask a question,

original: atthi, so pana avisāradadhātuko uṭṭhāya dasabalaṃ pucchituṃ na sakkoti, tasmā tassa
analyzed: atthi so pana a visārada dhātukaḥ uṭṭhāya dasabalam pucchitum na sakkoti tasmā tassa
translated: but he was timid and was unable to get up and ask the One of Ten Powers. Therefore,

original: ajjhāsayena sayameva pucchitvā vissajjento satthā evamāha. Chaṭṭhaṃ.🔽7. Natumhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ajjhāsayena sayam eva pucchitvā vissajjentaḥ satthā evam āha chaṭṭhaṃ  natumha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: the Teacher, knowing his thoughts, asked the question himself and answered it. The sixth sutta.🔽The sutta on “not yours”

original: 37. Sattame na tumhākanti attani hi sati attaniyaṃ nāma hoti. Attāyeva ca natthi,
analyzed: sattame na tumhākam ti attani hi sati attaniyam nāma hoti attāya iva ca natthi
translated: In the seventh sutta, “Not yours” means that if there is a self, there is what belongs to the self. But there is no self,

original: tasmā “na tumhāka”nti āha. Napi aññesanti añño nāma paresaṃ attā, tasmiṃ sati aññesaṃ
analyzed: tasmā na tumhākanti āha na pi aññesanti aññaḥ nāma paresam attā tasmin sati aññesam
translated: So he said, “It is not yours.”

original: nāma siyā, sopi natthi, tasmā “napi aññesa”nti āha. Purāṇamidaṃ, bhikkhave, kammanti
analyzed: nāma siyā saḥ api natthi tasmā na pi aññesan ti āha purāṇam idam bhikkhave kammanti
translated: Nor is it another’s: there is no other self of another’s. If there were, it might be another’s. But that does not exist. So he said, “Nor is it another’s.”🔽This body, bhikkhus, is produced by former kamma:

original: nayidaṃ purāṇakammameva, purāṇakammanibbatto panesa kāyo, tasmā paccayavohārena evaṃ
analyzed: na yidam purāṇa kammam eva purāṇa kamma nibbattaḥ pana esa kāyo tasmā paccaya vohārena evam
translated: it is not only former kamma, but this body is produced by former kamma. So it is said by way of the expression of condition.

original: vutto. Abhisaṅkhatantiādi kammavohārasseva vasena purimaliṅgasabhāgatāya vuttaṃ,🔽ayaṃ panettha attho – abhisaṅkhatanti paccayehi katoti daṭṭhabbo. Abhisañcetayitanti
analyzed: vuttaḥ abhisaṅkhata nti ādi kamma vohārassa iva vasena purima liṅga sabhā gatāya vuttam  ayam pana ittha atthaḥ paccayehi kato ti daṭṭhabbaḥ abhisañcetayitanti
translated: It is willed, etc., is said by way of the expression of kamma, and it is said in terms of the similarity of the former sign.

original: cetanāvatthuko cetanāmūlakoti daṭṭhabbo. Vedaniyanti vedaniyavatthūti daṭṭhabbo. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: cetanā vatthuko cetanāmūlako ti daṭṭhabbo vedaniyanti vedaniya vatthū ti daṭṭhabbo sattamam
translated: The meaning here is this: “It is willed” should be regarded as “made by conditions.” “It is resolved” should be regarded as “having volition as its basis and volition as its root.” “It is felt” should be regarded as “having a basis that is to be felt.”🔽The seventh section is finished.

original: 8. Cetanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cetanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on Volition

original: 38. Aṭṭhame yañca, bhikkhave, cetetīti yaṃ cetanaṃ ceteti, pavattetīti attho. Yañca
analyzed: aṭṭhame yam ca bhikkhave ceteti iti yam cetanam ceteti pavatteti iti atthaḥ yam ca
translated: In the eighth sutta, “What one intends” : what volition he intends, sets going, is the meaning.

original: pakappetīti yaṃ pakappanaṃ pakappeti, pavatteticceva attho. Yañca anusetīti yañca
analyzed: pakappeti iti yam pakappanam pakappeti pavattā iti ca iva atthaḥ yam ca anuseti iti yam ca
translated: “What one plans” : what planning he plans, sets going, is the meaning. “What one pursues” :

original: anusayaṃ anuseti, pavatteticceva attho. Ettha ca cetetīti tebhūmakakusalākusalacetanā🔽gahitā, pakappetīti aṭṭhasu lobhasahagatacittesu taṇhādiṭṭhikappā gahitā, anusetīti
analyzed: anusayam anuseti ettha ca ceteti iti tebhūmaka kusala akusala cetanā  gahitā pakappeti iti aṭṭhasu lobha sahagata cittesu taṇhā diṭṭhi kappāḥ gahitāḥ anuseti iti
translated: “It lies latent” means it is in the process of being latent. And here “it conceives” refers to the wholesome and unwholesome volition of the three planes.

original: dvādasannaṃ cetanānaṃ sahajātakoṭiyā ceva upanissayakoṭiyā ca anusayo gahito. Ārammaṇametaṃ
analyzed: dvādasannam cetanānam sahajāta koṭiyā ca iva upanissaya koṭiyā ca anusayaḥ gahitaḥ ārammaṇam etam
translated: “It conceives and conceives again” refers to the two kinds of conceiving, craving and views, in the eight consciousnesses associated with greed. “It lies latent” refers to the latent tendency in the twelve kinds of volition by way of its conascence and by way of its decisive support.

original: hotīti (cetanādidhammajāte sati kammaviññāṇassa uppattiyā avāritattā) etaṃ cetanādidhammajātaṃ🔽paccayo hoti. Paccayo hi idha ārammaṇanti adhippetā. Viññāṇassa ṭhitiyāti kammaviññāṇassa
analyzed: hoti iti cetanā ādi dhamma jāte sati kammaviññāṇassa uppattiyāḥ a vārita ttā etam cetanā ādi dhamma jātam  paccayaḥ hoti paccayaḥ hi idha ārammaṇanti adhippetā viññāṇassa ṭhitiyā ti kamma viññāṇassa
translated: “This is its object” means that when the dhammas such as volition, etc., exist, the arising of the kamma-resultant consciousness is unobstructed. Thus the dhammas such as volition, etc.,🔽are a condition for the kamma-resultant consciousness. For here a condition is what is intended by “object.”🔽“For the persistence of consciousness” means for the persistence of the kamma-resultant consciousness.

original: ṭhitatthaṃ. Ārammaṇe satīti tasmiṃ paccaye sati. Patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa hotīti tassa
analyzed: ṭhita ttham ārammaṇe sati iti tasmin paccaye sati patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa hoti iti tassa
translated: “When there is an object” means when there is a condition. “It is the support for consciousness” means it is the support for the kamma-resultant consciousness.

original: kammaviññāṇassa patiṭṭhā hoti. Tasmiṃ patiṭṭhite viññāṇeti tasmiṃ kammaviññāṇe patiṭṭhite.

translated: “When consciousness is supported” means when the kamma-resultant consciousness is supported.

original: Virūḷheti kammaṃ javāpetvā paṭisandhiākaḍḍhanasamatthatāya nibbattamūle jāte. Punabbhavābhinibbattīti
analyzed: virūḍhā iti kammam javāpetvā paṭisandhi ākaḍḍhana samattha tāya nibbatta mūle jāte punabbhava abhinibbattī iti

original: punabbhavasaṅkhātā abhinibbatti.🔽No ce, bhikkhave, cetetīti iminā tebhūmakacetanāya appavattanakkhaṇo vutto. No ce
analyzed: punabbhava saṅkhātā abhinibbatti  no ce bhikkhave ceteti iti iminā tebhūmaka cetanāya appavattana khaṇaḥ vuttaḥ no ce
translated: the rebirth-linking called “renewed becoming” .🔽“If he does not intend” : this refers to the moment when the intention of the three planes does not occur. “If he does not impel” : this refers to the moment when craving and views do not occur. “If he merely links up” :

original: pakappetīti iminā taṇhādiṭṭhikappānaṃ appavattanakkhaṇo. Atha ce anusetīti iminā🔽tebhūmakavipākesu parittakiriyāsu rūpeti ettha appahīnakoṭiyā anusayo gahito. Ārammaṇametaṃ
analyzed: pakappeti iti iminā taṇhā diṭṭhi kappānam a pavatta na khaṇaḥ atha ce anuseti iti iminā  tebhūmaka vipākesu paritta kiriyāsu rūpa iti ettha appahīna koṭiyā anusayaḥ gahito ārammaṇam etam
translated: here the underlying tendency that has not been eradicated is referred to. “This is the condition” :

original: hotīti anusaye sati kammaviññāṇassa uppattiyā avāritattā etaṃ anusayajātaṃ paccayova hoti.
analyzed: hoti iti anusaye sati kamma viññāṇassa uppattiyāḥ a vārita ttā etam anusaya jātam paccayaḥ uva hoti
translated: when there is an underlying tendency, it is a condition for the arising of the consciousness of kamma-result by virtue of the fact that it is an obstruction to the arising of the consciousness of kamma.

original: No ceva cetetītiādīsu paṭhamapade tebhūmakakusalākusalacetanā nivattā, dutiyapade
analyzed: no ca iva cetā iti itiādīsu paṭhama pade tebhūmaka kusala akusala cetanā nivattā dutiya pade
translated: In the passage beginning with “If he does not intend” , in the first clause the wholesome and unwholesome intentions of the three planes are excluded. In the second clause

original: aṭṭhasu cittesu taṇhādiṭṭhiyo, tatiyapade vuttappakāresu dhammesu yo appahīnakoṭiyā
analyzed: aṭṭhasu cittesu taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ tatiya pade vutta ppakāresu dhammesu yo appahīna koṭiyā

original: Apicettha asammohatthaṃ ceteti pakappeti anuseti, ceteti na pakappeti anuseti, na
analyzed: apica ittha asammoha attham ceteti pakappeti anuseti ceteti na pakappeti anuseti na

original: ceteti na pakappeti anuseti, na ceteti na pakappeti na anusetīti idampi catukkaṃ🔽veditabbaṃ. Tattha paṭhamanaye dhammaparicchedo dassito. Dutiyanaye cetetīti tebhūmakakusalacetanā🔽ceva catasso ca akusalacetanā gahitā. Na pakappetīti aṭṭhasu cittesu taṇhādiṭṭhiyo
analyzed: ceteti na pakappeti anuseti na ceteti na pakappeti na anuseti iti idam pi catukkam  veditabbam tattha paṭhama naye dhamma paricchedaḥ dassitaḥ dutiya naye ceteti iti tebhūmaka kusala cetanā  ca iva catasso ca akusala cetanā gahitā na pakappeti iti aṭṭhasu cittesu taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ

analyzed: nivattā anuseti iti tebhūmaka kusale upanissaya koṭiyā catūsu akusala cetanāsu sahajāta koṭiyā  ca iva upanissaya koṭiyā ca anusayaḥ gahitaḥ tatiya naye na ceteti iti tebhūmaka kusala akusalam
translated: Herein, in the first method the delimitation of ideas is shown. In the second method, “he intends” includes the profitable intentions of the three planes and the four unprofitable intentions. “He does not instigate” includes the craving and views in the eight consciousnesses. “He pursues” includes the underlying tendency of the profitable of the three planes by way of decisive support and of the four unprofitable intentions by way of conascence and by way of decisive support.

original: nivattaṃ, na pakappetīti aṭṭhasu cittesu taṇhādiṭṭhiyo nivattā, anusetīti sutte āgataṃ🔽vāretvā tebhūmakakusalākusalavipākakiriyārūpesu appahīnakoṭiyā upanissayo gahito.
analyzed: nivattam na pakappeti iti aṭṭhasu cittesu taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ nivattāḥ anuseti iti sutte āgatam 🔽vāretvā tebhūmaka kusala akusala vipāka kiriyā rūpesu appahīna koṭiyā upanissayaḥ gahito
translated: In the third method, “he does not intend” includes the profitable and unprofitable of the three planes. “He does not instigate” includes the craving and views in the eight consciousnesses. “He pursues” includes the decisive support in the profitable, unprofitable, resultant and in the immaterial-sphere-functional consciousnesses, which is not abandoned.

original: Catutthanayo purimasadisova.
analyzed: catuttha nayo purima sadisā uva

analyzed: anibbatta mūle ettha pana kim kathitan ti arahatta maggassa kiccam khīṇāsavassa kicca karaṇam ti pi  vattum vaṭṭati ettha ca viññāṇassa ca iva āyatim punabbhavassa

translated: rebirth called “appearance there.” This is called “death and rebirth.” Thus in this sutta, the knot and the coming and going

analyzed: saṃvattati sappurisa saṃsevaḥ saddhamma ssavanam yoniso manasikāraḥ dhamma anudhamma ppaṭipatti iti  evam āgatam paṭiladdha guṇassa ca sotāpattim patvā ṭhitassa aṅgam yam sotāpannassa

analyzed: tatiye dukkhassa ati vaṭṭa dukkhassa dve samudayā khaṇika samudayo ca
translated: The fourteenth is the same as the first except that the bhikkhus, bhikkhunis, and the male and female lay followers are addressed in the fourteenth.🔽The fifteenth is the same as the first except that the bhikkhus, bhikkhunis, and the male and female lay followers are addressed in the fifteenth.

original: paccayasamudayo ca. Paccayasamudayaṃ passantopi bhikkhu khaṇikasamudayaṃ passati,🔽khaṇikasamudayaṃ passantopi paccayasamudayaṃ passati. Atthaṅgamopi accantatthaṅgamo
analyzed: paccaya samudayaḥ ca paccaya samudayam passantaḥ api bhikkhu khaṇika samudayam passati 🔽khaṇika samudayam passantaḥ api paccaya samudayam passati atthaṅgamaḥ api accanta tthaṅgamaḥ
translated: The sixteenth is the same as the first except that the bhi

original: bhedatthaṅgamoti duvidho. Accantatthaṅgamaṃ passantopi bhedatthaṅgamaṃ passati, bhedatthaṅgamaṃ🔽passantopi accantatthaṅgamaṃ passati. Desessāmīti idaṃ vaṭṭadukkhassa samudayaatthaṅgamaṃ
analyzed: bheda tthaṅgamaḥ ti duvidhaḥ accanta tthaṅgamam passantaḥ api bheda tthaṅgamam passati bheda tthaṅgamam  passantaḥ api accanta atthaṅgamam passati desessāmi iti idam vaṭṭa dukkhassa samudaya atthaṅgamaṃ
translated: and the other is the dissolution of the breakup. When he sees the ultimate dissolution, he sees the dissolution of the breakup;🔽when he sees the dissolution of the breakup, he sees the ultimate dissolution.

original: nibbattibhedaṃ nāma desessāmi, taṃ suṇāthāti attho. Paṭiccāti nissayavasena ceva
analyzed: nibbatti bhedam nāma desessāmi tam suṇātha ati attho paṭicca ati nissaya vasena ca iva
translated: I shall teach: I shall teach the origin and the dissolution of the round of rebirths, which is the origination and the breakup of suffering. Listen to that, is the meaning.🔽With the support of: with the support of conditions as object condition and

original: ārammaṇavasena ca paccayaṃ katvā. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phassoti tiṇṇaṃ saṅgatiyā phasso.
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena ca paccayam katvā tiṇṇam saṅgati phasso ti tiṇṇam saṅgatiyā phasso
translated: as support condition. The meeting of the three is contact: contact through the meeting of the three.

original: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dukkhassa samudayoti ayaṃ vaṭṭadukkhassa nibbatti nāma. Atthaṅgamoti
analyzed: ayam kho bhikkhave dukkhassa samudayaḥ ti ayam vaṭṭa dukkhassa nibbatti nāma atthaṅgamaḥ ti
translated: This is the origin of suffering: this is the origination of the round of rebirths, which is the origination of suffering. Dissolution:

original: bhedo. Evañhi vaṭṭadukkhaṃ bhinnaṃ hoti appaṭisandhiyaṃ. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: bhedaḥ evam hi vaṭṭa dukkham bhinnam hoti appaṭisandhiyam tatiyam
translated: breakup. For the round of rebirths is broken up by the non-taking of rebirth. The third.

original: 4. Lokasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on the World.

original: 44. Catutthe lokassāti saṅkhāralokassa. Ayamettha viseso. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe lokassa ati saṅkhāra lokassa ayam ettha viseso catuttham
translated: In the fourth, of the world : of the world of formations. This is the difference here. The fourth.

original: 5. Ñātikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ñātika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Ñātika Discourse.

original: 45. Pañcame ñātiketi dvinnaṃ ñātakānaṃ gāme. Giñjakāvasatheti iṭṭhakāhi kate mahāpāsāde.
analyzed: pañcame ñātika iti dvinnam ñātakānam gāme giñjaka āvasatha iti kate mahā pāsāde
translated: 45. In the fifth, “relatives” : two relatives. “In the village” : in the brick house.

original: Dhammapariyāyanti dhammakāraṇaṃ. Upassutīti upassutiṭṭhānaṃ, yaṃ ṭhānaṃ upagatena
analyzed: dhamma pariyāyanti dhamma kāraṇam upassuti iti upassuti ṭhānam yam ṭhānam upagatena
translated: “A discourse on Dhamma” : a reason for Dhamma. “Within hearing” : within hearing range, a place where one can hear

original: sakkā hoti bhagavato saddaṃ sotuṃ, tattha ṭhitoti attho. So kira gandhakuṭipariveṇasammajjanatthaṃ🔽āgato attano kammaṃ pahāya bhagavato dhammaghosaṃ suṇanto aṭṭhāsi. Addasāti tadā
analyzed: sakkā hoti bhagavato saddam sotum tattha ṭhitaḥ ti attho saḥ kira gandha kuṭi pariveṇa sammajjana attham  āgataḥ attano kammam pahāya bhagavataḥ dhamma ghosam suṇantaḥ aṭṭhāsi addasāti tadā
translated: the Blessed One’s voice. The meaning is: “standing in a place where he could hear.” It seems that he had come to sweep the courtyard of the Fragrant Cell,

original: kira bhagavato āditova paccayākāraṃ manasikarontassa “idaṃ iminā paccayena hoti,🔽idaṃ iminā”ti āvajjato yāva bhavaggā ekaṅgaṇaṃ ahosi, satthā manasikāraṃ pahāya vacasā🔽sajjhāyaṃ karonto yathānusandhinā desanaṃ niṭṭhapetvā, “api nu kho imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: kira bhagavataḥ āditas va paccaya ākāram manasikarontassa idam iminā paccayena hoti  idam āvajjataḥ yāva bhavaggāḥ ekaṅgaṇam ahosi satthā manasikāram pahāya vacasā  sajjhāyam karontaḥ yathā anusandhinā desanam niṭṭhapetvā api nu kho imam dhammapariyāyam
translated: and he stood there listening to the Blessed One’s voice, having given up his own work. “Saw” : it seems that at that time, when the Blessed One first directed his mind to the principle of conditionality, thinking “This is conditioned by that,”🔽and observed the principle of conditionality from the beginning to the end of the world, the whole world became as clear as a crystal ball. The Teacher, having given up his attention to the principle of conditionality,

original: koci assosī”ti āvajjento taṃ bhikkhumaddasa. Tena vuttaṃ “addasā kho bhagavā”ti.
analyzed: koci assosi iti āvajjento tam bhikkhum addasa tena vuttam addasā kho bhagavā ti
translated: and having completed the teaching by way of the Thread, thought: “Did anyone hear this discourse on Dhamma?” He saw that bhikkhu. Therefore it is said: “The Blessed One saw that bhikkhu.”

original: Assosi noti assosi nu. Atha vā assosi noti amhākaṃ bhāsantānaṃ assosīti. Uggaṇhāhītiādīsu🔽sutvā tuṇhībhūtova paguṇaṃ karonto uggaṇhāti nāma. Padānupadaṃ ghaṭetvā vācāya paricitaṃ
analyzed: assosi no ti assosi nu atha vā assosi no ti amhākam bhāsantānam assosi iti uggaṇhāhi itiādīsu  sutvā tuṇhībhūtaḥ uva paguṇam karontaḥ uggaṇhāti nāma padānupadam ghaṭetvā vācāya paricitam
translated: Assosi means he heard. Or else, assosi means he heard what we were saying. In the passages beginning with “Learn it,”🔽he learns it by becoming silent after hearing it and making it his own. He memorizes it by arranging the words in order and making it familiar by recitation.

original: karonto pariyāpuṇāti nāma. Ubhayathāpi paguṇaṃ ādhārappattaṃ karonto dhāreti nāma.
analyzed: karontaḥ pariyāpuṇāti nāma ubhayathā api paguṇam ādhāra ppattam karontaḥ dhāreti nāma
translated: In both cases he retains it by making it his own and bringing it to mind.

original: Atthasaṃhitoti kāraṇanissito. Ādibrahmacariyakoti maggabrahmacariyassa ādi patiṭṭhānabhūto.
analyzed: attha saṃhitoti kāraṇa nissito ādibrahmacariyako ti magga brahmacariyassa ādi patiṭṭhāna bhūto
translated: It is connected with the meaning, i.e., it is based on a reason. It is the beginning of the holy life, i.e., it is the foundation of the path of the holy life.

original: Iti tīsupi imesu suttesu vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva kathitaṃ. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Aññatarabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iti imesu suttesu vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam eva kathitam pañcamam  aññatara brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Thus in these three suttas only the round and the transcending of the round are taught. The fifth sutta.🔽The explanation of the sutta on a certain brahmin.

original: 46. Chaṭṭhe aññataroti nāmavasena apākaṭo aññataro brāhmaṇo. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe aññataro ti nāma vasena apākaṭaḥ aññataraḥ brāhmaṇo chaṭṭham
translated: In the sixth, a certain brahmin: a certain brahmin who is not well known by name. The sixth sutta.

original: 7. Jāṇussoṇisuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the sutta on Jāṇussoṇi.

original: 47. Sattame jāṇussoṇīti ṭhānantaravasena evaṃladdhanāmo asītikoṭivibhavo mahāpurohito. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: sattame jāṇussoṇī iti evaṃladdha nāmaḥ asīti koṭi vibhavaḥ mahā purohitaḥ sattamam
translated: In the seventh, Jāṇussoṇi: the chief minister, who had a fortune of eighty koṭis, and who received his name from his position. The seventh sutta.

original: 8. Lokāyatikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: lokāyatika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the sutta on the world-contemplator.

original: 48. Aṭṭhame lokāyatikoti vitaṇḍasatthe lokāyate kataparicayo. Jeṭṭhametaṃ lokāyatanti
analyzed: aṭṭhame lokāyatiko ti vitaṇḍa satthe lokāyate kata paricayaḥ jeṭṭham etam
translated: The eighth is one who is skilled in the world’s systems of speculation. The first of these is called the world’s system of speculation.

original: paṭhamaṃ lokāyataṃ. Lokāyatanti ca lokasseva āyataṃ, bālaputhujjanalokassa āyataṃ,
analyzed: paṭhamam lokāyatam lokāyatanti ca lokassa iva āyatam bāla puthujjana lokassa āyatam
translated: And the world’s system of speculation is the world’s longings, the longings of the foolish ordinary men.

original: mahantaṃ gambhīranti upadhāritabbaṃ parittaṃ bhāvaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ. Ekattanti ekasabhāvaṃ,
analyzed: mahantam gambhīranti upadhāritabbam parittam bhāvam diṭṭhi gatam ekattam ti eka sabhāvam
translated: It should be understood as a doctrine of limited scope, a view that is shallow and not profound. “One” is of one nature.

original: niccasabhāvamevāti pucchati. Puthuttanti purimasabhāvena nānāsabhāvaṃ, devamanussādibhāvena🔽paṭhamaṃ hutvā pacchā na hotīti ucchedaṃ sandhāya pucchati. Evamettha “sabbamatthi,🔽sabbamekatta”nti imā dvepi sassatadiṭṭhiyo, “sabbaṃ natthi, sabbaṃ puthutta”nti imā
analyzed: nicca sabhāvam eva ati pucchati puthuttanti purima sabhāvena nānā sabhāvam deva manussa ādi bhāvena  paṭhamam hutvā pacchā na hoti iti ucchedam sandhāya pucchati evam ettha sabbam atthi  sabbam ekattam ti imāḥ dve pi sassata diṭṭhiyaḥ sabbam natthi sabbam puthuttam ti imāḥ
translated: He asks whether it is of a permanent nature. “Different” is of a different nature from the previous nature, of the nature of gods, human beings, etc.🔽He asks whether, having been one at first, it is not so afterwards, referring to annihilation. Thus here the two views “all exists” and “all is one” are eternalist views,

original: dve ucchedadiṭṭhiyoti veditabbā. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: dve uccheda diṭṭhiyo ti veditabbāḥ aṭṭhamam
translated: and the two views “all does not exist” and “all is different” are annihilationist views. The eighth is finished.

original: 9. Ariyasāvakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ariya sāvaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of “The Noble Disciple” is finished.

original: 49. Navame kiṃ nu khoti saṃsayuppattiākāradassanaṃ. Samudayatīti uppajjati. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: navame kim nu kho ti saṃsaya uppatti ākāra dassanam samudayati iti uppajjati navamam
translated: In the ninth sutta, “What, venerable sir?” shows the appearance of the arising of doubt. “Originates” means arises. The ninth is finished.🔽. The explanation of “The Nine Questions” is finished.

original: 10. Dutiyaariyasāvakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya ariya sāvaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 10. The second good person

original: 50. Dasame dvepi nayā ekato vuttā. Idameva purimena nānattaṃ, sesaṃ tādisamevāti. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: dasame dve api nayāḥ ekatas vuttāḥ idam eva purimena nānattam sesam tādisam eva ati dasamam
translated: In the tenth, both ways are stated together. This is the only difference from the preceding sutta. The rest is the same.

original: Gahapativaggo pañcamo.🔽6. Dukkhavaggo
analyzed: gahapati vaggo pañcamo  dukkha vaggaḥ
translated: The fifth sub-chapter on the householder is finished.🔽The misery chapter

original: 1. Parivīmaṃsanasuttavaṇṇanā🔽51. Dukkhavaggassa paṭhame parivīmaṃsamānoti upaparikkhamāno. Jarāmaraṇanti kasmā
analyzed: parivīmaṃsana sutta vaṇṇanā  dukkha vaggassa paṭhame parivīmaṃsamānaḥ ti upaparikkhamānaḥ jarā maraṇanti kasmā
translated: The contemplation of misery

original: jarāmaraṇaṃ ekameva “anekavidhaṃ nānappakāraka”nti vatvā gahitanti ce? Tasmiṃ gahite
analyzed: jarā maraṇam ekam eva anekavidham nānā pakārakanti vatvā gahitanti ce tasmin gahite
translated: In the first sutta of the misery chapter, “contemplating” means investigating. Why is it that “ageing-and-death” is stated as “of many kinds and of various kinds” and is then taken?🔽When it is taken,

original: sabbadukkhassa gahitattā. Yathā hi cūḷāya gahite purise so puriso gahitova hoti,🔽evaṃ jarāmaraṇe gahite sabbadukkhaṃ gahitameva hoti. Tasmā “yaṃ kho idaṃ anekavidhaṃ🔽nānappakārakaṃ dukkhaṃ loke uppajjatī”ti nhatvā ṭhitaṃ purisaṃ viya sabbadukkhaṃ
analyzed: sabba dukkhassa gahita ttā yathā hi cūḷāya gahite purise saḥ purisaḥ gahitaḥ uva hoti  evam jarā maraṇe gahite sabba dukkham gahitam eva hoti tasmai yam kho idam anekavidham  nānā ppakārakam dukkham loke uppajjati iti nhatvā ṭhitam purisam viya sabba dukkham
translated: all misery is taken. Just as when a man is taken by the hair, he is taken,

original: dassetvā taṃ cūḷāya gaṇhanto viya jarāmaraṇaṃ gaṇhi.
analyzed: dassetvā tam cūḷāya gaṇhantaḥ viya jarā maraṇam gaṇhi
translated: so when ageing-and-death is taken, all misery is taken. That is why he said “Whatever misery arises in the world” and then, as though showing all misery as a man standing after he has bathed, he took ageing-and-death as though taking that misery with the hair.

original: Jarāmaraṇanirodhasāruppagāminīti jarāmaraṇanirodhassa sāruppabhāvena nikkilesatāya🔽parisuddhatāya sadisāva hutvā gāminīti attho. Tathā paṭipanno ca hotīti yathā taṃ
analyzed: jarā maraṇa nirodha sāruppa gāminī iti jarā maraṇa nirodhassa sāruppa bhāvena nikkilesa tāya  parisuddha tāya sadisā ava hutvā gāminī iti tathā paṭipanno ca hoti iti yathā taṃ
translated: The meaning is that it leads in a manner similar to the cessation of aging-and-death.

original: paṭipannoti vuccati, evaṃ paṭipanno hoti. Anudhammacārīti nibbānadhammaṃ anugataṃ🔽paṭipattidhammaṃ carati, pūretīti attho. Dukkhakkhayāya paṭipannoti sīlaṃ ādiṃ katvā
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ ti vuccati evam paṭipannaḥ hoti anudhamma cārī iti nibbāna dhammam anugatam  paṭipatti dhammam carati pūreti iti attho dukkha kkhayāya paṭipannaḥ ti sīlam ādim katvā
translated: “One who practices in accordance with the Dhamma”: one who practices in such a way that he is called a “practitioner.”🔽“One who conducts himself in accordance with the Dhamma”: he conducts himself in the Dhamma leading to Nibbāna; the meaning is, he fulfills it.

original: jarāmaraṇadukkhassa nirodhatthāya paṭipanno. Saṅkhāranirodhāyāti saṅkhāradukkhassa
analyzed: jarā maraṇa dukkhassa nirodha tthāya paṭipanno saṅkhāra nirodhāya ati saṅkhāra dukkhassa
translated: “One who practices for the cessation of suffering”: he practices for the cessation of the suffering of aging-and-death, beginning with virtue.🔽“For the cessation of formations”: for the cessation of the suffering of formations.

original: nirodhatthāya. Ettāvatā yāva arahattā desanā kathitā.
analyzed: nirodha tthāya ettāvatā yāva arahattā desanā kathitā
translated: Up to this point the teaching has been given.

original: Idāni arahattaphalapaccavekkhaṇaṃ satatavihārañca dassetvā desanā nivattetabbā siyā,
analyzed: idāni arahatta phala paccavekkhaṇam satata vihārañca dassetvā desanā nivattetabbā siyā
translated: Now, the teaching could be concluded by showing the reviewing of the fruit of arahatship and the abiding in it,

original: tathā akatvā avijjāgatoti idaṃ kasmā gaṇhātīti? Khīṇāsavassa samatikkantavaṭṭadukkhadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: tathā a katvā avijja āgataḥ ti idam kasmai gaṇhāti iti khīṇāsavassa samatikkanta vaṭṭa dukkha dassana attham
translated: but without doing so, he takes up the phrase “one who is not free from ignorance” . Why? In order to show that the one who is free from cankers has transcended the suffering of the round.

original: Apica puna vaṭṭaṃ ārabhitvā vivaṭṭe kathiyamāne bujjhanakasatto cettha atthi, tassa
analyzed: apica puna vaṭṭam ārabhitvā vivaṭṭe kathiyamāne bujjhanaka satto ca ittha atthi tassa
translated: Furthermore, when the round is being expounded beginning with the words, “When this is, that is” , the being who is being enlightened here understands it by the method of his own inclination.

original: ajjhāsayavasenāpi idaṃ gaṇhātīti veditabbo. Tattha avijjāgatoti avijjāya gato upagato
analyzed: ajjhāsaya vasena api idam gaṇhāti iti veditabbaḥ tattha avijjā gataḥ ti avijjāya gataḥ upagataḥ
translated: Herein, he is “deluded by ignorance” : he has gone to , has approached, has become possessed by ignorance.🔽“A human being” : a human being is a person.

original: samannāgato. Purisapuggaloti purisoyeva puggalo. Ubhayenāpi sammutikathaṃ katheti.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ purisa puggalo ti purisaḥ yā iva puggalaḥ ubhayena api sammuti katham kathā iti
translated: With both terms he speaks a conventional expression.

original: Buddhānañhi sammutikathā paramatthakathāti dve kathā honti. Tattha “satto naro puriso
analyzed: buddhānam hi sammuti kathā paramattha kathā ati dve kathāḥ honti tattha sattaḥ naraḥ puriso
translated: For there are two kinds of talk for Buddhas: conventional talk and ultimate-meaning talk.

original: puggalo tisso nāgo”ti evaṃ pavattā sammutikathā nāma. “Khandhā dhātuyo āyatanānī”ti
analyzed: puggalo tissaḥ nāgo ti evam pavattā sammuti kathā nāma khandhāḥ dhātuyaḥ āyatanāni iti
translated: Herein, the talk that occurs thus, “A being, a man, a human being, a person, Tissa, a nāga” , is called conventional talk.🔽The talk that occurs thus, “Aggregates, bases, elements” ,

original: evaṃ pavattā paramatthakathā nāma. Paramatthaṃ kathentāpi sammutiṃ amuñcitvā kathenti.
analyzed: evam pavattā paramatthakathā nāma param attham kathentā api sammutim a muñcitvā kathenti
translated: is called ultimate-meaning talk. And when they speak ultimate meaning they speak without abandoning the conventional.

original: Te sammutiṃ kathentāpi paramatthaṃ kathentāpi saccameva kathenti. Teneva vuttaṃ –
analyzed: te sammutim kathentā api paramattham kathentā api saccam eva kathenti tena iva vuttam
translated: And when they speak the conventional they speak the truth, and when they speak ultimate meaning they speak the truth. That is why it is said:🔽“The Enlightened One, the best of speakers,

original: “Duve saccāni akkhāsi, sambuddho vadataṃ varo;
analyzed: duve saccāni akkhāsi sambuddhaḥ vadatam varaḥ
translated: Proclaimed two truths:🔽The conventional and the ultimate meaning;

original: Sammutiṃ paramatthañca, tatiyaṃ nūpalabbhati;
analyzed: sammutim paramattham ca tatiyam nūpalabbhati
translated: A third is not found.

original: Saṅketavacanaṃ saccaṃ, lokasammutikāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: saṅketa vacanam saccam loka sammuti kāraṇam
translated: Truth is a conventional term,🔽And truth is the ultimate term,

original: Paramatthavacanaṃ saccaṃ, dhammānaṃ bhūtalakkhaṇa”nti.
analyzed: paramattha vacanam saccam dhammānam bhūtalakkhaṇan ti
translated: The characteristics of the real dhammas.

original: Puññaṃ ce saṅkhāranti terasacetanābhedaṃ puññābhisaṅkhāraṃ. Abhisaṅkharotīti karoti.
analyzed: puññam terasa cetanā bhedam puñña abhisaṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti iti karoti
translated: If he forms a meritorious formation, he forms a meritorious formation consisting of thirteen kinds of consciousness. He forms it: he does it.

original: Puññūpagaṃ hoti viññāṇanti kammaviññāṇaṃ kammapuññena upagataṃ sampayuttaṃ hoti,
analyzed: puñña upagam hoti viññāṇam ti kamma viññāṇam kamma puññena upagatam sampayuttam hoti
translated: His consciousness is accompanied by merit: his kamma-resultant consciousness is accompanied by the merit of the kamma.

original: vipākaviññāṇaṃ vipākapuññena. Apuññaṃ ce saṅkhāranti dvādasacetanābhedaṃ apuññābhisaṅkhāraṃ🔽abhisaṅkharoti. Āneñjaṃ ce saṅkhāranti catucetanābhedaṃ āneñjābhisaṅkhāraṃ. Āneñjūpagaṃ
analyzed: vipāka viññāṇam vipāka puññena apuññam ce saṅkhāranti dvādasa cetanā bhedam apuñña abhisaṅkhāram  abhisaṅkharoti āneñjam ce catu cetanā bhedam āneñja abhisaṅkhāram āneñja upagam
translated: If he forms a demeritorious formation, he forms a demeritorious formation consisting of twelve kinds of consciousness.🔽He forms it: he does it. His consciousness is accompanied by demerit: his kamma-resultant consciousness is accompanied by the demerit of the kamma.

original: hoti viññāṇanti kammāneñjena kammaviññāṇaṃ, vipākāneñjena vipākaviññāṇaṃ upagataṃ
analyzed: hoti viññāṇanti kamma aneñjena kamma viññāṇam vipāka aneñjena vipāka viññāṇam upagatam
translated: If he forms an imperturbable formation, he forms an imperturbable formation consisting of four kinds of consciousness. His consciousness is accompanied by imperturbability: his kamma-resultant consciousness is accompanied by the imperturbability of the kamma.

original: hoti. Ettha ca tividhassa kammābhisaṅkhārassa gahitattā dvādasapadiko paccayākāro
analyzed: hoti ettha ca tividhassa kamma abhisaṅkhārassa gahita ttā dvādasa padiko paccaya ākāro
translated: The twelvefold mode of conditionality is included here by the inclusion of the threefold formation of kamma.

original: gahitova hoti. Ettāvatā vaṭṭaṃ dassitaṃ.
analyzed: gahitaḥ uva hoti ettāvatā vaṭṭam dassitam
translated: So far the round has been shown.

original: Idāni vivaṭṭaṃ dassento yato kho, bhikkhavetiādimāha. Tattha avijjāti catūsu saccesu
analyzed: idāni vivaṭṭam dassentaḥ yatas kho bhikkhave ti ādim āha tattha avijjā ti catūsu saccesu
translated: Now, in order to show the emergence , he said, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is thus perfectly liberated in mind, Translation: Now, in order to show the emergence , he said, “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is thus perfectly liberated in mind,

original: aññāṇaṃ. Vijjāti arahattamaggañāṇaṃ. Ettha ca paṭhamameva avijjāya pahīnāya vijjā
analyzed: aññāṇam vijjāti arahatta magga ñāṇam ettha ca paṭhamam eva avijjāya pahīnāya vijjā
translated: Ignorance is the unknowing of the four truths. Knowledge is the knowledge of the path of arahatship. And here, when ignorance is first abandoned, knowledge arises.

original: uppajjati. Yathā pana caturaṅgepi tame rattiṃ padīpujjalena andhakāro pahīyati, evaṃ🔽vijjuppādā avijjāya pahānaṃ veditabbaṃ. Na kiñci loke upādiyatīti loke kiñci dhammaṃ🔽na gaṇhāti na parāmasati. Anupādiyaṃ na paritassatīti anupādiyanto agaṇhanto neva
analyzed: uppajjati yathā pana catur aṅge pi tame rattim padīput jalena andhakāraḥ pahīyati evam  vijjuppādāḥ avijjāya pahānam veditabbam na kiñci loke upādiyati iti loke kiñci dhammam  na gaṇhāti na parāmasati anupādiyam na paritassati iti an upādiyantaḥ a gaṇhantaḥ na iva
translated: But just as when a lamp is lit, darkness is abandoned, so too,

original: taṇhāparitassanāya, na bhayaparitassanāya paritassati, na taṇhāyati na bhāyatīti
analyzed: taṇhā paritassanāya na bhaya paritassanāya paritassati na taṇhāyati na bhāyati iti
translated: with the arising of knowledge, ignorance is abandoned. He does not cling to anything in the world: he does not grasp or misapprehend any phenomenon in the world. Not clinging, he is not agitated: not clinging, not grasping, he is not agitated either by the agitation of craving or by the agitation of fear. The meaning is that he does not crave or fear.

original: attho. Paccattaññevāti sayameva attanāva parinibbāyati, na aññassa ānubhāvena.
analyzed: attho paccattaññā iva ati sayam eva attanā ava parinibbāyati na aññassa ānubhāvena
translated: He personally attains Nibbana: he himself, by himself, attains Nibbana.

original: So sukhaṃ ce vedananti idaṃ kasmā ārabhi? Khīṇāsavassa paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: saḥ sukham ce vedanam ti idam kasmai ārabhi khīṇāsavassa paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam dassetvā
translated: Why does he begin with “If he feels a pleasant feeling”? After showing the reviewing knowledge of one whose cankers are destroyed,

original: satatavihāraṃ dassetuṃ ārabhi. Anajjhositāti taṇhāya gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā agahitā.🔽Atha dukkhavedanā kasmā vuttā, kiṃ tampi abhinandanto atthīti? Āma atthi. Sukhaṃ
analyzed: satata vihāram dassetum ārabhi an ajjhositā ati taṇhāya gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā a gahitā  atha dukkha vedanā kasmā vuttā kim tam pi abhinandantaḥ atthi iti āma atthi sukham
translated: He began to point out the abiding in the present. Unhankered-after : not seized upon by craving after swallowing and digesting.

original: abhinandantoyeva hi dukkhaṃ abhinandati nāma dukkhaṃ patvā sukhaṃ patthanato sukhassa
analyzed: abhinandantaḥ yā iva hi dukkham abhinandati nāma dukkham patvā sukham patthanataḥ sukhassa
translated: But why is painful feeling mentioned? Is there anyone who delights in that? —Yes, there is. For it is by delighting in pleasure that one delights in pain, since when pain is present pleasure is longed for, and pleasure is the source of pain in its change.

original: ca vipariṇāmadukkhatoti. Kāyapariyantikanti kāyaparicchinnaṃ, yāva pañcadvārakāyo🔽pavattati, tāva pavattaṃ pañcadvārikavedananti attho. Jīvitapariyantikanti jīvitaparicchinnaṃ.
analyzed: ca vipariṇāma dukkhato ti kāya pariyantikanti kāya paricchinnam yāva pañca dvāra kāyo  pavattati tāva pavattam pañca dvārika vedanan ti attho jīvita pariyantikanti jīvita paricchinnam
translated: Limiting to the body : limited by the body. The meaning is: feeling occurring in the five doors as long as the five doors occur.

original: Yāva jīvitaṃ pavattati, tāva pavattaṃ manodvārikavedananti attho.
analyzed: yāva jīvitam pavattati tāva pavattam manodvārika vedananti attho
translated: Limiting to life : limited by life. The meaning is: feeling occurring in the mind door as long as life occurs.

original: Tattha pañcadvārikavedanā pacchā uppajjitvā paṭhamaṃ nirujjhati, manodvārikavedanā
analyzed: tattha pañca dvārika vedanā pacchā uppajjitvā paṭhamam nirujjhati manaḥ dvārika vedanā
translated: Herein, the feeling in the five doors arises later and ceases first, while the feeling in the mind door

original: paṭhamaṃ uppajjitvā pacchā nirujjhati. Sā hi paṭisandhikkhaṇe vatthurūpasmiṃyeva
analyzed: paṭhamam uppajjitvā pacchā nirujjhati sā hi paṭisandhi kkhaṇe vatthu rūpasmiṃ yeva
translated: arises first and ceases last. For that is present at the moment of rebirth-linking and continues as long as life lasts, being bound up with the material support.

original: patiṭṭhāti. Pañcadvārikā pavatte pañcadvāravasena pavattamānā paṭhamavaye vīsativassakāle
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti pañcadvārikā pavatte pañca dvāra vasena pavattamānā paṭhama vaye vīsati vassa kāle
translated: It is established. The five-door feeling occurs by way of the five doors in the five-door process. In the first stage of life, at the age of twenty,

original: rajjanadussanamuyhanavasena adhimattā balavatī hoti, paṇṇāsavassakāle ṭhitā hoti,
analyzed: rajjana dussana muyhana vasena adhimattā balavatī hoti paṇṇāsa vassa kāle ṭhitā hoti
translated: it is strong and powerful by way of lust, hatred, and delusion. At the age of fifty, it is stable.

original: saṭṭhivassakālato paṭṭhāya parihāyamānā asītinavutivassakāle mandā hoti. Tadā hi
analyzed: saṭṭhi vassa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya parihāyamānā asīti navuti vassa kāle mandā hoti tadā hi
translated: From the age of sixty onwards, it declines. At the age of eighty or ninety, it is weak. At that time,

original: sattā “cirarattaṃ ekato nisīdimhā nipajjimhā”ti vadantepi “na sañjānāmā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: sattā cira rattam ekatas nisīdimhā nipajjimha iti vadante api na sañjānāma ati vadanti
translated: beings say, “We have been sitting and lying down together for a long time,” but they say, “We do not recognize each other.”

original: Adhimattānipi rūpādiārammaṇāni “na passāma na suṇāma”, “sugandhaṃ duggandhaṃ vā sāduṃ🔽asāduṃ vā thaddhaṃ mudukanti vā na jānāmā”ti vadanti. Iti nesaṃ pañcadvārikavedanā
analyzed: adhimattāni api rūpa ādi ārammaṇāni na passāma na suṇāma sugandham duggandham vā  vā vā na jānāma ati vadanti iti na īsam pañca dvārika vedanā
translated: Even strong objects such as visible forms, etc., are said to be “not seen or heard,” and “we do not know whether a smell is good or bad, whether a taste is sweet or unsweet,

original: bhaggā hoti, manodvārikāva pavattati. Sāpi anupubbena parihāyamānā maraṇasamaye hadayakoṭiṃyeva
analyzed: bhaggā hoti manodvārikā āva pavattati sā api anupubbena parihāyamānā maraṇa samaye hadaya koṭiṃyā iva
translated: whether something is hard or soft.” Thus the five-door feeling of these beings is broken up. Only the mind-door feeling occurs. That, too, gradually declining, occurs at the time of death only by way of the heart-base.

original: nissāya pavattati. Yāva panesā pavattati, tāva satto jīvatīti vuccati. Yadā nappavattati,
analyzed: nissāya pavattati yāva pana esā pavattati tāva sattaḥ jīvati iti vuccati yadā na ppavattati
translated: As long as it occurs, the being is said to be living. When it does not occur,

original: tadā mato niruddhoti vuccati.
analyzed: tadā mataḥ niruddhaḥ ti vuccati
translated: then it is said to be ‘ceased’ and ‘disappeared.’

original: Svāyamattho vāpiyā dīpetabbo –
analyzed: svāyamatthaḥ vāpiyā dīpetabbaḥ
translated: This is the meaning that should be expounded:

original: Yathā hi puriso pañcaudakamaggasampannaṃ vāpiṃ kareyya, paṭhamaṃ deve vuṭṭhe pañcahi🔽udakamaggehi udakaṃ pavisitvā antovāpiyaṃ āvāṭe pūreyya, punappunaṃ deve vassante
analyzed: yathā hi purisaḥ pañca odaka magga sampannam vāpim kareyya paṭhamam deve vuṭṭhe pañcahi  udaka maggehi udakam pavisitvā antovāpiyam āvāṭe pūreyya punappunam deve vassante
translated: Just as a man might make a reservoir with five inlets and five outlets,🔽and when the rains had fallen, water from the mountain streams would flow in and fill the reservoir, and then the water would stand still;

original: udakamagge pūretvā gāvutaḍḍhayojanamattaṃ ottharitvā udakaṃ tiṭṭheyya tato tato vissandamānaṃ,🔽atha niddhamanatumbe vivaritvā khettesu kamme kariyamāne udakaṃ nikkhamantaṃ, sassapākakāle
analyzed: udaka magge pūretvā ottharitvā udakam tiṭṭheyya tatas tatas vissandamānam  atha niddhamana tumbe vivaritvā khettesu kamme kariyamāne udakam nikkhamantam sassa pāka kāle
translated: and then when the sun was hot and the wind blew, the water would evaporate and diminish, and then the water would flow out and disappear;

original: (udakaṃ nikkhamantaṃ,) udakaṃ parihīnaṃ “macche gaṇhāmā”ti vattabbataṃ āpajjeyya,
analyzed: udakam nikkhamantam udakam parihīnam macche gaṇhāma iti vattabbatam āpajjeyya
translated: and then when the farmers were ploughing in the fields, the water would flow out and disappear, and then the water would diminish and it would be possible to say that ‘the water has gone down and the fish can be caught’;

original: tato katipāhena āvāṭesuyeva udakaṃ saṇṭhaheyya. Yāva pana taṃ āvāṭesu hoti, tāva
analyzed: tatas katipāhena udakam saṇṭhaheyya yāva pana tam āvāṭesu hoti tāva
translated: and then after a few days the water would settle down in the pools; and as long as it was there,

original: “mahāvāpiyaṃ udakaṃ atthī”ti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Yadā pana tattha chijjati, tadā “vāpiyaṃ
analyzed: mahāvāpiyam udakam atthi iti saṅkham gacchati yadā pana tattha chijjati tadā vāpiyam
translated: it would be reckoned as ‘water in the great reservoir.’ But when it had disappeared there, then it would be possible to say that ‘the water in the great reservoir has disappeared;

original: udakaṃ natthī”ti vuccati, evaṃsampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: udakam natthi iti vuccati evaṃsampadam idam veditabbam
translated: “There is no water,” so too, this should be understood.

original: Paṭhamaṃ deve vassante pañcahi maggehi udake pavisante āvāṭānaṃ pūraṇakālo viya hi
analyzed: paṭhamam deve vassante pañcahi maggehi udake pavisante āvāṭānam pūraṇa kālaḥ viya hi
translated: Just as when the gods first rain down, the time of the filling up of the reservoirs is like

original: paṭhamameva paṭisandhikkhaṇe manodvārikavedanāya vatthurūpe patiṭṭhitakālo, punappunaṃ
analyzed: paṭhamam eva paṭisandhi kkhaṇe manodvārika vedanāya vatthu rūpe patiṭṭhita kālo punappunam
translated: the time of the establishment of the material form that is the basis for the mind-door-adverting feeling at the very first moment of rebirth-linking.

original: deve vassante pañcannaṃ maggānaṃ pūritakālo viya pavatte pañcadvārikavedanāya pavattikālo,
analyzed: deve vassante pañcannam maggānam pūrita kālaḥ viya pavatte pañcadvārika vedanāya pavatti kālaḥ
translated: Just as the time of the filling up of the five paths is like the time of the occurrence of the five-door-adverting feeling in the course of existence.

original: gāvutaḍḍhayojanamattaṃ ajjhottharaṇaṃ viya paṭhamavaye vīsativassakāle rajjanādivasena
analyzed: ajjhottharaṇam viya paṭhama vaye vīsati vassa kāle rajjana ādi vasena
translated: Just as the flooding over of the four leagues is like the time of the excess of passion, etc., in the first stage of life, at the age of twenty,

original: tassā adhimattabalavabhāvo, yāva vāpito udakaṃ na niggacchati, tāva pūrāya vāpiyā🔽ṭhitakālo viya paññāsavassakāle tassā ṭhitakālo, niddhamanatumbesu vivaṭesu kammante
analyzed: tassāḥ adhimatta balava bhāvaḥ yāva vāpitaḥ udakam na niggacchati tāva pūrāya vāpiyā  ṭhita kālaḥ viya paññāsa vassa kāle tassāḥ ṭhita kālaḥ niddhamana tumbesu vivaṭesu kammante
translated: or just as the time of the reservoir’s being full until the water goes out is like the time of its being full until the age of fifty,

original: kariyamāne udakassa nikkhamanakālo viya saṭṭhivassakālato paṭṭhāya tassā parihāni,
analyzed: kariyamāne udakassa nikkhamana kālaḥ viya saṭṭhi vassa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tassā
translated: just as the time of the water’s going out when the sluice gates are opened is like the time of its going out from the age of sixty onwards,

original: udake bhaṭṭhe udakamaggesu parittodakassa ṭhitakālo viya asītinavutivassakāle pañcadvārikavedanāya
analyzed: udake bhaṭṭhe udaka maggesu paritta udakassa ṭhita kālaḥ viya asīti navuti vassa kāle pañcadvārika vedanāya
translated: Just as when water is scarce in a waterless region, the time when the water is standing in the water-courses is short, so too, the time when the five-door feeling is slow is short, which is the time of the eighty-nine years.

original: mandakālo, āvāṭesuyeva udakassa patiṭṭhānakālo viya hadayavatthukoṭiṃ nissāya manodvārikavedanāya
analyzed: manda kālaḥ udakassa patiṭṭhāna kālaḥ viya hadaya vatthu koṭim nissāya manodvārika vedanāya
translated: Just as the time when the water stands in the pits is short, so too, the time when the mind-door feeling occurs is short, which is the time of the last five years.

original: pavattikālo, āvāṭesu parittepi udake sati “vāpiyaṃ udakaṃ atthī”ti vattabbakālo viya🔽yāva sā pavattati, tāva “satto jīvatī”ti vuccati. Yathā pana āvāṭesu udake chinne🔽“natthi vāpiyaṃ udaka”nti vuccati, evaṃ manodvārikavedanāya appavattamānāya “satto
analyzed: pavatti kālaḥ āvāṭesu paritte api udake sati vā api iyam udakam atthi iti vattabba kālaḥ viya  yāva sā pavattati tāva sattaḥ jīvati iti vuccati yathā pana āvāṭesu udake chinne  natthi vā api iyam udakanti vuccati evam manaḥ dvārika vedanāya a pavattamānāya satto
translated: Just as when there is a little water left in the pits it is still possible to say that there is water in the tank,🔽so too, as long as that feeling occurs it is still possible to say that the being is living. But just as when the water in the pits has dried up it is not possible to say that there is water in the tank,

original: mato”ti vuccati. Imaṃ vedanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vediyamāno”ti.
analyzed: mataḥ iti vuccati imam vedanam sandhāya vuttam jīvita pariyantikam vedanam vediyamāno ti
translated: so too, when mind-door feeling no longer occurs it is not possible to say that the being is living. It is this kind of feeling that is referred to in the words, “He feels the kind of feeling that ends with the breakup of the body.”

original: Kāyassa bhedāti kāyassa bhedena. Jīvitapariyādānā uddhanti jīvitakkhayato uddhaṃ.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā ati kāyassa bhedena jīvita pariyādānā uddham ti jīvita kkhayataḥ uddham
translated: With the breakup of the body: with the breakup of the body. When life ends: after the exhaustion of life.

original: Idhevāti paṭisandhivasena parato agantvā idheva. Sītībhavissantīti pavattivipphandadaratharahitāni🔽sītāni appavattanadhammāni bhavissanti. Sarīrānīti dhātusarīrāni. Avasissantīti avasiṭṭhāni bhavissanti.🔽Kumbhakārapākāti kumbhakārassa bhājanapacanaṭṭhānato. Paṭisisseyyāti ṭhapeyya. Kapallānīti🔽saha mukhavaṭṭiyā ekābaddhāni kumbhakapallāni. Avasisseyyunti tiṭṭheyyuṃ. Evameva
analyzed: idhā iva ati paṭisandhi vasena paratas a gantvā idhā iva sītībhavissanti iti pavatti vipphanda da ratha rahitāni  sītāni appavattana dhammāni bhavissanti sarīrāni iti dhātu sarīrāni avasissanti iti avasiṭṭhāni bhavissanti  kumbhakāra pākā ati kumbhakārassa bhājana pacana ṭṭhānato paṭisisseyya ati ṭhapeyya kapallāni iti  saha mukhavaṭṭiyā eka ābaddhāni kumbhaka pallāni avasisseyyun ti tiṭṭheyyuṃ evam eva
translated: ‘Here itself’: not going elsewhere by way of rebirth-linking, but here itself. ‘Will become cool’: they will be cool, devoid of the fever of the process of oscillation.🔽‘Will remain’: they will remain, without any further process of oscillation. ‘The bodies’: the material bodies.🔽‘Like a potter’s cooling’: like a potter’s place for baking his wares. ‘Would set aside’: would put aside. ‘The potsherds’:🔽the potsherds of the pot, together with the mouth-rim, would remain. ‘Would remain’: would stay. ‘Even so’:🔽

original: khoti ettha idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – ādittakumbhakārapāko viya hi tayo bhavā daṭṭhabbā,
analyzed: kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam āditta kumbhakāra pākaḥ viya hi tayaḥ bhavāḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: Here itself : not coming from elsewhere by way of rebirth-linking, but here itself. They will be cool : they will be cool , free from the fever of the process of becoming, not subject to revolution. Bodies : physical bodies. Will remain : will be left. From the potter’s kiln : from the place where the potter bakes his wares. Would take out : would remove. The potsherds : the potsherds of the pot, together with the rim, would remain. Would be left : would be there. In the same way : here is the correspondence of the simile: the three planes of becoming should be regarded as like the potter’s kiln heated with fire,

original: kumbhakāro viya yogāvacaro, pākato kumbhakārabhājanānaṃ nīharaṇadaṇḍako viya arahattamaggañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: kumbhakāraḥ viya yogāvacaraḥ pākataḥ nīharaṇa daṇḍakaḥ viya arahatta magga ñāṇam
translated: the meditator as like the potter, the path knowledge of Arahantship as like the potter’s rod for removing the wares from the kiln,

original: samo bhūmibhāgo viya asaṅkhataṃ nibbānatalaṃ, daṇḍakena uṇhakumbhaṃ ākaḍḍhitvā same
analyzed: samaḥ bhūmi bhāgaḥ viya asaṅkhatam nibbāna talam daṇḍakena uṇha kumbham ākaḍḍhitvā same
translated: the plane of the unformed Nibbāna as like the even ground, the removal of the hot wares from the kiln by the rod and their placing on the even ground,

original: bhūmibhāge kumbhassa ṭhapitakālo viya āraddhavipassakassa rūpasattakaṃ arūpasattakaṃ
analyzed: bhūmi bhāge kumbhassa ṭhapita kālaḥ viya āraddha vipassakassa rūpa sattakam arūpa sattakam
translated: As the time when the pot is placed on the ground, so should be understood the time when the seven kinds of material and immaterial meditation objects appear to the meditator who has begun insight.

original: vipassantassa kammaṭṭhāne ca paguṇe vibhūte upaṭṭhahamāne tathārūpaṃ utusappāyādiṃ🔽labhitvā ekāsane nisinnassa vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ patvā catūhi
analyzed: vipassantassa kammaṭṭhāne ca paguṇe vibhūte upaṭṭhahamāne tathārūpam utusappāya ādim  labhitvā ekāsane nisinnassa vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā agga phalam arahattam patvā catūhi
translated: When the meditation subject is mastered and clear, and appears in this way, then, having obtained suitable weather and so on,🔽he develops insight while sitting in one session only and reaches the supreme fruit, arahatship.

original: apāyehi attabhāvaṃ uddharitvā phalasamāpattivasena asaṅkhate nibbānatale ṭhitakālo

translated: The time when he stands in the deathless state of Nibbāna by lifting himself out of the four states of suffering should be regarded as the time when the pot is lifted off the ground.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Khīṇāsavo pana uṇhakumbho viya arahattappattadivaseyeva na parinibbāti,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ khīṇāsavaḥ pana uṇha kumbhaḥ viya arahatta patta divaseya iva na parinibbāti
translated: But the one whose cankers are destroyed does not attain final Nibbāna on the very day he reaches arahatship, like the hot pot.

original: sāsanappaveṇiṃ pana ghaṭayamāno paṇṇāsasaṭṭhivassāni ṭhatvā carimakacittappattiyā🔽upādiṇṇakakkhandhabhedā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāti. Athassa kumbhassa
analyzed: sāsana ppaveṇim pana ghaṭayamāno paṇṇāsa saṭṭhi vassāni ṭhatvā carimaka citta ppattiyā  upādiṇṇaka khandha bhedā an upādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāti athassa kumbhassa
translated: He lives on for fifty or sixty years, establishing the succession of the Dispensation, and then, by the arising of the last consciousness,🔽he attains final Nibbāna in the Nibbāna element without residue of clinging, like the pot’s being broken. Then only the bones, like the potsherds, remain.

original: viya kapallāni anupādiṇṇakasarīrāneva avasissantīti. Sarīrāni avasissantīti pajānātīti
analyzed: viya kapallāni anupādiṇṇaka sarīrān eva avasissanti iti sarīrāni avasissanti iti pajānāti iti

translated: But this is said for the purpose of urging on one whose cankers are exhausted.🔽“Consciousness would be evident”: rebirth-linking consciousness would be evident.

original: Viññāṇaṃ paññāyethāti paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ paññāyetha. Sādhu sādhūti therānaṃ byākaraṇaṃ🔽sampahaṃsati. Evametanti yadetaṃ tividhe abhisaṅkhāre asati paṭisandhiviññāṇassa
analyzed: viññāṇam paññāyetha ati paṭisandhi viññāṇam paññāyetha sādhu sādhu iti therānam byākaraṇam  sampahaṃsati evam etat ti yat etam tividhe abhisaṅkhāre asati paṭisandhi viññāṇassa
translated: “Good, good!”: he applauds the elders’ reply.🔽“Thus it is”: this is just so, just as it was said that “if the three kinds of determinations do not exist, rebirth-linking consciousness would not be evident, and so on.

original: appaññāṇantiādi, evameva etaṃ. Adhimuccathāti sanniṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ adhimokkhaṃ paṭilabhatha.

original: Esevanto dukkhassāti ayameva vaṭṭadukkhassa anto ayaṃ paricchedo, yadidaṃ nibbānanti. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: esa iva antaḥ dukkhassa ati ayam eva vaṭṭa dukkhassa antaḥ ayam paricchedaḥ yat idam nibbānam ti paṭhamam
translated: “This is the end of suffering”: this is the end, this is the limit of the suffering of the round, namely, Nibbāna. The first sutta is finished.

original: 2. Upādānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upādāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The second sutta

analyzed: dutiye upādāniyesu uti catunnam upādānānam paccayesu tebhūmaka dhammesu assāda anupassino ti

analyzed: etat eva aggi jaggaka purisaḥ viya vaṭṭa nissitaḥ bāla puthujjanaḥ sukkha tiṇa gomaya ādi pakkhipanam  viya assāda anupassino puthujjanassa taṇhā ādi vasena chahi dvārehi kusala akusala kamma karaṇaṃ  tiṇa gomaya ādīsu khīṇesu punappunam tesam pakkhipanena aggi kkhandhassa vaḍḍhanam viya
translated: The fool, the worldling, is like the man who tends the fire. The fool’s performance of profitable and unprofitable actions through the six sense doors by way of craving, etc., is like the man’s putting dry grass, etc., into the fire.

original: bālaputhujjanassa uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya yathāvuttakammāyūhanena aparāparaṃ vaṭṭadukkhanibbattanaṃ.

translated: The fool’s repeated production of the suffering of the round by his accumulation of kamma as described is like the man’s making the mass of flames grow by putting dry grass, etc., into the fire from time to time.

analyzed: na kālena kālam sukkhāni ca iva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya ati tat hi koci attha kāmaḥ evam vadeyya  bho kasmai uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya kalāpe bandhitvā sukkha tiṇaka ṭṭhānam
translated: “He should not put dry grass into it from time to time” is said by one who desires his welfare,

analyzed: pūretvā sukkha gomayāni pakkhipantaḥ etam aggim jālesi api nu te atthi itonidānam

translated: For while tending this fire I cannot bathe, eat, or lie down.

original: hi bho kiṃ te iminā niratthakena aggijālanena? Ehi tvaṃ etāni ābhatāni tiṇādīni ettha🔽nikkhipa, tāni sayameva jhāyissanti, tvaṃ pana asukasmiṃ ṭhāne sītodakā pokkharaṇī
analyzed: hi bho kim te iminā niratthakena aggi jālanena ehi tvam etāni ābhatāni tiṇa ādīni ettha  nikkhipa tāni sayam eva jhāyissanti tvam pana asukasmin ṭhāne sīta udakā pokkharaṇī
translated: “Well then, what is the use of this useless fire-tending? Come, put these brought faggots there,🔽and they will burn by themselves. But there is a lotus-tank with cool water in such-and-such a place.

original: atthi, tattha nhatvā, mālāgandhavilepanehi attānaṃ maṇḍetvā sunivattho supārutova
analyzed: atthi tattha nhatvā mālā gandha vilepanehi attānam maṇḍetvā sunivatthaḥ supārutaḥ iva
translated: Bathe there, adorn yourself with garlands and scents, and then, well dressed and well groomed,

analyzed: nisīda ekaggaḥ sukha samappitaḥ hutvā tattha te nisinnassa tiṇa ādīnam khayena sayam eva  ayam aggi appaṇṇatti bhāvam gamissati iti saḥ tathā kareyya tathā iva ca tattha nisinnassa
translated: attentively enjoying the pleasure of coolness. While you are sitting there,🔽the fire will go out by itself through the exhaustion of the fuel.” He would do as he was told. And the fire would go out in the same way while he was sitting there,

original: so aggi upādānakkhayena appaṇṇattibhāvaṃ gaccheyya. Idaṃ sandhāyetaṃ “na kālena kāla”ntiādi vuttaṃ.

original: Evameva khoti ettha pana idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – cattālīsāya kaṭṭhavāhānaṃ jalamāno🔽mahāaggikkhandho viya hi tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, aggijagganakapuriso viya vaṭṭasannissitako🔽yogāvacaro, atthakāmo puriso viya sammāsambuddho, tena purisena tassa dinnaovādo🔽viya tathāgatena “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, tebhūmakadhammesu nibbinda, evaṃ vaṭṭadukkhā
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha pana idam opamma saṃsandanam cattālīsāya kaṭṭhavāhānam jalamāno  mahā aggi khandhaḥ viya hi tebhūmaka vaṭṭam daṭṭhabbam aggi jagganaka purisaḥ viya vaṭṭa sannissitakaḥ  yogāvacaraḥ attha kāmo puriso viya sammāsambuddho tena purisena tassa dinna ovādaḥ  viya tathāgatena ehi tvam bhikkhu tebhūmaka dhammesu nibbinda evam vaṭṭa dukkhā
translated: Herein, the correlating of the simile should be understood in this way. The triple-world-system should be regarded as the great mass of fire burning with the forty-two types of fuel . The meditator who has entered upon the jhānas supported by the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man who tends the great mass of fire. The Fully Enlightened One should be regarded as the man who desires his welfare. The Blessed One’s advice to him should be regarded as the advice given by the man who desires his welfare. The meditator’s turning away from the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man’s turning away from the great mass of fire. The meditator’s emergence from the jhāna should be regarded as the man’s emergence from the great mass of fire. The meditator’s seeing the danger in the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man’s seeing the danger in the great mass of fire. The meditator’s abandoning of the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man’s abandoning of the great mass of fire. The meditator’s emergence from the jhāna should be regarded as the man’s emergence from the great mass of fire. The meditator’s seeing the danger in the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man’s seeing the danger in the great mass of fire. The meditator’s abandoning of the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man’s abandoning of the great mass of fire.

original: muccissasī”ti tassa tebhūmakadhammesu kammaṭṭhānassa kathitakālo, tassa purisassa🔽yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjitvā pāsāde nisinnakālo viya yogino sugatovādaṃ sampaṭicchitvā🔽suññāgāraṃ paviṭṭhassa tebhūmakadhammesu vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā anukkamena yathānurūpaṃ🔽āhārasappāyādiṃ labhitvā, ekāsane nisinnassa aggaphale patiṭṭhitakālo, tassa nhānavilepanādīhi
analyzed: muccissasi iti tassa tebhūmaka dhammesu kammaṭṭhānassa kathita kālo tassa purisassa 🔽yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjitvā pāsāde nisinna kālaḥ yogino sugata vādam sampaṭicchitvā 🔽suññāgāram paviṭṭhassa tebhūmaka dhammesu vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā anukkamena yathānurūpam 🔽āhāra sappāya ādim labhitvā eka āsane nisinnassa agga phale patiṭṭhita kālaḥ tassa nhāna vilepana ādīhi
translated: Likewise here, the correlating of the similes should be understood as follows. The triple-world-system should be regarded as the great mass of fire burning with forty khattiya fires. The yogi who is dependent on the triple-world-system should be regarded as the man who tends the fire. The Perfect Buddha should be regarded as the man who is well-disposed to him. The time when the Perfect One teaches him the meditation subject consisting in the contemplation of the three kinds of foulness should be regarded as the time when the man says, “Come here, my good man, take this fire produced by rubbing and keep it going.” The yogi’s acceptance of the Blessed One’s advice should be regarded as the man’s acceptance of the advice of the other man. The time when the yogi enters an empty place and begins insight by contemplating the three kinds of foulness should be regarded as the time when the man, acting as advised, sits down on the terrace. The time when the yogi, having accepted the advice of the Perfect One, enters an empty place and begins insight by contemplating the three kinds of foulness and eventually reaches the plane of the noble path in due course by obtaining the requisite food, etc., as he requires, while sitting in a single session should be regarded as the time when the man, acting as advised, sits down on the terrace and so on. The time when the yogi, having reached the plane of the noble path, attains the four jhānas in the fourfold system or the five jhānas in the fivefold system by developing the meditation subject in due course, should be regarded as the time when the man, having sat down on the terrace, etc.,

original: sudhotamaṇḍitakāyattā tasmiṃ nisinnassa ekaggasukhasamappitakālo viya yogino ariyamaggapokkharaṇiyaṃ
analyzed: tasmin nisinnassa ekagga sukha samappita kālaḥ viya yoginaḥ ariya magga pokkharaṇiyam
translated: and the time when he is seated in it is like the time when the meditator is seated in the lotus-tank of the noble path,🔽

original: maggañāṇodakena sunhātasudhotakilesamalassa hirottappasāṭake nivāsetvā sīlavilepanānulittassa
analyzed: magga ñāṇa udakena su nhāta su dhota kilesa malassa hira uttappa sāṭake nivāsetvā sīla vilepana anulittassa

original: arahattamaṇḍanena attabhāvaṃ maṇḍetvā vimuttipupphadāmaṃ piḷandhitvā iddhipādapādukā
analyzed: arahatta maṇḍanena atta bhāvam maṇḍetvā vimutti puppha dāmam piḷandhitvā iddhipāda pādukā
translated: having anointed his person with the unguent of the noble path, having adorned himself with the ornament of Arahantship, having put on the garland of flowers of deliverance, having put on the sandals of the bases of success,

analyzed: āruyha nibbāna nagaram pavisitvā dhammapāsādam āruyha sati paṭṭhāna mahā vīthiyam virocamānassa  nibbāna ārammaṇam phala samāpattim appetvā nisinna kālaḥ tassa pana purisassa tasmin  nisinnassa tiṇa ādīnam khayena aggi kkhandhassa appaṇṇatti gamana kālaḥ viya khīṇa āsavassa
translated: having entered the city of Nibbāna, having ascended to the palace of Dhamma, and having sat down in the great street of the foundations of mindfulness, shining with the light of the path,

translated: just as when the man sits down, the fire goes out owing to the exhaustion of the grass and sticks, so the meditator, having stood as long as he lives, and having attained final Nibbāna in the Nibbāna-element without residue of clinging, owing to the dissolution of the aggregates that were clung to,🔽should be seen as the great extinction of the round of rebirths. The second simile is finished.

original: 3. Saṃyojanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṃyojana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second sutta is finished.

analyzed: tatiye saṃyojaniyesu uti dasannam saṃyojanānam paccayesu jhāyeyya ati jaleyya telam  āsiñceyya vaṭṭim upasaṃhareyya ati dīpa paṭijaggana attham tela bhājanam ca mahantam ca vaṭṭi kapālam  gahetvā samīpe niccam ṭhitaḥ uva tele khīṇe telam āsiñceyya vaṭṭiyā khīṇāya vaṭṭim
translated: In the third of the things that lead to entanglements, in the conditions for the ten fetters. He would light it: he would set it alight.

translated: He would keep it trimmed: he would keep it going by taking a vessel of oil and a large wick-holder and standing near it all the time, and when the oil was used up he would replenish it, and when the wick was used up he would replace it. The rest is as in the foregoing. The third.

original: 4. Dutiyasaṃyojanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya saṃyojana sutta vaṇṇanā

analyzed: pañcame uddham ojam abhiharanti iti pathavī rasam ca āpaḥ rasam ca upari āropenti ojāya

translated: It remains. The application of the simile is this. The triple-rooted tree is like the triple-rooted round of rebirths. The roots are like the bases. translated: It remains. The application of the simile is this. The triple-rooted tree is like the triple-rooted round of rebirths. The roots are like the bases. The climbing up by means of the roots is like the climbing up by means of the six bases. Because of the climbing up by means of the roots, the tree remains as long as it does. The spade and basket are the knowledge and concentration. He would cut it down root and branch: he would cut it down making the small and large pieces. The application of the simile is this. Herein, the triple-rooted round of rebirths is like the triple-rooted tree. The meditator is like the man who wants to destroy the tree. The knowledge is like the spade. The concentration is like the basket. The knowledge is like the axe for cutting down the tree. The time when the tree is cut down at the roots is like the time when the round of rebirths is cut down at the roots by the cutting off of the six bases.

analyzed: pañca yojana satikaḥ ānandaḥ timinandaḥ ajjhārohaḥ mahātimī iti ime cattāraḥ yojana sahassikā  tattha timira piṅgalena iva dīpenti tassa kira dakkhiṇa kaṇṇam cālentassa pañca yojana sate

analyzed: mayam pakkha vāta pattharaṇa ukāsam pi na labhāma ati tattha kāya upapannassa supaṇṇa rañño  ākāsaḥ parittaḥ ti aññesam ca khuddaka pakkhīnam parittaḥ ti na vattabbo evam eva ñāṇa upapannassa
