analyzed: satthā pana ubbedhataḥ aṭṭhapaññāsa hatthaḥ ahosi tassa ubhinnam bāhānam antaram aṭṭhārasa hattham  nalāṭam pañca hattham hattha pādāḥ ekādasa hatthā tassa ekādasa hatthena pādena dvādasa hatthāya

translated: The young man heard this, and thinking to himself, “The Buddhas are not given to idle talk,” on the following day🔽he took the robe and bowl of the Exalted One and followed close behind him.🔽In the dispensation of this Buddha he gave alms for a hundred thousand years, and was reborn in the World of the Gods. In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa he gave a cloak to a monk in order that he might carry in it the bowl of the Buddha.

original: therassa pattaggahaṇatthaṃ uttarisāṭakaṃ datvā pūjaṃ akāsi. Puna sagge nibbattitvā
analyzed: therassa patta ggahaṇa attham uttari sāṭakam da tvā pūjam akāsi puna sagge nibbattitvā
translated: He made an offering to the monk, and was reborn in the World of the Gods.

original: tato cuto bārāṇasirājā hutvā aṭṭhannaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ paṇṇasālāyo kāretvā maṇiādhārake
analyzed: tatas cutaḥ bārāṇasi rājā hutvā aṭṭhannam paccekabuddhānam kāretvā maṇi ādhārake
translated: When he passed from that state of existence, he was reborn king of Benares. He built leaf huts for eight Private Buddhas, and made an offering to them of jeweled couches.

original: upaṭṭhapetvā catūhi paccayehi dasavassasahassāni upaṭṭhānaṃ akāsi. Etāni pākaṭaṭṭhānāni.
analyzed: upaṭṭhapetvā catūhi paccayehi dasa vassa sahassāni upaṭṭhānam akāsi etāni pākaṭa ṭṭhānāni
translated: and for ten thousand years he served him with the four requisites. These are the well-known instances.

original: Kappasatasahassaṃ pana dānaṃ dadamānova amhākaṃ bodhisattena saddhiṃ tusitapure nibbattitvā
analyzed: kappa sata sahassam pana dānam dadamānaḥ iva amhākam bodhisattena saddhim tusitapure nibbattitvā
translated: But for a hundred thousand aeons he was giving gifts, and then he was reborn in the Tusita heaven together with our Bodhisatta.

original: tato cuto amitodanasakkassa gehe paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā anupubbena katābhinikkhamano
analyzed: tatas cutaḥ amitodana sakkassa gehe paṭisandhim gahetvā anupubbena kata abhinikkhamanaḥ
translated: After he had passed away from there and had taken rebirth in the home of Amitodana the Sakka, he eventually went forth into homelessness,🔽and after he had attained omniscience he came to Kapilavatthu on his first wandering tour.

original: sammāsambodhiṃ patvā paṭhamagamanena kapilavatthuṃ āgantvā tato nikkhamante bhagavati
analyzed: sammāsambodhim patvā paṭhama gamanena kapilavatthum āgantvā tatas nikkhamante bhagavati
translated: When the Blessed One was leaving Kapilavatthu,

original: bhagavato parivāratthaṃ rājakumāresu pabbajantesu bhaddiyādīhi saddhiṃ nikkhamitvā🔽bhagavato santike pabbajitvā nacirasseva āyasmato puṇṇassa mantāṇiputtassa santike
analyzed: bhagavataḥ parivāra attham rāja kumāresu pabbajantesu bhaddiya ādīhi saddhim nikkhamitvā  bhagavato santike pabbajitvā nacirassa iva āyasmataḥ puṇṇassa mantāṇi puttassa santike
translated: and when the princes were going forth to be the Blessed One’s attendants, he went forth with them,🔽and after he had gone forth in the Blessed One’s presence, he was soon established in the fruit of stream-entry by the venerable Punna Mantaniputta.

original: dhammakathaṃ sutvā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. Evamesa āyasmā pubbūpanissayasampanno,
analyzed: dhamma katham sutvā sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi evam esa āyasmā pubba upanissaya sampanno
translated: So this venerable one had the requisite of former habit.

original: tassimāya pubbūpanissayasampattiyā gambhīropi paṭiccasamuppādo uttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: tassa imāya pubba upanissaya sampattiyā gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi
translated: And because of this requisite of former habit, the deep Dependent Origination appeared to him as clear as clear could be.

original: Titthavāsoti pana garūnaṃ santike uggahaṇasavanaparipucchanadhāraṇāni vuccanti. So
analyzed: titthavāso ti pana garūnam santike uggahaṇa savana paripucchana dhāraṇāni vuccanti so
translated: “The life of a wanderer” is said to refer to the learning, hearing, questioning, and memorizing that are done in the presence of teachers.🔽This was extremely pure in the Elder,

original: therassa ativiya parisuddho. Tenāpissāyaṃ gambhīropi uttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi. Sotāpannānañca
analyzed: therassa parisuddho tena api ssa ayam gambhīraḥ api uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi sotāpannānam ca
translated: and so the dependent origination, though profound, appeared to him as if it were obvious.🔽And the dependent origination appears to stream-enterers as if it were obvious,

original: nāma paccayākāro uttānako hutvā upaṭṭhāti, ayañca āyasmā sotāpanno. Bahussutānaṃ
analyzed: nāma paccaya ākāraḥ uttānakaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti ayam ca āyasmā sotāpannaḥ bahussutānam
translated: and this venerable one was a stream-enterer.

original: catuhatthe ovarake padīpe jalamāne mañcapīṭhaṃ viya nāmarūpaparicchedo pākaṭo hoti,
analyzed: catuhatthe ovarake padīpe jalamāne mañca pīṭham viya nāma rūpa paricchedaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti
translated: To those who are learned, the discernment of mentality-materiality is as obvious as a bed or chair,

original: ayañca āyasmā bahussutānaṃ aggo. Iti bāhusaccabhāvenapissa gambhīropi paccayākāro🔽uttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi. Paṭiccasamuppādo catūhi gambhīratāhi gambhīro. Sā panassa
analyzed: ayam ca āyasmā bahussutānam aggaḥ iti bāhusacca bhāvena pissa gambhīraḥ api paccaya ākāraḥ  uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi paṭiccasamuppādaḥ catūhi gambhīra tāhi gambhīraḥ sā panassa
translated: and this venerable one was the foremost among the learned. Thus, because of his great learning, the dependent origination, though profound,🔽appeared to him as if it were obvious.🔽The dependent origination is profound because of four kinds of profundity, which are treated in detail in the Visuddhimagga.

original: gambhīratā visuddhimagge vitthāritāva. Sā sabbāpi therassa uttānakā viya upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: gambhīra tā visuddhi magge vitthāritā ava sā sabbā api therassa uttānakā viya upaṭṭhāsi
translated: All of these kinds of profundity appeared to the Elder as if they were obvious.

original: Tena bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ ussādento mā hevantiādimāha. Ayañhettha adhippāyo
analyzed: tena bhagavā āyasmantam ānandam ussādentaḥ mā hevanti ādim āha ayan ha ittha adhippāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the Exalted One, in order to praise the venerable Ānanda, said, “Do not say so, Ānanda.” The intention here is this:

original: – ānanda, tvaṃ mahāpañño visadañāṇo, tena te gambhīropi paṭiccasamuppādo uttānako
analyzed: ānanda tvam mahā paññaḥ visada ñāṇo tena te gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānakaḥ
translated: “Ānanda, you are of great understanding, of clear knowledge. Therefore the deep Dependent Origination appears to you as if it were manifest.

original: viya khāyati. Tasmā “mayhameva nu kho esa uttānako viya hutvā upaṭṭhāti, udāhu aññesampī”ti mā evaṃ avaca.
analyzed: viya khāyati tasmai mayham eva nu kho esaḥ uttānakaḥ viya hutvā upaṭṭhāti udāhu aññesam pi iti mā evam avaca
translated: Therefore do not say: ‘It appears to me as if it were manifest, but does not to others.’

original: Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “apasādento”ti, tatthāyamadhippāyo – ānanda, “atha ca pana me uttānakuttānako🔽viya khāyatī”ti mā hevaṃ avaca. Yadi hi te esa uttānakuttānako viya khāyati, kasmā
analyzed: yam pana vuttam apasādento ti tattha ayam adhippāyaḥ ānanda atha ca pana me uttānakuttānakaḥ  viya khāyati iti mā ha ivam avaca yadi hi te esaḥ uttānaka uttānakaḥ viya khāyati kasmai
translated: But as to what was said: ‘disparaging,’ the meaning here is this: Ānanda, do not say: ‘It appears to me as if it were manifest, but not to others.’

original: tvaṃ attano dhammatāya sotāpanno nāhosi, mayā dinnanaye ṭhatvā sotāpattimaggaṃ paṭivijjhi?
analyzed: tvam attanaḥ dhammatāya sotāpannaḥ na ahosi mayā dinna naye ṭhatvā sotāpatti maggam paṭivijjhi
translated: For if it appeared to you as if it were manifest, why did you not become a stream-enterer by your own understanding, and only afterwards penetrate the path of stream-entry by following my instructions?

original: Ānanda, idaṃ nibbānameva gambhīraṃ, paccayākāro pana uttānako jāto, atha kasmā oḷārikaṃ
analyzed: ānanda idam nibbānam eva gambhīram paccaya ākāraḥ pana uttānakaḥ jātaḥ atha kasmai oḷārikam
translated: Ānanda, this Nibbāna is indeed deep, but the principle of conditionality has become manifest to you.

original: kāmarāgasaṃyojanaṃ paṭighasaṃyojanaṃ oḷārikaṃ kāmarāgānusayaṃ paṭighānusayanti ime
analyzed: kāma rāga saṃyojanam paṭigha saṃyojanam oḷārikam kāma rāga anusayam paṭigha anusayanti ime
translated: Then why did you abandon the gross fetter of sensual lust, the gross fetter of resistance, the gross underlying tendency to sensual lust, and the gross underlying tendency to resistance,

original: cattāro kilese samugghātetvā sakadāgāmiphalaṃ na sacchikarosi, teyeva aṇusahagate
analyzed: cattāro kilese samugghātetvā sakadāgāmi phalam na sacchikarosi aṇu sahagate
translated: You have not realized the fruit of Once-Returner after eradicating the four defilements. You have not realized the fruit of Non-Returner after eradicating the four defilements that are to be abandoned by the path of cultivation. You have not realized the state of Worthiness after eradicating the five fetters of the form-sphere,

original: cattāro kilese samugghātetvā anāgāmiphalaṃ na sacchikarosi, rūparāgādīni pañca saṃyojanāni,🔽mānānusayaṃ bhavarāgānusayaṃ avijjānusayanti ime aṭṭha kilese samugghātetvā arahattaṃ🔽na sacchikarosi? Kasmā vā satasahassakappādhikaṃ ekaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ pūritapāramino🔽sāriputtamoggallānā viya sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ na paṭivijjhasi, satasahassakappādhikāni🔽dve asaṅkhyeyyāni pūritapāramino paccekabuddhā viya ca paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ na paṭivijjhasi?
analyzed: cattāro kilese samugghātetvā anāgāmi phalam na sacchikarosi rūpa rāga ādīni pañca saṃyojanāni  māna anusayam bhava rāga anusayam avijjā anusayanti ime aṭṭha kilese samugghātetvā arahattam  na sacchikarosi kasmai vā sata sahassa kappa adhikam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam pūrita pāramino  sāriputta moggallānā viya sāvaka pāramīñāṇam na paṭivijjhasi sata sahassa kappa adhikāni  dve asaṅkhyeyyāni pūrita pāramino paccekabuddhāḥ viya ca pacceka bodhi ñāṇam na paṭivijjhasi
translated: the five fetters of the formless-sphere, the five lower fetters, the five higher fetters, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance,

original: Yadi vā te sabbathāva esa uttānako hutvā upaṭṭhāsi. Atha kasmā satasahassakappādhikāni🔽cattāri aṭṭha soḷasa vā asaṅkhyeyyāni pūritapāramino buddhā viya sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ
analyzed: yadi vā te sabbathāva esaḥ uttānakaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāsi atha kasmā sata sahassa kappa adhikāni 🔽cattāri aṭṭha soḷasa vā asaṅkhyeyyāni pūrita pāraminaḥ buddhāḥ viya sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds of conceit, the five kinds of views, the five kinds of ignorance, the five kinds of craving, the five kinds

original: na sacchikarosi? Kiṃ anatthikosi etehi visesādhigamehi? Passa yāva ca te aparaddhaṃ,
analyzed: na sacchikarosi kim anatthikaḥ asi etehi visesa adhigamehi passa yāva ca te aparaddham
translated: “Do you not realize it? Are you not interested in these special attainments? See how far you have strayed,

original: tvaṃ nāma sāvakapadesañāṇe ṭhito atigambhīraṃ paccayākāraṃ “uttānako viya me upaṭṭhātī”ti
analyzed: tvam nāma sāvaka padesa ñāṇe ṭhitaḥ ati gambhīram paccaya ākāram uttānakaḥ viya me upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: “You, who are standing on the level of knowledge of the disciples’ stage, say that the very profound principle of conditionality appears to you as clear as clear can be.🔽This statement of yours is contrary to the teaching of the Buddhas. It is not proper for a bhikkhu like you

original: vadasi. Tassa te idaṃ vacanaṃ buddhānaṃ kathāya paccanīkaṃ hoti. Tādisena nāma bhikkhunā🔽buddhānaṃ kathāya paccanīkaṃ kathetabbanti na yuttametaṃ. Nanu mayhaṃ, ānanda, imaṃ🔽paccayākāraṃ paṭivijjhituṃ vāyamantasseva kappasatasahassādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: vadasi tassa te idam vacanam buddhānam kathāya paccanīkam hoti tādisena nāma bhikkhunā  buddhānam kathāya paccanīkam kathetabbanti na yuttam etam nanu mayham ānanda imaṃ  paccaya ākāram paṭivijjhitum vā āyamantassa iva kappa sata sahassa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: to speak in a way contrary to the teaching of the Buddhas.🔽“Ānanda, it was only when I was striving to penetrate this principle of conditionality that four incalculables and a hundred thousand eons were wiped out for me.

original: atikkantāni. Paccayākārapaṭivijjhanatthāya ca pana me adinnadānaṃ nāma natthi, apūritapāramī
analyzed: atikkantāni paccaya ākāra paṭivijjhana atthāya ca pana me adinna dānam nāma natthi a pūrita pāramī
translated: And in my quest to penetrate the principle of conditionality, there is no gift I did not give, no virtue I did not practice, no patience I did not cultivate, no energy I did not arouse, no concentration I did not develop, no wisdom I did not cultivate.

original: nāma natthi. “Ajja paccayākāraṃ paṭivijjhissāmī”ti pana me nirussāhaṃ viya mārabalaṃ
analyzed: nāma natthi ajja paccaya ākāram paṭivijjhissāmi iti pana me nirussāham viya māra balam
translated: But I never thought: ‘Today I shall penetrate the principle of conditionality.’ It was as if I had taken up a sword against Māra’s army.

original: vidhamantassa ayaṃ mahāpathavī dvaṅgulamattampi nākampi, tathā paṭhamayāme pubbenivāsaṃ,
analyzed: vidhamantassa ayam mahā pathavī dvaṅgula mattam pi nākam pi tathā paṭhama yāme pubbenivāsam
translated: And so too in the first watch of the night when he was recollecting his past lives,🔽and in the middle watch of the night when he was perfecting the divine eye.

original: majjhimayāme dibbacakkhuṃ sampādentassa. Pacchimayāme pana me balavapaccūsasamaye,
analyzed: majjhima yāme dibba cakkhum sampādentassa pacchima yāme pana me balava paccūsa samaye
translated: But in the last watch of the night, at the break of day,

original: “avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ navahi ākārehi paccayo hotī”ti diṭṭhamatteyeva dasasahassilokadhātu🔽ayadaṇḍena ākoṭitakaṃsathālo viya viravasataṃ viravasahassaṃ muñcamānā vātāhate paduminipaṇṇe
analyzed: avijjā saṅkhārānam navahi ākārehi paccayaḥ hoti iti diṭṭhamattā iya iva dasa sahassi lokadhātu  ākoṭita kaṃsa thālaḥ viya virava satam virava sahassam muñcamānā vāta āhate
translated: as soon as he saw the twelve aspects of the three characteristics in the dependent origination, the ten-thousandfold world system quaked,🔽and the earth gods let loose a cry, “We are impermanent, we are impermanent!”🔽And the sound of it spread as far as the Brahmā-world.🔽And the great earth quaked in six ways, moved, trembled, quivered, and shook in six ways, moved, trembled, quivered, and shook all over, as if an oil-wheel had been set spinning.

original: udakabindu viya pakampittha. Evaṃ gambhīro cāyaṃ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso
analyzed: udaka bindu viya pakampittha evam gambhīraḥ ca ayam ānanda paṭiccasamuppādaḥ gambhīra avabhāso
translated: And so this dependent origination is deep, Ānanda, and it appears deep to you,

original: ca, etassa, ānanda, dhammassa ananubodhā…pe… nātivattatīti.
analyzed: ca etassa ānanda dhammassa an anubodhāpe na ativattati iti
translated: because you have not understood it … you have not penetrated it.”

original: Etassa dhammassāti etassa paccayadhammassa. Ananubodhāti ñātapariññāvasena ananubujjhanā.
analyzed: etassa dhammassa ati etassa paccaya dhammassa ananubodhā ati ñāta pariññā vasena ananubujjhanā
translated: “This Dhamma”: this dependent-originated state. “Not understood”: not understood by means of full-understanding as knowledge.

original: Appaṭivedhāti tīraṇappahānapariññāvasena appaṭivijjhanā. Tantākulakajātāti tantaṃ
analyzed: appaṭivedhā ti tīraṇa pahāna pariññā vasena appaṭivijjhanā tanta ākulaka jātā ati tantam
translated: “Not penetrated”: not penetrated by means of full-understanding as abandoning. “Tangled”: entangled with the tangle of craving.

original: viya ākulajātā. Yathā nāma dunnikkhittaṃ mūsikacchinnaṃ pesakārānaṃ tantaṃ tahiṃ🔽tahiṃ ākulaṃ hoti, “idaṃ aggaṃ, idaṃ mūla”nti aggena vā aggaṃ, mūlena vā mūlaṃ samānetuṃ
analyzed: viya ākula jātāḥ yathā nāma dunnikkhittam mūsika chinnam pesaka ārānam tantam tahim  tahim ākulam hoti idam aggam idam mūlam ti aggena vā aggam mūlena vā mūlam samānetum
translated: They are like a tangled skein of thread.🔽Just as a skein of thread badly put up by weavers, cut by rats, is all in a tangle here and there, and it is hard to get the beginning or end of the thread,

original: dukkaraṃ hoti. Evameva sattā imasmiṃ paccayākāre khalitā ākulā byākulā honti, na
analyzed: dukkaram hoti evam eva sattāḥ imasmin paccaya ākāre khalitāḥ ākulāḥ byākulāḥ honti na
translated: to get the beginning with the beginning or the end with the end, so too, beings are confused, bewildered, and perplexed about this dependent origination,🔽and they are unable to straighten out the dependent origination.

original: sakkonti paccayākāraṃ ujuṃ kātuṃ. Tattha tantaṃ paccattapurisakāre ṭhatvā sakkāpi
analyzed: sakkonti paccaya ākāram ujum kātum tattha tantam paccatta purisakāre ṭhatvā sakkā api
translated: Herein, it might be possible to straighten out the skein by standing over it and working on it,

original: bhaveyya ujuṃ kātuṃ, ṭhapetvā pana dve bodhisatte añño satto attano dhammatāya paccayākāraṃ
analyzed: bhaveyya ujum kātum ṭhapetvā pana dve bodhisatte aññaḥ satto attanaḥ dhammatāya paccayākāram
translated: but apart from the two Bodhisattas no other being is able to straighten out the dependent origination by himself.

original: ujuṃ kātuṃ samattho nāma natthi. Yathā pana ākulaṃ tantaṃ kañjiyaṃ datvā kocchena
analyzed: ujum kātum samatthaḥ nāma na atthi yathā pana ākulam tantam kañjiyam da tvā kocchena
translated: But just as the tangled skein, when it is put on the shuttlecock and beaten with the bat,

original: pahaṭaṃ tattha tattha guḷakajātaṃ hoti gaṇṭhibaddhaṃ, evamime sattā paccayesu pakkhalitvā
analyzed: pahaṭam tattha tattha guḷaka jātam hoti gaṇṭhi baddham evam ime sattā paccayesu pakkhalitvā
translated: becomes knotted here and there, so too, these beings, having slipped into the conditions,

original: paccaye ujuṃ kātuṃ asakkontā dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatavasena guḷakajātā honti gaṇṭhibaddhā.
analyzed: paccaye ujum kātum a sakkontāḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata vasena guḷaka jātāḥ honti gaṇṭhi baddhāḥ
translated: are unable to straighten out the conditions, and they become knotted up in the sixty-two views.

original: Ye hi keci diṭṭhiyo sannissitā, sabbe te paccayaṃ ujuṃ kātuṃ asakkontāyeva.
analyzed: ye hi keci diṭṭhiyaḥ sannissitā sabbe te paccayam ujum kātum a sakkontāya iva
translated: For whatever views there are that are dependent, all of them are only because of the inability to make straight the conditions.

original: Kulāgaṇṭhikajātāti kulāgaṇṭhikaṃ vuccati pesakārakañjiyasuttaṃ. Kulā nāma sakuṇikā,
analyzed: kulāgaṇṭhika jātā ati kulāgaṇṭhikam vuccati pesakārakañjiya suttam kulā nāma sa kuṇikā
translated: “They are born as a knot in a tree” : the knot in a tree is said to be the Pesakārakañjiya Sutta. A kulā is a bird.

original: tassā kulāvakotipi eke. Yathā hi tadubhayampi ākulaṃ aggena vā aggaṃ, mūlena vā mūlaṃ
analyzed: eke yathā hi tat ubhayam pi ākulam aggena vā aggam mūlena vā mūlam
translated: Some say that it is a kulāvaka. For just as it is difficult to make the top meet the top or the bottom meet the bottom of both of them,

original: samānetuṃ dukkaranti purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: samānetum purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: it should be construed in the same way as before.

original: Muñjapabbajabhūtāti muñjatiṇaṃ viya pabbajatiṇaṃ viya ca bhūtā tādisā jātā. Yathā
analyzed: muñja pabbaja bhūtā ati muñja tiṇam viya pabbaja tiṇam viya ca bhūtā tādisā jātā yathā
translated: “They are born as a reed or a bamboo” : they are born as such. For just as it is difficult to make the top meet the top or the bottom meet the bottom of those reeds

original: hi tāni tiṇāni koṭṭetvā katarajju jiṇṇakāle katthaci patitaṃ gahetvā tesaṃ tiṇānaṃ🔽“idaṃ aggaṃ, idaṃ mūla”nti aggena vā aggaṃ, mūlena vā mūlaṃ samānetuṃ dukkaraṃ, tampi
analyzed: hi tāni tiṇāni koṭṭetvā kata rajju jiṇṇa kāle katthaci patitam gahetvā tesam tiṇānam  idam aggam idam mūlam ti aggena vā aggam mūlena vā mūlam samānetum dukkaram
translated: by cutting them and taking hold of them somewhere when the rope is old,

original: paccattapurisakāre ṭhatvā sakkā bhaveyya ujuṃ kātuṃ, ṭhapetvā pana dve bodhisatte
analyzed: paccatta purisakāre ṭhatvā sakkā bhaveyya ujum kātum ṭhapetvā pana dve bodhisatte
translated: it is possible to make them straight by standing on one’s own effort, but except for the two Bodhisattas

original: añño satto attano dhammatāya paccayākāraṃ ujuṃ kātuṃ samattho nāma natthi, evamayaṃ🔽pajā paccayaṃ ujuṃ kātuṃ asakkontī diṭṭhigatavasena gaṇṭhikajātā hutvā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ
analyzed: aññaḥ sattaḥ attanaḥ dhamma tāya paccaya ākāram ujum kātum samatthaḥ nāma na atthi evam ayam  pajā paccayam ujum kātum asakkontī diṭṭhigata vasena gaṇṭhika jātā hutvā apāyam duggatim
translated: There is no other being who can make the principle of conditionality straight by his own power. Thus this generation,🔽unable to make the principle of conditionality straight, is entangled in the net of views and does not go beyond the cycle of existence with its three realms,

original: vinipātaṃ saṃsāraṃ nātivattati.🔽Tattha apāyoti nirayatiracchānayonipettivisayaasurakāyā. Sabbepi hi te vaḍḍhisaṅkhātassa
analyzed: vinipātam saṃsāram na ativattati  tattha apāyo ti niraya tiracchāna yoni petti visaya asura kāyā sabbe pi hi te vaḍḍhi saṅkhātassa
translated: its four planes of existence, and its five destinations.🔽Herein, the three lower realms are the hell realm, the animal realm, and the realm of ghosts. For all these are called “lower realms” because they lack the increase of the good, which is called “wealth” .

original: ayassa abhāvato “apāyo”ti vuccati, tathā dukkhassa gatibhāvato duggati, sukhasamussayato🔽vinipatitattā vinipāto. Itaro pana –
analyzed: ayassa abhāvataḥ apāyaḥ ti vuccati tathā dukkhassa gati bhāvataḥ duggati sukha samussayato  vinipatita ttā vinipātaḥ itaraḥ pana
translated: Likewise, they are “evil destinations” because they are the going of suffering, and “abysses” because they are the falling away from happiness. The other realms are called “the cycle of existence” in the sense of cycling round and in the sense of being whirled round.

original: “Khandhānañca paṭipāṭi, dhātuāyatanāna ca;
analyzed: khandhānam ca paṭipāṭi dhātu āyatanāna ca
translated: “The succession of aggregates, And of elements and sense bases,

original: Abbhocchinnaṃ vattamānā, saṃsāroti pavuccati”.
analyzed: vattamānā saṃsāro ti pavuccati
translated: Whirling on, with no beginning, Is called the ‘cycle of existence.’“

original: Taṃ sabbampi nātivattati nātikkamati, atha kho cutito paṭisandhiṃ, paṭisandhito cutinti
analyzed: tam sabbam pi na ativattati na atikkamati atha kho cutitaḥ paṭisandhim paṭisandhitaḥ cutim ti
translated: One does not go beyond, does not get beyond, this cycle of existence. Instead, one goes again and again from death to rebirth-linking and from rebirth-linking to death,

original: evaṃ punappunaṃ cutipaṭisandhiyo gaṇhamānā tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu
analyzed: evam punappunam cuti paṭisandhiyaḥ gaṇhamānā tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu
translated: and thus one is caught up in the round of death and rebirth-linking in the three realms, the four planes of existence, and the five destinations.

original: sattasu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu navasu sattāvāsesu mahāsamudde vātakkhittā nāvā viya yante
analyzed: sattasu viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu navasu sattāvāsesu mahā samudde vāta khittāḥ nāvāḥ viya yante
translated: He wanders about like a ship on the ocean driven by the wind, or like a bull with a rope through its nose.

original: yuttagoṇo viya ca paribbhamatiyeva. Iti sabbametaṃ bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ apasādento
analyzed: yutta goṇaḥ viya ca iti sabbam etam bhagavā āyasmantam ānandam apasādentaḥ
translated: The Blessed One said this in order to dissuade the venerable Ānanda.

original: āha. Sesamettha vuttanayamevāti. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: āha sesam ettha vutta nayam evā ti dasamam
translated: The rest is as already stated. The tenth chapter.

original: Dukkhavaggo chaṭṭho.
analyzed: dukkha vaggaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ
translated: The sixth vagga, the Vagga on Suffering, is finished.

original: 7. Mahāvaggo
analyzed: mahāvaggo
translated: The Great Chapter

original: 1. Assutavāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽61. Mahāvaggassa paṭhame assutavāti khandhadhātuāyatanapaccayākārasatipaṭṭhānādīsu
analyzed: mahāvaggassa paṭhame khandha dhātu āyatana paccaya ākāra sati paṭṭhāna ādīsu
translated: The First Unlearned Section

original: uggahaparipucchāvinicchayarahito. Puthujjanoti puthūnaṃ nānappakārānaṃ kilesādīnaṃ
analyzed: uggaha paripucchā vinicchaya rahitaḥ puthujjanaḥ ti puthūnam nānappakārānam kilesa ādīnam
translated: In the first sutta of the Great Chapter, the unlearned is one who is devoid of learning, questioning, and discernment about the aggregates, elements, sense bases, conditions, aspects of the foundations of mindfulness, and so on.🔽The worldling is one who gives rise to various defilements and so on.

original: jananādikāraṇehi puthujjano. Vuttañhetaṃ – “puthu kilese janentīti puthujjanā”ti🔽sabbaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ. Apica puthūnaṃ gaṇanapathamatītānaṃ ariyadhammaparammukhānaṃ
analyzed: janana ādi kāraṇehi puthujjanaḥ vuttam ha etam puthu kilese janenti iti puthujjanāti  sabbam vitthāretabbam apica puthūnam gaṇana patham atītānam ariya dhamma parammukhānam
translated: For this is said: “They give rise to various defilements, thus they are worldlings.”🔽All should be expanded. Moreover, the worldling is included among those who have gone beyond the count of many, who are averse to the noble Dhamma,

original: nīcadhammasamācārānaṃ janānaṃ antogadhattāpi puthujjano, puthu vā ayaṃ visuṃyeva
analyzed: nīca dhamma samācārānam janānam puthujjanaḥ puthu vā ayam
translated: who behave in a low way. He is also a worldling because he is separate, distinct,

original: saṅkhaṃ gato, visaṃsaṭṭho sīlasutādiguṇayuttehi ariyehi janoti puthujjano. Evametehi
analyzed: saṅkham gataḥ visaṃsaṭṭhaḥ sīla suta ādi guṇa yuttehi ariyehi janoti puthujjanaḥ evam etehi
translated: He is called a “person” because he has gone into a group , and he is called “ordinary” because he is not associated with the noble ones who are endowed with virtue, etc. Thus he is called “an ordinary man who has not heard” by means of these two terms.

original: “assutavā puthujjano”ti dvīhipi padehi ye te –🔽“Duve puthujjanā vuttā, buddhenādiccabandhunā;
analyzed: assutavā puthujjanoti dvīhi pi padehi ye te  duve puthujjanāḥ vuttāḥ buddhena adicca bandhunā
translated: As to the two terms “ordinary man” and “unlearned” ,

original: Andho puthujjano eko, kalyāṇeko puthujjano”ti. ; –
analyzed: andhaḥ puthujjanaḥ ekaḥ kalyāṇa ekaḥ puthujjano ti
translated: “Two kinds of ordinary men are mentioned By the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun: The blind ordinary man is one, And one is called the fair-weather friend. ”🔽Of these two kinds of ordinary men, the blind ordinary man is included here.

original: Dve puthujjanā vuttā, tesu andhaputhujjano gahito. Imasminti paccuppannapaccakkhakāyaṃ
analyzed: dve puthujjanāḥ vuttā tesu andha puthujjanaḥ gahitaḥ imasmin ti paccuppanna paccakkha kāyam
translated: In this: he shows the present visible body.

original: dasseti. Cātumahābhūtikasminti catumahābhūtakāye catumahābhūtehi nibbatte catumahābhūtamayeti🔽attho. Nibbindeyyāti ukkaṇṭheyya. Virajjeyyāti na rajjeyya. Vimucceyyāti muccitukāmo
analyzed: dassa iti cātumahābhūtikasmin ti catu mahābhūta kāye catu mahābhūtehi nibbatte catu mahābhūta maya iti  attho nibbindeyya ati ukkaṇṭheyya virajjeyya ati na rajjeyya vimucceyya ati muccitu kāmo
translated: In the four-element class: in the body consisting of the four great primaries, born of the four great primaries, is the meaning.🔽He would become disenchanted: he would become disgusted. He would become dispassionate: he would not be passionate. He would be liberated: he would be desirous of being liberated.

original: bhaveyya. Ācayoti vuḍḍhi. Apacayoti parihāni. Ādānanti nibbatti. Nikkhepananti bhedo.
analyzed: bhaveyya ācayo ti vuḍḍhi apacayo ti parihāni ādāna nti nibbatti nikkhepana nti bhedaḥ
translated: Increase: growth. Decrease: loss. Taking up: rebirth. Giving up: dissolution.

original: Tasmāti yasmā ime cattāro vuḍḍhihāninibbattibhedā paññāyanti, tasmā taṃkāraṇāti attho.
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai ime cattāro vuḍḍhi hāni nibbatti bhedā paññāyanti tasmā attho
translated: Therefore: because these four kinds of growth, loss, rebirth, and dissolution are evident, therefore, is the meaning.

original: Iti bhagavā cātumahābhūtike kāye rūpaṃ pariggahetuṃ ayuttarūpaṃ katvā arūpaṃ pariggahetuṃ
analyzed: iti bhagavā cātumahābhūtike kāye rūpam pariggahetum ayutta rūpam katvā arūpam pariggahetum
translated: So the Blessed One, having made the form that should be discerned in the four-constituent body the inferior form, makes the formless that should be discerned the superior form.

original: yuttarūpaṃ karoti. Kasmā? Tesañhi bhikkhūnaṃ rūpasmiṃ gāho balavā adhimatto, tena
analyzed: yutta rūpam karoti kasmā tesam hi bhikkhūnam rūpasmim gāhaḥ balavā adhimattaḥ tena
translated: Why? Because the bhikkhus’ apprehension of form is strong and excessive,

original: tesaṃ rūpe gāhassa pariggahetabbarūpataṃ dassetvā nikkaḍḍhanto arūpe patiṭṭhāpanatthaṃ evamāha.🔽Cittantiādi sabbaṃ manāyatanasseva nāmaṃ. Tañhi cittavatthutāya cittagocaratāya sampayuttadhammacittatāya
analyzed: tesam rūpe gāhassa pariggahetabba rūpa tam dassetvā nikkaḍḍhantaḥ arūpe patiṭṭhāpana attham evam āha  citta ntiādi sabbam manāyatanassa iva nāmam tat hi citta vatthu tāya citta gocara tāya sampayutta dhamma citta tāya
translated: so he says this in order to show that the form to be discerned is the form to be eliminated by substitution of opposites and in order to establish them in the formless.🔽The word mind, etc., are all names for the mind base. For that is called mind because it is the basis of cognizance, because it is the domain of cognizance, and because it is the cognizance of associated states;

original: ca cittaṃ, mananaṭṭhena mano, vijānanaṭṭhena viññāṇanti vuccati. Nālanti na samattho.🔽Ajjhositanti taṇhāya gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā gahitaṃ. Mamāyitanti taṇhāmamattena
analyzed: ca cittam manana ṭṭhena manaḥ vijānana ṭṭhena viññāṇanti vuccati na alam ti na samattho  taṇhāya gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā gahitam mamāyitanti taṇhā mamattena
translated: it is called mind because it accumulates, and it is called consciousness because it is the knowing of objects.

original: mama idanti gahitaṃ. Parāmaṭṭhanti diṭṭhiyā parāmasitvā gahitaṃ. Etaṃ mamāti taṇhāgāho,
analyzed: mama idam ti gahitam parāmaṭṭhanti diṭṭhiyā parāmasitvā gahitam etam mama ati taṇhā gāho
translated: It is clung to by craving: it is held by swallowing it with craving and by completing it. It is regarded as “I” and “mine”: it is held by swallowing it with craving and by completing it. It is misconstrued by views: it is held by misconstruing it with views. This is the misapprehension of a self by craving.

original: tena aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritaṃ gahitaṃ hoti. Esohamasmīti mānagāho, tena nava mānā🔽gahitā honti. Eso me attāti diṭṭhigāho, tena dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo gahitā honti. Tasmāti
analyzed: tena aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritam gahitam hoti esa uham asmi iti māna gāho tena nava mānā  gahitāḥ honti esaḥ me attā ati diṭṭhi gāho tena dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ gahitāḥ honti tasmā iti
translated: thus the eighty-eight ways of behaviour of craving are included. The assumption of “I am” is the assumption of conceit, thus the nine conceits are included. The assumption of “This is my self” is the assumption of views, thus the sixty-two views are included. Therefore

original: yasmā evaṃ dīgharattaṃ gahitaṃ, tasmā nibbindituṃ na samattho.🔽Varaṃ, bhikkhaveti idaṃ kasmā āha? Paṭhamañhi tena rūpaṃ pariggahetuṃ ayuttarūpaṃ🔽kataṃ, arūpaṃ yuttarūpaṃ, atha “tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ rūpato gāho nikkhamitvā arūpaṃ gato”ti
analyzed: yasmai evam dīgharattam gahitam tasmai nibbinditum na samatthaḥ  varam bhikkhave iti idam kasmai āha paṭhamam hi tena rūpam pariggahetum ayutta rūpam  katam arūpam yutta rūpam atha tesam bhikkhūnam rūpataḥ gāhaḥ nikkhamitvā arūpam gataḥ ti
translated: Thus the eighty-eight ways of conceiving craving are included. The conceit “I am” is a grasping; thus the nine kinds of conceit are included. The view “This is my self” is a grasping; thus the sixty-two views are included. Therefore: because it has been grasped for so long, one is unable to become dispassionate.

original: ñatvā taṃ nikkaḍḍhituṃ imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha attato upagaccheyyāti attāti gaṇheyya.🔽Bhiyyopīti vassasatato uddhampi. Kasmā pana bhagavā evamāha? Kiṃ atirekavassasataṃ
analyzed: ñatvā tam nikkaḍḍhitum imam desanam ārabhi tattha attataḥ upagaccheyya ati attā ati gaṇheyya  bhiyyas api iti vassa satataḥ uddham pi kasmai pana bhagavā evam āha kim atireka vassa satam
translated: Why did the Exalted One say, “It would be better, bhikkhus”? For the first time he had made non-sensuous form a suitable object for grasping. Sensuous form was a suitable object for grasping. Then, knowing that the bhikkhus’ grasping had emerged from sensuous form and had gone to non-sensuous form, he began this teaching in order to remove that grasping. Herein, he would take it as self means he would grasp it as self.

original: tiṭṭhamānaṃ rūpaṃ nāma atthi? Nanu paṭhamavaye pavattaṃ rūpaṃ majjhimavayaṃ na pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: tiṭṭhamānam rūpam nāma atthi nanu paṭhama vaye pavattam rūpam majjhima vayam na pāpuṇāti
translated: For a hundred years means for more than a hundred years. But why did the Exalted One say this? Is there any form that lasts for more than a hundred years? Does not the form that occurs in the first stage of life not reach the middle stage of life?

original: majjhimavaye pavattaṃ pacchimavayaṃ, purebhatte pavattaṃ pacchābhattaṃ, pacchābhatte
analyzed: majjhima vaye pavattam pacchima vayam purebhatte pavattam pacchābhattam pacchābhatte
translated: and the latter part of the middle period does not reach the latter part of the later period. The time after the morning meal does not reach the time after the midday meal.

original: pavattaṃ paṭhamayāmaṃ, paṭhamayāme pavattaṃ majjhimayāmaṃ, majjhimayāme pavattaṃ
analyzed: pavattam paṭhama yāmam paṭhama yāme pavattam majjhima yāmam majjhima yāme pavattam
translated: The first watch of the night does not reach the middle watch of the night. The middle watch of the night does not reach the last watch of the night.

original: pacchimayāmaṃ na pāpuṇāti? Tathā gamane pavattaṃ ṭhānaṃ, ṭhāne pavattaṃ nisajjaṃ,
analyzed: pacchima yāmam na pāpuṇāti tathā gamane pavattam ṭhānam ṭhāne pavattam nisajjam
translated: So too, the time of walking does not reach the time of standing, the time of standing does not reach the time of sitting,

original: nisajjāya pavattaṃ sayanaṃ na pāpuṇāti. Ekairiyāpathepi pādassa uddharaṇe pavattaṃ🔽atiharaṇaṃ, atiharaṇe pavattaṃ vītiharaṇaṃ, vītiharaṇe pavattaṃ vossajjanaṃ, vossajjane
analyzed: nisajjāya pavattam sayanam na pāpuṇāti eka eriyāpathe pi pādassa uddharaṇe pavattam  atiharaṇam atiharaṇe pavattam vītiharaṇam vītiharaṇe pavattam vossajjanam vossajjane
translated: the time of sitting does not reach the time of lying down. And in the case of a single action, the lifting up of the foot does not reach the moving forward,

original: pavattaṃ sannikkhepanaṃ, sannikkhepane pavattaṃ sannirujjhanaṃ na pāpuṇāti, tattha
analyzed: pavattam sannikkhepanam sannikkhepane pavattam sannirujjhanam na pāpuṇāti tattha
translated: the moving forward does not reach the putting down. The placing does not reach the pressing down.🔽The pressing down does not reach the spreading out. And there the formations break up,

original: tattheva odhi odhi pabbaṃ pabbaṃ hutvā tattakapāle pakkhittatilā viya paṭapaṭāyantā
analyzed: tattha iva odhi odhi pabbam pabbam hutvā tatta kapāle pakkhitta tilāḥ viya paṭapaṭāyantā
translated: breaking up here and there, crackling and crumbling away like sesame seeds put into a hot pan.

original: saṅkhārā bhijjantīti? Saccametaṃ. Yathā pana padīpassa jalato jātā taṃ taṃ vaṭṭippadesaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ bhijjanti iti saccam etam yathā pana padīpassa jalataḥ jātā tam tam vaṭṭi ppadesam
translated: Is this so? Yes, it is. But just as when a lamp is burning the flame that arises in the first part of the wick does not reach the second part,

original: anatikkamitvā tattha tattheva bhijjati, atha ca pana paveṇisambandhavasena sabbarattiṃ
analyzed: an atikkamitvā tattha tattha iva bhijjati atha ca pana paveṇi sambandha vasena sabbarattim
translated: and it breaks up there and then without going beyond that place, and yet, by the connection of the series,🔽

original: jalito padīpoti vuccati, evamidhāpi paveṇivasena ayampi kāyo evaṃ ciraṭṭhitiko viya katvā dassito.
analyzed: jalito padīpaḥ ti vuccati evam idha api paveṇi vasena ayam pi kāyaḥ evam cira ṭṭhitikaḥ viya katvā dassitaḥ
translated: and it breaks up there and then without outlasting that, still it is called a lamp burning all night by way of the continuity of the flame. So too here this body is shown as lasting so long by way of the continuity of the aggregates.

original: Rattiyā ca divasassa cāti rattimhi ca divase ca. Bhummatthe hetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Aññadeva
analyzed: rattiyā ca divasassa ca ati rattimhi ca divase ca bhumma atthe ha itam sāmi vacanam aññadeva
translated: In the night and in the day: this is a locative of time referring to the night and the day.

original: uppajjati, aññaṃ nirujjhatīti yaṃ rattiṃ uppajjati ca nirujjhati ca, tato aññadeva🔽divā uppajjati ca nirujjhati cāti attho. Aññaṃ uppajjati, anuppannameva aññaṃ nirujjhatīti
analyzed: uppajjati aññam nirujjhati iti yam rattim uppajjati ca nirujjhati ca tatas aññat eva  divā uppajjati ca nirujjhati ca ati atthaḥ aññam uppajjati anuppannam eva aññam nirujjhati iti
translated: Another arises and another ceases: what arises in the night and ceases in the night is one thing,🔽and what arises in the day and ceases in the day is another thing.🔽The meaning should not be taken as “another arises and another ceases without arising,”

original: evaṃ pana attho na gahetabbo. “Rattiyā ca divasassa cā”ti idaṃ purimapaveṇito parittakaṃ
analyzed: evam pana atthaḥ na gahetabbaḥ rattiyā ca divasassa ca ati idam purima paveṇitaḥ parittakam
translated: but rather as “another arises and another ceases.” “In the night and in the day” is said by way of the continuity of the aggregates, taking a short continuity of aggregates from the previous night and a short continuity from the present night.

original: paveṇiṃ gahetvā paveṇivaseneva vuttaṃ, ekarattiṃ pana ekadivasaṃ vā ekameva cittaṃ
analyzed: paveṇim gahetvā paveṇi vasena iva vuttam eka rattim pana eka divasam vā ekam eva cittam
translated: But in a single night or in a single day a single consciousness

original: ṭhātuṃ samatthaṃ nāma natthi. Ekasmiñhi accharākkhaṇe anekāni cittakoṭisatasahassāni
analyzed: ṭhātum samattham nāma natthi ekasmin hi accharā kkhaṇe anekāni citta koṭi sata sahassāni
translated: There is none that can. For in a single moment of thought there arise many hundreds of thousands of mental states.

original: uppajjanti. Vuttampi cetaṃ milindapañhe –
analyzed: uppajjanti vuttam pi ca itam milinda pañhe
translated: And this is said in the Milindapañha:

original: “Vāhasataṃ kho, mahārāja, vīhīnaṃ, aḍḍhacūḷañca vāhā, vīhisattambaṇāni, dve ca tumbā,
analyzed: vāha satam kho mahā rāja vīhīnam aḍḍhacūḷam ca vāhāḥ vīhi sattambaṇāni dve ca tumbā
translated: “A hundred cartloads of paddy, great king, and a half, and seven measures of paddy, and two tumbas,

original: ekaccharākkhaṇe pavattassa cittassa ettakā vīhī lakkhaṃ ṭhapīyamānā parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyyu”nti.
analyzed: ekaccharākkhaṇe pavattassa cittassa ettakā vīhī lakkham ṭhapīyamānā parikkhayam pariyādānam gaccheyyunti
translated: would be needed to make a hundred-thousandth part of a single moment of thought that occurs in a single moment of consciousness.”

original: Pavaneti mahāvane. Taṃ muñcitvā aññaṃ gaṇhāti, taṃ muñcitvā aññaṃ gaṇhātīti iminā
analyzed: pavana iti mahā vane tam muñcitvā aññam gaṇhāti tam muñcitvā aññam gaṇhāti iti iminā
translated: In the forest: in the great forest. He takes one and then another,

original: na so gaṇhitabbasākhaṃ alabhitvā bhūmiṃ otarati. Atha kho tasmiṃ mahāvane vicaranto
analyzed: na saḥ gaṇhitabba sākham a labhitvā bhūmim otarati atha kho tasmin mahā vane vicarantaḥ
translated: by this it is shown that he does not descend to the ground without finding a branch to grasp. But rather, wandering in that great forest,

original: taṃ taṃ sākhaṃ gaṇhantoyeva caratīti ayamattho dassito.
analyzed: tam tam sākham gaṇhanto yā iva carati iti ayam atthaḥ dassito
translated: he goes on his way by grasping this branch and that.

original: Evameva khoti ettha idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – araññamahāvanaṃ viya hi ārammaṇavanaṃ
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam arañña mahā vanam viya hi ārammaṇa vanam
translated: Thus too: here is the correspondence of the similes: the forest of consciousness is like the forest in the simile.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tasmiṃ vane vicaraṇamakkaṭo viya ārammaṇavane uppajjanakacittaṃ. Sākhāgahaṇaṃ🔽viya ārammaṇe lubbhanaṃ. Yathā so araññe vicaranto makkaṭo taṃ taṃ sākhaṃ pahāya🔽taṃ taṃ sākhaṃ gaṇhāti, evamidaṃ ārammaṇavane vicarantaṃ cittampi kadāci rūpārammaṇaṃ🔽gahetvā uppajjati, kadāci saddādīsu aññataraṃ, kadāci atītaṃ, kadāci anāgataṃ vā
analyzed: veditabbam tasmin vane vicaraṇa makkaṭaḥ viya ārammaṇa vane uppajjanaka cittam sākhā gahaṇam  viyaḥ ārammaṇe lubbhanam yathā saḥ araññe vicarantaḥ makkaṭaḥ tam tam sākham pahāya  tam tam sākham gaṇhāti evam idam ārammaṇa vane vicarantam cittam api kadāci rūpa ārammaṇam  gahetvā uppajjati kadāci sadda ādīsu aññataram kadāci atītam kadāci anāgatam vā
translated: and the consciousness that arises in the object-sign jungle is like the monkey wandering in the jungle. The seizing of the object-sign is like the seizing of the branch.

original: paccuppannaṃ vā, tathā kadāci ajjhattaṃ, kadāci bāhiraṃ. Yathā ca so araññe vicaranto🔽makkaṭo sākhaṃ alabhitvā oruyha bhūmiyaṃ nisinnoti na vattabbo, ekaṃ pana paṇṇasākhaṃ🔽gahetvāva nisīdati, evameva ārammaṇavane vicarantaṃ cittampi ekaṃ olubbhārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: paccuppannam vā tathā kadāci ajjhattam kadāci bāhiram yathā ca so araññe vicarantaḥ  makkaṭaḥ sākham a labhitvā oruyha bhūmiyam nisinnaḥ iti na vattabbo ekam pana paṇṇa sākham  gahetvā ava nisīdati evam eva ārammaṇa vane vicarantam cittam pi ekam olubbha ārammaṇam
translated: Just as the monkey, while wandering in the jungle, lets go of one branch and seizes another, so too, the consciousness that wanders in the object-sign jungle sometimes arises apprehending a visible-form sign, sometimes a sound sign, and so on. Sometimes it arises in the past, sometimes in the future, and sometimes in the present. Likewise, sometimes it arises internally and sometimes externally.

original: alabhitvā uppannanti na vattabbaṃ, ekajātiyaṃ pana ārammaṇaṃ gahetvāva uppajjatīti
analyzed: a labhitvā uppannanti na vattabbam eka jātiyam pana ārammaṇam gahetvā āva uppajjati iti
translated: And just as the monkey, while wandering in the jungle, cannot be said to come down to the ground and sit there, since it sits only after seizing a leaf-branch, so too, the consciousness that wanders in the object-sign jungle cannot be said to arise without apprehending a sign, since it arises only after apprehending a sign in a single cognitive series.

original: veditabbaṃ. Ettāvatā ca pana bhagavatā rūpato nīharitvā arūpe gāho patiṭṭhāpito,
analyzed: veditabbam ettāvatā ca pana bhagavatā rūpataḥ nīharitvā arūpe gāho patiṭṭhāpito
translated: and it should be understood that the Blessed One has thus established the apprehension of the formless by excluding the formed,

original: arūpato nīharitvā rūpe.
analyzed: arūpataḥ nīharitvā rūpe
translated: and the apprehension of the formed by excluding the formless.

original: Idāni taṃ ubhayato nikkaḍḍhitukāmo tatra, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvakoti desanaṃ
analyzed: idāni tam ubhayatas nikkaḍḍhitu kāmo tatra bhikkhave sutavā ariya sāvakaḥ iti desanam
translated: Now, wishing to remove it from both, he began the teaching with the words, “In that case, bhikkhus, a well-taught noble disciple … ”

original: ārabhi. Ayaṃ panattho āsīvisadaṭṭhūpamāya dīpetabbo – eko kira puriso āsīvisena daṭṭho,
analyzed: ārabhi ayam pana atthaḥ āsīvisa daṭṭhu upamāya dīpetabbaḥ ekaḥ kira purisaḥ āsīvisena daṭṭhaḥ
translated: But the meaning of this should be illustrated by the simile of the snake’s head. A man was bitten by a snake, it seems.

original: athassa visaṃ harissāmīti cheko bhisakko āgantvā vamanaṃ kāretvā heṭṭhā garuḷo, upari
analyzed: athassa visam harissāmi iti chekaḥ bhisakkaḥ āgantvā vamanam kāretvā heṭṭhā garuḷaḥ upari
translated: A skilled doctor came and made him vomit, and after that he recited a spell over him and bound on a medicinal amulet.

original: nāgoti mantaṃ parivattetvā visaṃ upari āropesi. So yāva akkhippadesā āruḷhabhāvaṃ
analyzed: nāgaḥ ti mantam parivattetvā visam upari āropesi saḥ yāva akkhippa desāḥ āruḷha bhāvam
translated: The man knew that the poison had mounted as far as the head,

original: ñatvā “ito paraṃ abhiruhituṃ na dassāmi, daṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva ṭhapessāmī”ti upari garuḷo,
analyzed: ñatvā itas param abhiruhitum na dassāmi ṭhapessāmi iti upari garuḷaḥ
translated: and he said, “I will not let it go any further. I will keep it right where it is.” He recited the spell again and bound on another amulet.

original: heṭṭhā nāgoti mantaṃ parivattetvā kaṇṇe dhumetvā daṇḍakena paharitvā visaṃ otāretvā
analyzed: heṭṭhā nāgā iti mantam parivattetvā kaṇṇe dhumetvā daṇḍakena paharitvā visam otāretvā
translated: Then he squeezed the man’s veins at the base of the skull with his fingers and knocked out the poison with a blow from his fist.

original: daṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva ṭhapesi. Tatrassa ṭhitabhāvaṃ ñatvā agadalepena visaṃ nimmathetvā
analyzed: daṭṭha ṭṭhāneyā iva ṭhapesi tatrassa ṭhita bhāvam ñatvā agada lepena visam nimmathetvā
translated: He kept it right where it was, and knowing that it was there, he counteracted it with a non-poisonous ointment.

original: nhāpetvā “sukhī hohī”ti vatvā yenakāmaṃ pakkāmi.
analyzed: nhāpetvā sukhī hohi iti vatvā yenakāmam pakkāmi
translated: and after bathing him, he said, “Be happy,” and went away as he had come.

original: Tattha āsīvisena daṭṭhassa kāye visapatiṭṭhānaṃ viya imesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ rūpe adhimattagāhakālo,🔽cheko bhisakko viya tathāgato, mantaṃ parivattetvā upari visassa āropitakālo viya🔽tathāgatena tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ rūpato gāhaṃ nīharitvā arūpe patiṭṭhāpitakālo, yāva🔽akkhippadesā āruḷhavisassa upari abhiruhituṃ adatvā puna mantabalena otāretvā daṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva
analyzed: tattha āsīvisena daṭṭhassa kāye visa patiṭṭhānam viya imesam bhikkhūnam rūpe adhimatta gāha kālaḥ  chekaḥ bhisakkaḥ viya tathāgataḥ mantam parivattetvā upari visassa āropita kālaḥ viya  tathāgatena tesam bhikkhūnam rūpataḥ gāham nīharitvā arūpe patiṭṭhāpita kālaḥ yāva  akkhippa desā āruḷha visassa upari abhiruhitum a datvā puna manta balena otāretvā
translated: Herein, the time when these bhikkhus were over-concerned with the visible-form aspect of the Blessed One’s beauty was as if the poison had spread through the body of the man bitten by the snake.🔽The time when the Blessed One removed their concern with visible form and established them in the formless was as if the skilled physician had recited the appropriate spell and had made the poison rise upwards in the man’s body.

original: ṭhapanaṃ viya satthārā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ arūpato gāhaṃ nīharitvā rūpe patiṭṭhāpitakālo.🔽Daṭṭhaṭṭhāne ṭhitassa visassa agadalepena nimmathanaṃ viya ubhayato gāhaṃ nīharaṇatthāya
analyzed: ṭhapanam viya satthārā tesam bhikkhūnam arūpataḥ gāham nīharitvā rūpe patiṭṭhāpita kālaḥ  daṭṭha ṭṭhāne ṭhitassa visassa agada lepena nimmathanam viya ubhayatas gāham nīharaṇa tthāya
translated: The time when the Blessed One removed their concern with the formless and established them in the visible-form aspect of his beauty was as if the poison had been made to descend again by the force of the spell and had been placed in the place where it had been bitten out of the man’s body.

original: imissā desanāya āraddhakālo veditabbo. Tattha nibbindaṃ virajjatīti iminā maggo kathito,
analyzed: imissā desanāya āraddha kālaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha nibbindam virajjati iti iminā maggaḥ kathito
translated: The time when the Blessed One began this teaching in order to remove their concern with both visible form and the formless should be understood as like the time when the man was anointed with the antidote ointment in the place where he had been bitten. Herein, the path is stated in the words “He becomes dispassionate” and “He attains fading of lust” .

original: virāgā vimuccatīti phalaṃ, vimuttasmintiādinā paccavekkhaṇā. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: virāgā vimuccati iti phalam vimuttasmin tiādinā paccavekkhaṇā paṭhamam
translated: and ‘through dispassion he is released’ is the fruit. The reviewing is ‘In one who is released …’ .

original: 2. Dutiyaassutavāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya assutavāsutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Second, on the untaught runaways

original: 62. Dutiye sukhavedaniyanti sukhavedanāya paccayaṃ. Phassanti cakkhusamphassādiṃ.
analyzed: dutiye sukha vedaniyanti sukha vedanāya paccayam phassanti cakkhu samphassa ādim
translated: . ‘Conducive to pleasant feeling’: a condition for pleasant feeling. ‘Contact’: eye-contact, etc.

original: Nanu ca cakkhusamphasso sukhavedanāya paccayo na hotīti? Sahajātapaccayena na hoti,🔽upanissayapaccayena pana javanavedanāya hoti, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Sotasamphassādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Tajjanti tajjātikaṃ tassāruppaṃ, tassa phassassa anurūpanti attho. Dukkhavedaniyantiādi
analyzed: nanu ca cakkhu samphassaḥ sukha vedanāya paccayaḥ na hoti iti sahajāta paccayena na hoti  upanissaya paccayena pana javana vedanāya hoti tam sandhāya itam vuttam sota samphassa ādīsu pi  esa iva nayaḥ tajjanti tad jātikam tassa āruppam tassa phassassa anurūpanti atthaḥ dukkha vedaniya ntiādi
translated: But is not eye-contact not a condition for pleasant feeling? It is not as conascence condition,🔽but it is as decisive-support condition for the feeling that arises with impulsion. That is what is meant here. The same method applies in the case of ear-contact, and so on.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Saṅghaṭṭanasamodhānāti saṅghaṭṭanena ceva samodhānena ca,
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbam saṅghaṭṭana samodhānā ati saṅghaṭṭanena ca iva samodhānena ca
translated: ‘Related to that’: born of that, arisen from that, appropriate to that, is the meaning. ‘Conducive to painful feeling’ and so on should be understood in the way already given.

original: saṅghaṭṭanasampiṇḍanenāti attho. Usmāti uṇhākāro. Tejo abhinibbattatīti aggicuṇṇo
analyzed: saṅghaṭṭana sampiṇḍanena ti attho usmā ati uṇhā ākāraḥ tejaḥ abhinibbattati iti aggicuṇṇaḥ
translated: ‘By impact and by accumulation’: by impact and by accumulation, is the meaning. ‘Heat’: the mode of heat. ‘Fire is generated’: fire is produced, as it were, by the impact of the sun’s rays on a glass globe.

original: nikkhamatīti na gahetabbaṃ, usmākārasseva pana etaṃ vevacanaṃ. Tattha dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: nikkhamati iti na gahetabbam usmākārassa iva pana etam vevacanam tattha dvinnam kaṭṭhānam ti
translated: Herein, “of two sticks” :

original: dvinnaṃ araṇīnaṃ. Tattha adhoaraṇī viya vatthu, uttarāraṇī viya ārammaṇaṃ, saṅghaṭṭanaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam araṇīnam tattha adhoaraṇī viya vatthu uttarāraṇī viya ārammaṇam saṅghaṭṭanam
translated: of two fire-sticks. Herein, the “lower fire-stick” is like the physical basis, and the object is like the “upper fire-stick” . Contact is like the

original: viya phasso, usmādhātu viya vedanā. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: viya phassaḥ usmādhātu viya vedanā dutiyam
translated: rubbing, and feeling is like the heat element. The second simile is finished.

original: 3. Puttamaṃsūpamasuttavaṇṇanā🔽63. Tatiye cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārātiādi vuttanayameva. Yasmā panassa aṭṭhuppattiko
analyzed: tatiye cattāro me bhikkhave āhārā tiādi vutta nayam eva yasmā panassa aṭṭhuppattiko
translated: The Simile of the Son’s Flesh

original: nikkhepo, tasmā taṃ dassetvāvettha anupubbapadavaṇṇanaṃ karissāmi. Katarāya pana
analyzed: nikkhepaḥ tasmā tam dassetvā avettha anupubba pada vaṇṇanam karissāmi katarāya pana
translated: In the third , the words “Bhikkhus, there are these four kinds of nutriment” are in the way already stated. But since this sutta was delivered in order to show the origin of the nutriment, I shall explain the words in due sequence after showing that origin.

original: idaṃ aṭṭhuppattiyā nikkhittanti? Lābhasakkārena. Bhagavato kira mahālābhasakkāro🔽uppajji, yathā taṃ cattāro asaṅkhyeyye pūritadānapāramīsañcayassa. Sabbadisāsu hissa
analyzed: idam aṭṭhuppattiyā lābha sakkārena bhagavataḥ kira mahā lābha sakkāro  uppajji yathā tam cattāraḥ asaṅkhyeyye pūrita dāna pāramī sañcayassa sabba disāsu
translated: But in what origin did the Blessed One show it? In gain and honour. For the Blessed One’s gain and honour had arisen thus:🔽As one who had fulfilled the perfection of giving in four incalculable ages and a hundred thousand aeons,

original: yamakamahāmegho vuṭṭhahitvā mahoghaṃ viya sabbapāramiyo “ekasmiṃ attabhāve vipākaṃ
analyzed: yamaka mahā meghaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā mahā ogham viya sabba pāramiyaḥ ekasmin atta bhāve vipākam
translated: he had, as it were, drawn to himself all the perfections. For showers of rain from a double cloud had fallen on him, and all the perfections had become a great mass, like a great flood, in his existence.

original: dassāmā”ti sampiṇḍitā viya lābhasakkāramahoghaṃ nibbattayiṃsu. Tato tato annapānayānavatthamālāgandhavilepanādihatthā🔽khattiyabrāhmaṇādayo āgantvā, “kahaṃ buddho, kahaṃ bhagavā, kahaṃ devadevo narāsabho
analyzed: dassāma ati sampiṇḍitāḥ viya lābha sakkāram ahogham nibbattayiṃsu tato tatas anna pāna yāna vattha mālā gandha vilepana ādi hatthā  khattiya brāhmaṇa ādayaḥ āgantvā kaham buddhaḥ kaham bhagavā kaham devadevaḥ narāsabhaḥ
translated: and they produced a flood of gain and honour as if they had combined together. Then Khattiyas, Brahmins, etc., coming from here and there with their hands full of food, drink, vehicles, clothes, garlands, scents, ointments, etc.,🔽asked, “Where is the Buddha? Where is the Blessed One? Where is the God of gods, the Best of men,

original: purisasīho”ti? Bhagavantaṃ pariyesanti. Sakaṭasatehipi paccaye āharitvā okāsaṃ alabhamānā
analyzed: purisa sīhaḥ ti bhagavantam pariyesanti sakaṭa satehi pi paccaye āharitvā okāsam a labhamānā
translated: the Lion of men, the King of men?” They searched for the Blessed One. Bringing requisites even on a hundred carts, not finding an opportunity,

original: samantā gāvutappamāṇampi sakaṭadhurena sakaṭadhuraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhanti ceva anuppavattanti
analyzed: samantā gāvuta ppamāṇam pi sakaṭa dhurena sakaṭa dhuram āhacca tiṭṭhanti ca iva anuppavattanti
translated: they stood all round even a gāvuta in extent, cart-load pressing on cart-load, and they went on pressing,

original: ca andhakavindabrāhmaṇādayo viya. Sabbaṃ khandhake tesu tesu suttesu ca āgatanayena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca andhaka vinda brāhmaṇa ādayaḥ viya sabbam khandhake tesu tesu suttesu ca āgata nayena veditabbam
translated: like the Andhakavinda Brahmins, etc. All this should be understood according to the method stated in the Khandhakas and in the suttas.

original: Yathā bhagavato, evaṃ bhikkhusaṅghassāpi. Vuttañcetaṃ –🔽“Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī
analyzed: yathā bhagavataḥ evam bhikkhu saṅghassa api vuttam ca itam  tena khaḥ pana samayena bhagavā sakkataḥ hoti garukataḥ mānitaḥ pūjitaḥ apacitaḥ lābhī
translated: As with the Blessed One, so also with the Community of Bhikkhus. For this is said:

original: cīvara-piṇḍapāta-senāsana-gilāna-paccaya-bhesajja-parikkhārānaṃ. Bhikkhusaṅghopi
analyzed: cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārānam bhikkhu saṅghaḥ api
translated: “Now at that time the Blessed One was honoured, respected, revered, venerated, esteemed, and in receipt of robes, alms food, dwellings, and medicinal requisites to help when he was sick. The Community of Bhikkhus

original: kho sakkato hoti…pe… parikkhārāna”nti.
analyzed: kho sakkataḥ hoti pe
translated: and he is honored with requisites.”

original: Tathā “yāvatā kho, cunda, etarahi saṅgho vā gaṇo vā loke uppanno, nāhaṃ, cunda, aññaṃ ekasaṅghampi samanupassāmi evaṃ lābhaggayasaggapattaṃ yatharivāyaṃ, cunda, bhikkhusaṅgho”ti.🔽Svāyaṃ bhagavato ca saṅghassa ca uppanno lābhasakkāro ekato hutvā dvinnaṃ mahānadīnaṃ
analyzed: tathā yāvatā kho cunda etarahi saṅghaḥ vā gaṇaḥ vā loke uppannaḥ na aham cunda aññam eka saṅgham pi samanupassāmi evam lābha gga yasagga pattam yathari vā ayam cunda bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti  svāyam bhagavato ca saṅghassa ca uppannaḥ lābha sakkāraḥ ekatas hutvā dvinnam mahā nadīnam
translated: And he said: “Cunda, as far as any community or society of wanderers goes, I do not see one that is so prosperous and powerful as this community of bhikkhus.”🔽The gain and honor that had arisen for the Exalted One and the Community of Bhikkhus were immeasurable, like the water in the two great oceans.

original: udakaṃ viya appameyyo ahosi. Atha satthā rahogato cintesi – “mahālābhasakkāro atītabuddhānampi🔽evarūpo ahosi, anāgatānampi evarūpo bhavissati. Kiṃ nu kho bhikkhū āhārapariggāhakena
analyzed: udakam viya appameyyaḥ ahosi atha satthā rahogataḥ cintesi mahā lābha sakkāro atīta buddhānam pi  evarūpaḥ ahosi anāgatānam pi evarūpaḥ bhavissati kim nu kho bhikkhū āhāra pariggāhakena
translated: Then the Teacher, in seclusion, thought: “Such great gain and honor arose for the Buddhas of the past,

original: satisampajaññena samannāgatā majjhattā nicchandarāgā hutvā āhāraṃ paribhuñjituṃ sakkonti, na sakkontī”ti?
analyzed: sati sampajaññena samannāgatāḥ majjhattāḥ nicchanda rāgāḥ hutvā āhāram paribhuñjitum sakkonti na sakkonti iti
translated: and it will arise for the Buddhas of the future. But can the bhikkhus now enjoy their food with the mindfulness and clear comprehension of one who has no more craving, with equanimity whether they are served much or little?”

original: So addasa ekacce adhunā pabbajite kulaputte apaccavekkhitvā āhāraṃ paribhuñjamāne.
analyzed: saḥ addase ekacce adhunā pabbajite kula putte a paccavekkhitvā āhāram paribhuñjamāne
translated: He saw that some young men of good family had recently gone forth and were enjoying their food without reflection.

original: Disvānassa etadahosi – “mayā kappasatasahassādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni pāramiyo🔽pūrentena na cīvarādihetu pūritā, uttamaphalassa pana arahattassatthāya pūritā. Imepi
analyzed: disvānassa etat ahosi mayā kappa sata sahassa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni pāramiyaḥ  na cīvara ādi hetu pūritāḥ uttama phalassa pana arahattassa atthāya pūritāḥ ime pi
translated: When he saw this, he thought: “When I was fulfilling the perfections for four incalculable ages and 100,000 aeons, I did not fulfil them for the sake of robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites,

original: bhikkhū mama santike pabbajantā na cīvarādihetu pabbajitā, arahattasseva pana atthāya
analyzed: bhikkhū mama santike pabbajantā na cīvara ādi hetu pabbajitāḥ arahattassa iva pana atthāya
translated: but for the sake of the supreme fruit of liberation. And these bhikkhus who went forth under me did not go forth for the sake of robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites,

original: pabbajitā. Te idāni asārameva sāraṃ anatthameva ca atthaṃ karontī”ti evamassa dhammasaṃvego🔽udapādi. Tato cintesi – “sace pañcamaṃ pārājikaṃ paññapetuṃ sakkā abhavissa, apaccavekkhitāhāraparibhogo
analyzed: pabbajitā te idāni asāram eva sāram anattham eva ca attham karonti iti evam assa dhamma saṃvegaḥ  udapādi tatas cintesi sace pañcamam pārājikam paññapetum sakkā abhavissa a paccavekkhita āhāra paribhogo
translated: but for the sake of liberation. But now they are making what is not the essence the essence and what is not the benefit the benefit.” So he was stirred with the inspiration of the Dhamma.

original: pañcamaṃ pārājikaṃ katvā paññapetabbo bhaveyya. Na pana sakkā evaṃ kātuṃ, dhuvapaṭisevanaṭṭhānañhetaṃ
analyzed: pañcamam pārājikam katvā paññapetabbaḥ bhaveyya na pana sakkā evam kātum dhuva paṭisevana ṭhānam hetam
translated: Then he thought: “If it were possible to lay down a fifth offence involving defeat, the use of requisites after reviewing would have to be made a fifth offence involving defeat. But that cannot be done, for this is a fixed resort of creatures.

original: sattānaṃ. Yathā pana kathite pañcamaṃ pārājikaṃ viya naṃ passissanti. Evaṃ dhammādāsaṃ
analyzed: sattānam yathā pana kathite pañcamam pārājikam viya nam passissanti evam dhamma ādāsam
translated: But they will see it as a fifth offence involving defeat only if it is taught in the way I am going to teach it.

original: saṃvaraṃ mariyādaṃ ṭhapessāmi, yaṃ āvajjitvā āvajjitvā anāgate bhikkhū cattāro paccaye
analyzed: saṃvaram mariyādam ṭhapessāmi yam āvajjitvā āvajjitvā anāgate bhikkhū cattāraḥ paccaye
translated: I will set up a rule of restraint, having frequently reflected on which future bhikkhus will be able to use the four requisites

original: paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjissantī”ti. Imāya aṭṭhuppattiyā imaṃ puttamaṃsūpamasuttantaṃ
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā paribhuñjissanti iti imāya aṭṭhuppattiyā imam puttamaṃsūpama suttantam
translated: after reflecting on them.” He placed this sutta, the Simile of the Piece of Flesh,

original: nikkhipi. Tattha cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārātiādi heṭṭhā vuttatthameva.🔽Cattāro pana āhāre vitthāretvā idāni tesu ādīnavaṃ dassetuṃ kathañca, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tattha cattāro me bhikkhave āhārā tiādi heṭṭhā vutta ttham eva  cattāro pana āhāre vitthāretvā idāni tesu ādīnavam dassetum katham ca bhikkhave
translated: in the Canon of Discourses with this as the occasion for its composition. Herein, there are four kinds of nutriment, bhikkhus, etc., has the same meaning as given below .

original: kabaḷīkāro āhāro daṭṭhabbotiādimāha? Tattha jāyampatikāti jāyā ceva pati ca. Parittaṃ
analyzed: kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ ti ādim āha tattha jāyampatikā ati jāyā ca iva pati ca parittam
translated: But now, in order to show the danger in the four kinds of nutriment by expounding them in detail, he said, “And how, bhikkhus, should the kind of nutriment consisting of edible food be seen? ” Herein, husband and wife are the man and the woman who are husband and wife.

original: sambalanti puṭabhattasattumodakādīnaṃ aññataraṃ appamattakaṃ pātheyyaṃ. Kantāramagganti🔽kantārabhūtaṃ maggaṃ, kantāre vā maggaṃ. Kantāranti corakantāraṃ vāḷakantāraṃ amanussakantāraṃ
analyzed: sambalanti puṭa bhatta sattu modaka ādīnam aññataram appamattakam pātheyyam kantāram agganti  kantāra bhūtam maggam kantāre vā maggam kantāranti cora kantāram vāḷa kantāram amanussa kantāram
translated: A little salt is a small amount of food such as a ball of rice, a cake, a sweet dumpling, etc.🔽A desert road is a road that is a desert or a desert road.🔽A desert is of five kinds: a desert of thieves, a desert of wild beasts, a desert of spirits, a desert of water, and a desert of food.

original: nirudakakantāraṃ appabhakkhakantāranti pañcavidhaṃ. Tesu yattha corabhayaṃ atthi,
analyzed: nirudaka kantāram appabhakkha kantāranti pañcavidham tesu yattha cora bhayam atthi
translated: Herein, where there is danger from thieves it is a desert of thieves;

original: taṃ corakantāraṃ. Yattha sīhabyagghādayo vāḷā atthi, taṃ vāḷakantāraṃ. Yattha balavāmukhayakkhiniādīnaṃ🔽amanussānaṃ vasena bhayaṃ atthi, taṃ amanussakantāraṃ. Yattha pātuṃ vā nhāyituṃ vā🔽udakaṃ natthi, taṃ nirudakakantāraṃ. Yattha khāditabbaṃ vā bhuñjitabbaṃ vā antamaso🔽kandamūlādimattampi natthi, taṃ appabhakkhakantāraṃ nāma. Yattha panetaṃ pañcavidhampi🔽bhayaṃ atthi, taṃ kantārameva. Taṃ panetaṃ ekāhadvīhatīhādivasena nittharitabbampi🔽atthi, na taṃ idha adhippetaṃ. Idha pana nirudakaṃ appabhakkhaṃ yojanasatikakantāraṃ🔽adhippetaṃ. Evarūpe kantāre maggaṃ. Paṭipajjeyyunti chātakabhayena ceva rogabhayena
analyzed: tam cora kantāram sīha byaggha ādayaḥ vāḷāḥ atthi tam vāḷa kantāram  amanussānam vasena bhayam atthi tam amanussa kantāram yattha pātum vā nhāyitum vā  udakam natthi tam nirudaka kantāram yattha khāditabbam vā bhuñjitabbam vā antamasaḥ  kanda mūla ādi mattam pi natthi tam appabhakkhakantāram nāma yattha pana itam pañcavidham pi  bhayam atthi tam kantāram eva tam pana itam ekāha dvīha tīha ādi vasena nittharitabbam pi  atthi na tat idha adhippetam idha pana nirudakam appabhakkham yojana satika kantāram  adhippetam evarūpe kantāre maggam paṭipajjeyyunti chātaka bhayena ca iva roga bhayena
translated: This is the wilderness of robbers. The wilderness of beasts is where there are wild beasts such as lions and tigers, etc. The wilderness of human beings is where there is danger from human beings such as from powerful and violent yakkhas, etc. The wilderness of non-human beings is where there is danger from non-human beings such as from powerful and violent yakkhas, etc. The wilderness of tangles is where there is danger from tangles. The wilderness of water is where there is no water to drink or to bathe in. The wilderness of food is where there is nothing to eat or to drink, not even roots and fruits. The wilderness of danger is where all these five dangers are present. This wilderness can be measured by the day’s journey of a single day, two days, or three days, etc., but that is not intended here. What is intended here is the wilderness of water and food, a wilderness a hundred leagues across. They would enter upon that wilderness: because of the danger of heat and the danger of disease,

original: ca rājabhayena ca upaddutā paṭipajjeyyuṃ “etaṃ kantāraṃ nittharitvā dhammikassa rañño
analyzed: ca rāja bhayena ca upaddutā paṭipajjeyyuṃ etam kantāram nittharitvā dhammikassa rañño
translated: This is the wilderness of robbers. The wilderness of beasts is where there are wild beasts such as lions and tigers, etc. The wilderness of human beings is where there is danger from non-human beings such as powerful female spirits, etc. The wilderness of non-human beings is where there is danger from human beings such as robbers, etc. The wilderness of grass and reeds is where there is danger from grass and reeds. The wilderness of water is where there is no water for drinking or washing. The wilderness of food is where there is nothing to eat or to chew, not even roots and fruits. The wilderness that has the five kinds of dangers is called the wilderness of dangers. This wilderness should be understood as being of two kinds: that which can be crossed in one day and that which cannot. But that is not intended here. Here the wilderness is a waterless and foodless wilderness a hundred leagues across. They would enter upon the path: they would enter upon the path because of the fear of the sun’s heat, the fear of sickness, and the fear of the king. “Having crossed this wilderness, we shall be safe in the kingdom of King Dhammapāla.

original: nirupaddave raṭṭhe sukhaṃ vasissāmā”ti maññamānā.
analyzed: nirupaddave raṭṭhe sukham vasissāma iti maññamānā
translated: thinking, “We shall live happily in a country free from troubles.”

original: Ekaputtakoti ukkhipitvā gahito anukampitabbayutto athirasarīro ekaputtako. Vallūrañca
analyzed: eka puttakaḥ ti ukkhipitvā gahitaḥ anukampitabba yuttaḥ athira sarīraḥ eka puttakaḥ vallūrañca
translated: A son is a tender thing, a helpless little creature, a body of flesh, and so they are worthy of compassion.

original: soṇḍikañcāti ghanaghanaṭṭhānato gahetvā vallūraṃ, aṭṭhinissitasirānissitaṭṭhānāni
analyzed: soṇḍikam ca ati ghana ghana ṭṭhānataḥ gahetvā vallūram aṭṭhi nissita sirā nissita ṭṭhānāni
translated: A lump of flesh and a piece of meat: they take a lump of flesh from a place where it is thick and a piece of meat from a place where it is attached to a bone.

original: gahetvā sūlamaṃsañcāti attho. Paṭipiseyyunti pahareyyuṃ. Kahaṃ ekaputtakāti ayaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā sūla maṃsam ca ati attho paṭipiseyyunti pahareyyum kaham eka puttakā ti ayam
translated: The meaning is: they take a piece of flesh from the ribs. They would strike: they would beat. Where is our son?

original: tesaṃ paridevanākāro.
analyzed: tesam paridevanā kāraḥ
translated: This is the way they lamented.

original: Ayaṃ panettha bhūtamatthaṃ katvā ādito paṭṭhāya saṅkhepato atthavaṇṇanā – dve kira
analyzed: ayam pana ittha bhūtam attham katvā āditas paṭṭhāya saṅkhepato attha vaṇṇanā dve kira
translated: But the meaning of the text can be explained as follows.

original: jāyampatikā puttaṃ gahetvā parittena pātheyyena yojanasatikaṃ kantāramaggaṃ paṭipajjiṃsu.
analyzed: jāyampatikā puttam gahetvā parittena pātheyyena yojana satikam kantāra maggam paṭipajjiṃsu
translated: Two people, a man and his wife, it seems, took their son and set out on a desert journey a hundred leagues long with a small supply of provisions.

original: Tesaṃ paññāsayojanāni gantvā pātheyyaṃ niṭṭhāsi, te khuppipāsāturā viraḷacchāyāyaṃ
analyzed: tesam paññāsa yojanāni gantvā pātheyyam te khudh pipāsā āturāḥ
translated: After they had gone fifty leagues their provisions ran out. They sat down in the shade of a tree, exhausted and thirsty.

original: nisīdiṃsu. Tato puriso bhariyaṃ āha – “bhadde ito samantā paññāsayojanāni gāmo vā
analyzed: nisīdiṃsu tatas purisaḥ bhariyam āha bhadde itas samantā paññāsa yojanāni gāmaḥ vā
translated: Then the man said to his wife, “My dear, there is no village within fifty leagues of here.

original: nigamo vā natthi. Tasmā yaṃ taṃ purisena kātabbaṃ bahumpi kasigorakkhādikammaṃ, na🔽dāni sakkā taṃ mayā kātuṃ, ehi maṃ māretvā upaḍḍhamaṃsaṃ khāditvā upaḍḍhaṃ pātheyyaṃ
analyzed: nigamaḥ vā na atthi tasmai yam tam purisena kātabbam bahum pi kasi gorakkha ādi kammam na  dāni sakkā tam mayā kātum ehi mama māretvā upaḍḍha maṃsam khāditvā upaḍḍham pātheyyam
translated: “There is no village. Therefore, I cannot do the many things that a man should do, such as farming, guarding the cattle, and so on.

original: katvā puttena saddhiṃ kantāraṃ nittharāhī”ti. Puna sāpi taṃ āha – “sāmi mayā dāni
analyzed: katvā puttena saddhim kantāram nittharāhi iti puna sā api tam āha sāmi mayā dāni
translated: Come, kill me, eat half of my flesh, and taking the other half as provisions, cross the desert with your son.”

original: yaṃ taṃ itthiyā kātabbaṃ bahumpi suttakantanādikammaṃ, taṃ kātuṃ na sakkā, ehi maṃ
analyzed: yam tam itthiyā kātabbam bahum pi sutta kantana ādi kammam tam kātum na sakkā ehi mama
translated: Again she said to him, “Husband, now I cannot do the many things that a woman should do, such as spinning, weaving, and so on.

original: māretvā upaḍḍhamaṃsaṃ khāditvā upaḍḍhaṃ pātheyyaṃ katvā puttena saddhiṃ kantāraṃ
analyzed: māretvā upaḍḍha maṃsam khāditvā upaḍḍham pātheyyam katvā puttena saddhim kantāram
translated: Come, kill me, eat half of my flesh, and taking the other half as provisions, cross the desert with your son.”

original: nittharāhī”ti. Puna sopi taṃ āha – “bhadde mātugāmamaraṇena dvinnaṃ maraṇaṃ paññāyati.🔽Na hi mando kumāro mātarā vinā jīvituṃ sakkoti. Yadi pana mayaṃ jīvāma. Puna dārakaṃ
analyzed: nittharāhi iti puna saḥ api tam āha bhadde mātu gāma maraṇena dvinnam maraṇam paññāyati  na hi mandaḥ kumāraḥ mātarā vinā jīvitum sakkoti yadi pana mayam jīvāma puna dārakam
translated: Again he said to her, “Dear, the death of a woman and the death of a child are seen to be the death of two.

original: labheyyāma. Handa dāni puttakaṃ māretvā, maṃsaṃ gahetvā kantāraṃ nittharāmā”ti. Tato
analyzed: labheyyāma handa dāni puttakam māretvā maṃsam gahetvā kantāram nittharāma ati tatas
translated: For a foolish child cannot live without a mother. But if we live, we may get another child. Well then, kill the child, take the flesh, and cross the desert.”🔽Then she said, “Very well,” and killed the child.

original: mātā puttamāha – “tāta, pitusantikaṃ gacchā”ti, so agamāsi. Athassa pitā, “mayā ‘puttakaṃ🔽posessāmī’ti kasigorakkhādīhi anappakaṃ dukkhamanubhūtaṃ, na sakkomi ahaṃ puttaṃ
analyzed: mātā puttam āha tāta pitu santikam gacchāti saḥ agamāsi atha assa pitā mayā puttakam  posessāmi iti kasi gorakkha ādīhi anappakam dukkham anubhūtam na sakkomi aham puttam
translated: The mother said to the son, “Go to your father.” He went. His father said to him, “Son, I have suffered much hardship in order to support you,

original: māretuṃ, tvaṃyeva tava puttaṃ mārehī”ti vatvā, “tāta mātusantikaṃ gacchā”ti āha.
analyzed: māretum tvaṃyā iva tava puttam mārehi iti vatvā tāta mātu santikam gaccha āti āha
translated: having to work in the fields and so on. I cannot kill you. You kill your own son.” And he said, “Go to your mother.”

original: So agamāsi. Athassa mātāpi, “mayā puttaṃ patthentiyā govatakukkuravatadevatāyācanādīhipi🔽tāva anappakaṃ dukkhamanubhūtaṃ, ko pana vādo kucchinā pariharantiyā? Na sakkomi
analyzed: saḥ agamāsi athassa mātā api mayā puttam patthentiyā govata kukkuravata devatā yācanā ādīhi pi  tāva anappakam dukkham anubhūtam kaḥ pana vādaḥ kucchinā pariharantiyā na sakkomi
translated: He went. His mother said to him, “Son, I have suffered much hardship in order to get you,

original: ahaṃ puttaṃ māretu”nti vatvā “tāta, pitusantikameva gacchā”ti āha. Evaṃ so dvinnamantarā
analyzed: aham puttam māretum iti vatvā tāta pitu santikam eva gaccha āti āha evam saḥ dvinnam antarā
translated: having to go without food and drink, to beg from cows and dogs and deities, and so on. How much more so in carrying you in my womb! I cannot kill you.” And she said, “Go to your father.”

original: gacchantoyeva mato. Te taṃ disvā paridevitvā vuttanayena maṃsāni gahetvā khādantā pakkamiṃsu.
analyzed: te tam disvā paridevitvā vutta nayena maṃsāni gahetvā khādantā pakkamiṃsu
translated: Thus he died while going back and forth between the two. When they saw him dead, they lamented and took his flesh and ate it as before, and then they left.

original: Tesaṃ so puttamaṃsāhāro navahi kāraṇehi paṭikūlattā neva davāya hoti, na madāya,
analyzed: tesam saḥ putta maṃsa āhāraḥ navahi kāraṇehi paṭikūla ttā na iva davāya hoti na madāya
translated: The flesh of their son was not for their enjoyment or pleasure, but for nine reasons it was repulsive to them.

original: na maṇḍanāya, na vibhūsanāya, kevalaṃ kantāranittharaṇatthāyeva hoti. Katamehi navahi
analyzed: na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya kevalam kantāra nittharaṇa tthāya iva hoti katamehi navahi
translated: not for the sake of adornment or beautification, but only for the sake of crossing the desert.

original: kāraṇehi paṭikūloti ce? Sajātimaṃsatāya ñātimaṃsatāya puttamaṃsatāya piyaputtamaṃsatāya
analyzed: kāraṇehi paṭikūlaḥ ti ce sajāti maṃsa tāya ñāti maṃsa tāya putta maṃsa tāya piya putta maṃsa tāya
translated: If you ask why it is repulsive for nine reasons, it is because of its nature as human flesh, its nature as the flesh of a kinsman, its nature as the flesh of a son, its nature as the flesh of a beloved son,

original: taruṇamaṃsatāya āmakamaṃsatāya abhogamaṃsatāya aloṇatāya adhūpitatāyāti. Evañhi te🔽navahi kāraṇehi paṭikūlaṃ taṃ puttamaṃsaṃ khādantā na sārattā giddhamānasā hutvā
analyzed: taruṇa maṃsa tāya āmaka maṃsa tāya a bhoga maṃsa tāya a loṇa tāya a dhūpita tāya ati evam hi te  navahi kāraṇehi paṭikūlam tam putta maṃsam khādantā na sārattāḥ giddha mānasāḥ hutvā
translated: its nature as the flesh of a young man, its nature as raw flesh, its nature as uneaten flesh, its lack of salt, and its lack of roasting.

original: khādiṃsu, majjhattabhāveyeva pana nicchandarāgaparibhoge ṭhitā khādiṃsu. Na aṭṭhinhārucammanissitaṭṭhānāni🔽apanetvā thūlathūlaṃ varamaṃsameva khādiṃsu, hatthasampattaṃ maṃsameva pana khādiṃsu.
analyzed: khādiṃsu pana nicchanda rāga paribhoge ṭhitā khādiṃsu na aṭṭhinha aru camma nissita ṭṭhānāni  apanetvā thūla thūlam vara maṃsam eva khādiṃsu hattha sampattam maṃsam eva pana khādiṃsu
translated: For it was not with lustful minds that they ate the flesh of their beloved son, regarding it as a delicacy, but they ate it with minds indifferent, as if it were not flesh,🔽and they did not pick out the pieces of flesh that were attached to the bones, sinews, and skin and eat only the choice pieces, but they ate the flesh that came to their share.

original: Na yāvadatthaṃ kaṇṭhappamāṇaṃ katvā khādiṃsu, thokaṃ thokaṃ pana ekadivasaṃ yāpanamattameva
analyzed: na yāvadattham kaṇṭha ppamāṇam katvā khādiṃsu thokam thokam pana eka divasam yāpanam attam eva
translated: And they did not eat as much as they wanted, filling their mouths,

original: khādiṃsu. Na aññamaññaṃ maccharāyantā khādiṃsu, vigatamaccheramalena pana parisuddheneva🔽cetasā khādiṃsu. Na aññaṃ kiñci migamaṃsaṃ vā moramaṃsādīnaṃ vā aññataraṃ khādāmāti🔽sammūḷhā khādiṃsu, piyaputtamaṃsabhāvaṃ pana jānantāva khādiṃsu. Na “aho vata mayaṃ
analyzed: khādiṃsu na aññam aññam maccharāyantā khādiṃsu vigata macchera malena pana parisuddhena iva  cetasā khādiṃsu na aññam kiñci miga maṃsam vā mora maṃsa ādīnam vā aññataram khādāma ati  sammūḍhā khādiṃsu piya putta maṃsa bhāvam pana jānantāva khādiṃsu na aho vata mayam
translated: They did not eat it with mutual envy, but they ate it with a mind purified from the stain of envy.🔽They did not eat it thinking, “We are eating the flesh of other animals, such as deer, wild beasts, etc.,” but they ate it knowing that it was the flesh of their own dear child.

original: punapi evarūpaṃ puttamaṃsaṃ khādeyyāmā”ti patthanaṃ katvā khādiṃsu, patthanaṃ pana🔽vītivattāva hutvā khādiṃsu. Na “ettakaṃ kantāre khāditvā avasiṭṭhaṃ kantāraṃ atikkamma🔽loṇambilādīhi yojetvā khādissāmā”ti sannidhiṃ akaṃsu, kantārapariyosāne pana “pure🔽mahājano passatī”ti bhūmiyaṃ vā nikhaṇiṃsu, agginā vā jhāpayiṃsu. Na “koci añño amhe
