analyzed: puna api evarūpam putta maṃsam khādeyyāma ati patthanam katvā khādiṃsu patthanam pana  vītivattā ava hutvā khādiṃsu na ettakam kantāre khāditvā avasiṭṭham kantāram atikkamma  loṇambila ādīhi yojetvā khādissāma ati sannidhim akaṃsu kantāra pariyosāne pana pure  mahājano passati iti bhūmiyam vā nikhaṇiṃsu agginā vā jhāpayiṃsu na koci aññaḥ amhe

analyzed: tava puttaḥ mama puttaḥ iti aññam aññam atimaññiṃsu samaggā pana sammodamānā hutvā
translated: but lived together in concord and harmony,

original: khādiṃsu, evamevaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ labhitvā yathā ekacco “ko tumhādisānaṃ dassati nikkāraṇā
analyzed: evam evam piṇḍapātam labhitvā yathā ekacco ko dassati nikkāraṇā
translated: so too, when he has obtained alms food, he should not despise anyone, thinking, “Who will give to people like you?

original: ummāresu pakkhalantānaṃ āhiṇḍantānaṃ vijātamātāpi vo dātabbaṃ na maññati, mayaṃ pana
analyzed: ummāresu pakkhalantānam āhiṇḍantānam vijāta mātā api vaḥ dātabbam na maññati mayam pana
translated: Even your own mother would not give you anything, let alone anyone else,

original: gatagataṭṭhāne paṇītāni cīvarādīni labhāmā”ti sīlavante sabrahmacārī atimaññati,
analyzed: gata gata ṭṭhāne paṇītāni cīvara ādīni labhāmāti sīlavante sabrahmacārī atimaññati
translated: if you wander about begging like a beggar.”

original: yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: For this is said:

original: “So tena lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto aññe pesale bhikkhū atimaññati. Tañhi tassa, bhikkhave, moghapurisassa hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
analyzed: so tena lābha sakkāra silokena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādiṇṇa citto aññe pesale bhikkhū atimaññati tat hi tassa bhikkhave mogha purisassa hoti dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya ati
translated: “When he gets it, he becomes intoxicated … He becomes contemptuous of other good men … That is a long-extending misfortune for that foolish man.”

original: Evaṃ kañci anatimaññitvā sabbehi sabrahmacārīhi saddhiṃ samaggena sammodamānena hutvā paribhuñjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam kañci an atimaññitvā sabbehi sabrahmacārīhi saddhim samaggena sammodamānena hutvā paribhuñjitabbam
translated: Thus he should use it in a way that does not slight anyone, but in a way that is shared by all his virtuous fellows in the life of purity.

original: Pariññāteti ñātapariññā tīraṇapariññā pahānapariññāti imāhi tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte.🔽Kathaṃ? Idha bhikkhu “kabaḷīkārāhāro nāma ayaṃ savatthukavasena ojaṭṭhamakarūpaṃ
analyzed: pariññāte iti ñāta pariññā tīraṇa pariññā pahāna pariññā ati imāhi tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte  katham idha bhikkhu kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ nāma ayam sa vatthuka vasena
translated: “Well-known”: well known by the three kinds of clear knowledge, namely, the clear knowledge of what is known, the clear knowledge of inquiry, and the clear knowledge of the overcoming of despair.

original: hoti, ojaṭṭhamakarūpaṃ kattha paṭihaññati? Jivhāpasāde, jivhāpasādo kinnissito? Catumahābhūtanissito.🔽Iti ojaṭṭhamakaṃ jivhāpasādo tassa paccayāni mahābhūtānīti ime dhammā rūpakkhandho
analyzed: hoti ojaṭṭham akarūpam kattha paṭihaññati jivhā apasāde jivhā apasādaḥ kinnissitaḥ catu mahābhūta nissitaḥ  iti oja ṭṭhamakam jivhā pasādaḥ tassa paccayāni mahābhūtāni iti ime dhammāḥ rūpa kkhandho
translated: How? Here a bhikkhu understands thus: “The kind of nutriment called ‘food by the mouthful’ is the four primary elements, and the four primary elements are the material support for the nutriment called ‘food by the mouthful.’ Where is the nutriment ‘food by the mouthful’ deposited? It is deposited in the tongue-receptacle. What is the tongue-receptacle supported by? It is supported by the four primary elements.

original: nāma, taṃ pariggaṇhato uppannā phassapañcamakā dhammā cattāro arūpakkhandhā. Iti
analyzed: nāma tam pariggaṇhataḥ uppannā phassa pañcamakāḥ dhammāḥ cattāro arūpa kkhandhāḥ iti
translated: Thus the nutriment ‘food by the mouthful,’ the tongue-receptacle, and the four primary elements that are its support—these states are the materiality aggregate.🔽The five aggregates are the states that arise with the contact at the head of the fivefold group.

original: sabbepime pañcakkhandhā saṅkhepato nāmarūpamattaṃ hotī”ti pajānāti. So te dhamme
analyzed: sabbe pi ime pañca kkhandhāḥ saṅkhepataḥ nāma rūpa mattam hoti iti pajānāti saḥ te dhamme
translated: “Thus all these five aggregates are in brief simply mentality-materiality.”🔽He understands these states,

original: sarasalakkhaṇato vavatthapetvā tesaṃ paccayaṃ pariyesanto anulomapaṭilomaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ
analyzed: sa rasa lakkhaṇataḥ vavatthapetvā tesam paccayam pariyesantaḥ anuloma paṭilomam paṭiccasamuppādam
translated: Having defined them by their characteristics, he seeks their conditions. He sees the dependent origination in forward order and in reverse order.

original: passati. Ettāvatānena kabaḷīkārāhāramukhena sappaccayassa nāmarūpassa yāthāvato diṭṭhattā🔽kabaḷīkārāhāro ñātapariññāya pariññāto hoti. So tadeva sappaccayaṃ nāmarūpaṃ aniccaṃ
analyzed: passati ettāvatā anena kabaḷīkāra āhāra mukhena sappaccayassa nāma rūpassa yāthāvataḥ diṭṭha ttā  kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ ñāta pariññāya pariññātaḥ hoti saḥ tat eva sappaccayam nāma rūpam aniccam
translated: At this point he has seen the name-and-form with its conditions in the nutriment of edible food in its true nature.

original: dukkhaṃ anattāti tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā sattannaṃ anupassanānaṃ vasena sammasati.
analyzed: dukkham anattā ti tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā sattannam anupassanānam vasena sammasati
translated: So the nutriment of edible food is fully understood by the understanding of the known. He imputes the three characteristics of impermanence, suffering, and non-self to that same name-and-form with its conditions. He comprehends it by means of the seven contemplations.

original: Ettāvatānena so tilakkhaṇapaṭivedhasammasanañāṇasaṅkhātāya tīraṇapariññāya pariññāto
analyzed: ettāvatā anena so ti lakkhaṇa paṭivedha sammasana ñāṇa saṅkhātāya tīraṇa pariññāya pariññātaḥ
translated: At this point he has fully understood it by the full understanding of penetrating insight, which is the knowledge of comprehension.

original: hoti. Tasmiṃyeva nāmarūpe chandarāgāvakaḍḍhanena anāgāmimaggena parijānatā pahānapariññāya pariññāto hotīti.
analyzed: hoti tasmin yeva nāma rūpe chanda rāga avakaḍḍhanena anāgāmi maggena parijānatā pahāna pariññāya pariññātaḥ hoti iti
translated: He has fully understood it by the full understanding of abandoning when he abandons lust and desire in that same name-and-form by means of the non-return path.

original: Pañcakāmaguṇikoti pañcakāmaguṇasambhavo rāgo pariññāto hoti. Ettha pana tisso pariññā
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇiko ti pañca kāmaguṇa sambhavaḥ rāgaḥ pariññātaḥ hoti ettha pana tisso pariññā
translated: The lust that is the origin of the five cords of sensual pleasure is fully understood. Herein, there are three kinds of full understanding:

original: ekapariññā sabbapariññā mūlapariññāti. Katamā ekapariññā? Yo bhikkhu jivhādvāre ekarasataṇhaṃ
analyzed: eka pariññā sabba pariññā mūla pariññā ati katamā eka pariññā yaḥ bhikkhu jivhā dvāre eka rasa taṇham
translated: One full-understanding is the full-understanding of all. What is the one full-understanding? When a bhikkhu fully understands craving for the one taste in the tongue’s field,

original: parijānāti, tena pañcakāmaguṇiko rāgo pariññātova hotīti. Kasmā? Tassāyeva tattha
analyzed: parijānāti tena pañca kāmaguṇikaḥ rāgaḥ pariññātaḥ uva hoti iti kasmā
translated: then lust for the five strands of sensual desire is fully understood too. Why?

original: uppajjanato. Sāyeva hi taṇhā cakkhudvāre uppannā rūparāgo nāma hoti, sotadvārādīsu🔽uppannā saddarāgādayo. Iti yathā ekasseva corassa pañcamagge hanato ekasmiṃ magge🔽gahetvā sīse chinne pañcapi maggā khemā honti, evaṃ jivhādvāre rasataṇhāya pariññātāya
analyzed: uppajjanato sāyā iva hi taṇhā cakkhu dvāre uppannā rūparāgaḥ nāma hoti sota dvāra ādīsu  uppannā iti yathā ekassa iva corassa pañca magge hanataḥ ekasmin magge  gahetvā sīse chinne pañca api maggā khemā honti evam jivhā dvāre rasa taṇhāya pariññātāya
translated: Because it arises in that. For that craving itself, when it arises in the eye’s field, is called lust for visible forms, and when it arises in the ear’s field, etc.,🔽it is called lust for sounds, and so on. So just as when a single thief is caught after a crime in five villages, then when he is executed after being caught in one village, the crimes in the other four villages are cleared too,

original: pañcakāmaguṇiko rāgo pariññāto hotīti ayaṃ ekapariññā nāma.🔽Katamā sabbapariññā? Patte pakkhittapiṇḍapātasmiñhi ekasmiṃyeva pañcakāmaguṇikarāgo
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇikaḥ rāgaḥ pariññātaḥ hoti iti ayam eka pariññā nāma  katamā sabba pariññā patte pakkhitta piṇḍapātasmin hi ekasmin yeva pañca kāmaguṇika rāgaḥ
translated: so too, when craving for the one taste in the tongue’s field is fully understood, lust for the five strands of sensual desire is fully understood. This is called the one full-understanding.

original: labbhati. Kathaṃ? Parisuddhaṃ tāvassa vaṇṇaṃ olokayato rūparāgo hoti, uṇhe sappimhi
analyzed: labbhati katham parisuddham tāvassa vaṇṇam olokayataḥ rūpa rāgaḥ hoti uṇhe sappimhi
translated: What is the full-understanding of all? For in a bowl of alms food there is lust for the five strands of sensual desire. How? When he sees the colour, there is lust for visible forms; when he smells the smell, there is lust for smells; when he tastes the taste, there is lust for tastes; when he touches the tangible, there is lust for tangibles; and when he cognizes the cognizable, there is lust for ideas.

original: tattha āsiñcante paṭapaṭāti saddo uṭṭhahati, tathārūpaṃ khādanīyaṃ vā khādantassa🔽murumurūti saddo uppajjati, taṃ assādayato saddarāgo. Jīrakādivasagandhaṃ assādentassa
analyzed: tattha āsiñcante paṭa paṭāti saddaḥ uṭṭhahati tathārūpam khādanīyam vā khādantassa  muru muru iti saddaḥ uppajjati tam assādayataḥ sadda rāgaḥ jīrakā divasa gandham assādentassa
translated: Herein, when they sprinkle it, the sound patapatā arises. When he eats such food, the sound murumura arises. The passion for sound is in one who enjoys it.

original: gandharāgo, sādurasavasena rasarāgo. Mudubhojanaṃ phassavantanti assādayato phoṭṭhabbarāgo.
analyzed: gandha rāgaḥ sādu rasa vasena rasa rāgaḥ mudu bhojanam assādayato phoṭṭhabba rāgo
translated: The passion for smell is in one who enjoys the smell of rotting corpses, etc. The passion for taste is in one who enjoys the taste of the six flavours. The passion for touch is in one who enjoys soft food that is full of nutriment.

original: Iti imasmiṃ āhāre satisampajaññena pariggahetvā nicchandarāgaparibhogena paribhutte
analyzed: iti imasmin āhāre sati sampajaññena pariggahetvā nicchanda rāga paribhogena paribhutte
translated: So when he has taken this food with mindfulness and full awareness and has eaten it with a sense of moderation that is free from craving and passion,

original: sabbopi so pariññāto hotīti ayaṃ sabbapariññā nāma.
analyzed: sabbaḥ api so pariññātaḥ hoti iti ayam sabbapariññā nāma
translated: then all that is fully understood by him. This is called full understanding of all.

original: Katamā mūlapariññā? Pañcakāmaguṇikarāgassa hi kabaḷīkārāhāro mūlaṃ. Kasmā? Tasmiṃ
analyzed: katamā mūla pariññā pañca kāmaguṇika rāgassa hi kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ mūlam kasmā tasmin
translated: What is full understanding of the root? The gross physical food is the root of the passion of the five cords of sense desire. Why?

original: sati tassuppattito. Brāhmaṇatissabhaye kira dvādasa vassāni jāyampatikānaṃ upanijjhānacittaṃ
analyzed: sati tad uppattitaḥ brāhmaṇa tissa bhaye kira dvādasa vassāni jāyampatikānam upanijjhāna cittam
translated: Because it is when that exists that that arises. In the Brāhmaṇatissa Jātaka, it seems, for twelve years the thoughts of the young couple did not incline to anything else.

original: nāma nāhosi. Kasmā? Āhāramandatāya. Bhaye pana vūpasante yojanasatiko tambapaṇṇidīpo
analyzed: nāma kasmai āhāra manda tāya bhaye pana vūpasante yojana satiko tamba paṇṇi dīpo
translated: Why? Because of the paucity of food. But when the danger had passed, the island of Tambapaṇṇi, which was a yojana and a half long,

original: dārakānaṃ jātamaṅgalehi ekamaṅgalo ahosi. Iti mūlabhūte āhāre pariññāte pañcakāmaguṇiko
analyzed: dārakānam jāta maṅgalehi eka maṅgalaḥ ahosi iti mūla bhūte āhāre pariññāte pañca kāmaguṇiko
translated: and at the birth festival of the children he was the only one who was happy. So when the nutriment that is the root is fully understood,

original: rāgo pariññātova hotīti ayaṃ mūlapariññā nāma.
analyzed: rāgo pariññātaḥ iva hoti iti ayam mūlapariññā nāma
translated: the lust for the five cords of sense desire is fully understood too. This is what is called “the understanding of the root.”

original: Natthi taṃ saṃyojananti tena rāgena saddhiṃ pahānekaṭṭhatāya pahīnattā natthi. Evamayaṃ🔽desanā yāva anāgāmimaggā kathitā. “Ettakena pana mā vosānaṃ āpajjiṃsū”ti etesaṃyeva
analyzed: natthi tam saṃyojanan ti tena rāgena saddhim pahāna ekaṭṭha tāya pahīna ttā natthi evam ayam  desanā yāva anāgāmi maggā kathitā ettakena pana mā vosānam āpajjiṃsu iti etesam yeva
translated: “There is no fetter”: it is abandoned because it is abandoned together with that lust. So this teaching is given as far as the non-return path.

original: rūpādīnaṃ vasena pañcasu khandhesu vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā yāva arahattā kathetuṃ vaṭṭatīti.
analyzed: rūpa ādīnam vasena pañcasu khandhesu vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā yāva arahattā kathetum vaṭṭati iti
translated: “But they did not reach the end of it”: it is proper to continue the teaching by developing insight into the five aggregates, which are the same as the above-mentioned materiality, etc., and to lead them to arahatship.

original: Paṭhamāhāro (niṭṭhito).
analyzed: paṭhama āhāraḥ niṭṭhito
translated: The first nutriment is ended.

original: Dutiye niccammāti khurato paṭṭhāya yāva siṅgamūlā sakalasarīrato uddālitacammā kiṃsukarāsivaṇṇā.
analyzed: dutiye khurataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva siṅga mūlā sakala sarīrataḥ uddālita cammā kiṃsukara asi vaṇṇā
translated: In the second simile, “the flayed cow” is a cow whose hide has been removed from the neck down. It is the colour of the kiṃsuka flower.

original: Kasmā pana aññaṃ hatthiassagoṇādiupamaṃ agahetvā niccammagāvūpamā gahitāti? Titikkhituṃ
analyzed: kasmā pana aññam hatthi assa goṇa ādi upamam a gahetvā niccammagāvu upamā gahitā ati titikkhitum
translated: But why, instead of taking another simile such as an elephant, a horse, or an ox, did he take the simile of a flayed cow?🔽In order to show that they are incapable of enduring

original: asamatthabhāvadīpanatthaṃ. Mātugāmo hi uppannaṃ dukkhavedanaṃ titikkhituṃ adhivāsetuṃ
analyzed: asamattha bhāva dīpana attham mātu gāmaḥ hi uppannam dukkha vedanam titikkhitum adhivāsetum
translated: pain. For women are incapable of enduring, of bearing up against, any painful feeling that has arisen,

original: na sakkoti, evameva phassāhāro abalo dubbaloti dassanatthaṃ sadisameva upamaṃ āhari.
analyzed: na sakkoti evam eva phassa āhāraḥ abalaḥ dubbalaḥ ti dassana attham sadisam eva upamam āhari
translated: Just as the man could not do so, so too the nutriment contact is weak and powerless.🔽A wall: any one of the walls of stone, etc.,

original: Kuṭṭanti silākuṭṭādīnaṃ aññataraṃ. Kuṭṭanissitā pāṇā nāma uṇṇanābhisarabūmūsikādayo.
analyzed: kuṭṭanti silākuṭṭa ādīnam aññataram kuṭṭanissitā pāṇāḥ nāma uṇṇa nābhi sara būmūsika ādayo
translated: Wall-clinging creatures: such as spiders, scorpions, centipedes, and so on.🔽Tree-clinging creatures: such as large ants, termites, etc.🔽Water-clinging creatures: such as fish, turtles, etc.

original: Rukkhanissitāti uccāliṅgapāṇakādayo. Udakanissitāti macchasuṃsumārādayo. Ākāsanissitāti🔽ḍaṃsamakasakākakulalādayo. Khādeyyunti luñcitvā khādeyyuṃ. Sā tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne
analyzed: rukkha nissitā ati uccāliṅga pāṇaka ādayaḥ udaka nissitā ati maccha suṃsumāra ādayaḥ ākāsa nissitā ati  ḍaṃsa makasa kāka kulala ādayaḥ khādeyyunti luñcitvā khādeyyum sā tasmin tasmin ṭhāne
translated: Air-clinging creatures: such as flies, bees, birds, etc.🔽She would not want any honour or respect for herself,

original: taṃ taṃṭhānasannissayamūlikaṃ pāṇakhādanabhayaṃ sampassamānā neva attano sakkārasammānaṃ,
analyzed: tam taṃ ṭhāna sannissaya mūlikam pāṇa khādana bhayam sampassamānāḥ na iva attanaḥ sakkāra sammānam
translated: nor any rubbing and massaging of her back, body, and limbs, nor any hot water,🔽seeing the danger of being devoured by the creatures that would be her nutriment in each place.🔽So too, the bhikkhu, seeing the danger in the creatures of defilement that would be his nutriment,

original: na piṭṭhiparikammasarīrasambāhanauṇhodakāni icchati, evameva bhikkhu phassāhāramūlakaṃ🔽kilesapāṇakakhādanabhayaṃ sampassamāno tebhūmakaphassena anatthiko hoti.
analyzed: na piṭṭhi parikamma sarīra sambāhana oṇha udakāni icchati evam eva bhikkhu phassa āhāra mūlakam  kilesa pāṇaka khādana bhayam sampassamāno tebhūmaka phassena anatthikaḥ hoti
translated: does not want the three-world-element contact.

original: Phasse, bhikkhave, āhāre pariññāteti tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte. Idhāpi tisso pariññā.
analyzed: phasse bhikkhave āhāre pariññāte iti tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte idha api tisso pariññā
translated: When the nutriment contact is fully understood: it is fully understood through the three kinds of full understanding. Here too the three kinds of full understanding are the same as those already described.

original: Tattha “phasso saṅkhārakkhandho, taṃsampayuttā vedanā vedanākkhandho, saññā saññākkhandho,🔽cittaṃ viññāṇakkhandho, tesaṃ vatthārammaṇāni rūpakkhandho”ti evaṃ sappaccayassa🔽nāmarūpassa yāthāvato dassanaṃ ñātapariññā. Tattheva tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā sattannaṃ
analyzed: tattha phassaḥ saṅkhāra kkhandho tad sampayuttā vedanā vedanā kkhandho saññā saññā kkhandho  cittam viññāṇa kkhandho tesam vattha ārammaṇāni rūpa kkhandho ti evam sappaccayassa  nāma rūpassa yāthāvataḥ dassanam ñāta pariññā tattha eva ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā
translated: Herein, contact is the formations aggregate, the feeling associated therewith is the feeling aggregate, perception is the perception aggregate,🔽the consciousness is the consciousness aggregate, and their physical support and object are the form aggregate. Thus the seeing of mentality-materiality with its conditions as it actually is is full-understanding as investigation.🔽The weighing of mentality-materiality as impermanent, etc., by means of the seven contemplations is full-understanding as scrutiny.

original: anupassanānaṃ vasena aniccādito tulanaṃ tīraṇapariññā. Tasmiṃyeva pana nāmarūpe chandarāganikkaḍḍhano🔽arahattamaggo pahānapariññā. Tisso vedanāti evaṃ phassāhāre tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte
analyzed: anupassanānam vasena anicca āditaḥ tulanam tīraṇa pariññā tasmin yeva pana nāma rūpe chanda rāga nikkaḍḍhano  arahatta maggo pahāna pariññā tisso vedanā ti evam phassa āhāre tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte
translated: The abandoning of desire and lust in regard to that same mentality-materiality is full-understanding as abandoning.

original: tisso vedanā pariññātāva honti tammūlakattā taṃsampayuttattā ca. Iti phassāhāravasena
analyzed: tissaḥ vedanā pariññātā ava honti tad mūlaka ttā tad sampayutta ttā ca iti phassa āhāra vasena
translated: When the nutriment contact has been fully understood by means of these three kinds of full-understanding, the three kinds of feeling are also fully understood, because they have the same origin and because they are associated with it.

original: desanā yāva arahattā kathitā. Dutiyāhāro.
analyzed: desanā yāva arahattā kathitā dutiya āhāro
translated: Thus the teaching by way of the nutriment contact is given up to arahantship. This is the second nutriment.

original: Tatiye aṅgārakāsūti aṅgārānaṃ kāsu. Kāsūti rāsipi vuccati āvāṭopi.
analyzed: tatiye aṅgārakāsu iti vuccati āvāṭopi
translated: In the third, the “pit of live embers” is the place for embers. A pit is called a place.

original: “Aṅgārakāsuṃ apare phuṇanti,🔽Narā rudantā paridaḍḍhagattā;
analyzed: aṅgāraka asum apare phuṇanti 🔽narā rudantā paridaḍḍha gattā
translated: “Some, with their bodies all ablaze,🔽Cry out as they fall into the pit of live embers.

original: Bhayañhi maṃ vindati sūta disvā,
analyzed: bhayan hi mam vindati sūta disvā
translated: For fear of you I feel, O charioteer,

original: Pucchāmi taṃ mātali devasārathī”ti. ; –
analyzed: pucchāmi tam mātali deva sārathi iti
translated: When I behold you, charioteer of gods. ”

original: Ettha rāsi “kāsū”ti vutto.
analyzed: ettha rāsi kāsu iti vutto
translated: Here the pit is called “kasu.”

original: “Kinnu santaramānova, kāsuṃ khanasi sārathī”ti?. –
analyzed: kinnu santaramānā uva kāsum khanasi sārathī iti
translated: “Why, charioteer, do you dig a kasu as though you were in a hurry? ”

original: Ettha āvāṭo. Idhāpi ayameva adhippeto. Sādhikaporisāti atirekaporisā pañcaratanappamāṇā.🔽Vītaccikānaṃ vītadhūmānanti etenassa mahāpariḷāhataṃ dasseti. Jālāya vā hi dhūme
analyzed: ettha āvāṭaḥ idha api ayam eva adhippeto sā adhika porisā ati atireka porisā pañca ratana ppamāṇā  vīta ccikānam vīta dhūmānam ti etena assa mahā pariḷāha tam dasseti jālāya vā hi dhūme
translated: Here the pit is a pit. Here too this is what is intended. With a rim exceeding the rim: with a rim exceeding the rim of the five treasures.

original: vā sati vāto samuṭṭhāti, pariḷāho mahā na hoti, tadabhāve vātābhāvato pariḷāho mahā
analyzed: vā sati vāto samuṭṭhāti pariḷāhaḥ mahā na hoti tad abhāve vāta abhāvato pariḷāhaḥ mahā
translated: The fire is without smoke, without flame: this shows that it is intensely hot. For when there is a net or smoke, the wind rises and the heat is not intense. But when these are absent, there is no wind and the heat is intense.

original: hoti. Ārakāvassāti dūreyeva bhaveyya.
analyzed: hoti ārakāvassā ati dūreyā iva bhaveyya
translated: It is far away: it would be far away.

original: Evameva khoti ettha idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – aṅgārakāsu viya hi tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam aṅgārakāsu viya hi tebhūmaka vaṭṭam daṭṭhabbam
translated: Here is the correlation of the similes: the three-world round should be regarded as the fire-pit.

original: Jīvitukāmo puriso viya vaṭṭanissito bālaputhujjano. Dve balavanto purisā viya kusalākusalakammaṃ.
analyzed: jīvitu kāmo purisaḥ viya vaṭṭa nissitaḥ bāla puthujjanaḥ dve balavanto purisāḥ viya kusala akusala kammaṃ
translated: The fool, the worldling, who is dependent on the round is like the man who wants to live. The profitable and unprofitable kamma are like the two strong men.

original: Tesaṃ taṃ purisaṃ nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuṃ upakaḍḍhanakālo viya puthujjanassa
analyzed: tesam tam purisam nānā bāhāsu gahetvā aṅgāraka asum upakaḍḍhana kālaḥ viya puthujjanassa
translated: For them the time of being seized by the men and dragged to the charcoal pit is like the time of the worldling’s accumulation of kamma.

original: kammāyūhanakālo. Kammañhi āyūhiyamānameva paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhati nāma. Aṅgārakāsunidānaṃ
analyzed: kamma āyūhana kālaḥ kamman hi āyūhiyamānam eva paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhati nāma aṅgārakāsu nidānam
translated: For kamma, as it is being accumulated, is said to drag along rebirth-linking. The suffering that has the charcoal pit as its source

original: dukkhaṃ viya kammanidānaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dukkham viya kamma nidānam vaṭṭa dukkham veditabbam
translated: should be understood as the suffering of the round of rebirths that has kamma as its source.

original: Pariññāteti tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte. Pariññāyojanā panettha phasse vuttanayeneva
analyzed: pariññātā iti tīhi pariññāhi pariññāte pariññā yojanā pana ittha phasse vutta nayena iva
translated: ‘Are fully understood’: are fully understood by means of the three kinds of full understanding. The application of the three kinds of full understanding here should be understood in the way already stated under contact .

original: veditabbā. Tisso taṇhāti kāmataṇhā bhavataṇhā vibhavataṇhāti imā pariññātā honti.
analyzed: veditabbā tissaḥ taṇhā ati kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā ati imā pariññātāḥ honti
translated: ‘The three kinds of craving’: craving for sense desires, craving for becoming, and craving for non-becoming. These are fully understood.

original: Kasmā? Taṇhāmūlakattā manosañcetanāya. Na hi hetumhi appahīne phalaṃ pahīyati. Iti
analyzed: kasmā taṇhā mūlaka ttā manaḥ sañcetanāya na hi hetumhi appahīne phalam pahīyati iti
translated: Why? Because of the root-cause of craving in the case of mental volition. For as long as the root-cause is not abandoned, the fruit is not abandoned. Thus

original: manosañcetanāhāravasenapi yāva arahattā desanā kathitā. Tatiyāhāro.
analyzed: manaḥ sañcetanā āhāra vasena api desanā kathitā tatiya āhāro
translated: the teaching is given up to arahantship by means of the nutriment mental volition. This is the third nutriment.

original: Catutthe āgucārinti pāpacāriṃ dosakārakaṃ. Kathaṃ so purisoti so puriso kathaṃbhūto, kiṃ yāpeti, na yāpetīti pucchati? Tatheva deva jīvatīti yathā pubbe, idānipi tatheva jīvati.
analyzed: catutthe āgucārinti pāpa cārim dosa kārakam katham so puriso ti saḥ puriso kathaṃbhūtaḥ kim yāpeti na yāpeti iti pucchati tathā iva deva jīvati iti yathā pubbe idāni pi tathā iva jīvati
translated: In the fourth, “a wrongdoer” is a wrongdoer, a hater. “How does that man live?” he asks, “what does he eat, does he not eat?” “Just so, sire, he lives” — just as before, so now he lives.

original: Evameva khoti idhāpi idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – rājā viya hi kammaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, āgucārī
analyzed: evam eva kho ti idha api idam opamma saṃsandanam rājā viya hi kammam daṭṭhabbam āgu cārī
translated: “Even so, sire” — here is the correspondence of the similes: The king should be seen as kamma. The wrongdoer

original: puriso viya vaṭṭasannissito bālaputhujjano, tīṇi sattisatāni viya paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: purisaḥ viya vaṭṭa sannissitaḥ bāla puthujjano tīṇi satti satāni viya paṭisandhi viññāṇam
translated: is the fool who is dependent on the round of rebirths. The three hundred spears are the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: āgucāriṃ purisaṃ “tīhi sattisatehi hanathā”ti raññā āṇattakālo viya kammaraññā vaṭṭasannissitaputhujjanaṃ
analyzed: āgucārim purisam tīhi satti satehi hanatha ati raññā āṇatta kālaḥ viya kamma raññā vaṭṭa sannissita puthujjanam
translated: The king’s command, “Execute the wrongdoer with three hundred spears,” is like the kamma-king’s taking the fool who is dependent on the round of rebirths

original: gahetvā paṭisandhiyaṃ pakkhipanakālo. Tattha kiñcāpi tīṇi sattisatāni viya paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: gahetvā paṭisandhiyam pakkhipana kālo tattha kiñcā api tīṇi satti satāni viya paṭisandhi viññāṇam
translated: and inserting him into rebirth-linking. Here, although the rebirth-linking consciousness is like the three hundred spears,

original: sattīsu pana dukkhaṃ natthi, sattīhi pahaṭavaṇamūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ, evameva paṭisandhiyampi
analyzed: sattīsu pana dukkham natthi sattīhi pahaṭa vaṇa mūlakam dukkham evam eva paṭisandhiyam pi
translated: there is no pain in the spears, but the pain is in the wound made by the spears. Even so, although the rebirth-linking consciousness is

original: dukkhaṃ natthi, dinnāya pana paṭisandhiyā pavatte vipākadukkhaṃ sattipahaṭavaṇamūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ viya hoti.
analyzed: dukkham natthi dinnāya pana paṭisandhiyā pavatte vipāka dukkham satti pahaṭa vaṇa mūlakam dukkham viya hoti
translated: There is no suffering, but there is suffering as the result of rebirth-linking and as the suffering of the formations in the process of becoming, like the suffering of a wound caused by a spear.

original: Pariññāteti tīheva pariññāhi pariññāte. Idhāpi pariññāyojanā phassāhāre vuttanayeneva
analyzed: pariññātā iti tīhi iva pariññāhi pariññāte idha api pariññā yojanā phassa āhāre vutta nayena iva
translated: “Fully understood”: fully understood by the three kinds of full understanding. The application of the term “full understanding” should be understood here in the way already described under the nutriment contact.

original: veditabbā. Nāmarūpanti viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ. Viññāṇasmiñhi pariññāte taṃ pariññātameva
analyzed: veditabbā nāma rūpanti viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpam viññāṇasmin hi pariññāte tam pariññātam eva
translated: “Mentality-materiality”: mentality-materiality with consciousness as condition. For when consciousness is fully understood, that is fully understood too,

original: hoti tammūlakattā sahuppannattā ca. Iti viññāṇāhāravasenapi yāva arahattā desanā
analyzed: hoti tad mūlaka ttā sahuppanna ttā ca iti viññāṇa āhāra vasena api yāva arahattā desanā
translated: because it has the same root and because it is associated with it. So the teaching is given up to arahantship by means of the nutriment consciousness.

original: kathitāti. Catutthāhāro. Tatiyaṃ.🔽4. Atthirāgasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kathitā ati catuttha āhāro tatiyam  atthirāga sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: This is the fourth nutriment. The third sutta is finished.🔽. The Sutta on Greed, etc.

original: 64. Catutthe rāgotiādīni lobhasseva nāmāni. So hi rañjanavasena rāgo, nandanavasena
analyzed: catutthe rāga uti ādīni lobhassa iva nāmāni saḥ hi rañjana vasena rāgaḥ nandana vasena
translated: In the fourth sutta, “greed,” etc., are names for greed. For that is called “greed” because of its state of being mixed with enjoyment ,🔽and it is called “delight” because of its state of being mixed with delight , and it is called “craving” because of its state of being mixed with the act of seeking .

original: nandī, taṇhāyanavasena taṇhāti vuccati. Patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ virūḷhanti kammaṃ🔽javāpetvā paṭisandhiākaḍḍhanasamatthatāya patiṭṭhitañceva virūḷhañca. Yatthāti tebhūmakavaṭṭe
analyzed: nandī taṇhāyana vasena taṇhā ati vuccati patiṭṭhitam tattha viññāṇam virūḷhanti kammaṃ 🔽javāpetvā paṭisandhi ākaḍḍhana samattha tāya patiṭṭhitam ca iva virūḍham ca yatthā ati tebhūmaka vaṭṭe
translated: “The consciousness is steadied and grows”: it is steadied and grows because it has the ability to draw along rebirth-linking after it has made the kamma quick.🔽“In what”: in the round of the three planes.

original: bhummaṃ, sabbattha vā purimapurimapade etaṃ bhummaṃ. Atthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhīti
analyzed: bhummam sabbattha vā purima purima pade etam bhummam atthi tattha
translated: Or else the word “there” is to be construed with each clause.

original: idaṃ imasmiṃ vipākavaṭṭe ṭhitassa āyativaṭṭahetuke saṅkhāre sandhāya vuttaṃ. Yattha
analyzed: idam imasmin vipāka vaṭṭe ṭhitassa āyati vaṭṭa hetuke saṅkhāre sandhāya vuttam yattha
translated: This is said with reference to the formations that are the cause for the future round of rebirths of one who is standing in this round of results.

original: atthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattīti yasmiṃ ṭhāne āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti atthi.
analyzed: atthi āyatim punabbhava abhinibbatti iti yasmin ṭhāne āyatim punabbhava abhinibbatti atthi
translated: Where there is … a future arising in a renewed existence: where there is a future arising in a renewed existence in a certain place.

original: Evameva khoti ettha idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – rajakacittakārā viya hi sahakammasambhāraṃ🔽kammaṃ, phalakabhittidussapaṭā viya tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ. Yathā rajakacittakārā parisuddhesu
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam rajaka citta kārāḥ viya hi saha kamma sambhāram  kammam phalaka bhitti dussapaṭāḥ viya tebhūmaka vaṭṭam yathā rajaka citta kārā parisuddhesu
translated: Just so: here is the application of the simile. The kamma together with its requisites is like the painter and the decorator.🔽The round of rebirths in the three planes is like the wall, etc. Just as the painter and the decorator produce the picture on the well-prepared wall, etc.,

original: phalakādīsu rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpenti, evameva sasambhārakakammaṃ bhavesu rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.🔽Tattha yathā akusalena cittakārena samuṭṭhāpitaṃ rūpaṃ virūpaṃ hoti dussaṇṭhitaṃ
analyzed: phalaka ādīsu rūpam samuṭṭhāpenti evam eva sa sambhāraka kammam bhavesu rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti  tattha yathā akusalena cittakārena samuṭṭhāpitam rūpam virūpam hoti dussaṇṭhitam
translated: so kamma together with its requisites produces materiality in the various kinds of becoming.🔽Just as the picture produced by an unskilful painter and decorator is ugly, badly arranged, and unpleasing,

original: amanāpaṃ, evameva ekacco kammaṃ karonto ñāṇavippayuttena cittena karoti, taṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: amanāpam evam eva ekaccaḥ kammam karontaḥ ñāṇa vippayuttena cittena karoti tam kammaṃ
translated: so the materiality produced by kamma done with a mind destitute of knowledge is ugly, badly arranged, and unpleasing.

original: rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpentaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ sampattiṃ adatvā dubbaṇṇaṃ dussaṇṭhitaṃ mātāpitūnampi🔽amanāpaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Yathā pana kusalena cittakārena samuṭṭhāpitaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: rūpam samuṭṭhāpentam cakkha ādīnam sampattim a datvā dubbaṇṇam dussaṇṭhitam mātā pitūnam pi  amanāpam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti yathā pana kusalena cittakārena samuṭṭhāpitam rūpam
translated: and it produces materiality that is ugly and badly disposed, disagreeable even to its parents, without giving the eye, etc., their perfection.🔽But just as materiality produced by a skillful craftsman is beautiful, well disposed, and agreeable,

original: surūpaṃ hoti susaṇṭhitaṃ manāpaṃ, evameva ekacco kammaṃ karonto ñāṇasampayuttena🔽cittena karoti, taṃ kammaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpentaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ sampattiṃ datvā suvaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: surūpam hoti su saṇṭhitam manāpam evam eva ekacco kammam karontaḥ ñāṇa sampayuttena  cittena karoti tam kammam rūpam samuṭṭhāpentam cakkha ādīnam sampattim da tvā suvaṇṇam
translated: so too, when one performs an action with consciousness associated with knowledge,

original: susaṇṭhitaṃ alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ viya rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: su saṇṭhitam alaṅkata paṭiyattam viya rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: that action produces materiality that gives the eye, etc., their perfection, and it produces materiality that is beautiful, well disposed, like a well-fashioned ornament.

original: Ettha ca āhāraṃ viññāṇena saddhiṃ saṅkhipitvā āhāranāmarūpānaṃ antare eko sandhi,🔽vipākavidhiṃ nāmarūpena saṅkhipitvā nāmarūpasaṅkhārānaṃ antare eko sandhi, saṅkhārānañca
analyzed: ettha ca āhāram viññāṇena saddhim saṅkhipitvā āhāra nāma rūpānaṃ antare ekaḥ sandhi  vipāka vidhim nāma rūpena saṅkhipitvā antare
translated: Herein, one junction is to be understood between nutriment and mentality-materiality by omitting consciousness together with nutriment,

original: āyatibhavassa ca antare eko sandhīti veditabbo.🔽Kūṭāgāranti ekakaṇṇikaṃ gāhāpetvā kataṃ agāraṃ. Kūṭāgārasālāti dve kaṇṇike gahetvā
analyzed: āyati bhavassa ca antare ekaḥ sandhi iti veditabbo 🔽eka kaṇṇikam gāhāpetvā katam agāram kūṭāgāra sālā ati dve kaṇṇike gahetvā
translated: one junction between mentality-materiality and the corporeal basis by omitting the process of kamma-result together with mentality-materiality, and one junction between the kamma-process and the next becoming by omitting the kamma-process and the next becoming.

original: katasālā. Evameva khoti ettha khīṇāsavassa kammaṃ sūriyarasmisamaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sūriyarasmi
analyzed: kata sālā evam eva kho ti ettha khīṇāsavassa kammam sūriya rasmi samam veditabbam sūriya rasmi
translated: and the hall is finished. So too, the action of one who is without cankers should be understood to be like the sun’s rays. But the sun’s rays

original: pana atthi, sā kevalaṃ patiṭṭhāya abhāvena appatiṭṭhā nāma jātā, khīṇāsavassa kammaṃ🔽natthitāya eva appatiṭṭhaṃ. Tassa hi kāyādayo atthi, tehi pana katakammaṃ kusalākusalaṃ🔽nāma na hoti, kiriyamatte ṭhatvā avipākaṃ hoti. Evamassa kammaṃ natthitāya eva appatiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pana atthi sā kevalam patiṭṭhāya abhāvena appatiṭṭhā nāma jātā khīṇāsavassa kammaṃ  eva appatiṭṭham tassa hi kāya ādayaḥ atthi tehi pana kata kammam kusala akusalam  nāma na hoti kiriya matte avipākam hoti evam assa kammam natthitāya eva appatiṭṭham
translated: are, nevertheless, only called “unsupported” because of the absence of a support. The action of one who is without cankers is

original: nāma jātanti. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: nāma jātanti catuttham
translated: unsupported because it does not exist. For although his body, etc., exist, the action that he performs by means of them is neither profitable nor unprofitable; it is only indeterminate, and it does not exist for the purpose of ripening. Thus his action is called “unsupported” because it does not exist. The fourth kind is finished.

original: 5. Nagarasuttavaṇṇanā🔽65. Pañcame nāmarūpe kho sati viññāṇanti ettha “saṅkhāresu sati viññāṇa”nti ca “avijjāya🔽sati saṅkhārā”ti ca vattabbaṃ bhaveyya, tadubhayampi na vuttaṃ. Kasmā? Avijjāsaṅkhārā
analyzed: nagara sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcame nāma rūpe kho sati viññāṇanti ettha saṅkhāresu sati viññāṇanti ca avijjāya  sati saṅkhārā iti ca vattabbam bhaveyya tat ubhayam pi na vuttam kasmai avijjā saṅkhārā
translated: . The explanation of the “City” sutta is finished.🔽. In the passage, “With mentality-materiality present, consciousness” , it should be said that “with formations present, consciousness” and “with ignorance present, formations” . But both are not said. Why? Because ignorance and formations are the third becoming, and insight does not coincide with that. For the Great Man is intent on the five aggregates of the present becoming.

original: hi tatiyo bhavo, tehi saddhiṃ ayaṃ vipassanā na ghaṭīyati. Mahāpuriso hi paccuppannapañcavokāravasena abhiniviṭṭhoti.
analyzed: hi tatiyaḥ bhavo tehi saddhim ayam vipassanā na mahāpuriso hi paccuppanna pañcavokāra vasena abhiniviṭṭho ti
translated: for the third becoming, and so this insight does not fit in with them. For the Great Man is attached to the five aggregates of the present becoming.

original: Nanu ca avijjāsaṅkhāresu adiṭṭhesu na sakkā buddhena bhavitunti. Saccaṃ na sakkā,
analyzed: nanu ca avijjā saṅkhāresu a diṭṭhesu na sakkā buddhena bhavitun ti saccam na sakkā
translated: But surely, if the ignorance and the formations have not been seen, the Buddha cannot have existed? It is true that he cannot have existed,

original: iminā pana te bhavaupādānataṇhāvasena diṭṭhāva. Tasmā yathā nāma godhaṃ anubandhanto
analyzed: iminā pana te bhava aupādāna taṇhā vasena diṭṭhāva tasmai yathā nāma godham anubandhanto
translated: but they have been seen by him through craving for becoming and assuming of becoming. Therefore, just as a man tracking a deer

original: puriso taṃ kūpaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ disvā otaritvā paviṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ khaṇitvā godhaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: puriso tam kūpam paviṭṭham disvā otaritvā paviṭṭha ṭhānam khaṇitvā godham gahetvā
translated: would see the place where the deer had gone down into a pit, and after going down there himself, he would dig up the place where the deer had gone down and

original: pakkameyya, na parabhāgaṃ khaneyya, kasmā? Kassaci natthitāya. Evaṃ mahāpurisopi
analyzed: pakkameyya na parabhāgam khaneyya kasmai kassaci natthitāya evam mahā purisaḥ api
translated: catch the deer and go away, and would not dig up the other side, because there was no deer there, so too, the Great Man,

original: godhaṃ anubandhanto puriso viya bodhipallaṅke nisinno jarāmaraṇato paṭṭhāya “imassa🔽ayaṃ paccayo, imassa ayaṃ paccayo”ti pariyesanto yāva nāmarūpadhammānaṃ paccayaṃ
analyzed: godham anubandhantaḥ puriso viya bodhi pallaṅke nisinno jarā maraṇataḥ paṭṭhāya imassa  ayam paccayaḥ imassa ayam paccayo ti pariyesantaḥ yāva nāma rūpa dhammānam paccayam
translated: like the man tracking the deer, sitting on the seat of enlightenment, investigating from aging-and-death thus “This has such-and-such a condition”

original: disvā tassapi paccayaṃ pariyesanto viññāṇameva addasa. Tato “ettako pañcavokārabhavavasena
analyzed: disvā tassa api paccayam pariyesantaḥ viññāṇam eva addasa tatas ettako pañcavokāra bhava vasena
translated: until he saw the condition for mental formations, and investigating the condition for that too, saw only consciousness. Then he turned back the insight thus “This much is the range of the five aggregates as becoming”

original: sammasanacāro”ti vipassanaṃ paṭinivattesi, parato tucchakūpassa abhinnaṭṭhānaṃ viya
analyzed: sammasana cāro ti vipassanam paṭinivattesi paratas tuccha kūpassa a bhinna ṭṭhānam viya
translated: and he did not go beyond that, just as the man tracking the deer would not dig up the other side of the pit.

original: avijjāsaṅkhāradvayaṃ atthi, tadetaṃ heṭṭhā vipassanāya gahitattā pāṭiyekkaṃ sammasanūpagaṃ🔽na hotīti na aggahesi.
analyzed: avijjā saṅkhāra dvayam atthi tat etam heṭṭhā vipassanāya gahita ttā pāṭiyekkam sammasana upagaṃ  na hoti iti na aggahesi
translated: The two, ignorance and formations, are there, but they are not included separately in the method of reviewing because they have already been included in insight.

original: Paccudāvattatīti paṭinivattati. Katamaṃ panettha viññāṇaṃ paccudāvattatīti? Paṭisandhiviññāṇampi🔽vipassanāviññāṇampi. Tattha paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ paccayato paṭinivattati, vipassanāviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: paccudāvattati iti paṭinivattati katamam pana ittha viññāṇam paccudāvattati iti paṭisandhi viññāṇam pi  vipassanā viññāṇam pi tattha paṭisandhi viññāṇam paccayataḥ paṭinivattati vipassanā viññāṇam
translated: It turns back: it turns back from the occurrence of rebirth-linking. But what is it that turns back here? The rebirth-linking consciousness and the insight consciousness. Herein, the rebirth-linking consciousness turns back from the condition,

original: ārammaṇato. Ubhayampi nāmarūpaṃ nātikkamati, nāmarūpato paraṃ na gacchati. Ettāvatā🔽jāyetha vātiādīsu viññāṇe nāmarūpassa paccaye honte, nāmarūpe viññāṇassa paccaye🔽honte, dvīsupi aññamaññapaccayesu hontesu ettakena jāyetha vā upapajjetha vā. Ito
analyzed: ārammaṇataḥ ubhayam pi nāma rūpam na atikkamati nāma rūpataḥ param na gacchati ettāvatā  jāyetha vā tiādīsu viññāṇe nāma rūpassa paccaye honte nāma rūpe viññāṇassa paccaye  honte dvīsu pi aññamañña paccayesu hontesu ettakena jāyetha vā upapajjetha vā itas
translated: and the insight consciousness turns back from the object. Both of them do not go beyond mentality-materiality; they do not go beyond to anything beyond mentality-materiality.🔽As far as this goes, there is birth, there is descent into the womb, there is rebirth-linking, there is appearance, there is the manifestation of the aggregates, there is the manifestation of the sense bases, there is the manifestation of the elements, there is the occurrence of formations, there is the descent of consciousness, there is the descent of ignorance, there is the condition, there is the cause, there is the origin, there is the conditionality, there is the process of conditionality, there is the generation, there is the production, there is the arising, there is the manifestation, there is the appearance of this whole world, of the three worlds, of the four great systems, of the five aggregates, of the six bases, of the seven factors of existence, of the eight worldly conditions, of the nine roots, of the ten bases.🔽When consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality, and mentality-materiality is a condition for consciousness, and both these are conditions for each other, then with this much there is birth, there is descent into the womb, there is rebirth-linking, there is appearance, there is the manifestation of the aggregates, there is the manifestation of the sense bases, there is the manifestation of the elements, there is the occurrence of formations, there is the descent of consciousness, there is the descent of ignorance, there is the condition, there is the cause, there is the origin, there is the conditionality, there is the process of conditionality, there is the generation, there is the production, there is the arising, there is the manifestation, there is the appearance of this whole world, of the three worlds, of the four great systems, of the five aggregates, of the six bases, of the seven factors of existence, of the eight worldly conditions, of the nine roots, of the ten bases.

original: hi paraṃ kimaññaṃ jāyetha vā upapajjetha vā, nanu etadeva jāyati ca upapajjati cāti?
analyzed: hi param kimaññam jāyetha vā upapajjetha vā nanu etat eva jāyati ca upapajjati ca ati
translated: What else is there to be born or descend into a

original: Evaṃ saddhiṃ aparāparacutipaṭisandhīhi pañca padāni dassetvā puna taṃ ettāvatāti
analyzed: evam saddhim apara apara cuti paṭisandhīhi pañca padāni dassetvā puna tam ettāvatā ti
translated: Having thus shown the five terms with the successive deaths and rebirths, he again interprets the meaning stated in the words “to that extent”

original: vuttamatthaṃ niyyātento yadidaṃ nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpanti🔽vatvā tato paraṃ anulomapaccayākāravasena viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpamūlakaṃ āyatijarāmaraṇaṃ
analyzed: vutta mattham niyyātentaḥ yat idam nāma rūpa paccayā viññāṇam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpanti  vatvā tato param anuloma paccaya ākāra vasena viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpa mūlakam āyati jarā maraṇam
translated: by the words “With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality; with mentality-materiality as condition, consciousness” .

original: dassetuṃ nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanantiādimāha.
analyzed: dassetum nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatana ntiādim āha
translated: Then, in order to show future ageing-and-death rooted in mentality-materiality with consciousness as condition by the method of conditions in direct order, he says “With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base” .

original: Añjasanti maggasseva vevacanaṃ. Uddhāpavantanti āpato uggatattā uddhāpanti laddhavohārena🔽pākāravatthunā samannāgataṃ. Ramaṇīyanti samantā catunnaṃ dvārānaṃ abbhantare ca
analyzed: añjasanti maggassa iva vevacanam āpataḥ uggata ttā uddhāpanti laddha vohārena  samannāgatam ramaṇīyanti samantā abbhantare ca
translated: Añjasā is a synonym for “path.” Uddhāpavantīti means “they cause to be lifted out” because they have risen above the danger.

original: nānābhaṇḍānaṃ sampattiyā ramaṇīyaṃ. Māpehīti mahājanaṃ pesetvā vāsaṃ kārehi. Māpeyyāti
analyzed: nānā bhaṇḍānam sampattiyāḥ ramaṇīyam mā āpehi iti mahājanam pesetvā vāsam kārehi mā āpeyya ati
translated: They are endowed with a wall-like substance. Ramaṇīya means delightful because of the abundance of various goods inside the four gates on all sides. Māpehīti means “having sent a great crowd, cause them to dwell.” Māpeyyāti means “he would cause them to dwell.”

original: vāsaṃ kāreyya. Kārento ca paṭhamaṃ aṭṭhārasa manussakoṭiyo pesetvā “sampuṇṇa”nti

original: vasitukāmā, yathāsukhaṃ gacchantu, imañcimañca parihāraṃ labhissantī’ti nagarassa
analyzed: vasitu kāmāḥ yathāsukham gacchantu iman ca iman ca parihāram labhissanti iti nagarassa
translated: If they wish to live here, let them come and live here as they like and get this bedding and seat.”

original: ceva vaṇṇaṃ lokassa ca parihāralābhaṃ ghosāpethā”ti vadeyya. So evaṃ kareyya. Tato
analyzed: ca iva vaṇṇam lokassa ca parihāra lābham ghosāpetha ati vadeyya saḥ evam kareyya tatas
translated: And let them proclaim the city’s good qualities and the benefits of the alms to be got there.’ He would do so. Then

analyzed: manussāḥ nagara guṇañca iva parihāra lābhañca sutvā sabba disāhi samosaritvā nagaram pūreyyuṃ  tam aparena samayena iddham ca iva assa phītam ca tam sandhāya tat assa nagaram aparena
translated: people, hearing about the city’s good qualities and the benefits of the alms to be got there, would come together from all quarters and fill the city.

original: samayena iddhañceva phītañcātiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha iddhanti samiddhaṃ subhikkhaṃ. Phītanti sabbasampattīhi pupphitaṃ. Bāhujaññanti
analyzed: samayena iddham ca iva phītam ca atiādi vuttaṃ  tattha iddham ti samiddham subhikkham phītam ti sabba sampattīhi pupphitam bāhujaññam
translated: After a time it would become prosperous and flourishing.🔽The Blessed One said this: “Bhikkhus, in the future this city of Kesaputta will become prosperous, flourishing, and populous; it will be full of human beings, and it will be thriving.”

original: bahūhi ñātabbaṃ, bahujanānaṃ hitaṃ vā. “Bahujana”ntipi pāṭho. Ākiṇṇamanussanti manussehi🔽ākiṇṇaṃ nirantaraṃ phuṭṭhaṃ. Vuḍḍhivepullappattanti vuḍḍhippattañceva vepullappattañca,
analyzed: bahūhi ñātabbam bahu janānam hitam vā bahu jana nti pi pāṭhaḥ ākiṇṇa manussanti manussehi 🔽ākiṇṇam nirantaram phuṭṭham vuḍḍhi vepulla ppattanti vuḍḍhi ppattam ca iva vepulla ppattam ca
translated: Herein, prosperous means well supplied with the requisites of life. Flourishing means it has reached growth and abundance. Populous means it is full of people. Full of human beings means it is crowded with people. Thriving means it has reached growth.

original: seṭṭhabhāvañceva vipulabhāvañca pattaṃ, dasasahassacakkavāḷe agganagaraṃ jātanti attho.🔽Evameva khoti ettha idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – araññapavane caramānapuriso viya hi
analyzed: seṭṭha bhāvam ca iva vipula bhāvam ca pattam dasa sahassa cakkavāḷe agga nagaram jātanti attho  evam eva kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam arañña pavane caramāna puriso viya hi
translated: and it has attained the state of being the best and the state of being the most extensive, the meaning is that it has become the chief city in the ten-thousandfold world-system.

original: dīpaṅkarapādamūlato paṭṭhāya pāramiyo pūrayamāno mahāpuriso daṭṭhabbo, tassa purisassa🔽pubbakehi manussehi anuyātamaggadassanaṃ viya mahāsattassa anupubbena bodhipallaṅke🔽nisinnassa pubbabhāge aṭṭhaṅgikassa vipassanāmaggassa dassanaṃ, purisassa taṃ ekapadikamaggaṃ
analyzed: dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya pāramiyaḥ pūrayamāno mahā puriso daṭṭhabbo tassa purisassa  pubbakehi manussehi anuyāta magga dassanam viya mahāsattassa anupubbena bodhi pallaṅke  nisinnassa pubba bhāge aṭṭhaṅgikassa vipassanā maggassa dassanam purisassa tam ekapadika maggaṃ
translated: “So too, bhikkhus, here” : here is the correlativity of the simile. The Great Man who fulfilled the pāramīs beginning from the time of the Buddha Dīpaṅkara should be regarded as the man wandering in the forest and the jungle.🔽The man’s seeing the path previously used by men is like the Great Being’s gradual seeing of the eightfold noble path of insight,

original: anugacchato aparabhāge mahāmaggadassanaṃ viya mahāsattassa uparivipassanāya ciṇṇante🔽lokuttaramaggadassanaṃ, purisassa teneva maggena gacchato purato nagaradassanaṃ viya
analyzed: anugacchataḥ apara bhāge mahā magga dassanam viya mahāsattassa upari vipassanāya ciṇṇante  lokuttara magga dassanam purisassa tena iva maggena gacchataḥ puratas nagara dassanam viya
translated: which is the preliminary stage of his sitting down on the seat of enlightenment. The man’s seeing the great road after following the single path is like the Great Being’s seeing of the supramundane path after completing the higher insight.

original: tathāgatassa nibbānanagaradassanaṃ, bahinagaraṃ panettha aññena diṭṭhaṃ, aññena manussavāsaṃ
analyzed: tathāgatassa nibbāna nagara dassanam bahi nagaram pana ittha aññena diṭṭham aññena manussa vāsam
translated: The man’s seeing the city ahead of him as he goes by that road is like the Tathāgata’s seeing of the city of Nibbāna. But here the city outside is seen by one, and the city of human beings by another.

original: kataṃ, nibbānanagaraṃ satthā sayameva passi, sayaṃ vāsamakāsi. Tassa purisassa catunnaṃ🔽dvārānaṃ diṭṭhakālo viya tathāgatassa catunnaṃ maggānaṃ diṭṭhakālo, tassa catūhi
analyzed: katam nibbāna nagaram satthā sayam eva passi sayam vāsam akāsi tassa purisassa catunnam  dvārānam diṭṭha kālo viya tathāgatassa catunnam maggānam diṭṭha kālo tassa catūhi
translated: The Teacher himself saw the city of Nibbāna and himself dwelt there. The time when the Tathāgata saw the four paths was like the time when the man saw the four gates.

original: dvārehi nagaraṃ paviṭṭhakālo viya tathāgatassa catūhi maggehi nibbānaṃ paviṭṭhakālo,
analyzed: dvārehi nagaram paviṭṭha kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa catūhi maggehi nibbānam paviṭṭha kālaḥ
translated: The Teacher himself saw the city of Nibbāna and himself entered it. The time when the man saw the four gates is like the time when the Tathāgata saw the four paths. The time when the man entered the city through the four gates is like the time when the Tathāgata entered Nibbāna through the four paths.

original: tassa nagarabbhantare bhaṇḍavavatthānakālo viya tathāgatassa paccavekkhaṇañāṇena🔽paropaṇṇāsakusaladhammavavatthānakālo. Nagarassa agārakaraṇatthaṃ kulapariyesanakālo🔽viya satthu phalasamāpattito vuṭṭhāya veneyyasatte volokanakālo, tena purisena yācitassa🔽rañño ekaṃ mahākuṭumbikaṃ diṭṭhakālo viya mahābrahmunā yācitassa bhagavato aññāsikoṇḍaññattheraṃ
analyzed: tassa nagara bbhantare bhaṇḍa vavatthāna kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena  paropaṇṇāsa kusala dhamma vavatthāna kālo nagarassa agāra karaṇa attham kula pariyesana kālo  viya satthu phala samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya veneyya satte volokana kālo tena purisena yācitassa  raññaḥ ekam mahākuṭumbikam diṭṭha kālaḥ viya mahābrahmunā yācitassa bhagavataḥ aññāsikoṇḍañña ttheram
translated: The time when the man laid out the goods in the city is like the time when the Tathāgata, by means of the knowledge of reviewing, laid out the fifty-two kinds of skill in the aggregates, etc.🔽The time when the man searched for a family to live with in order to build a house is like the time when the Master, after emerging from the fruition attainment, looked for disciples to instruct. The time when the man saw the great householder whom the king had asked to live in the city is like the time when the Blessed One saw the Elder Aññāsi Koṇḍañña whom he had been asked to instruct by the Great Brahma.

original: diṭṭhakālo, rañño mahākuṭumbikaṃ pakkosāpetvā “nagaravāsaṃ karohī”ti pahitakālo viya
analyzed: diṭṭha kālaḥ raññaḥ mahākuṭumbikam pakkosāpetvā nagara vāsam karohi iti pahita kālaḥ viya
translated: The time when the king summoned the great householder and told him to live in the city is like the time when the Blessed One summoned the Elder Aññāsi Koṇḍañña and told him to instruct the bhikkhus.

original: bhagavato ekasmiṃ pacchābhatte aṭṭhārasayojanamaggaṃ gantvā āsāḷhipuṇṇamadivase bārāṇasiyaṃ
analyzed: bhagavato ekasmin pacchābhatte aṭṭhārasa yojana maggam gantvā āsāḷhipuṇṇama divase bārāṇasiyam
translated: and the time when the Exalted One, after going eighteen leagues in one day, entered the Deer Park at Bārāṇasī on the full-moon day of Āsāḷhi,

original: isipatanaṃ pavisitvā theraṃ kāyasakkhiṃ katvā dhammaṃ desitakālo, mahākuṭumbikena🔽aṭṭhārasa purisakoṭiyo gahetvā nagaraṃ ajjhāvuṭṭhakālo viya tathāgatena dhammacakke
analyzed: isipatanam pavisitvā theram kāya sakkhim katvā dhammam desita kālaḥ mahākuṭumbikena  aṭṭhārasa purisa koṭiyaḥ gahetvā nagaram ajjhāvuṭṭha kālaḥ viya tathāgatena dhammacakke
translated: and taught the Dhamma with the Elder as his physical witness, like the time when the great householder,🔽after taking eighteen koṭis of men, entered the city,

analyzed: pavattite therassa aṭṭhārasahi brahmakoṭīhi saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhita kālo
