analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathābala santosaḥ aparaḥ  bahum paṇītam piṇḍapātam labhati saḥ tam cīvaram viya cira pabbajita bahu suta appa lābha gilānānam
translated: And even while doing the ascetic’s duty he is content. This is his contentment with regard to alms food as to what suits him.

original: datvā, tesaṃ vā sesakaṃ piṇḍāya vā caritvā missakāhāraṃ bhuñjantopi santuṭṭhova hoti.🔽Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: datvā tesam vā sesakam piṇḍāya vā caritvā missaka āhāram bhuñjantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti  ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā sāruppa santosaḥ
translated: Another gets much fine alms food. He gives it to those who are long ordained, learned, and of good character, and to the sick, keeping it for them, as it were, and he himself goes for alms and eats miscellaneous alms food.🔽And even while doing the ascetic’s duty he is content. This is his contentment with regard to alms food as to getting it without trouble.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu senāsanaṃ labhati manāpaṃ vā amanāpaṃ vā, so tena neva somanassaṃ
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu senāsanam labhati manāpam vā amanāpam vā so tena na iva somanassam
translated: Here a bhikkhu gets a lodging, whether good or bad,

original: na paṭighaṃ uppādeti, antamaso tiṇasanthārakenāpi yathāladdheneva tussati. Ayamassa🔽senāsane yathālābhasantoso. Yo pana attano pakativiruddhaṃ vā byādhiviruddhaṃ vā
analyzed: na paṭigham uppādeti antamasaḥ tiṇa santhārakena api yathā laddhena iva tussati ayam assa  senāsane yathā lābha santosaḥ yaḥ pana pakati viruddham vā byādhi viruddham vā
translated: He does not arouse discontent with what he has got, even if it is only a spread of grass. This is his🔽contentment with regard to the resting place as it is got. But if he gets a resting place that is unsuitable for his temperament or unsuited to his illness,

original: senāsanaṃ labhati, yatthassa vasato aphāsu hoti, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā
analyzed: senāsanam labhati yatthassa vasataḥ a phāsu hoti saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhunaḥ da tvā
translated: where he is not comfortable, he should give it to a fellow-monk and

original: tassa santake sappāyasenāsane vasantopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa senāsane yathābalasantoso.🔽Aparo mahāpuñño leṇamaṇḍapakūṭāgārādīni bahūni paṇītasenāsanāni labhati, so tāni🔽cīvarādīni viya cirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhagilānānaṃ datvā yattha katthaci vasantopi
analyzed: tassa santake sappāya senāsane vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathābala santoso  aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ leṇa maṇḍapa kūṭāgāra ādīni bahūni paṇīta senāsanāni labhati saḥ tāni  cīvara ādīni viya cira pabbajita bahu ssuta appa lābha gilānānam da tvā yattha katthaci vasantaḥ api
translated: dwell in the resting place of one who suits him. This is his contentment with regard to the resting place as to its suitability.

original: santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa senāsane yathāsāruppasantoso. Yopi “uttamasenāsanaṃ nāma
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathā sāruppa santosaḥ yaḥ api uttama senāsanam nāma
translated: Another, though he has great merit, gets many fine resting places such as caves, huts, and stilt houses. He gives these to those who have gone forth when old, to those who are learned, to those who are energetic, to those who are poor, and to those who are ill, and he is content with whatever resting place he gets for himself. This is his contentment with regard to the resting place as to its suitability.

original: pamādaṭṭhānaṃ, tattha nisinnassa thinamiddhaṃ okkamati, niddābhibhūtassa paṭibujjhato
analyzed: pamāda ṭṭhānam tattha nisinnassa thinam iddham okkamati niddā abhibhūtassa paṭibujjhato
translated: One who is a great meditator gets a fine resting place, but he thinks, “A fine resting place is a cause of negligence, and when I sit in it drowsiness and lethargy beset me, and when I lie down sloth and torpor increase.

original: pāpavitakkā pātubhavantī”ti paṭisañcikkhitvā tādisaṃ senāsanaṃ pattampi na sampaṭicchati,
analyzed: pāpa vitakkā pātubhavanti iti paṭisañcikkhitvā tādisam senāsanam pattam pi na sampaṭicchati
translated: and evil thoughts appear to him, he does not accept even a place to sleep in.🔽He rejects that and is satisfied with sleeping in the open, at the root of a tree, etc.,

original: so taṃ paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsarukkhamūlādīsu vasanto santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayampi senāsane🔽yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: saḥ tam paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsa rukkha mūla ādīsu vasantaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam pi senāsane  yathā sāruppa santosaḥ
translated: This is his satisfaction with any kind of resting place.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjaṃ labhati lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so yaṃ labhati teneva tussati,
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā saḥ yam labhati tena iva tussati
translated: Herein, when a bhikkhu gets a medicine, whether coarse or refined, he is satisfied with that alone,

original: aññaṃ na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhāti. Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathālābhasantoso.
analyzed: aññam na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhāti ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathā lābha santoso
translated: he does not seek another, and if he gets another he does not take it. This is his satisfaction with any kind of requisite.

original: Yo pana telenatthiko phāṇitaṃ labhati, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā tassa hatthato
analyzed: yaḥ pana telenatthikaḥ phāṇitam labhati saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhuno da tvā tassa hatthato
translated: But when one who needs oil gets molasses, he gives it to a fellow-bhikkhu who is a co-sharer of his alms and gets oil from him,

original: telaṃ gahetvā vā aññadeva vā pariyesitvā bhesajjaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa
analyzed: telam gahetvā vā aññatra eva vā pariyesitvā bhesajjam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa
translated: or he makes medicine with the molasses after getting oil or something else by exchanging it. He is satisfied in either case. This is his satisfaction with any kind of medicine.

original: gilānapaccaye yathābalasantoso. Aparo mahāpuñño bahuṃ telamadhuphāṇitādipaṇītabhesajjaṃ
analyzed: gilāna paccaye yathābala santosaḥ aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ bahum tela madhu phāṇita ādi paṇīta bhesajjam
translated: Another bhikkhu, who has great merit, gets much refined medicine such as oil, honey, molasses, etc.,

original: labhati, so taṃ cīvaraṃ viya cirapabbajita-bahussuta-appalābhagilānānaṃ datvā tesaṃ🔽ābhatena yena kenaci yāpentopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Yo pana ekasmiṃ bhājane muttaharītakaṃ
analyzed: labhati saḥ tam cīvaram viya cira pabbajita bahu suta appalābha gilānānam da tvā tesam  ābhatena yena kenacid yāpentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti yaḥ pana ekasmim bhājane mutta harītakam
translated: He gives that robe to those who have gone forth for a long time, who are learned, who have little gain, and who are sick.🔽He is content with whatever he gets in exchange for it. But if one were to put senna pods in one vessel and the four-ingredient medicine in another and say, “Venerable sir, take whichever you like,”

original: ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ catumadhuraṃ “gaṇha, bhante, yadicchasī”ti vuccamāno sacassa tesu🔽aññatarenapi rogo vūpasammati, atha “muttaharītakaṃ nāma buddhādīhi vaṇṇita”nti catumadhuraṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetvā ekasmin catu madhuram gaṇha bhante yat icchasi iti vuccamāno sacassa tesu  aññatarena api rogaḥ vūpasammati atha muttaharītakam nāma buddha ādīhi vaṇṇitanti catu madhuram
translated: and if his illness were to abate with either of them,

original: paṭikkhipitvā muttaharītakena bhesajjaṃ karonto paramasantuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa🔽gilānapaccaye yathāsāruppasantoso. Iti ime tayo santose sandhāya “santuṭṭhāyaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā mutta harītakena bhesajjam karonto parama santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam assa  gilāna paccaye yathā sāruppa santoso iti ime tayo santose sandhāya santuṭṭhā ayam bhikkhave
translated: then, thinking, “The senna pods are praised by the Enlightened One,” he would reject the four-ingredient medicine and make medicine with the senna pods. He would be supremely content. This is his contentment with regard to medicine as it occurs from day to day.

original: kassapo itarītarena cīvarenā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kassapaḥ itarītarena cīvarena ati vuttam
translated: So it was with reference to these three kinds of contentment that it was said: “Bhikkhus, Kassapa is content with any kind of alms and with any kind of resting place and with any kind of medicine.”

original: Vaṇṇavādīti eko santuṭṭho hoti, santosassa vaṇṇaṃ na katheti. Eko na santuṭṭho hoti,
analyzed: vaṇṇa vādī iti ekaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ hoti santosassa vaṇṇam na katheti ekaḥ na santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: One kind of bhikkhu is content but does not advertise his contentment;

original: santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti. Eko neva santuṭṭho hoti, na santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti.
analyzed: santosassa vaṇṇam katheti ekaḥ na iva santuṭṭhaḥ hoti na santosassa vaṇṇam katheti
translated: He speaks in praise of contentment. One is neither content nor does he speak in praise of contentment.🔽One is content and speaks in praise of contentment. The other is the one who is like this.

original: Eko santuṭṭho ca hoti, santosassa ca vaṇṇaṃ katheti. Ayaṃ tādisoti dassetuṃ itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā
analyzed: ekaḥ santuṭṭho ca hoti santosassa ca vaṇṇam katheti ayam tādisaḥ ti dassetum itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā
translated: To show this, the commentator said, “he is one who speaks in praise of contentment with any kind of robe.”

original: ca vaṇṇavādīti vuttaṃ. Anesananti dūteyyapahiṇagamanānuyogappabhedaṃ nānappakāraṃ
analyzed: ca vaṇṇa vādī iti vuttam anesanam ti dūteyya pahiṇa gamana anuyoga ppabhedam nāna ppakāram
translated: “Without importunity”: without the various kinds of importunity such as sending a messenger, going in person, and importunate solicitation.🔽“Without asking”: without asking.

original: anesanaṃ. Aladdhāti alabhitvā. Yathā ca ekacco “kathaṃ nu kho cīvaraṃ labhissāmī”ti
analyzed: an esanam a labhitvā yathā ca ekacco katham nu kho cīvaram labhissāmi iti
translated: And just as one, thinking, “How can I get a robe?”

original: puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ ekato hutvā kohaññaṃ karonto uttasati paritassati,
analyzed: puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhim ekatas hutvā kohaññam karontaḥ uttasati paritassati
translated: makes a display of being scrupulous and fearful, and makes a show of being disgusted,🔽this one, not having got a robe, is not scrupulous and fearful.

original: ayaṃ evaṃ aladdhā ca cīvaraṃ na paritassati. Laddhā cāti dhammena samena labhitvā.🔽Agadhitoti vigatalobhagedho. Amucchitoti adhimattataṇhāya mucchaṃ anāpanno. Anajjhāpannoti
analyzed: ayam evam a laddhā ca cīvaram na paritassati laddhā ca ati dhammena samena labhitvā  vigata lobha gedhaḥ amucchitaḥ iti adhimatta taṇhāya muccham an āpannaḥ an ajjhāpannaḥ ti
translated: “Having got it”: having got it by right means.🔽“Without greed”: without the greed-obsession. “Without attachment”: without the attachment-obsession. “Without clinging”:

original: taṇhāya anotthaṭo apariyonaddho. Ādīnavadassāvīti anesanāpattiyañca gadhitaparibhoge
analyzed: taṇhāya an utthaṭaḥ a pariyonaddhaḥ ādīnava dassāvī iti gadhita paribhoge
translated: without the clinging-obsession. “Seeing danger”: seeing the danger in the offense of importunity and in the enjoyment of what is clung to.

original: ca ādīnavaṃ passamāno. Nissaraṇapaññoti, “yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāyā”ti vuttanissaraṇameva🔽jānanto paribhuñjatīti attho. Itarītarena piṇḍapātenātiādīsupi yathāladdhādīnaṃ yena🔽kenaci piṇḍapātena, yena kenaci senāsanena, yena kenaci gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārenāti
analyzed: ca ādīnavam passamānaḥ nissaraṇa pañño ti yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya ati vutta nissaraṇam eva  jānantaḥ paribhuñjati iti yathā laddha ādīnam yena  kenaci piṇḍapātena yena kenaci senāsanena yena kenaci gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārena ati
translated: and seeing the danger in it. “With the knowledge of escape” means that he uses them knowing the escape stated thus, “For the purpose of warding off the distress due to cold” .

original: evamattho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Kassapena vā hi vo, bhikkhave, ovadissāmīti ettha yathā mahākassapatthero catūsu🔽paccayesu tīhi santosehi santuṭṭho, tumhepi tathārūpā bhavathāti ovadanto kassapena🔽ovadati nāma. Yo vā panassa kassapasadisoti etthāpi yo vā panaññopi kassapasadiso
analyzed: evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ  kassapena vā hi vaḥ bhikkhave ovadissāmi iti ettha yathā mahākassapa thero catūsu  paccayesu tīhi santosehi santuṭṭho tumhe pi tathārūpāḥ bhavatha ati ovadanto kassapena  ovadati nāma yaḥ vā panassa kassapa sadisaḥ ti ettha api yaḥ vā panaññaḥ api kassapa sadisaḥ
translated: The meaning of the rest should be understood in the way already stated.🔽“Or I will advise you as Kassapa did” : here the venerable elder Kassapa advised the bhikkhus thus, “You should be satisfied with whatever alms broth, etc., you get,” and so he advised them as Kassapa did.

original: mahākassapatthero viya catūsu paccayesu tīhi santosehi santuṭṭho bhaveyya, tumhepi
analyzed: mahākassapa theraḥ viya catūsu paccayesu tīhi santosehi santuṭṭhaḥ bhaveyya tumhe pi
translated: Or he who is like Kassapa: here he who is like Kassapa, that is, like the elder Kassapa, should be satisfied with whatever alms broth, etc., he gets.

original: tathārūpā bhavathāti ovadanto kassapasadisena ovadati nāma. Tathattāya paṭipajjitabbanti
analyzed: tathārūpāḥ bhavatha ati ovadantaḥ kassapa sadisena ovadati nāma tathattāya paṭipajjitabbanti
translated: He advises them, saying, “You should train thus.”

original: “sammāsambuddhassa imāya imasmiṃ santuṭṭhisutte vuttasallekhācārapaṭipattiyā kathanaṃ
analyzed: sammāsambuddhassa imāya imasmin santuṭṭhi sutte vutta sallekhā ācāra paṭipattiyā kathanaṃ
translated: The Exalted One’s statement that he is satisfied with this kind of conduct, with this kind of practice of seclusion,

original: nāma bhāro, amhākampi imaṃ paṭipattiṃ paripūraṃ katvā pūraṇaṃ bhāroyeva, āgato kho🔽pana bhāro gahetabbo”ti cintetvā yathā mayā kathitaṃ, tathattāya tathābhāvāya tumhehipi
analyzed: nāma bhāraḥ amhākam pi imam paṭipattim paripūram katvā pūraṇam āgataḥ kho  pana bhāraḥ gahetabbaḥ iti cintetvā yathā mayā kathitam tathattāya tathābhāvāya
translated: is a burden for us. It is a burden for us to fulfill this practice. But a burden that has come🔽should be taken up.” Thinking thus, he says, “You should train thus.”

original: paṭipajjitabbanti. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: paṭipajjitabbanti paṭhamam
translated: . The first section for recitation on the unashamed.

original: 2. Anottappīsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . The second section for recitation on the unashamed

original: 145. Dutiye anātāpīti yaṃ vīriyaṃ kilese ātapati, tena rahito. Anottappīti nibbhayo🔽kilesuppattito kusalānuppattito ca bhayarahito. Sambodhāyāti sambujjhanatthāya. Nibbānāyāti🔽nibbānasacchikiriyāya. Anuttarassa yogakkhemassāti arahattassa tañhi anuttarañceva
analyzed: dutiye anātāpī iti yam vīriyam kilese ātapati tena rahitaḥ anottappī iti nibbhayo  kilesa uppattitaḥ kusala anuppattitaḥ ca bhaya rahitaḥ sambodhāya ati sambujjhana tthāya nibbānāya ati  nibbāna sacchikiriyāya anuttarassa yogakkhemassa ati arahattassa tat hi anuttarañca eva
translated: . “Without urgency”: he is devoid of the energy that burns up defilements. “Without dread”: he is devoid of fear,

original: catūhi ca yogehi khemaṃ.
analyzed: catūhi ca yogehi khemam
translated: both from the arising of defilements and from the non-arising of the wholesome. “For the realization of Nibbana”: for the realization of Nibbana. “For the supreme security from bondage”: for arahatship. For that is supreme and secure from the four bonds.🔽.

original: Anuppannātiādīsu ye pubbe appaṭiladdhapubbaṃ cīvarādiṃ vā paccayaṃ upaṭṭhākasaddhivihārika-antevāsīnaṃ
analyzed: anuppanna iti ādīsu ye pubbe appaṭiladdha pubbam cīvara ādim vā paccayam upaṭṭhāka saddhivihārika antevāsīnam
translated: As regards the words “unarisen” and so on, when one who is not getting what he wants, such as robe-cloth, etc., or a desirable object such as a monastery attendant, pupil, or work-assistant,

original: vā aññatarato manuññavatthuṃ paṭilabhitvā taṃ subhaṃ sukhanti ayoniso gaṇhantassa
analyzed: vā aññataratas manuñña vatthum paṭilabhitvā tam subham sukhanti ayonisaḥ gaṇhantassa
translated: and who misapprehends it as beautiful and pleasant,

original: aññataraṃ vā pana ananubhūtapubbaṃ ārammaṇaṃ yathā tathā vā ayoniso āvajjentassa
analyzed: aññataram vā pana ananubhūta pubbam ārammaṇam yathā tathā vā ayonisas āvajjentassa
translated: or who misapprehends some object that has not been experienced before, as it were,

original: lobhādayo pāpakā akusalā dhammā uppajjanti, te anuppannāti veditabbā. Aññathā hi
analyzed: lobha ādayaḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjanti te anuppannā ati veditabbāḥ aññathā hi
translated: then evil unwholesome states arise in him such as greed, etc. These should be understood as “unrisen.” For otherwise

original: anamatagge saṃsāre anuppannā nāma pāpakā dhammā natthi. Anubhūtapubbepi ca vatthumhi
analyzed: anamatagge saṃsāre anuppannāḥ nāma pāpakāḥ dhammāḥ natthi anubhūta pubbe pi ca vatthumhi
translated: there would be no evil states that have not arisen in the beginningless round of rebirths.🔽And even in regard to an object that has been experienced before,

original: ārammaṇe vā yassa pakatibuddhiyā vā uddesaparipucchāya vā pariyattinavakammayonisomanasikārānaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇe vā yassa pakati buddhiyā vā uddesa paripucchāya vā
translated: when evil states do not arise in one through the natural strength of his understanding, or through questioning others, or through reflection, or through development,

original: vā aññataravasena pubbe anuppajjitvā pacchā tādisena paccayena sahasā uppajjanti,
analyzed: vā aññatara vasena pubbe an uppajjitvā pacchā tādisena paccayena sahasā uppajjanti
translated: but arise suddenly through some such condition as a wrong step,

original: imepi “anuppannā uppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyu”nti veditabbā. Tesuyeva pana vatthārammaṇesu
analyzed: ime api anuppannāḥ uppajjamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti veditabbā tesu yeva pana vattha ārammaṇesu
translated: These should be understood as “unrisen states that would lead to harm if they arose.”

original: punappunaṃ uppajjamānā nappahīyanti nāma, te “uppannā appahīyamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyu”nti🔽veditabbā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato pana uppannānuppannabhedo ca pahānappahānavidhānañca
analyzed: punappunam uppajjamānāḥ na pahīyanti nāma te uppannāḥ a pahīyamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti  veditabbāḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārataḥ pana uppanna anuppanna bhedaḥ ca pahāna ppahāna vidhānañca
translated: But when they arise again and again in the same objective fields and bases, they are called “unabandoned.” These should be understood as “risen states that would lead to harm if they were unabandoned.”

original: sabbaṃ visuddhimagge ñāṇadassanavisuddhiniddese kathitaṃ.
analyzed: sabbam visuddhimagge ñāṇadassanavisuddhi niddese kathitam
translated: This is the brief treatment of the matter here. But the exposition of the arisen and unarisen states and of the way in which they are abandoned should be understood in detail according to the Visuddhimagga in the Description of the Purification by Knowledge and Vision of the Way .

original: Anuppannā me kusalā dhammāti appaṭiladdhāpi sīlasamādhimaggaphalasaṅkhātā anavajjadhammā.🔽Uppannāti teyeva paṭiladdhā. Nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti te sīlādidhammā
analyzed: anuppannāḥ me kusalāḥ dhammā ti a paṭiladdhā api sīla samādhi magga phala saṅkhātāḥ anavajja dhammāḥ  uppannā ati te yeva paṭiladdhāḥ nirujjhamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyun ti te sīla ādi dhammā
translated: “Unrisen wholesome states”: blameless states consisting of virtue, concentration, and the path, which have not been obtained.🔽“Risen”: those same states when they have been obtained.

original: parihānivasena puna anuppattiyā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti veditabbā.
analyzed: parihāni vasena puna anuppattiyāḥ nirujjhamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyun ti veditabbā
translated: “Would lead to harm if they ceased”: they would lead to harm through the cessation of their reappearance by way of non-abandonment.🔽And here, mundane states are abandoned, but supramundane states are not abandoned.

original: Ettha ca lokiyā parihāyanti, lokuttarānaṃ parihāni natthīti. “Uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca lokiyā parihāyanti lokuttarānam natthi iti uppannānam kusalānam
translated: “Risen wholesome states”

original: dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā”ti imassa pana sammappadhānassa vasenāyaṃ desanā katā. Dutiyamaggo
analyzed: dhammānam ṭhitiyā ti imassa pana sammappadhānassa vasena ayam desanā katā dutiya maggo
translated: This is the meaning here.

original: vā sīghaṃ anuppajjamāno, paṭhamamaggo nirujjhamāno anatthāya saṃvatteyyāti evampettha
analyzed: vā sīgham an uppajjamānaḥ paṭhama maggaḥ nirujjhamānaḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyya ati evam pa ittha
translated: The second path, if it did not arise quickly, and the first path, if it were to cease, would be to the disadvantage of the Great Man.🔽So the meaning here should be regarded thus.

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Iti imasmiṃ sutte ime cattāro sammappadhānā pubbabhāgavipassanāvasena kathitāti. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ iti imasmim sutte ime cattāro sammappadhānā pubbabhāga vipassanā vasena kathitā ati dutiyam
translated: In this Thread these four Right Endeavours are stated in the way of the prior-to-maturity insight.

original: 3. Candūpamasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: candūpama sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Third Simile: The Moon🔽In the third , “moon-like” is like the moon.

original: 146. Tatiye candūpamāti candasadisā hutvā. Kiṃ parimaṇḍalatāya? No, apica kho yathā🔽cando gaganatalaṃ pakkhandamāno na kenaci saddhiṃ santhavaṃ vā sinehaṃ vā ālayaṃ🔽vā nikantiṃ vā patthanaṃ vā pariyuṭṭhānaṃ vā karoti, na ca na hoti mahājanassa piyo
analyzed: tatiye candu upamāti canda sadisā hutvā kim parimaṇḍala tāya no api ca khaḥ yathā  candaḥ gagana talam pakkhandamānaḥ na kenacid saddhim santhavam vā sineham vā ālayam  vā nikantim vā patthanam vā pariyuṭṭhānam vā karoti na ca na hoti mahājanassa piyaḥ
translated: What is it like? Not by its roundness, but rather

original: manāpo, tumhepi evaṃ kenaci saddhiṃ santhavādīnaṃ akaraṇena bahujanassa piyā manāpā
analyzed: manāpaḥ tumhe pi evam kenacid saddhim santhava ādīnam a karaṇena bahu janassa piyā manāpā
translated: just as the moon, when it has risen in the sky, does not make any intimacy, or affection, or reliance, or cleaving, or longing, or obsession with anything, and yet it is dear and pleasing to the great multitude, so you too, by not making any intimacy, etc., are dear and pleasing to the multitude.

original: candūpamā hutvā khattiyakulādīni cattāri kulāni upasaṅkamathāti attho. Apica yathā
analyzed: canda upamāḥ hutvā khattiya kula ādīni cattāri kulāni upasaṅkamatha ati atthaḥ api ca yathā
translated: The meaning is that they should approach the four families, the aristocratic and so on, as the moon does the four major mountain ranges. Moreover,

original: cando andhakāraṃ vidhamati, ālokaṃ pharati, evaṃ kilesandhakāravidhamanena ñāṇālokapharaṇena
analyzed: candaḥ andhakāram vidhamati ālokam pharati evam kilesa ndhakāra vidhamanena ñāṇa āloka pharaṇena
translated: just as the moon dispels darkness and spreads light, so too the moon-like bhikkhu dispels the darkness of defilements and spreads the light of knowledge.

original: cāpi candūpamā hutvāti evamādīhipi nayehi ettha attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Apakasseva kāyaṃ apakassa cittanti teneva santhavādīnaṃ akaraṇena kāyañca cittañca
analyzed: ca api canda upamāḥ hutvā iti evamādīhi pi nayehi ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam ti tena iva santhava ādīnam a karaṇena kāyam ca cittam ca
translated: The meaning should be regarded in this way too.

original: apakassitvā, apanetvāti attho. Yo hi bhikkhu araññepi na vasati, kāmavitakkādayopi🔽vitakketi, ayaṃ neva kāyaṃ apakassati, na cittaṃ. Yo hi araññepi kho viharati, kāmavitakkādayo🔽pana vitakketi, ayaṃ kāyameva apakassati, na cittaṃ. Yo gāmante vasati, kāmavitakkādayopi
analyzed: apakassitvā apanetvā ti attho yaḥ hi bhikkhu araññe pi na vasati kāma vitakka ādayaḥ api  vitakka iti ayam na iva kāyam apakassati na cittam yaḥ hi araññe pi kho viharati kāma vitakka ādayaḥ  pana vitakka iti ayam kāyam eva apakassati na cittam yaḥ gāmante vasati kāma vitakka ādayaḥ api
translated: Having removed the body and removed the mind: the meaning is that he has removed, has banished, both body and mind by not doing the things that lead to intimacy. For a bhikkhu who does not live in the forest and who thinks thoughts of sensual desire, etc.,🔽has not removed either the body or the mind. One who lives in the forest but thinks thoughts of sensual desire, etc.,🔽has removed the body but not the mind. One who lives in a village but does not think thoughts of sensual desire, etc.,

original: kho na ca vitakketi, ayaṃ cittameva apakassati, na kāyaṃ. Yo pana araññe ceva vasati,
analyzed: kho na ca vitakketi ayam cittam eva apakassati na kāyam yaḥ pana araññe ca iva vasati
translated: has removed the mind but not the body. But one who lives in the forest

original: kāmavitakkādayo ca na vitakketi, ayaṃ ubhayampi apakassati. Evarūpā hutvā kulāni
analyzed: kāma vitakka ādayaḥ ca na vitakka iti ayam ubhayam pi apakassati evarūpāḥ hutvā kulāni
translated: Having become such, he should approach families.

original: upasaṅkamathāti dīpento “apakasseva kāyaṃ apakassa citta”nti āha.🔽Niccanavakāti niccaṃ navakāva, āgantukasadisā eva hutvāti attho. Āgantuko hi paṭipāṭiyā🔽sampattagehaṃ pavisitvā sace naṃ gharasāmikā disvā, “amhākaṃ puttabhātaro vippavāsaṃ🔽gatā evaṃ vicariṃsū”ti anukampamānā nisīdāpetvā bhojenti, bhuttamattoyeva “tumhākaṃ
analyzed: upasaṅkamatha iti dīpentaḥ apakassa iva kāyam apakassa cittam iti āha  nicca navakā ti niccam āgantuka sadisāḥ eva hutvā iti atthaḥ āgantukaḥ hi paṭipāṭiyā  sampatta geham pavisitvā sace nam ghara sāmikā disvā amhākam putta bhātaraḥ vippavāsam  gatāḥ evam vicariṃsu iti anukampamānāḥ nisīdāpetvā bhojenti tumhākam
translated: “Keep your body in check, keep your mind in check”: he says this to show that he should approach families with a mind that is not intent on sense desires, etc.,

original: bhājanaṃ gaṇhathā”ti uṭṭhāya pakkamati, na tehi saddhiṃ santhavaṃ vā karoti, na kiccakaraṇīyāni🔽vā saṃvidahati, evaṃ tumhepi paṭipāṭiyā sampattagharaṃ pavisitvā yaṃ iriyāpathesu
analyzed: bhājanam gaṇhatha ati uṭṭhāya pakkamati na tehi saddhim santhavam vā karoti na kicca karaṇīyāni  vā saṃvidahati evam tumhe api paṭipāṭiyā sampatta gharam pavisitvā yam iriyāpathesu
translated: “Always as if new”: the meaning is that he should be like a newcomer. For when a newcomer enters a house by turns, if the owners of the house see him and out of compassion for him, thinking “Our son or brother who has gone away is just like this,” invite him to sit down and give him food, then as soon as he has eaten he gets up and leaves, saying, “Take your bowl,” and he does not engage in conversation with them or make any plans with them about doing work.

original: pasannā manussā denti, taṃ gahetvā chinnasanthavā, tesaṃ kiccakaraṇīye abyāvaṭā hutvā
analyzed: pasannāḥ manussāḥ denti tam gahetvā chinna santhavā tesam kicca karaṇīye abyāvaṭā hutvā
translated: In the same way, you should enter a house by turns and take what is given to you by people who are pleased with you among the various postures. Without engaging in conversation, without becoming involved in their affairs,

original: nikkhamathāti dīpeti.
analyzed: nikkhamatha ati dīpeti
translated: you should leave.

original: Imassa pana niccanavakabhāvassa āvibhāvatthaṃ dvebhātikavatthu kathetabbaṃ – vasāḷanagaragāmato
analyzed: imassa pana nicca navaka bhāvassa āvi bhāva attham dvebhātika vatthu kathetabbam vasāḷa nagara gāmataḥ
translated: In order to illustrate the meaning of the state of being ever new, the story of the two brothers should be told.

original: kira dve bhātikā nikkhamitvā pabbajitā, te cūḷanāgatthero ca mahānāgatthero cāti
analyzed: kira dve bhātikāḥ nikkhamitvā pabbajitā te cūḷanāga thero ca mahānāga tthero ca ati
translated: It seems that two brothers left the village of Vasala and went forth into homelessness. They became known as the Elder Cūḷanāga and the Elder Mahānāga.

original: paññāyiṃsu. Te cittalapabbate tiṃsa vassāni vasitvā arahattaṃ pattā “mātaraṃ passissāmā”ti
analyzed: paññāyiṃsu te cittalapabbate tiṃsa vassāni vasitvā arahattam pattāḥ mātaram passissāma ati
translated: After living for thirty years on the Cittalapabbata, they attained arahatship. Then they thought, “Let us see our mother.”

original: āgantvā vasāḷanagaravihāre vasitvā punadivase mātugāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu. Mātāpi
analyzed: āgantvā vasāḷa nagara vihāre vasitvā puna divase mātu gāmam piṇḍāya mātā api
translated: They went to the monastery at Vasala and stayed there. On the following day they entered the village for alms. Their mother

original: tesaṃ uḷuṅkena yāguṃ nīharitvā ekassa patte ākiri. Tassā taṃ olokayamānāya puttasineho
analyzed: tesam uḷuṅkena yāgum nīharitvā ekassa patte ākiri tassā tam olokayamānāya putta sinehaḥ
translated: took rice gruel in a gourd and poured it into the bowl of one of the brothers. As she looked at him,

original: uppajji. Atha naṃ āha – “tvaṃ, tāta, mayhaṃ putto mahānāgo”ti. Thero “pacchimaṃ theraṃ🔽puccha upāsike”ti vatvā pakkāmi. Pacchimatherassapi yāguṃ datvā, “tāta, tvaṃ mayhaṃ
analyzed: uppajji atha nam āha tvam tāta mayham putto mahā nāgaḥ ti thero pacchimam theraṃ  pucche upāsikā iti vatvā yāgum da tvā tāta tvam mayham
translated: love for her son arose in her. She said to him, “Dear, you are my son Mahānāga.” The elder replied, “Ask the other elder, lay devotee.”🔽With that he left. When the lay devotee gave gruel to the second elder, she asked, “Dear, you are my son Cūḷanāga, aren’t you?”

original: putto cūḷanāgo”ti pucchi? Thero “kiṃ, upāsike, purimaṃ theraṃ na pucchasī”ti? Vatvā
analyzed: putto cūḷanāgaḥ ti pucchi theraḥ kim upāsike purimam theram na pucchasi iti vatvā
translated: The elder replied, “Why, lay devotee, didn’t you ask the other elder?”

original: pakkāmi. Evaṃ mātarāpi saddhiṃ chinnasanthavo bhikkhu niccanavako nāma hoti.🔽Appagabbhāti na pagabbhā, aṭṭhaṭṭhānena kāyapāgabbhiyena, catuṭṭhānena vacīpāgabbhiyena,
analyzed: evam mātarā api saddhim chinna santhavaḥ bhikkhu niccanavakaḥ nāma hoti  appagabbhā ati na pagabbhā aṭṭha ṭṭhānena kāya pāgabbhiyena catu ṭṭhānena vacī pāgabbhiyena
translated: Thus the monk who has broken his association with his mother is always a novice.🔽Not forward: not forward in the eight ways, not forward in the four ways,🔽not forward in the many ways. The meaning is that he is devoid of forwardness in the eight ways in body, in the four ways in speech,

original: anekaṭṭhānena manopāgabbhiyena ca virahitāti attho. Aṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ kāyapāgabbhiyaṃ
analyzed: aneka ṭṭhānena manaḥ pāgabbhiyena ca virahitā ati atthaḥ aṭṭha ṭṭhānam kāya pāgabbhiyam
translated: and in the many ways in mind. The eight ways in body are as follows:

original: nāma saṅghagaṇapuggala-bhojanasālā-jantāgharanahānatittha-bhikkhācāramagga-antaragharappavesanesu
analyzed: nāma saṅgha gaṇa puggala bhojana sālā jantā ghara na hāna tittha bhikkhā cāra magga antara ghara ppavesanesu
translated: in the midst of the Sangha, in a group, in the presence of an individual, in the refectory, in the assembly hall, in the bathroom, at the bathing place, on the alms round, on the way to a village, and on the way back.

original: kāyena appatirūpakaraṇaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ – idhekacco saṅghamajjhe pallatthikāya vā nisīdati
analyzed: kāyena appatirūpa karaṇam seyyathidam idha ekaccaḥ saṅgha majjhe pallatthikāya vā nisīdati
translated: He does not behave improperly in these places. For example, in the midst of the Sangha he sits with his legs locked or with his knee knocking on knee.

original: pāde pādaṃ ādhāyitvā vāti evamādi. Tathā gaṇamajjhe. Gaṇamajjheti catuparisasannipāte
analyzed: pāde pādam ādhāyitvā vāti evamādi tathā gaṇa majjhe gaṇa majjhe iti catu parisa sannipāte
translated: In the midst of a group: in the midst of an assembly of four or more,

original: vā suttantikagaṇādisannipāte vā. Tathā vuḍḍhatare puggale. Bhojanasālāya pana vuḍḍhānaṃ
analyzed: vā sutta ntika gaṇa ādi sannipāte vā tathā vuḍḍhatare puggale bhojana sālāya pana vuḍḍhānam
translated: or in the midst of an assembly of students of the Suttas, etc. In the presence of an elder: in the refectory he does not give a seat to the elders,

original: āsanaṃ na deti, navānaṃ āsanaṃ paṭibāhati. Tathā jantāghare. Vuḍḍhe cettha anāpucchā
analyzed: āsanam na deti āsanam paṭibāhati tathā jantāghare vuḍḍhe ca ittha anāpucchā
translated: he obstructs the seats of the newcomers. In the assembly hall: without asking permission of the elders,

original: aggijalanādīni karoti. Nhānatitthe ca yadidaṃ “daharo vuḍḍhoti pamāṇaṃ akatvā āgatapaṭipāṭiyā🔽nhāyitabba”nti vuttaṃ, tampi anādiyanto pacchā āgantvā udakaṃ otaritvā vuḍḍhe ca
analyzed: aggi jala na ādīni karoti nhāna titthe ca yat idam daharaḥ vuḍḍho ti pamāṇam a katvā āgata paṭipāṭiyā  nhāyitabbanti vuttam tam pi an ādiyantaḥ pacchā āgantvā udakam otaritvā vuḍḍhe ca
translated: He makes a noise like fire, water, and so on. And when it is said at the bathing place, “Without regard to whether he is a junior or a senior, he should bathe in the order of arrival,” he does not do so.🔽He goes in after those who have already gone in, and he disturbs the water for those who are bathing.

original: nave ca bādhati. Bhikkhācāramagge pana aggāsanaaggodakaaggapiṇḍānaṃ atthāya purato
analyzed: nave ca bādhati bhikkhā cāra magge pana agga āsana agga udaka agga piṇḍānaṃ atthāya puratas
translated: On the alms round he goes in front of the others in order to get the best seat, the best water, and the best alms food.

original: gacchati bāhāya bāhaṃ paharanto. Antaragharappavesane vuḍḍhehi paṭhamataraṃ pavisati,
analyzed: gacchati bāhāya bāham paharantaḥ antara ghara ppavesane vuḍḍhehi paṭhamataram pavisati
translated: He pushes his way through the crowd, elbowing people right and left. When entering a house, he enters first, even before the seniors,

original: daharehi saddhiṃ kāyakīḷanakaṃ karotīti evamādi.
analyzed: daharehi saddhim kāya kīḍanakam karoti iti evamādi
translated: and he plays games with the boys.

original: Catuṭṭhānaṃ vacīpāgabbhiyaṃ nāma saṅghagaṇapuggalaantaragharesu appatirūpavācānicchāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: catu ṭṭhānam vacīpāgabbhiyam nāma saṅgha gaṇa puggala antara gharesu
translated: Speech that is unbecoming is the uttering of words that are unbecoming in an Order, a group, to an individual, or in a house.

original: Seyyathidaṃ – idhekacco saṅghamajjhe anāpucchā dhammaṃ bhāsati. Tathā pubbe vuttappakārassa
analyzed: seyyathīdam idha ekaccaḥ saṅgha majjhe anāpucchā dhammaṃ bhāsati tathā pubbe vutta ppakārassa
translated: Herein, one speaks on the Dhamma in the midst of an Order without being asked. So too in the midst of a group of the kind already stated,

original: gaṇassa majjhe puggalassa ca santike, tattheva manussehi pañhaṃ puṭṭho vuḍḍhataraṃ
analyzed: gaṇassa majjhe puggalassa ca santike tattha eva manussehi pañham puṭṭhaḥ vuḍḍhataram
translated: and in the presence of an individual. And in each case he does so without being asked.

original: anāpucchā vissajjeti. Antaraghare pana “itthannāme kiṃ atthi? Kiṃ yāgu, udāhu khādanīyaṃ
analyzed: an āpucchā vissajjā iti antara ghare pana itthannāme kim atthi kim yāgu udāhu khādanīyaṃ
translated: He does not ask permission but gives the answer himself. But in a house he speaks thus: “What is there, so and so? Is there rice gruel, or fresh or cooked food?

original: bhojanīyaṃ? Kiṃ me dassasi? Kiṃ ajja khādissāma? Kiṃ bhuñjissāma? Kiṃ pivissāmā”tiādīni bhāsati.
analyzed: bhojanīyam kim me dassasi kim ajja khādissāma kim bhuñjissāma kim pivissāma ati ādīni bhāsati
translated: What will you give me? What shall we eat today? What shall we eat? What shall we drink?”

original: Anekaṭṭhānaṃ manopāgabbhiyaṃ nāma tesu tesu ṭhānesu kāyavācāhi ajjhācāraṃ anāpajjitvāpi🔽manasāva kāmavitakkādīnaṃ vitakkanaṃ. Apica dussīlasseva sato “sīlavāti maṃ jano
analyzed: anekaṭṭhānam manopāgabbhiyam nāma tesu tesu ṭhānesu kāya vācāhi ajjhācāram an āpajjitvā api  manasā ava kāma vitakka ādīnam vitakkanam api ca dussīlassa iva sataḥ sīlavāti mama janaḥ
translated: “Many a place” means that without committing any offence by body or speech in such and so many places,

original: jānātū”ti evaṃ pavattā pāpicchatāpi manopāgabbhiyaṃ. Iti sabbesampi imesaṃ pāgabbhiyānaṃ
analyzed: jānātu uti evam pavattā manopāgabbhiyam iti sabbesam pi imesam pāgabbhiyānam
translated: he merely thinks of sensual thoughts, etc., with his mind. Furthermore, the evil desire of one who is unvirtuous, thinking: “Let people know me as virtuous,” is also “many a place.”

original: abhāvena appagabbhā hutvā upasaṅkamathāti vadati.🔽Jarudapānanti jiṇṇakūpaṃ. Pabbatavisamanti pabbate visamaṃ papātaṭṭhānaṃ. Nadīvidugganti
analyzed: abhāvena appagabbhāḥ hutvā upasaṅkamatha iti vadati  jaru dapānanti jiṇṇa kūpam pabbata visamanti pabbate visamam papāta ṭṭhānam nadī vidugganti
translated: Thus, he says: “Go to him without being suspicious of any of these many places.”🔽“An old well”: a dilapidated well. “A mountain difficult of access”: a difficult place on a mountain, a precipice. “A river difficult of access”:

original: nadiyā viduggaṃ chinnataṭaṭṭhānaṃ. Apakasseva kāyanti tādisāni ṭhānāni yo khiḍḍādipasuto
analyzed: nadiyāḥ viduggam chinna taṭa ṭṭhānam apakassa iva kāyanti tādisāni ṭhānāni yaḥ khiḍḍa ādi pasuto
translated: a difficult place on a river, a place where the bank has collapsed. “You should avoid the body”: such places are dangerous for one who is addicted to play, etc.,

original: kāyaṃ anapakassa ekatobhāriyaṃ akatvāva vāyupatthambhakaṃ aggāhāpetvā cittampi anapakassa🔽“ettha patito hatthapādabhañjanādīni pāpuṇātī”ti anādīnavadassāvitāya anubbejetvā
analyzed: kāyam an apakassa ekatobhāriyam a katvā ava vāyu patthambhakam aggāhāpetvā cittam pi an apakassa  ettha patitaḥ hattha pāda bhañjana ādīni pāpuṇāti iti anādīnava dassāvitāya anubbejetvā
translated: and without making his body and mind ready, he has the rope fastened to the top of the head and looks up with his mind not made ready,

original: sampiyāyamāno oloketi, so patitvā hatthapādabhañjanādianatthaṃ pāpuṇāti. Yo pana
analyzed: sampiyāyamānaḥ oloketi saḥ patitvā hattha pāda bhañjana ādi anattham pāpuṇāti yaḥ pana
translated: seeing no danger in it, he is killed. But one who wants to look up

original: udakatthiko vā aññena vā kenaci kiccena oloketukāmo kāyaṃ apakassa ekato bhāriyaṃ
analyzed: udakatthikaḥ vā aññena vā kenacid kiccena oloketu kāmo kāyam apakasse ekatas bhāriyam
translated: after making his body and mind ready,

original: katvā vāyupatthambhakaṃ gāhāpetvā, cittampi apakassa ādīnavadassanena saṃvejetvā
analyzed: katvā vāyupatthambhakam gāhāpetvā cittam pi apakassa ādīnava dassanena saṃvejetvā
translated: and after fastening the rope to the top of the head, and after making his mind ready,

analyzed: gacchati tattha ca na bahu saṃsayaḥ hoti  katham apiṇḍapātikaḥ hi gāmataḥ dūra vihāre vasamānaḥ kālassa iva yāgum vā pārivāsika bhattam

original: vā lacchāmi, āsanasālāya vā pana uddesabhattādīsu kiñcideva mayhaṃ pāpuṇissatī”ti
analyzed: vā lacchāmi āsana sālāya vā pana uddesa bhatta ādīsu kiñcid eva mayham pāpuṇissati iti
translated: How so? The non-alms-food-eater who lives in a monastery far from a village thinks, “I shall get rice gruel or food for wanderers or something to eat in the refectory,”🔽and he sets out early in the morning, cutting off his conversation in mid-sentence, leaving his bed all rumpled,

original: makkaṭakasuttāni chindanto sayitagorūpāni uṭṭhāpento pātova gacchanto akālacārī hoti.

analyzed: manusse khetta kamma ādīnam atthāya gehā nikkhanteya iva sampāpuṇitum migam anubandhantaḥ
translated: in order to get there before the people have left their houses to go to the fields, etc.,

original: viya vegena gacchanto turitacārī hoti. Antarā kiñcideva disvā “asukaupāsako vā asukaupāsikā
analyzed: viya vegena gacchantaḥ turita cārī hoti antarā kiñcid eva disvā asu kaupāsakaḥ vā asu kaupāsikā
translated: and he has many doubts about what is and what is not allowable, thinking, “Is this or that layman or laywoman an alms-food-eater or not?”

analyzed: viya pavedhati sayam pacchima disam gantu kāmo pācīna disāya salākam labhitvā aññam

analyzed: pacchima disāya laddha salākam upasaṅkamitvā bhante aham pacchima disam gamissāmi

analyzed: mama salākam tumhe gaṇhatha tumhākam salākam mayham detha ati salākam parivatta iti

original: Ekaṃ vā pana salākabhattaṃ āharitvā paribhuñjanto “aparassāpi salākabhattassa pattaṃ🔽dethā”ti manussehi vutte, “bhante, tumhākaṃ pattaṃ detha, ahaṃ mayhaṃ patte bhattaṃ
analyzed: ekam vā pana salāka bhattam āharitvā paribhuñjantaḥ aparassa api salāka bhattassa pattam  detha ati manussehi vutte bhante tumhākam pattam detha aham mayham patte bhattam
translated: Or if he gets a ticket for a meal and is told, “Give your bowl to another,”

original: pakkhipitvā tumhākaṃ pattaṃ dassāmī”ti aññassa pattaṃ dāpetvā bhatte āhaṭe attano
analyzed: pakkhipitvā tumhākam pattam dassāmi iti aññassa pattam dāpetvā bhatte āhaṭe attano
translated: he says, “Venerable sir, give me your bowl; I shall put my meal in your bowl and give it to you,” and he gets another’s bowl given to him. When the meal is brought,🔽he puts it in his own bowl, and when he hands over the bowl, he exchanges the bowl.

original: patte pakkhipitvā pattaṃ paṭidento pattaṃ parivatteti nāma. Vihāre rājarājamahāmattādayo
analyzed: patte pakkhipitvā pattam paṭidento pattam parivattā iti nāma vihāre rāja rāja mahāmatta ādayo
translated: If kings, royal ministers, etc.,

analyzed: mahā dānam denti iminā ca bhiyyas dūra gāme salākā laddhā tattha a gacchanto puna sattāham
translated: They give a great gift, and more than that, they have received a vote in a distant village, and in coming here he has been absent for seven days,

analyzed: salākam na labhati iti alābha bhayena gacchati evam gacchantaḥ palibuddhaḥ hutvā gacchati  nāma yassa ca isa salākabhatta ādinaḥ atthāya gacchati tam dassanti nu kho me udāhu
translated: He gives a great deal of alms, and he has received a ticket in a distant village, and he thinks, “If I go there I shall not get a ticket again for seven days,” and he goes out of fear of not getting one. So he goes with the hindrance of fear.

original: na dassanti, paṇītaṃ nu kho dassanti, udāhu lūkhaṃ, thokaṃ nu kho, udāhu bahukaṃ,🔽sītalaṃ nu kho, udāhu uṇha”nti evaṃ tattha ca bahusaṃsayo hoti.🔽Piṇḍapātiko pana kālasseva vuṭṭhāya vattapaṭivattaṃ katvā sarīraṃ paṭijaggitvā vasanaṭṭhānaṃ🔽pavisitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikatvā kālaṃ sallakkhetvā mahājanassa uḷuṅkabhikkhādīni
analyzed: na dassanti paṇītam nu kho dassanti udāhu lūkham thokam nu kho udāhu bahukam  sītalam nu kho udāhu uṇhanti evam tattha ca bahu saṃsayaḥ hoti  piṇḍapātikaḥ pana kālassa iva vuṭṭhāya vatta paṭivattam katvā sarīram paṭijaggitvā vasanaṭṭhānam  pavisitvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikatvā kālam sallakkhetvā mahājanassa uḷuṅka bhikkhā ādīni
translated: He goes with the hindrance of doubt when he goes thinking, “They will give me something to eat for the sake of the ticket, but will they give me much or a little, good food or bad, hot food or cold?”

original: dātuṃ pahonakakāle gacchatīti na akālacārī hoti, ekekaṃ padavāraṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā
analyzed: dātum pahonaka kāle gacchati iti na akāla cārī hoti ekekam padavāram cha koṭṭhāse katvā
translated: The alms-food-eater, however, gets up early and performs his duties. After he has attended to his body’s needs, he enters his living room, and after he has given attention to his meditation subject, he considers the time. When it is time for the people to give out the alms to the bhikkhus, he goes. So he does not go at the wrong time. He divides each stage of the path into six segments and goes at a pace that enables him to cover a segment with each step.

original: vipassanto gacchatīti na turitacārī hoti, attano garubhāvena “asuko gehe, na gehe”ti
analyzed: vipassantaḥ gacchati iti na turita cārī hoti attanaḥ garu bhāvena asukaḥ gehe na gehe iti
translated: He does not go quickly, thinking, “In such and such a house there is no alms,” because of his own slowness.

original: na pucchati, salākabhattādīniyeva na gaṇhāti. Agaṇhanto kiṃ parivattessati? Na aññassa

original: alabhitvā aññattha caranto missakodanaṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā amataṃ viya paribhuñjitvā gacchati.🔽Paṃsukūlikasseva labbhati, no apaṃsukūlikassa. Apaṃsukūliko hi vassāvāsikaṃ pariyesanto🔽carati, na senāsanasappāyaṃ pariyesati. Paṃsukūliko pana na vassāvāsikaṃ pariyesanto
analyzed: a labhitvā aññattha carantaḥ missaka udanam saṅkaḍḍhitvā amatam viya paribhuñjitvā gacchati  paṃsukūlikassa iva labbhati no a paṃsukūlikassa a paṃsukūlikaḥ hi vassāvāsikam pariyesantaḥ  carati na senāsana sappāyam pariyesati paṃsukūlikaḥ pana na vassāvāsikam pariyesantaḥ
translated: If he does not get any there either, he goes on to yet another. And as he goes on getting nothing, he goes on collecting it, and he goes on eating it, as if it were ambrosia.🔽It is only allowable for one who is a rag-robe wearer, not for one who is not. For one who is not a rag-robe wearer goes about seeking a dwelling for the rains,

original: carati, senāsanasappāyameva pariyesati. Tecīvarikasseva labbhati, na itarassa. Atecīvariko
analyzed: carati senāsana sappāyam eva pariyesati tecīvarikassa iva labbhati na itarassa a tecīvarikaḥ
translated: but one who is a rag-robe wearer does not go about seeking a dwelling for the rains; he seeks only a place suitable for a meditation subject. It is only allowable for one who has the triple robe, not for one who has more than the triple robe.

original: hi bahubhaṇḍo bahuparikkhāro hoti, tenassa phāsuvihāro natthi. Appicchādīnañceva
analyzed: hi bahu bhaṇḍaḥ bahu parikkhāraḥ hoti tena assa phāsu vihāraḥ natthi appiccha ādīnam ca eva
translated: for he had many goods and much wealth, and so he had no comfortable abiding. But it is only those who are few in wishes, etc.,🔽who can get it, not others. Hence it was said: “seeing his own abiding in bliss here and now” .

original: labbhati, na itaresanti. Tena vuttaṃ – “attano ca diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ sampassamāno”ti. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Ovādasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: labbhati na itaresan ti tena vuttam attanaḥ ca diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāram sampassamānaḥ ti pañcamam  ovāda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The fifth.🔽The sixth.

original: 149. Chaṭṭhe ahaṃ vāti kasmā āha? Theraṃ attano ṭhāne ṭhapanatthaṃ. Kiṃ sāriputtamoggallānā
analyzed: chaṭṭhe aham vāti kasmai āha theram ṭhāne ṭhapana attham kim

analyzed: natthi iti atthi evam panassa ahosi ime na ciram kassapaḥ pana
translated: They were. But he thought, “These will not last long. Kassapa, however, will live two hundred years.

original: so mayi parinibbute sattapaṇṇiguhāyaṃ nisīditvā dhammavinayasaṅgahaṃ katvā mama sāsanaṃ
analyzed: saḥ mayi parinibbute satta paṇṇi guhāyam nisīditvā dhamma vinaya saṅgaham katvā mama sāsanam

original: pañcavassasahassaparimāṇakālapavattanakaṃ karissati, attano taṃ ṭhāne ṭhapemi, evaṃ
analyzed: pañca vassa sahassa parimāṇa kāla pavattanakam karissati tam ṭhāne ṭhapemi evam
translated: He will make my Dispensation last for a period of five thousand years. I shall place him in my own place.

original: bhikkhū kassapassa sussūsitabbaṃ maññissantī”ti. Tasmā evamāha. Dubbacāti dukkhena

translated: In that case the bhikkhus will think that they should listen to Kassapa.” That is why he said it. “Difficult to admonish”: difficult to instruct.

analyzed: vattabbāḥ dovacassa karaṇehi iti dubbaca bhāva karaṇehi appadakkhiṇa ggāhinaḥ ti anusāsanim  sutvā padakkhiṇam na gaṇhanti yathānusiṭṭham na paṭipajjanti a paṭipajjantāḥ vāmagāhino

original: nissāya saṅghaṃ bhindeyyunti yathā devadatto sapariso kulesu viññāpetvā bhuñjanto🔽pāpicche nissāya saṅghaṃ bhindi, evaṃ aññepi pāpicchā gaṇabandhena kulesu viññāpetvā
analyzed: nissāya saṅgham bhindeyyunti yathā devadatto sa parisaḥ kulesu viññāpetvā bhuñjantaḥ  pāpa icche nissāya saṅgham evam aññe api pāpa icchāḥ gaṇa bandhena kulesu viññāpetvā
translated: having gained a faction, split the Order: just as Devadatta, having eaten in families after inviting,🔽having gained a faction, split the Order, so too others of evil wishes, having eaten in families after inviting with a group,

original: bhuñjamānā gaṇaṃ vaḍḍhetvā taṃ pakkhaṃ nissāya mā saṅghaṃ bhindeyyunti, iti iminā
analyzed: bhuñjamānāḥ gaṇam vaḍḍhetvā tam pakkham nissāya mā saṅgham bhindeyyun ti iti iminā
translated: having increased the group, may not, having gained that faction, split the Order. Thus for the purpose of this,

original: kāraṇena paññattanti attho. Kulānuddayatāya cāti bhikkhusaṅghe uposathapavāraṇaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇena paññattanti attho kula anuddaya tāya ca ati bhikkhu saṅghe uposatha pavāraṇam
translated: The meaning is: “it is laid down for a reason.” And out of respect for families:🔽

original: katvā samaggavāsaṃ vasante manussā salākabhattādīni datvā saggaparāyaṇā bhavanti,
analyzed: katvā samagga vāsam vasante manussā salākabhatta ādīni da tvā sagga parāyaṇāḥ bhavanti
translated: The meaning is: it is laid down for the sake of a reason. And for the sake of the welfare of families: when the Community of monks has done the Uposatha and the Invitation Ceremony and is living together in concord, people give them food in turns and so on, and they are reborn in heaven.

original: iti imāya kulānuddayatāya ca paññattanti attho.🔽Sassaghātaṃ maññe carasīti sassaṃ ghātento viya āhiṇḍasi. Kulūpaghātaṃ maññe carasīti
analyzed: iti imāya ca paññattanti  sassa ghātam maññe carasi iti sassam ghātentaḥ viyas āhiṇḍasi kulūpaghātam maññe carasi iti
translated: The meaning is: it is laid down for the sake of this welfare of families.🔽You are going about as if destroying the crops: you are wandering about as if destroying the crops. You are going about as if destroying families:

original: kulāni upaghātento viya hananto viya āhiṇḍasi. Olujjatīti visesena palujjati bhijjati.
analyzed: kulāni upaghātentaḥ viya hanantaḥ viya āhiṇḍasi olujjati iti visesena palujjati bhijjati
translated: you are wandering about as if destroying families, as if killing them. It is falling away: it is falling away in a special way, it is breaking up.

original: Palujjanti kho te, āvuso, navappāyāti, āvuso, ete tuyhaṃ pāyena yebhuyyena navakā
analyzed: palujjanti kho te āvuso nava ppāyā ati āvuso ete tuyham pāyena yebhuyyena navakā
translated: They are falling away, friend, your new arrivals: friend, these new arrivals of yours, for the most part, are young,

original: ekavassikaduvassikā daharā ceva sāmaṇerā ca palujjanti bhijjanti. Na vāyaṃ kumārako
analyzed: ekavassika duvassikāḥ daharāḥ ca iva sāmaṇerāḥ ca palujjanti bhijjanti na vā ayam kumārako
translated: one-year and two-year monks, and novices. This boy

original: mattamaññāsīti ayaṃ kumārako attano pamāṇaṃ na jānātīti theraṃ tajjento āha.
analyzed: mattam aññāsi iti ayam kumārakaḥ attano pamāṇam na jānāti iti theram āha
translated: does not know moderation: he is reproaching the elder, saying: “This boy does not know his own measure.”

original: Kumārakavādā na muccāmāti kumārakavādato na muccāma. Tathā hi pana tvanti idamassa🔽evaṃ vattabbatāya kāraṇadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – yasmā tvaṃ imehi🔽navehi bhikkhūhi indriyasaṃvararahitehi saddhiṃ vicarasi, tasmā kumārakehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: kumāraka vādāḥ na muccāma ati kumāraka vādataḥ na muccāma tathā hi pana idam assa  evam vattabba tāya kāraṇa dassana attham vuttam ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ yasmā tvam imehi  navehi bhikkhūhi indriya saṃvara rahitehi saddhim vicarasi tasmai kumārakehi saddhim
translated: I am not released from the talk of boys: I am not released from the talk of boys.

original: vicaranto kumārakoti vattabbataṃ arahasīti.🔽Aññatitthiyapubbo samānoti idaṃ yasmā therassa imasmiṃ sāsane neva ācariyo na upajjhāyo
analyzed: vicarantaḥ kumārako ti vattabbatam arahasi iti  añña titthiya pubbaḥ samānaḥ ti idam yasmā therassa imasmim sāsane na iva ācariyaḥ na upajjhāyaḥ
translated: But you are just like that: this was said in order to show the reason why he should be spoken to in this way. The intention here is this: since you go about with these nine monks who are devoid of restraint of the faculties, therefore you deserve to be spoken to as a boy who goes about with boys.

original: paññāyati, sayaṃ kāsāyāni gahetvā nikkhanto, tasmā anattamanatāya aññatitthiyapubbataṃ āropayamānā āha.
analyzed: paññāyati sayam kāsāyāni gahetvā nikkhanto tasmai anatta manatāya añña titthiya pubbatam āropayamānā āha
translated: A former member of another sect: this was said because it is not known that the Elder had either a teacher or a preceptor in this Dispensation; he went forth on his own after taking on the yellow robes. Therefore, in his displeasure, they said this in order to attribute to him the status of a former member of another sect.

original: Sahasāti ettha rāgamohacāropi sahasācāro, idaṃ pana dosacāravasena vuttaṃ. Appaṭisaṅkhāti
analyzed: sahasā ti ettha rāga moha cāraḥ api sahasā ācāraḥ idam pana dosa cāra vasena vuttam appaṭisaṅkhā ti
translated: In haste: here “in haste” is also “in haste through passion and delusion,” but this was said in terms of “in haste through hate.” Without reflection:

original: appaccavekkhitvā, idāni attano pabbajjaṃ sodhento yatvāhaṃ, āvusotiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: a paccavekkhitvā idāni attanaḥ pabbajjam sodhentaḥ yatvā aham āvuso ti ādim āha tattha
translated: without consideration. Now, in order to purify his own going forth, he said, “When I went away, friends,” and so on. Herein,

original: aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddisitunti ṭhapetvā bhagavantaṃ aññaṃ mayhaṃ satthāti evaṃ uddisituṃ🔽na jānāmi. Sambādho gharāvāsotiādīsu sacepi saṭṭhihatthe ghare yojanasatantarepi
analyzed: aññam satthāram uddisitunti ṭhapetvā bhagavantam aññam mayham satthā iti evam uddisitum  na jānāmi sambādhaḥ ghara āvāsaḥ ti ādīsu sace pi ghare
translated: I do not know of any other teacher to whom I could go for refuge.🔽Even if there are two married couples living in a house sixty cubits long,

original: vā dve jāyampatikā vasanti, tathāpi tesaṃ sakiñcanasapalibodhaṭṭhena gharāvāso sambādhoyeva.🔽Rajāpathoti rāgarajādīnaṃ uṭṭhānaṭṭhānanti mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. “Āgamanapatho”tipi
analyzed: vā dve jāyampatikāḥ vasanti tathā api tesam ghara āvāso  rajāpatho ti rāgaraja ādīnam uṭṭhāna ṭṭhānanti mahā aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam āgamana patho tipi
translated: or even a hundred leagues long, still the house life is crowded for them, in the sense that they have property and are subject to censure.🔽The “road of dust” is the place of origin of the dust of lust, etc. So it is said in the Mahā-Aṭṭhakathā. It is also proper to say “the road of coming in.”

original: vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Alagganaṭṭhena abbhokāso viyāti abbhokāso. Pabbajito hi kūṭāgāraratanamayapāsādadevavimānādīsu
analyzed: vattum vaṭṭati a laggana ṭṭhena abbhokāsaḥ viyāti abbhokāsaḥ pabbajitaḥ hi kūṭāgāra ratana maya pāsāda deva vimāna ādīsu
translated: The “open air” is like the open air in the sense of being a place of no clinging. For even though one who has gone forth may live in a peaked-roofed mansion, a jeweled palace, or a celestial mansion,

original: pihitadvāravātapānesu paṭicchannesu vasantopi neva laggati na sajjati na bajjhati,
analyzed: pihita dvāra vāta pānesu paṭicchannesu vasantaḥ api na iva laggati na sajjati na bajjhati
translated: with the doors and windows closed, still he does not cling or adhere or stick to any of them,

original: tena vuttaṃ “abbhokāso pabbajjā”ti. Apica sambādho gharāvāso kusalakiriyāya okāsābhāvato
analyzed: tena vuttam abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā ti api ca sambādhaḥ ghara āvāsaḥ kusala kiriyāya okāsa abhāvato
translated: hence it is said: “The open air is the going forth.” Moreover, the house life is crowded because there is no opportunity for wholesome activity.

original: rajāpatho asaṃvutasaṅkāraṭṭhānaṃ viya rajānaṃ, kilesarajānaṃ sannipātaṭṭhānato, abbhokāso
analyzed: rajāpathaḥ asaṃvuta saṅkāra ṭṭhānam viya rajānam kilesa rajānam sannipāta ṭṭhānataḥ abbhokāsaḥ
translated: The open air is like a king’s highway, which is a place for the king’s use, and like a place for disposing of rubbish, which is a place for the use of the defilements.

original: pabbajjā kusalakiriyāya yathā sukhaṃ okāsasabbhāvato.
analyzed: pabbajjā kusala kiriyāya yathā sukham okāsa sabbhāvato
translated: The going forth is a place for the use of profitable action, since it is a place for the use of one who is comfortable.🔽This is not easy to do while living in a home,

original: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ…pe… pabbajeyyanti ettha ayaṃ saṅkhepakathā – yadetaṃ sikkhattayabrahmacariyaṃ🔽ekampi divasaṃ akhaṇḍaṃ katvā carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ caritabbaṃ,
analyzed: na idam sukaraṃpe pabbajeyyanti ettha ayam saṅkhepa kathā yat etam sikkhattaya brahmacariyam  ekam pi divasam akhaṇḍam katvā carimaka cittam pāpetabba tāya ekanta paripuṇṇam caritabbam
translated: Here is a brief explanation. This life of purity consisting of the three trainings should be lived🔽without a break for even a single day, and the last consciousness should be entered upon after the last action has been done.

original: ekadivasampi ca kilesamalena amalīnaṃ katvā carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparisuddhaṃ,
analyzed: eka divasam pi ca kilesa malena a malīnam katvā carimaka cittam pāpetabba tāya ekanta parisuddham
translated: And it should be lived without being soiled by the stain of defilement, and the last consciousness should be entered upon after the last action has been done.

original: saṅkhalikhitaṃ likhitasaṅkhasadisaṃ dhotasaṅkhasappaṭibhāgaṃ caritabbaṃ, idaṃ na🔽sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā agāramajjhe vasantena ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ…pe… carituṃ, yaṃnūnāhaṃ
analyzed: saṅkha likhitam likhita saṅkha sadisam dhota saṅkha sappaṭibhāgam caritabbam idam na  sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā agāra majjhe vasantena caritum
translated: It should be lived like a written letter, like a written letter that is read, like a written letter that is read and its meaning understood.🔽This is not easy to do while living in a home,🔽while dwelling in a house in the midst of the village, to live it completely fulfilled, completely purified, completely cleansed.🔽So let me shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kasāyarasapītatāya kāsāyāni brahmacariyaṃ carantānaṃ anucchavikāni
analyzed: kesa massum ohāretvā kasāya rasa pīta tāya kāsāyāni brahmacariyam anucchavikāni
translated: The ochre robes are suitable for those who are living the spiritual life.

original: vatthāni acchādetvā paridahitvā agārasmā nikkhamitvā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjeyyanti. Ettha
analyzed: vatthāni a chādetvā paridahitvā agārasmā nikkhamitvā anagāriyam pabbajjeyyanti ettha
translated: and having cut them up and sewn them together, I would go forth from the home life into homelessness.’

original: ca yasmā agārassa hitaṃ kasivaṇijjādikammaṃ agāriyanti vuccati, taṃ pabbajjāya natthi,
analyzed: ca yasmai agārassa hitam kasi vaṇijja ādi kammam agāriyanti vuccati tam pabbajjāya na atthi
translated: And here, since the profitable and trade, etc., which are beneficial to the home life are called ‘the home life,’ and since these do not exist in going forth,🔽it should be understood that ‘going forth’ is ‘homelessness.’

original: tasmā pabbajjā anagāriyāti ñātabbā, taṃ anagāriyaṃ. Pabbajeyyanti paṭipajjeyyaṃ.🔽Paṭapilotikānanti jiṇṇapilotikānaṃ terasahatthopi hi navasāṭako dasānaṃ chinnakālato
analyzed: tasmā pabbajjā anagāriyā ati ñātabbā tam anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti paṭipajjeyyam  paṭa pilotikānam ti jiṇṇa pilotikānam terasa hatthaḥ api hi nava sāṭakaḥ dasānam chinna kālataḥ
translated: ‘I would go forth’: I would practise.🔽‘Old cast-off rags’: a new cloth that is thirteen hands long and seven hands wide is called ‘old’ and ‘cast off’ from the time it has been cut up into pieces.

original: paṭṭhāya pilotikāti vuccati. Iti mahārahāni vatthāni chinditvā kataṃ saṅghāṭiṃ sandhāya🔽“paṭapilotikānaṃ saṅghāṭi”nti vuttaṃ. Addhānamaggappaṭipannoti aḍḍhayojanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: paṭṭhāya pilotikā ati vuccati iti mahā rahāni vatthāni chinditvā katam saṅghāṭim sandhāya  paṭa pilotikānam saṅghāṭinti vuttam addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ ti aḍḍha yojanataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: So it is a cloak made from rags cut from expensive cloth that is meant here.

original: maggo addhānanti vuccati, taṃ addhānamaggaṃ paṭipanno, dīghamaggaṃ paṭipannoti attho.🔽Idāni yathā esa pabbajito, yathā ca addhānamaggaṃ paṭipanno, imassatthassa āvibhāvatthaṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ addhānanti vuccati tam addhāna maggam paṭipannaḥ dīgha maggam paṭipannaḥ ti attho 🔽idāni yathā esa pabbajitaḥ yathā ca addhāna maggam paṭipannaḥ imassa atthassa āvi bhāva attham
translated: ‘Travelling the path’: a path that is more than half a yojana long is called ‘a path’; he is travelling that path, the long path, is the meaning.

original: abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya anupubbikathā kathetabbā – atīte kira kappasatasahassamatthake
analyzed: abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya anupubbi kathā kathetabbā atīte kira kappa sata sahassa matthake
translated: From the time of his aspiration onwards the gradual talk should be given: “In the past, it seems, a hundred thousand cycles of time ago,

original: padumuttaro nāma satthā udapādi, tasmiṃ haṃsavatīnagaraṃ upanissāya kheme migadāye🔽viharante vedeho nāma kuṭumbiko asītikoṭidhanavibhavo pātova subhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: padumuttaraḥ nāma satthā udapādi tasmin haṃsavatī nagaram upanissāya kheme migadāye  viharante vedehaḥ nāma kuṭumbikaḥ asīti koṭi dhana vibhavaḥ su bhojanam bhuñjitvā
translated: the Teacher Padumuttara arose. In his time, in the city of Haṃsavatī, in the deer park of Khema,🔽which was dependent on the city,

original: uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya gandhapupphādīni gahetvā vihāraṃ gantvā satthāraṃ pūjetvā
analyzed: uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya gandha puppha ādīni gahetvā vihāram gantvā satthāram pūjetvā
translated: having taken perfumes, flowers, etc., he went to the monastery, worshipped the Teacher,

original: vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe satthā mahānisabhattheraṃ nāma tatiyasāvakaṃ
analyzed: vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi tasmin khaṇe satthā mahānisabhattheram nāma tatiya sāvakam
translated: and sat down on one side. At that moment the Teacher placed the Elder Mahānisabha, who was his third disciple,

original: “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhutavādānaṃ yadidaṃ nisabho”ti
analyzed: etat aggam bhikkhave mama sāvakānam bhikkhūnam dhuta vādānam yat idam
translated: in the foremost position among those who were strict in the practice of the ascetic practices, saying: ‘This bhikkhu Nisabha is the foremost of those who are strict in the practice of the ascetic practices.’

original: etadagge ṭhapesi. Upāsako taṃ sutvā pasanno dhammakathāvasāne mahājane uṭṭhāya gate
analyzed: etad agge ṭhapesi upāsakaḥ tam sutvā pasannaḥ dhamma kathā avasāne mahājane uṭṭhāya gate
translated: When the layman heard this, he was pleased. At the end of the lesson, when the great crowd had risen and departed,

original: satthāraṃ vanditvā, “bhante, sve mayhaṃ bhikkhaṃ adhivāsethā”ti āha. Mahā kho, upāsaka,
analyzed: satthāram vanditvā bhante sve mayham bhikkham adhivāsetha ati āha mahā kho upāsaka
translated: he worshipped the Teacher and said: ‘Venerable sir, let the Teacher accept my invitation to take a meal with the Community of Bhikkhus tomorrow.’ ‘The Community is large, layman,

original: bhikkhusaṅghoti. Kittako bhagavāti. Aṭṭhasaṭṭhibhikkhusatasahassanti. Bhante, ekaṃ🔽sāmaṇerampi vihāre asesetvā bhikkhaṃ adhivāsethāti. Satthā adhivāsesi. Upāsako satthu
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti kittakaḥ bhagavā ati aṭṭhasaṭṭhi bhikkhu sata sahassanti bhante ekam  sāmaṇeram pi vihāre a sesetvā bhikkham adhivāsetha ati satthā adhivāsesi upāsakaḥ satthu
translated: “The Community of monks.” “How many monks are there, Lord?” “Six hundred and eighty thousand.” “Venerable Sir, please accept almsfood tomorrow at my house, without leaving out even one monk.” The Teacher accepted.

original: adhivāsanaṃ viditvā gehaṃ gantvā mahādānaṃ sajjetvā punadivase satthu kālaṃ ārocāpesi.
analyzed: adhivāsanam viditvā geham gantvā mahādānam sajjetvā puna divase satthu kālam ārocāpesi
translated: “The Community of Bhikkhus.” “How many, Reverend Sir?” “Six hundred and eighty thousand.” “Reverend Sir, will you please not leave a single novice in the monastery, but take them all with you?” The Teacher consented. The lay disciple, understanding the Teacher’s consent, went to his house, prepared a great quantity of food, and the next day announced the hour of meal-time.

original: Satthā pattacīvaramādāya bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto upāsakassa gharaṃ gantvā paññattāsane🔽nisinno dakkhiṇodakāvasāne yāgubhattādīni sampaṭicchanto bhattavissaggaṃ akāsi. Upāsakopi🔽satthu santike nisīdi.
analyzed: satthā patta cīvaram ādāya bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ upāsakassa gharam gantvā paññatta āsane  nisinnaḥ dakkhiṇa udaka avasāne yāgu bhatta ādīni sampaṭicchantaḥ bhatta vissaggam akāsi upāsakaḥ api  satthu santike nisīdi
translated: The Teacher, taking bowl and robe, surrounded by the Community of Bhikkhus, went to the house of the lay disciple, sat down on the seat prepared for him,🔽and when the water-offering had been made, accepted the rice-gruel, boiled rice, etc., and made an end of the food that had been prepared. The lay disciple also sat down in the presence of the Teacher.

original: Tasmiṃ antare mahānisabhatthero piṇḍāya caranto tameva vīthiṃ paṭipajji. Upāsako
analyzed: tasmin antare mahānisabha theraḥ piṇḍāya carantaḥ tam eva vīthim paṭipajji upāsako
translated: At that moment the Elder Mahā-Nissabha, going about for alms, entered that very street. The lay disciple,

original: disvā uṭṭhāya gantvā theraṃ vanditvā “pattaṃ, bhante, no dethā”ti āha. Thero pattaṃ
analyzed: disvā uṭṭhāya gantvā theram vanditvā pattam bhante naḥ detha iti āha thero pattaṃ
translated: seeing him, rose up, went to him, saluted him, and said, “Reverend Sir, give me your bowl.” The Elder gave him his bowl.

original: adāsi. Bhante, idheva pavisatha, satthāpi gehe nisinnoti. Na vaṭṭissati upāsakāti.
analyzed: adāsi bhante idhā iva pavisatha satthā api gehe nisinnaḥ ti na vaṭṭissati upāsaka ati
translated: “Venerable, enter right here. The Teacher is sitting in the house.” “It will not do for me to enter, lay disciple.”

original: Upāsako therassa pattaṃ gahetvā piṇḍapātassa pūretvā nīharitvā adāsi. Tato theraṃ🔽anugantvā nivatto satthu santike nisīditvā evamāha – “bhante, mahānisabhatthero ‘satthā🔽gehe nisinno’ti vuttepi pavisituṃ na icchi, atthi nu kho etassa tumhākaṃ guṇehi atireko
analyzed: upāsakaḥ therassa pattam gahetvā piṇḍapātassa pūretvā nīharitvā adāsi tatas theram  anugantvā nivattaḥ satthu santike nisīditvā evam āha bhante mahānisabha theraḥ satthā  gehe nisinnaḥ ti vutte api pavisitum na icchi atthi nu kho etassa tumhākam guṇehi atirekaḥ
translated: The lay disciple took the Elder’s bowl, filled it with boiled rice, brought it out, and gave it to him. Then he followed the Elder,

original: guṇo”ti. Buddhānañca vaṇṇamaccheraṃ nāma natthi. Atha satthā evamāha – “upāsaka,
