translated: If I were to see a teacher, I would see only the Blessed One.

original: bhagavantaṃ passeyyaṃ. Na hi me ito aññena satthārā bhavituṃ sakkāti. Sugatañca vatāhaṃ
analyzed: bhagavantam passeyyam na hi me itas aññena satthārā bhavitum sakkā ati sugatam ca vata aham
translated: For it is not possible for me to have a teacher other than him.

original: passeyyaṃ bhagavantameva passeyyanti sace ahaṃ sammāpaṭipattiyā suṭṭhu gatattā sugataṃ
analyzed: passeyyam bhagavantam eva passeyyanti sace aham sammā paṭipattiyā suṭṭhu gata ttā sugatam
translated: If I were to see a well-gone one, I would see only the Blessed One.

original: nāma passeyyaṃ, imaṃyeva bhagavantaṃ passeyyaṃ. Na hi me ito aññena sugatena bhavituṃ🔽sakkāti. Sammāsambuddhañca vatāhaṃ passeyyaṃ bhagavantameva passeyyanti sace ahaṃ
analyzed: nāma passeyyam imaṃyeva bhagavantam passeyyam na hi me itas aññena sugatena bhavituṃ  sakka ati sammāsambuddham ca vata aham passeyyam bhagavantam eva passeyyanti sace aham
translated: For it is not possible for me to have a well-gone one other than him.

original: sammā sāmañca saccāni buddhattā sammāsambuddhaṃ nāma passeyyaṃ, imaṃyeva bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: sammā sāmañca saccāni buddha ttā sammāsambuddham nāma passeyyam imaṃ yeva bhagavantam
translated: If I were to see a fully enlightened one, I would see only the Blessed One.

original: passeyyaṃ. Na hi me ito aññena sammāsambuddhena bhavituṃ sakkāti ayamettha adhippāyo.
analyzed: passeyyam na hi me itas aññena sammāsambuddhena bhavitum sakkā iti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ
translated: For it is not possible for me to have a fully enlightened one other than him. This is the intention here.

original: Evaṃ dassaneneva “bhagavati ‘ayaṃ satthā, ayaṃ sugato, ayaṃ sammāsambuddho’ti nikkaṅkho
analyzed: evam dassanena iva bhagavati ayam satthā ayam sugataḥ ayam sammāsambuddhaḥ iti nikkaṅkhaḥ
translated: “Thus, friend, I was freed from doubt as to the Master, thinking: ‘This is the Master, this is the Sugata, this is the One Well-Gone, this is the One with Clear Vision, this is the Worthy One, this is the Fully Enlightened One’”.

original: ahaṃ, āvuso, ahosi”nti dīpeti. Satthā me, bhanteti idaṃ kiñcāpi dve vāre āgataṃ,
analyzed: aham āvuso ahosin ti dīpeti satthā me bhante iti idam kiñca api dve vāre āgatam
translated: “The Master, venerable Sir” is said twice, but it should be understood as said three times,

original: tikkhattuṃ pana vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Iminā hi so “evaṃ tikkhattuṃ sāvakattaṃ sāvesiṃ, āvuso”ti dīpeti.
analyzed: tikkhattum pana vuttan ti veditabbam iminā hi saḥ evam tikkhattum sāvaka ttam āvuso ti dīpeti
translated: for by this he shows that he “announced his discipleship three times, friend”.

original: Ajānaññevāti ajānamānova. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti yassa
analyzed: a jānaññā iva ati a jānamānā uva dutiya pade pi esa iva nayaḥ muddhā api tassa vipateyya ati yassa
translated: “Not knowing”: not knowing. The same construction applies to the second clause. “His head would split in seven”:

original: aññassa “ajānaṃyeva jānāmī”ti paṭiññassa bāhirakassa satthuno evaṃ sabbacetasā samannāgato🔽pasannacitto sāvako evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ kareyya, tassa vaṇṭachinnatālapakkaṃ
analyzed: aññassa a jānaṃya iva jānāmi iti paṭiññassa bāhirakassa satthunaḥ evam sabba cetasā samannāgataḥ  pasanna cittaḥ sāvakaḥ evarūpam parama nipacca kāram kareyya tassa vaṇṭa chinna tāla pakkam
translated: if anyone else, a heretic, were to make such an announcement, saying: “Not knowing, I know”,🔽and if a disciple of his were to be so devoted to him,

original: viya gīvato muddhāpi vipateyya, sattadhā pana phaleyyāti attho. Kiṃ vā etena, sace
analyzed: viya gīvataḥ muddhā api vipateyya sattadhā pana phaleyya ati attho kim vai etena sace
translated: and if he were to render such supreme service, his head would split like a palmyra fruit split by a stroke from a sharp axe. The meaning is that it would split into seven pieces. What is the use of that?

original: mahākassapatthero iminā cittappasādena imaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ mahāsamuddassa kareyya,🔽tattakapāle pakkhittaudakabindu viya vilayaṃ gaccheyya. Sace cakkavāḷassa kareyya,
analyzed: mahākassapa theraḥ iminā citta ppasādena imam parama nipaccakāram mahā samuddassa kareyya  tad ta kapāle pakkhitta udaka bindu viya vilayam gaccheyya sace cakkavāḷassa kareyya
translated: The Elder Kassapa the Great could have shown this highest respect to the ocean, but the ocean would have been destroyed, like a drop of water thrown into a red-hot mass of iron.🔽If he had shown it to the world-sphere mountain, the mountain would have been shattered to pieces, like a handful of sand struck by the thunderbolt.

original: thusamuṭṭhi viya vikireyya. Sace sinerupabbatassa kareyya, kākatuṇḍena pahaṭapiṭṭhamuṭṭhi
analyzed: thusa muṭṭhi viya vikireyya sace sineru pabbatassa kareyya kākatuṇḍena pahaṭa piṭṭha muṭṭhi
translated: If he had shown it to Mount Sineru, the mountain would have been split asunder, like a heap of bran struck by the edge of a winnowing basket.

original: viya viddhaṃseyya. Sace mahāpathaviyā kareyya, vātāhatabhasmapuñjo viya vikireyya.
analyzed: sace mahā pathaviyā kareyya vāta āhata bhasma puñjaḥ viya vikireyya
translated: If he had shown it to the earth, the earth would have been scattered, like a heap of ashes struck by the wind.

original: Evarūpopi pana therassa nipaccākāro satthu suvaṇṇavaṇṇe pādapiṭṭhe lomamattampi vikopetuṃ
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api pana therassa nipacca ākāraḥ satthu suvaṇṇa vaṇṇe pāda piṭṭhe loma mattam pi vikopetum
translated: But even such a great respect as this could not ruffle even a hair of the Teacher’s golden-colored foot-sole.

original: nāsakkhi. Tiṭṭhatu ca mahākassapo, mahākassapasadisānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sahassampi satasahassampi
analyzed: na asakkhi tiṭṭhatu ca mahākassapaḥ mahākassapa sadisānam bhikkhūnam sahassam pi sata sahassam pi
translated: Let alone Kassapa the Great, even a thousand or a hundred thousand monks like Kassapa the Great

original: nipaccākāradassanena neva dasabalassa pādapiṭṭhe lomamattampi vikopetuṃ paṃsukūlacīvare
analyzed: nipacca ākāra dassanena na iva dasabalassa pāda piṭṭhe loma mattam pi vikopetum paṃsukūla cīvare
translated: could not ruffle even a hair of the Ten-Powered One’s foot-sole or stir even a hair of his refuse-rag robe by showing their respect.

original: vā aṃsumattampi cāletuṃ sakkoti. Evaṃ mahānubhāvo hi satthā.
analyzed: vā aṃsu mattam pi cāletum sakkoti evam mahā anubhāvaḥ hi satthā
translated: So mighty was the Teacher.

original: Tasmātiha te kassapāti yasmā ahaṃ jānanto eva “jānāmī”ti, passanto eva ca “passāmī”ti🔽vadāmi, tasmā, kassapa, tayā evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ. Tibbanti bahalaṃ mahantaṃ. Hirottappanti
analyzed: tasmā ati ha te kassapāti yasmai aham jānantaḥ eva jānāmi iti passantaḥ eva ca passāmi iti  vadāmi tasmai kassapa tayā evam sikkhitabbam tibbanti bahalam mahantam hirā uttappanti
translated: “Therefore, Kassapa, you should train yourself thus: ‘I will be one who is thick-skinned and has a thick skull, and I will be one who has established conscience and shame. ’”🔽Thick-skinned and thick-headed: thick-skinned means having thick skin; thick-headed means having a thick skull.

original: hirī ca ottappañca. Paccupaṭṭhitaṃ bhavissatīti paṭhamatarameva upaṭṭhitaṃ bhavissati.🔽Yo hi therādīsu hirottappaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā upasaṅkamati therādayopi taṃ sahirikā saottappā
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhitam bhavissati iti paṭhamataram eva upaṭṭhitam bhavissati  yaḥ hi thera ādīsu hirottappam upaṭṭhapetvā upasaṅkamati thera ādayaḥ api tam sa hirikā sa ottappā
translated: Established: first established.🔽For one who approaches elders, etc., with conscience and shame established, the elders, etc., also approach him with conscience and shame established. This is the benefit here.

original: ca hutvā upasaṅkamantīti ayamettha ānisaṃso. Kusalūpasaṃhitanti kusalasannissitaṃ.
analyzed: ca hutvā upasaṅkamanti iti ayam ettha ānisaṃso kusala upasaṃhitanti kusala sannissitam
translated: Associated with the wholesome: dependent on the wholesome.

original: Aṭṭhiṃ katvāti attānaṃ tena dhammena aṭṭhikaṃ katvā, taṃ vā dhammaṃ “esa mayhaṃ attho”ti🔽aṭṭhiṃ katvā. Manasi katvāti citte ṭhapetvā. Sabbacetasā samannāharitvāti cittassa
analyzed: aṭṭhim katvā ti attānam tena dhammena aṭṭhikam katvā tam vā dhammam esa mayham atthaḥ ti  aṭṭhim katvā manasi katvā ati citte ṭhapetvā sabba cetasā samannāharitvā ati cittassa
translated: Making the Dhamma a support: making oneself a support for that Dhamma, or making the Dhamma a support by thinking: “This is my goal.”🔽Paying attention: placing in the mind.🔽Concentrating the entire mind: concentrating the mind without allowing even a little to go outside.

original: thokampi bahi gantuṃ adento sabbena samannāhāracittena samannāharitvā. Ohitasototi
analyzed: thokam pi bahi gantum a dento sabbena samannāhāra cittena samannāharitvā ohita soto ti
translated: With ears attentive:

original: ṭhapitasoto, ñāṇasotañca pasādasotañca odahitvā mayā desitaṃ dhammaṃ sakkaccameva🔽suṇissāmīti evañhi te sikkhitabbaṃ. Sātasahagatā ca me kāyagatāsatīti asubhesu ceva🔽ānāpāne ca paṭhamajjhānavasena sukhasampayuttā kāyagatāsati. Yo ca panāyaṃ tividho
analyzed: ṭhapita sotaḥ ñāṇa sotam ca pasāda sotam ca odahitvā mayā desitam dhammam sakkaccam eva  suṇissāmi iti evam hi te sikkhitabbam sāta sahagatā ca me kāya gatā asatī iti asubhesu ca iva  āna apāne ca paṭhama jhāna vasena sukha sampayuttā kāya gatā asati yaḥ ca pana ayam tividhaḥ
translated: “You should train like this: ‘I will listen to the Dhamma with ears that are open,🔽with a mind that is ready to be instructed, and I will direct my whole mind to wisdom. I will listen to the Dhamma with a mind that is full of joy,🔽full of happiness, and full of confidence.’ This is how you should train. ‘I will listen to the Dhamma with a mind that is full of joy,🔽full of happiness, and full of confidence’ means that mindfulness related to the body is associated with the pleasure of the first jhāna in the case of foulness and in the case of breathing.🔽And this mindfulness related to the body

original: ovādo, therassa ayameva pabbajjā ca upasampadā ca ahosi.🔽Saraṇoti sakileso saiṇo hutvā. Raṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ bhuñjinti saddhādeyyaṃ bhuñjiṃ. Cattāro
analyzed: ovādaḥ therassa ayam eva pabbajjā ca upasampadā ca ahosi  saraṇo ti sa kilesaḥ sa eṇaḥ hutvā raṭṭha piṇḍam bhuñjinti saddhādeyyam bhuñjim cattāro
translated: and having directed the ear-faculty to the sound of the Dhamma, and having directed the knowledge-faculty and the faith-faculty, I will listen to the Dhamma that is being taught by the Fortunate One with respect. Thus, monks, should you train. And my mindfulness while possessing happiness is connected with the body. In the unpleasant (subject of meditation) and in the mindfulness while possessing happiness is connected with the body. And this threefold advice, for the Elder, was both his going-forth and his higher ordination.

original: hi paribhogā theyyaparibhogo iṇaparibhogo dāyajjaparibhogo sāmiparibhogoti. Tattha
analyzed: hi paribhogā theyya paribhogo iṇa paribhogo dāyajja paribhogo sāmi paribhogo ti tattha
translated: Having become one who is defiled by defilements, I ate the country’s almsfood. There are four kinds of enjoyments: the enjoyment of theft, the enjoyment of debt, the enjoyment of inheritance, the enjoyment of a master.

original: dussīlassa saṅghamajjhe nisīditvā bhuñjantassāpi paribhogo theyyaparibhogo nāma.
analyzed: dussīlassa saṅgha majjhe nisīditvā bhuñjantassa api paribhogaḥ theyya paribhogaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, the enjoyment of one who is unvirtuous, while sitting in the midst of the Community and eating, is called the enjoyment of theft.

original: Kasmā? Catūsu paccayesu anissaratāya. Sīlavato apaccavekkhitaparibhogo iṇaparibhogo
analyzed: kasmā catūsu paccayesu a nissara tāya sīlavataḥ a paccavekkhita paribhogo iṇa paribhogo
translated: Why is it so? Because he is not independent in the four requisites. The enjoyment of one who is virtuous, but who does not reflect, is the enjoyment of debt.

original: nāma. Sattannaṃ sekhānaṃ paribhogo dāyajjaparibhogo nāma. Khīṇāsavassa paribhogo🔽sāmiparibhogo nāma. Iti khīṇāsavova sāmī hutvā anaṇo paribhuñjati. Thero attanā puthujjanena
analyzed: nāma sattannam sekhānam paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogaḥ nāma khīṇāsavassa paribhogaḥ  sāmi paribhogaḥ nāma iti sāmī hutvā anaṇaḥ paribhuñjati theraḥ attanā puthujjanena
translated: The use of the seven kinds of disciples is called the use of a son. The use of one whose cankers are destroyed is called the use of a master. Thus it is only one whose cankers are destroyed who, having become a master, uses the requisites without debt. The elder, who had used the requisites himself as a worldling,

original: hutvā paribhuttaparibhogaṃ iṇaparibhogaṃyeva karonto evamāha. Aṭṭhamiyā aññā udapādīti
analyzed: hutvā paribhutta paribhogam iṇa paribhogam yeva karontaḥ evam āha aṭṭhamiyā aññā udapādi iti
translated: said this, making the use of the requisites by one whose cankers are destroyed the use of a son and his own use the use of a debtor.

original: aṭṭhame divase arahattaphalaṃ uppajji.🔽Atha kho, āvuso, bhagavā maggā okkammāti maggato okkamanaṃ paṭhamataraṃ taṃdivaseyeva
analyzed: aṭṭhame divase arahatta phalam uppajji  atha kho āvuso bhagavā maggā okkamma ati maggataḥ okkamanam paṭhamataram
translated: The knowledge of the eighth stage arose means the fruit of arahantship arose on the eighth day.

original: ahosi, arahattādhigamo pacchā. Desanāvārassa pana evaṃ āgatattā arahattādhigamo paṭhamaṃ🔽dīpito. Kasmā pana bhagavā maggā okkantoti? Evaṃ kirassa ahosi “imaṃ bhikkhuṃ jātiāraññikaṃ
analyzed: ahosi arahatta adhigamo pacchā desanā vārassa pana evam āgata ttā arahatta adhigamo paṭhamam  dīpitaḥ kasmā pana bhagavā maggā okkanto ti evam kirassa ahosi imam bhikkhum jāti āraññikam
translated: Then the Blessed One came down from the road means that the Blessed One’s descent from the road took place earlier on that very day, while the attainment of arahantship took place later. But because the sutta passage comes in this way, the attainment of arahantship is shown as first.

original: jātipaṃsukūlikaṃ jātiekāsanikaṃ karissāmī”ti. Tasmā okkami.
analyzed: jāti paṃsukūlikam jāti eka āsanikam karissāmi iti tasmai okkami
translated: Why did the Blessed One come down from the road? It seems that he thought: “I will make this bhikkhu a forest-dweller, a refuse-rag-wearer, and a single-blanketed-wearer by birth.” Therefore he came down from the road.

original: Mudukā kho tyāyanti mudukā kho te ayaṃ. Imañca pana vācaṃ bhagavā taṃ cīvaraṃ padumapupphavaṇṇena
analyzed: mudukā kho tyāyanti mudukā kho te ayam imam ca pana vācam bhagavā tam cīvaram paduma puppha vaṇṇena
translated: “Soft, indeed, are these to you” means “Soft, indeed, are these to you, Gotama.” And the Blessed One, having accepted that robe, which was the colour of a lotus flower,

original: pāṇinā antantena parāmasanto āha. Kasmā evamāhāti? Therena saha cīvaraṃ parivattetukāmatāya.
analyzed: pāṇinā āha kasmai evam āha ati therena saha cīvaram
translated: “Soft, indeed, are these to you” : soft, indeed, are these to you. And the Blessed One spoke this word while touching with his lotus-like hand the end of the robe. Why did he speak thus? Because he desired to exchange the robe with the Elder.

original: Kasmā parivattetukāmo jātoti? Theraṃ attano ṭhāne ṭhapetukāmatāya. Thero pana yasmā
analyzed: kasmā theraṃ attano ṭhāne ṭhapetu kāma tāya theraḥ pana yasmā
translated: Why did he desire to exchange? Because he desired to place the Elder in his own place. But the Elder,

original: cīvarassa vā pattassa vā vaṇṇe kathite “imaṃ tumhākaṃ gaṇhathā”tivacanaṃ cārittameva,🔽tasmā “paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā”ti āha. Dhāressasi pana me tvaṃ, kassapa,🔽sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanānīti, kassapa, tvaṃ imāni paribhogajiṇṇāni paṃsukūlāni
analyzed: cīvarassa vā pattassa vā vaṇṇe kathite imam tumhākam gaṇhatha ativacanam cārittam eva  tasmai paṭiggaṇhātu me bhante bhagavā ati āha dhāressasi pana me tvam kassapa  sāṇāni paṃsukūlāni nibbasanāni iti kassapa tvam imāni paribhoga jiṇṇāni paṃsukūlāni
translated: because it is the custom to say “Take this” when the colour of a robe or a bowl is mentioned,

original: pārupituṃ sakkhissasīti vadati. Tañca kho na kāyabalaṃ sandhāya, paṭipattipūraṇaṃ
analyzed: sakkhissasi iti vadati tat ca kho na kāya balam sandhāya paṭipatti pūraṇam
translated: therefore he said: “May the Blessed One accept from me, venerable Sir, this robe.” “But, Kassapa, will you be able to wear my cast-off hempen rag-robes?” : “Kassapa, will you be able to wear these cast-off rag-robes which are worn out by use?” He said this not with reference to physical strength,

original: pana sandhāya evamāha. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – ahaṃ imaṃ cīvaraṃ puṇṇaṃ nāma dāsiṃ
analyzed: pana sandhāya evam āha ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ aham imam cīvaram puṇṇam nāma dāsim
translated: but with reference to the fulfilment of the practice . This is the intention here: I will give this robe to Puṇṇa, a slave-woman,

original: pārupitvā āmakasusāne chaḍḍitaṃ taṃ susānaṃ pavisitvā tumbamattehi pāṇakehi samparikiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: pārupitvā āmaka susāne chaḍḍitam tam susānam pavisitvā tumba mattehi pāṇakehi samparikiṇṇam
translated: and he had it thrown into the charnel ground. He went into the charnel ground and took it,

original: te pāṇake vidhunitvā mahāariyavaṃse ṭhatvā aggahesiṃ, tassa me imaṃ cīvaraṃ gahitadivase
analyzed: te pāṇake vidhunitvā mahāariya vaṃse ṭhatvā aggahesim tassa me imam cīvaram gahita divase
translated: after removing the worms that were all over it, and he put it on the noble tree. On the day he took it,

original: dasasahassacakkavāḷe mahāpathavī mahāviravaṃ viravamānā kampittha, ākāso taṭataṭāyi,
analyzed: dasa sahassa cakkavāḷe mahā pathavī mahā viravam viravamānā kampittha ākāsaḥ taṭa taṭāyi
translated: the great earth shook and rumbled with a great noise in the ten-thousandfold world-element, the sky rumbled,

original: cakkavāḷadevatā sādhukāramadaṃsu, “imaṃ cīvaraṃ gaṇhantena bhikkhunā jātipaṃsukūlikena🔽jātiāraññikena jātiekāsanikena jātisapadānacārikena bhavituṃ vaṭṭati, tvaṃ imassa
analyzed: cakkavāḷa devatā imam cīvaram gaṇhantena bhikkhunā jāti paṃsukūlikena  jāti āraññikena jāti ekāsanikena jāti sa padāna cārikena bhavitum vaṭṭati tvam imassa
translated: and the deities of the world-element cried Bravo! “It is proper for a bhikkhu who takes up this robe to be one who wears robes made of cast-off cloth,🔽one who is a forest-dweller by nature, one who is a bed-spacer by nature, and one who goes on continuous alms round by nature. Can you do this?”

original: cīvarassa anucchavikaṃ kātuṃ sakkhissasī”ti. Theropi attanā pañcannaṃ hatthīnaṃ balaṃ🔽dhāreti, so taṃ atakkayitvā “ahametaṃ paṭipattiṃ pūressāmī”ti ussāhena sugatacīvarassa
analyzed: cīvarassa anucchavikam kātum sakkhissasi iti theraḥ api attanā pañcannam hatthīnam balaṃ  dhāra iti saḥ tam a takkayitvā aham etam paṭipattim pūressāmi iti ussāhena sugata cīvarassa
translated: The elder had the strength of five elephants,

original: anucchavikaṃ kātukāmo “dhāressāmahaṃ, bhante”ti āha. Paṭipajjinti paṭipannosmi. Evaṃ
analyzed: anucchavikam kātu kāmaḥ dhāressām aham bhante ti āha paṭipajjin ti paṭipannaḥ asmi evam
translated: and without considering this he said, “I shall fulfil this practice,” and with eagerness to do what was proper for the Sugata’s robe he said, “I shall wear it, venerable sir.” “I am practising it, venerable sir,” he said, “I am undertaking it.”

original: pana cīvaraparivattanaṃ katvā ca therena pārutacīvaraṃ bhagavā pārupi, satthu cīvaraṃ
analyzed: pana cīvara parivattanam katvā ca therena pāruta cīvaram bhagavā pārupi satthu cīvaram
translated: But after exchanging robes with the Elder, the Blessed One put on the robe of wind. The Elder put on the robe of the Master.

original: thero. Tasmiṃ samaye mahāpathavī udakapariyantaṃ katvā unnadantī kampittha.
analyzed: thero tasmin samaye mahā pathavī udaka pariyantam katvā unnadantī kampittha
translated: At that moment the great earth rose up and trembled to the edge of the water.

analyzed: anta rahitesu ubhatas vibhaṅga matte mahāvinaye anta rahite dvīsu pātimokkhesu vattamānesu pi
translated: and when two of the two Pātimokkhas have disappeared, and only one remains,

original: sāsanaṃ anantarahitameva. Yadā pana dve pātimokkhā antaradhāyissanti, atha pariyattisaddhammassa🔽antaradhānaṃ bhavissati. Tasmiṃ antarahite sāsanaṃ antarahitaṃ nāma hoti. Pariyattiyā
analyzed: sāsanam anantara hitam eva yadā pana dve pātimokkhāḥ antaradhāyissanti atha pariyatti saddhammassa  antaradhānam bhavissati tasmin antarahite sāsanam antarahitam nāma hoti pariyattiyā
translated: then the Dispensation is not yet disappeared. But when the two Pātimokkhas have disappeared, then the Dispensation has disappeared with the disappearance of the scriptures.

original: hi antarahitāya paṭipatti antaradhāyati, paṭipattiyā antarahitāya adhigamo antaradhāyati.
analyzed: hi antarahitāya paṭipatti antaradhāyati paṭipattiyā antarahitāya adhigamaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: For when the scriptures have disappeared, the practice disappears, and when the practice has disappeared, the realization disappears.

original: Kiṃ kāraṇā? Ayañhi pariyatti paṭipattiyā paccayo hoti, paṭipatti adhigamassa. Iti
analyzed: kim kāraṇā ayam hi pariyatti paṭipattiyā paccayaḥ hoti paṭipatti adhigamassa iti
translated: Why is this? Because this scripture is a condition for the practice, and the practice is a condition for realization.

original: paṭipattitopi pariyattimeva pamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: paṭipattitaḥ pi pariyattim eva pamāṇam
translated: So the practice too has the scriptures as its measure.

original: Nanu ca kassapasammāsambuddhakāle kapilo nāma anārādhakabhikkhu “pātimokkhaṃ uddisissāmī”ti
analyzed: nanu ca kassapa sammāsambuddha kāle kapilaḥ nāma anārādhaka bhikkhu pātimokkham uddisissāmi iti
translated: But did not the Dispensation not disappear even when the Elder Revata, who was the foremost in prolonged meditation, had attained Nibbāna, and also when the Elder Mahā-Moggallāna’s pupil, the Elder Abhibhū, who was foremost in spiritual powers, had attained Nibbāna?

original: bījaniṃ gahetvā āsane nisinno “atthi imasmiṃ vattantā”ti pucchi, atha tassa bhayena
analyzed: bījanim gahetvā āsane nisinnaḥ atthi imasmin vattantā ati pucchi atha tassa bhayena
translated: and he took up his fan and sat down on his seat and asked, “Is the Pāṭimokkha recited here? ” Then,

original: yesampi pātimokkho vattati, tepi “mayaṃ vattāmā”ti avatvā “na vattāmā”ti vadiṃsu,
analyzed: yesam pi pātimokkhaḥ vattati te pi mayam vattāma iti a vatvā na vattāma iti vadiṃsu
translated: through fear of him, even those who had recited the Pāṭimokkha said, “We have not recited it,” and those who had not said, “We have.”

original: so bījaniṃ ṭhapetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā gato, tadā sammāsambuddhassa sāsanaṃ osakkitanti?
analyzed: saḥ bījanim ṭhapetvā uṭṭhāya āsanā gataḥ tadā sammāsambuddhassa sāsanam osakkitanti
translated: So he put down his fan, got up from his seat and went away. Was it then that the Enlightened One’s dispensation declined?

original: Kiñcāpi osakkitaṃ, pariyatti pana ekanteneva pamāṇaṃ. Yathā hi mahato taḷākassa pāḷiyā
analyzed: kiñca api osakkitam pariyatti pana ekantena iva pamāṇam yathā hi mahataḥ taḷākassa pāḷiyā
translated: Even though it declined, the tradition is the sole criterion. For just as it cannot be said that there is no water in a great tank

original: thirāya udakaṃ na ṭhassatīti na vattabbaṃ, udake sati padumādīni pupphāni na pupphissantīti🔽na vattabbaṃ, evameva mahātaḷākassa thirapāḷisadise tepiṭake buddhavacane sati mahātaḷāke
analyzed: thirāya udakam na na ṭhassati iti na vattabbam udake sati paduma ādīni pupphāni na pupphissanti iti  na vattabbam evam eva mahā taḷākassa thira pāḷi sadise tepiṭake buddha vacane sati mahā taḷāke
translated: because there is no water in the moat, so too it cannot be said that there are no flowers of the noble fruits of stream-entry, etc.,🔽in the great tank of the dispensation of the Enlightened One, which is a great tank, because there are no such flowers in the moat, which is the tradition.

original: udakasadisā paṭipattipūrakā kulaputtā natthīti na vattabbā, tesu sati mahātaḷāke🔽padumādīni pupphāni viya sotāpannādayo ariyapuggalā natthīti na vattabbāti evaṃ ekantato
analyzed: udaka sadisā paṭipatti pūrakā kula puttā natthi iti na vattabbā tesu sati mahā taḷāke 🔽paduma ādīni pupphāni viya sotāpanna ādayaḥ ariya puggalāḥ natthi iti na vattabbā ati evam ekantato
translated: And just as it cannot be said that there are no lotuses in the great tank because there are none in the moat, so too it cannot be said that there are no persons of the noble kinds of excellence in the dispensation of the Enlightened One because there are none in the tradition.🔽So the tradition is the sole criterion.

original: pariyattiyeva pamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: pariyattiyā iva pamāṇam
translated: The scriptures alone are the measure.

original: Pathavīdhātūti dve satasahassāni cattāri ca nahutāni bahalā mahāpathavī. Āpodhātūti🔽pathavito paṭṭhāya yāva subhakiṇhabrahmalokā uggataṃ kappavināsakaṃ udakaṃ. Tejodhātūti
analyzed: pathavī dhātū ti dve sata sahassāni cattāri ca nahutāni bahalā mahā pathavī āpaḥ dhātū ti  pathavitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva subha kiṇha brahmalokāḥ uggatam kappa vināsakam udakam tejaḥ dhātu uti
translated: The earth-element: the great earth is two hundred and forty thousand leagues in depth. The water-element:🔽the water that has risen up from the earth as far as the Subhakiṇha Brahmā-world at the time of the dissolution of the world by water. The fire-element:

original: pathavito paṭṭhāya yāva ābhassarabrahmalokā uggato kappavināsako aggi. Vāyodhātūti
analyzed: pathavitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva ābhassara brahmalokāḥ uggataḥ kappa vināsakaḥ aggi vāyodhātu uti
translated: the fire that has risen up from the earth as far as the Ābhassara Brahmā-world at the time of the dissolution of the world by fire. The air-element:

original: pathavito paṭṭhāya yāva vehapphalabrahmalokā uggato kappavināsako vāyu. Etesu hi
analyzed: pathavitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva vehapphala brahmalokāḥ uggataḥ kappa vināsakaḥ vāyu etesu hi
translated: the air that has risen up from the earth as far as the Vehapphala Brahmā-world at the time of the dissolution of the world by air. For not even one of these

original: ekadhammopi satthu sāsanaṃ antaradhāpetuṃ na sakkoti, tasmā evamāha. Idheva te uppajjantīti
analyzed: eka dhammaḥ api satthu sāsanam antaradhāpetum na sakkoti tasmai evam āha idha iva te uppajjanti iti
translated: is able to cause the Master’s Dispensation to disappear. Therefore he said as above. They arise here itself:

original: lohato lohakhādakaṃ malaṃ viya imasmiṃ mayhaṃyeva sāsane te uppajjanti. Moghapurisāti tucchapurisā.
analyzed: lohataḥ loha khādakam malam imasmin mayhaṃyeva sāsane te uppajjanti mogha purisā ati tuccha purisā
translated: they arise in my Dispensation itself, like the rust that arises on iron from the iron itself. Empty men: hollow men.

original: Ādikeneva opilavatīti ettha ādikenāti ādānena gahaṇena. Opilavatīti nimujjati. Idaṃ
analyzed: ādikena iva opilavatī iti ettha ādikena ati ādānena opilavatī iti idam
translated: The first: the beginning, the taking up, the grasping. It sinks: it submerges. This is the meaning of the passage.

original: vuttaṃ hoti – yathā udakacarā nāvā bhaṇḍaṃ gaṇhantī nimujjati, evaṃ pariyattiādīnaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti yathā udaka carā nāvā bhaṇḍam gaṇhantī nimujjati evam pariyatti ādīnam
translated: The meaning is this: just as a boat carrying goods sinks in water, so too the Dispensation does not disappear with the filling up of the scriptures, etc.

original: pūraṇena saddhammassa antaradhānaṃ na hoti. Pariyattiyā hi hāyamānāya paṭipatti hāyati,
analyzed: pūraṇena saddhammassa antaradhānam na hoti pariyattiyāḥ hi hāyamānāya paṭipatti hāyati
translated: For when the scriptures decline, practice declines;

original: paṭipattiyā hāyamānāya adhigamo hāyati. Pariyattiyā pūrayamānāya pariyattidharā puggalā🔽paṭipattiṃ pūrenti, paṭipattipūrakā adhigamaṃ pūrenti. Iti navacando viya pariyattiyādīsu
analyzed: paṭipattiyā hāyamānāya adhigamaḥ hāyati pariyattiyā pūrayamānāya pariyatti dharā puggalā  paṭipattim pūrenti paṭipatti pūrakāḥ adhigamam pūrenti iti nava candaḥ viya pariyattiya ādīsu
translated: when practice declines, realization declines. When the scriptures are filled up, individuals who are bearers of the scriptures

original: vaḍḍhamānāsu mayhaṃ sāsanaṃ vaḍḍhati yevāti dasseti.🔽Idāni yehi dhammehi saddhammassa antaradhānañceva ṭhiti ca hoti, te dassento pañca
analyzed: vaḍḍhamānāsu mayham sāsanam vaḍḍhati yeva ati dassa iti  idāni yehi dhammehi saddhammassa antaradhānañca iva ṭhiti ca hoti te dassento pañca
translated: fill up the practice, and those who fill up the practice fill up realization. Thus he shows that just as the new moon waxes, so too my Dispensation waxes🔽when the scriptures, etc., wax.

original: khotiādimāha. Tattha okkamanīyāti avakkamanīyā, heṭṭhāgamanīyāti attho. Satthari
analyzed: kho ti ādim āha tattha okkamanīyā ati avakkamanīyā heṭṭhāgamanīyā ati attho satthari
translated: Now, showing those things by which the Dispensation disappears and by which it endures, he said: “There are, bhikkhus, five things that lead to the disappearance of the true Dhamma.🔽What five? Disrespect towards the Teacher, disrespect towards the Dhamma, disrespect towards the Sangha, disrespect towards the training, and the disappearance of the old bhikkhus who embody the Dhamma.”

original: agāravātiādīsu agāravāti gāravarahitā. Appatissāti appatissayā anīcavuttikā. Tattha
analyzed: agāravā atiādīsu agāravā ati gārava rahitā appatissā ati appatissayā anīca vuttikā tattha
translated: Herein, the disappearance of the old bhikkhus who embody the Dhamma means the disappearance of the elder bhikkhus who have entered upon the way.

original: yo cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ ārohanto chattaṃ dhāreti, upāhanaṃ dhāreti, aññato oloketvā kathaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ cetiyaṅgaṇam ārohanto chattam dhāreti upāhanam dhāreti aññatas oloketvā katham
translated: If, when going up to the shrine terrace, he carries his sunshade and sandals, looks around, and goes talking,

original: kathento gacchati, ayaṃ satthari agāravo nāma.🔽Yo dhammassavanassa kāle saṅghuṭṭhe daharasāmaṇerehi parivārito nisīdati, aññāni
analyzed: kathentaḥ gacchati ayam satthari agāravaḥ nāma  yaḥ dhammassavanassa kāle saṅghuṭṭhe dahara sāmaṇerehi parivāritaḥ nisīdati aññāni
translated: this is lack of respect for the Teacher.

original: vā navakammādīni karoti, dhammassavanagge nisinno niddāyati, vikkhitto vā aññaṃ kathento

analyzed: nisīdati ayam dhamme agāravaḥ nāma
translated: this is lack of respect for the Dhamma.

original: Yo therupaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā, avanditvā nisīdati, hatthapallatthikaṃ dussapallatthikaṃ

original: ayaṃ saṅghe agāravo nāma.
analyzed: ayam saṅghe agāravaḥ nāma
translated: this is lack of respect for the Sangha.

original: Tisso pana sikkhā apūrentova sikkhāya agāravo nāma hoti. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo anibbattento
analyzed: tissaḥ pana sikkhāḥ a pūrentaḥ iva sikkhāya agāravaḥ nāma hoti aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ a nibbattento

original: adhigaccheyya, svāssa samucchedamagamā sabbaso samucchinno vinaṭṭho. Paṭhamādīni.
analyzed: adhigaccheyya sabbaso samucchinnaḥ vinaṭṭhaḥ paṭhama ādīni
translated: But because of his interruption of the state of blamelessness, he was completely interrupted and destroyed. The first, etc.

original: 5. Acirapakkantasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: acirapakkanta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Fifth Portion for Repeating.

original: 184. Pañcame parābhavāyāti avaḍḍhiyā vināsāya. Assatarīti vaḷavāya kucchismiṃ gadrabhassa
analyzed: pañcame parābhavāya ati avaḍḍhiyā vināsāya assatarīti vaḷavāya kucchismim gadrabhassa
translated: . In the fifth , for his downfall : for his non-increase, for his destruction. A mule : a mare-colt born in a mare.

original: jātā. Attavadhāya gabbhaṃ gaṇhātīti taṃ assena saddhiṃ sampayojenti, sā gabbhaṃ gaṇhitvā🔽kāle sampatte vijāyituṃ na sakkoti, pādehi bhūmiyaṃ paharantī tiṭṭhati, athassā cattāro
analyzed: jātā atta vadhāya gabbham gaṇhāti iti tam assena saddhim sampayojenti sā gabbham gaṇhitvā  kāle sampatte vijāyitum na sakkoti pādehi bhūmiyam paharantī tiṭṭhati athassā cattāro
translated: She conceives for her own destruction : they mate her with a horse. She conceives.

original: pāde catūsu khāṇukesu bandhitvā kucchiṃ phāletvā potaṃ nīharanti, sā tattheva marati.
analyzed: pāde catūsu khāṇukesu bandhitvā kucchim phāletvā potam nīharanti sā tattha iva marati
translated: When the time comes she cannot give birth. She stands kicking her feet on the ground. Then they bind her four feet to four stakes and split open her belly and take out the foal. She dies there and then.

original: Tenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Pañcarathasatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tena itam vuttam pañcamam
translated: That is why it is said. The fifth.🔽. The explanation of the Sixth Portion for Repeating.

original: 185. Chaṭṭhe bhattābhihāroti abhiharitabbaṃ bhattaṃ. Tassa pana pamāṇaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe bhatta abhihāraḥ ti abhiharitabbam bhattam tassa pana pamāṇam dassetuṃ
translated: . In the sixth , food-offering : food to be offered. But in order to show the measure of it,

original: pañca ca thālipākasatānīti vuttaṃ. Tattha eko thālipāko dasannaṃ purisānaṃ bhattaṃ
analyzed: pañca ca thālipāka satāni iti vuttam tattha ekaḥ thālipāko dasannam purisānam bhattam
translated: and five hundred hot meals. Herein, one hot meal takes ten men to eat.

original: gaṇhāti. Nāsāya pittaṃ bhindeyyunti acchapittaṃ vā macchapittaṃ vāssa nāsapuṭe pakkhipeyyaṃ. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇhāti nāsāya pittam bhindeyyunti accha pittam vā maccha pittam vā assa nāsa puṭe pakkhipeyyam chaṭṭham
translated: He would burst a vein in his nose: he would put raw bile or fish bile into his nostrils. The sixth.

original: 7-13. Mātusuttādivaṇṇanā🔽186-187. Sattame mātupi hetūti “sace musā bhaṇasi, mātaraṃ te vissajjessāma. No ce🔽bhaṇasi, na vissajjessāmā”ti evaṃ corehi aṭaviyaṃ pucchamāno tassā corahatthagatāya
analyzed: sattame hetu uti sace musā bhaṇasi mātaram te vissajjessāma no ce  bhaṇasi na vissajjessāma ati evam corehi aṭaviyam pucchamāno tassā cora hattha gatāya
translated: The commentary on the Mātusutta, etc.

original: mātuyāpi hetu sampajānamusā na bhāseyyāti attho. Ito paresupi eseva nayoti. Sattamādīni.
analyzed: hetu sampajāna musā na bhāseyya ati attho itas paresu pi esa iva sattama ādīni
translated: In the seventh, even for his mother’s sake: the meaning is that he would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of his mother who had fallen into the hands of robbers, if he were asked by robbers in the forest thus: “If you tell a lie, we shall release your mother. If you do not, we shall not.” The same method applies to the rest beginning with the seventh.

original: Lābhasakkārasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the Sagāthāvagga is finished.

original: 7. Rāhulasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: rāhula saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Rāhula

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggo
analyzed: paṭhama vaggo
translated: The First Chapter

original: 1-8. Cakkhusuttādivaṇṇanā🔽188-195. Rāhulasaṃyuttassa paṭhame ekoti catūsu iriyāpathesu ekavihārī. Vūpakaṭṭhoti
analyzed: 🔽rāhulasaṃyuttassa paṭhame ekaḥ ti catūsu iriyāpathesu ekavihārī vūpakaṭṭho ti
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on the Eye, etc.

original: vivekaṭṭho nissaddo. Appamattoti satiyā avippavasanto. Ātāpīti vīriyasampanno. Pahitatto
analyzed: viveka ṭṭhaḥ nissaddaḥ appamattaḥ ti satiyā a vippavasantaḥ ātāpī iti vīriya sampanno pahitatto
translated: The meaning of seclusion is the meaning of “without sound.” “He should be ardent”: he should not be devoid of mindfulness. “He should be self-effulgent”: he should be endowed with energy. “He should be resolute”: he should be intent on the attainment of distinction.

original: vihareyyanti visesādhigamatthāya pesitatto hutvā vihareyyaṃ. Aniccanti hutvā abhāvākārena
analyzed: vihareyyanti visesa adhigama atthāya pesitatto hutvā vihareyyam aniccanti hutvā abhāva ākārena
translated: “He should dwell”: he should live. “Impermanent”: in the sense of non-existence.

original: aniccaṃ. Atha vā uppādavayavantatāya tāvakālikatāya vipariṇāmakoṭiyā niccapaṭikkhepatoti
analyzed: aniccam atha vā uppāda vayava antatāya tāvakālika tāya vipariṇāma koṭiyā nicca paṭikkhepato ti
translated: Or else, it is impermanent in the sense of arising and vanishing, in the sense of being momentary, and in the sense of being subject to change.

original: imehipi kāraṇehi aniccaṃ. Dukkhanti catūhi kāraṇehi dukkhaṃ dukkhamanaṭṭhena dukkhavatthukaṭṭhena
analyzed: imehi pi kāraṇehi aniccam dukkhanti catūhi kāraṇehi dukkham dukkha manaṭṭhena dukkha vatthukaṭṭhena
translated: It is impermanent for these reasons. “Suffering”: it is suffering in four senses: in the sense of being subject to suffering, in the sense of being the basis of suffering,

original: satatasampīḷanaṭṭhena sukhapaṭikkhepenāti. Kallanti yuttaṃ. Etaṃ mamāti taṇhāgāho.
analyzed: satata sampīḷana ṭṭhena sukha paṭikkhepena ati kallanti yuttam etam mama ati taṇhā gāhaḥ
translated: in the sense of being oppressed by suffering, and in the sense of being the opposite of happiness. “Empty”: it is suitable. “This is mine”: this is the grasping of craving.

original: Esohamasmīti mānagāho. Eso me attāti diṭṭhigāho. Taṇhāgāho cettha aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritavasena,
analyzed: esaḥ aham asmi iti māna gāho esaḥ me attā ati diṭṭhi gāho taṇhā gāho ca ittha aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicarita vasena
translated: “This I am”: this is the grasping of conceit. “This is my self”: this is the grasping of views. Herein, the grasping of craving should be understood as the eighty-nine types of craving;

original: mānagāho navavidhamānavasena, diṭṭhigāho dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhivasena veditabbo. Nibbindaṃ
analyzed: māna gāhaḥ navavidha māna vasena diṭṭhi gāhaḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi vasena veditabbaḥ nibbindam
translated: the grasping of conceit as the nine types of conceit; and the grasping of views as the sixty-two views. “He should be dispassionate”

original: virajjatīti ettha virāgavasena cattāro maggā kathitā, virāgā vimuccatīti ettha vimuttivasena
analyzed: virajjati iti ettha virāga vasena cattāro maggā kathitāḥ virāgā vimuccati iti ettha vimutti vasena
translated: “He becomes dispassionate” : the four paths are stated here by way of dispassion. “He is liberated” : the four fruits are stated here by way of liberation.

original: cattāri sāmaññaphalāni.
analyzed: cattāri sāmañña phalāni
translated: “He becomes dispassionate” : the four paths are stated here by way of dispassion. “He is liberated” : the four fruits of asceticism are stated here by way of liberation.

original: Ettha ca pañcasu dvāresu pasādāva gahitā, manoti iminā tebhūmakaṃ sammasanacāracittaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca pañcasu dvāresu iminā tebhūmakam sammasana cāra cittam
translated: And here the five doors are stated by way of confidence. “Mind” : by this the applied-thought consciousness of the three planes is stated.

original: Dutiye pañcasu dvāresu ārammaṇameva. Tatiye pañcasu dvāresu pasādavatthukacittameva,
analyzed: dutiye pañcasu dvāresu ārammaṇam eva tatiye pañcasu dvāresu pasāda vatthuka cittam eva
translated: In the second, the five doors are stated by way of object. In the third, the five doors are stated by way of the consciousness that has confidence as its object.

original: manoviññāṇena tebhūmakaṃ sammasanacāracittaṃ gahitaṃ. Evaṃ sabbattha nayo netabbo.
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇena tebhūmakam sammasana cāra cittam gahitam evam sabbattha nayaḥ netabbo
translated: By the mind-consciousness the applied-thought consciousness of the three planes is stated. Thus the method should be understood in all cases.

original: Chaṭṭhe tebhūmakadhammā. Aṭṭhame pana taṇhāti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ dvāre javanappattāva
analyzed: chaṭṭhe tebhūmaka dhammāḥ aṭṭhame pana taṇhāti tasmim tasmim dvāre javana ppattā ava
translated: In the sixth, the dhammas of the three planes are stated. But in the eighth, craving is stated only in the case of the javanas that occur in the respective doors.

original: labbhati. Paṭhamādīni.
analyzed: paṭhama ādīni
translated: The first, etc.

original: 9. Dhātusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhātu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Explanation of the “Elements” Discourse

original: 196. Navame viññāṇadhātuvasena nāmaṃ, sesāhi rūpanti nāmarūpaṃ kathitaṃ. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: navame viññāṇa dhātu vasena nāmam sesāhi nāma rūpam kathitam navamam
translated: In the ninth, by way of the consciousness element, name is stated; by way of the rest, form. Thus name-and-form is stated. The ninth.

original: 10. Khandhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: khandha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Explanation of the “Aggregates” Discourse

original: 197. Dasame rūpakkhandho kāmāvacaro, sesā cattāro sabbasaṅgāhikaparicchedena catubhūmakā. Idha pana tebhūmakāti gahetabbā. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: dasame rūpa khandho kāmāvacaro sesā cattāro sabba saṅgāhika paricchedena catu bhūmakāḥ idha pana te bhūmakā ati gahetabbāḥ dasamam
translated: In the tenth, the material form aggregate is of the sense sphere; the remaining four are of four planes, according to the method of the “all-inclusive” definition . But here they should be taken as of three planes. The tenth.

original: Paṭhamo vaggo.
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ vaggo
translated: The first chapter.

original: 2. Dutiyavaggo
analyzed: dutiya vaggo
translated: The second chapter

original: 1-10. Cakkhusuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the eye sutta, etc.

analyzed: dutiye dasa paṭhama ādīni
translated: In the second, the ten are obvious in meaning. The first, etc.

original: 11. Anusayasuttavaṇṇanā🔽200. Ekādasame imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāyeti attano saviññāṇakakāyaṃ dasseti, bahiddhā🔽cāti parassa saviññāṇakaṃ vā aviññāṇakaṃ vā. Purimena vā attano ca parassa ca viññāṇameva🔽dasseti, pacchimena bahiddhā anindriyabaddharūpaṃ. Ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayāti🔽ahaṃkāradiṭṭhi ca mamaṃkārataṇhā ca mānānusayā ca. Na hontīti ete kilesā kathaṃ jānantassa
analyzed: anusaya sutta vaṇṇanā  ekādasame imasmin ca saviññāṇake kāye iti attanaḥ saviññāṇaka kāyam dasseti bahiddhā  ca ati parassa sa viññāṇakam vā aviññāṇakam vā purimena vā attanaḥ ca parassa ca viññāṇam eva  dassa iti pacchimena bahiddhā an indriya baddha rūpam  ahaṃkāra diṭṭhi ca mamaṃkāra taṇhā ca māna anusayā ca na honti iti ete kilesā katham jānantassa
translated: The exposition of the cankers sutta

original: etesu vatthūsu na hontīti pucchati. Sammappaññāya passatīti saha vipassanāya maggapaññāya
analyzed: etesu vatthūsu na honti iti pucchati sammappaññāya passati iti saha vipassanāya magga paññāya
translated: In the eleventh, in the phrase “in this cognizance-accompanied body” he shows his own cognizance-accompanied body. In the phrase “ externally” he shows another’s cognizance-accompanied body or an unconscious body. Or alternatively, in the first phrase he shows cognizance itself in himself and in another, and in the second phrase he shows the external materiality not bound up with faculties. In the phrase “ the cankers of self-illusion, of possession-illusion, and of conceit-illusion” he shows the three cankers. In the phrase “ are not” he asks how he who knows thus can have in these instances the defilements. In the phrase “ sees with right understanding” he shows the path understanding together with insight.

original: suṭṭhu passati. Ekādasamaṃ.🔽12. Apagatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: suṭṭhu passati ekādasamam  apagata sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: he sees it well. The eleventh.🔽. The explanation of the Dvādasama Sutta is finished.

original: 201. Dvādasame ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagatanti ahaṃkārato ca mamaṃkārato ca mānato🔽ca apagataṃ. Vidhā samatikkantanti mānakoṭṭhāse suṭṭhu atikkantaṃ. Santaṃ suvimuttanti
analyzed: dvādasame ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra māna ahaṃkārataḥ ca mamaṃkārataḥ ca mānataḥ  ca apagatam vidhā samatikkantanti māna koṭṭhāse suṭṭhu atikkantam santam su vimuttanti
translated: . In the twelfth, devoid of conceit, pride, and arrogance: devoid of conceit, pride, and arrogance.🔽Having transcended the plane: having well transcended the plane of conceit.

original: kilesavūpasamena santaṃ, kileseheva suṭṭhu vimuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānamevāti. Dvādasamaṃ.
analyzed: kilesa vūpasamena santam kilesehi iva suṭṭhu vimuttam sesam uttānam eva ati dvādasamam
translated: Tranquil, well liberated: tranquil through the stilling of defilements, well liberated by means of the defilements themselves. The rest is self-evident. The twelfth.

original: Dutiyo vaggo.
analyzed: dutiyaḥ vaggo
translated: The second sub-chapter is finished.

original: Dvīsupi asekkhabhūmi kathitā. Paṭhamo panettha āyācantassa desito, dutiyo anāyācantassa. Sakalepi pana rāhulasaṃyutte therassa vimuttiparipācanīyadhammāva kathitāti.
analyzed: dvīsu pi asekkha bhūmi kathitā paṭhamaḥ pana ittha āyācantassa desitaḥ dutiyaḥ an āyācantassa sakale pi pana rāhulasaṃyutte therassa kathitā ati
translated: In both the plane of the adept is spoken of. But the first was taught to one who asked, the second to one who did not ask. And in the entire Rāhula Samyutta the Dhamma that brings about the maturity of the Elder’s liberation is taught.

original: Rāhulasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rāhula saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Rāhula Samyutta is finished.

original: 8. Lakkhaṇasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇa saṃyuttam
translated: . The Connected Discourses on Characteristics

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggo🔽1. Aṭṭhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama vaggo  aṭṭhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The first sub-chapter🔽. The Skeleton Sutta

original: 202. Lakkhaṇasaṃyutte yvāyaṃ āyasmā ca lakkhaṇoti lakkhaṇatthero vutto, esa jaṭilasahassabbhantare
analyzed: lakkhaṇa saṃyutte yvā ayam ca lakkhaṇo ti lakkhaṇa theraḥ vuttaḥ esa jaṭila sahassa bbhantare
translated: . In the Connected Discourses on Characteristics, the venerable Lakkhaṇa is the Elder Lakkhaṇa. He was one of a thousand matted-hair ascetics.

original: ehibhikkhūpasampadāya upasampanno ādittapariyāyāvasāne arahattaṃ patto eko mahāsāvakoti🔽veditabbo. Yasmā panesa lakkhaṇasampannena sabbākāraparipūrena brahmasamena attabhāvena
analyzed: ehi bhikkhu upasampadāya upasampannaḥ āditta pariyāya avasāne arahattam patto ekaḥ mahāsāvako ti  veditabbaḥ yasmā pana esa lakkhaṇa sampannena sabba ākāra paripūrena brahma samena atta bhāvena
translated: and he became the first chief disciple, having been ordained by the Elder Saṅgāmaji with the words “Come, bhikkhu.”

original: samannāgato, tasmā “lakkhaṇo”ti saṅkhaṃ gato. Mahāmoggallāno pana pabbajitadivasato
analyzed: samannāgato tasmā lakkhaṇo ti saṅkham gataḥ mahāmoggallāno pana pabbajita divasato
translated: But he is called “Lakkhaṇa” because he was endowed with a personality that was complete in all its characteristics and was like Brahmā himself.

original: sattame divase arahattaṃ patto dutiyo aggasāvako.🔽Sitaṃ pātvākāsīti mandahasitaṃ pātuakāsi, pakāsayi dassesīti vuttaṃ hoti. Kiṃ pana
analyzed: sattame divase arahattam pattaḥ dutiyaḥ aggasāvako  sitam pātu akāsi iti manda hasitam pātu akāsi pakāsayi dassesi iti vuttam hoti kim pana
translated: The Elder Mahā Moggallāna became the second chief disciple on the seventh day after he had gone forth.

original: disvā thero sitaṃ pātvākāsīti? Upari pāḷiyaṃ āgataṃ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ ekaṃ petaloke🔽nibbattaṃ sattaṃ disvā. Tañca kho dibbena cakkhunā, na pasādacakkhunā. Pasādacakkhussa
analyzed: disvā theraḥ sitam upari pāḷiyam āgatam aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam ekam peta loke  nibbattam sattam disvā tat ca kho dibbena cakkhunā na pasāda cakkhunā pasāda cakkhussa
translated: “He smiled a gentle smile”: he smiled a gentle smile, that is, he manifested a gentle smile, he showed a gentle smile. But what did the Elder see that he smiled a gentle smile? He saw a certain being that had been reborn in the realm of hungry shades, a skeleton with the flesh partly restored.

original: hi ete attabhāvā na āpāthaṃ āgacchanti. Evarūpaṃ pana attabhāvaṃ disvā kāruññe kattabbe
analyzed: hi ete atta bhāvāḥ na āpātham āgacchanti evarūpam pana atta bhāvam disvā kāruññe kattabbe
translated: And he saw it with the divine eye, not with the eye of the flesh. For such a personality does not come within the range of the eye of the flesh. But when he saw such a personality, he saw that compassion should be exercised towards it.

original: kasmā sitaṃ pātvākāsīti? Attano ca buddhañāṇassa ca sampattiṃ samanussaraṇato. Tañhi
analyzed: kasmai sitam pātvā akāsi iti attanaḥ ca buddha ñāṇassa ca sampattim samanussaraṇato tat hi
translated: Why did he smile? Because he was recollecting his own and the Blessed One’s knowledge.

original: disvā thero “adiṭṭhasaccena nāma puggalena paṭilabhitabbā evarūpā attabhāvā mutto
analyzed: disvā theraḥ adiṭṭhasaccena nāma puggalena paṭilabhitabbāḥ evarūpāḥ attabhāvāḥ muttaḥ
translated: For when he saw that, he thought: “Such a person as I, who has not seen the truths, am free from such a state of being.

original: ahaṃ, lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me”ti attano ca sampattiṃ anussaritvā – “aho
analyzed: aham lābhāḥ vata me su laddham vata me iti attano ca sampattim anussaritvā aho
translated: I am fortunate, very fortunate.” Thus he recollected his own good fortune.

original: buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇasampatti, ‘yo kammavipāko, bhikkhave, acinteyyo na cintetabbo’ti
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavataḥ ñāṇa sampatti yaḥ kamma vipākaḥ bhikkhave a cinteyyaḥ na cintetabbaḥ ti
translated: And he thought: “How great is the Blessed One’s knowledge! He has taught that the result of kamma is inconceivable.

original: desesi, paccakkhaṃ vata katvā buddhā desenti, suppaṭividdhā buddhānaṃ dhammadhātū”ti
analyzed: desesi paccakkham vata katvā buddhāḥ desenti suppaṭividdhā buddhānam dhammadhātū ti
translated: The Buddhas teach after seeing for themselves. The dispensation of the Buddhas is well penetrated.”

original: evaṃ buddhañāṇasampattiñca anussaritvā sitaṃ pātvākāsīti.🔽Atha lakkhaṇatthero kasmā na addasa, kimassa dibbacakkhu natthīti? No natthi, mahāmoggallāno
analyzed: evam buddha ñāṇa sampattim ca anussaritvā sitam pātvā akāsi iti  atha lakkhaṇatthero kasmā na addasa kim assa dibba cakkhu natthi iti no natthi mahāmoggallāno
translated: Thus he recollected the Blessed One’s knowledge. That is why he smiled.

original: pana āvajjento addasa, itaro pana anāvajjanena na addasa. Yasmā pana khīṇāsavā nāma
analyzed: pana āvajjentaḥ addasa itaraḥ pana anāvajjanena na addasa yasmai pana khīṇāsavā nāma
translated: Why did the Elder Lakkhaṇa not see? Was his divine eye not developed? It was developed, but he did not advert his mind. The Elder Mahā Moggallāna saw by adverting his mind. The other did not see because he did not advert his mind. But those whose cankers are destroyed do not advert their minds to see whether or not others have fulfilled their duties.

original: na akāraṇā sitaṃ karonti, tasmā taṃ lakkhaṇatthero pucchi ko nu kho, āvuso moggallāna,
analyzed: na akāraṇā sitam karonti tasmā tam lakkhaṇa thero pucchi kaḥ nu kho āvuso moggallāna
translated: They do not do so without reason. That is why the Elder Lakkhaṇa asked him, “What is the reason, friend Moggallāna, what is the cause, for the manifestation of this smile? ”

original: hetu, ko paccayo sitassa pātukammāyāti? Thero pana yasmā yehi ayaṃ upapatti sāmaṃ🔽adiṭṭhā, te dussaddhāpayā honti, tasmā bhagavantaṃ sakkhiṃ katvā byākātukāmatāya
analyzed: hetu ko paccayaḥ sitassa pātukammāya ati theraḥ pana yasmā yehi ayam upapatti sāmam  a diṭṭhā te dussaddha apayāḥ honti tasmai bhagavantam sakkhim katvā byākātu kāma tāya
translated: But since the elder had not seen this occurrence himself,🔽he was not confident in explaining it, so he said, “It is not the time, friend, to explain this matter. The Blessed One, friend, is our teacher, and he is the one who should explain this matter. ”

original: akālo kho, āvusotiādimāha. Tato bhagavato santike puṭṭho idhāhaṃ, āvusotiādinā nayena byākāsi.
analyzed: akālaḥ kho āvuso tiādim āha tatas bhagavato santike puṭṭhaḥ idha aham āvuso ti ādinā nayena byākāsi
translated: Then, when asked by the Blessed One in the Blessed One’s presence, he explained it in the way beginning, “Here, venerable sir, I saw a certain person” .

original: Tattha aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikanti setaṃ nimmaṃsalohitaṃ aṭṭhisaṅghātaṃ. Gijjhāpi kākāpi🔽kulalāpīti etepi yakkhagijjhā ceva yakkhakākā ca yakkhakulalā ca paccetabbā. Pākatikānaṃ🔽pana gijjhādīnaṃ āpāthampi etaṃ rūpaṃ nāgacchati. Anupatitvā anupatitvāti anubandhitvā
analyzed: tattha aṭṭhika saṅkhalikanti setam nimmaṃsa lohitam aṭṭhi saṅghātam gijjhā api kākā api  kulalā api iti ete pi yakkhagijjhā ca iva yakkhakākā ca yakkhakulalā ca paccetabbā pākatikānam  pana gijjha ādīnam etam rūpam na āgacchati anupatitvā anupatitvā ati anubandhitvā
translated: Herein, a skeleton with flesh and blood is a collection of bones covered with flesh and blood. Vultures, crows, and hawks🔽are to be understood as both spirit-vultures, etc., and ordinary vultures, etc. But this appearance does not come within the range of ordinary vultures, etc.,

original: anubandhitvā. Vitudentīti asidhārūpamehi tikhiṇehi lohatuṇḍakehi vijjhitvā vijjhitvā
analyzed: anubandhitvā vitudenti iti tikhiṇehi loha tuṇḍakehi vijjhitvā vijjhitvā
translated: who are not spirits. Having approached, having approached: having followed, having followed. They tear it: they pierce it with sharp iron beaks like razor blades.

original: ito cito ca caranti gacchanti. Sā sudaṃ aṭṭassaraṃ karotīti ettha sudanti nipāto,🔽sā aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikā aṭṭassaraṃ āturassaraṃ karotīti attho. Akusalavipākānubhavanatthaṃ
analyzed: itas citas ca caranti gacchanti sā sudam aṭṭassaram karoti iti ettha nipāto  sā aṭṭhika saṅkhalikā aṭṭassaram āturassaram karoti iti atthaḥ akusala vipāka anubhavana attham
translated: The expression sudam is a particle.🔽The meaning is that the skeleton makes a sound of distress, a sound of pain.

original: kira yojanappamāṇāpi tādisā attabhāvā nibbattanti, pasādussadā ca honti pakkagaṇḍasadisā.
analyzed: kira yojana ppamāṇā api tādisāḥ atta bhāvāḥ nibbattanti pasādussadāḥ ca honti pakka gaṇḍa sadisā
translated: It seems that such a body, a league in size, is produced for the purpose of experiencing the results of unwholesome kamma, and it is soft and tender like a wound.

original: Tasmā sā aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikā balavavedanāturā tādisaṃ saddamakāsīti.
analyzed: tasmai sā aṭṭhika saṅkhalikā balava vedanā āturā tādisam saddam akāsi iti
translated: Therefore, the skeleton made such a sound, being afflicted with intense pain.

original: Evañca pana vatvā puna āyasmā mahāmoggallāno “vaṭṭagāmisattā nāma evarūpā attabhāvā🔽na muccantī”ti sattesu kāruññaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ dhammasaṃvegaṃ dassento tassa mayhaṃ,
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā punar āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ vaṭṭagāmisattā nāma evarūpā atta bhāvā  na muccanti iti sattesu kāruññam paṭicca uppannam dhamma saṃvegam dassento tassa mayham
translated: After saying this, the Venerable Mahā Moggallāna, out of compassion for beings, said: “Beings who go round the cycle of rebirths do not escape such a state of existence.”🔽Then, in order to show the spiritual anxiety that arose in him, he said: “Friends, this occurred to me: ‘How wonderful is the Dhamma!”

original: āvuso, etadahosi acchariyaṃ vata bhotiādimāha. Tato bhagavā therassa ānubhāvaṃ pakāsento
analyzed: āvuso etat ahosi acchariyam vata bho ti ādim āha tatas bhagavā therassa ānubhāvam pakāsentaḥ
translated: Then, in order to reveal the Elder’s power, the Exalted One said: “Monks, my disciples live having become eye-witnesses to the Dhamma.”

original: cakkhubhūtā vata, bhikkhave, sāvakā viharantītiādimāha. Tattha cakkhu bhūtaṃ jātaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu bhūtāḥ vata bhikkhave sāvakāḥ viharanti iti ādim āha tattha cakkhu bhūtam jātam
translated: Here, the word cakkhu means “become” .

original: uppannaṃ etesanti cakkhubhūtā, bhūtacakkhukā uppannacakkhukā cakkhuṃ uppādetvā viharantīti
analyzed: uppannam etesanti cakkhu bhūtāḥ bhūta cakkhukā uppanna cakkhukā cakkhum uppādetvā viharanti iti
translated: “They have arisen in them” : they are eye-beings, element-eye-beings, arisen-eye-beings, eye-beings who have arisen and live.

original: attho. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Yatra hi nāmāti ettha yatrāti kāraṇavacanaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ dutiya pade pi esā iva nayaḥ yatra hi nāma ati ettha yatra ati kāraṇa vacanam tatra ayam
translated: This is the meaning. In the second phrase, too, the same method of explanation applies.🔽“Yatra hi nāma” : here, “yatra” is a causal expression.

original: atthayojanā – yasmā nāma sāvakopi evarūpaṃ ñassati vā dakkhati vā sakkhiṃ vā karissati,
analyzed: attha yojanā yasmai nāma sāvakaḥ api evarūpam ñassati vā dakkhati vā sakkhim vā karissati
translated: This is the construction of the meaning: “Since even a disciple will know, see, and realize such a thing,

original: tasmā avocumha – “cakkhubhūtā vata, bhikkhave, sāvakā viharanti, ñāṇabhūtā vata,
analyzed: tasmai avocumha cakkhu bhūtāḥ vata bhikkhave sāvakāḥ viharanti ñāṇa bhūtāḥ vata
translated: therefore we say: ‘Monks, disciples live as eye-beings, knowledge-beings.’“

original: bhikkhave, sāvakā viharantī”ti. Pubbeva me so, bhikkhave, satto diṭṭhoti bodhimaṇḍe
analyzed: bhikkhave sāvakāḥ viharanti iti pubbā iva me saḥ bhikkhave satto diṭṭho ti bodhimaṇḍe
translated: “I have seen that being before” : on the Bodhi throne,

original: sabbaññutaññāṇapaṭivedhena appamāṇesu cakkavāḷesu appamāṇe sattanikāye bhavagatiyoniṭhitinivāse
analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇa paṭivedhena appamāṇesu cakkavāḷesu appamāṇe satta nikāye bhava gati yoni ṭhiti nivāse
translated: by the penetration of omniscient knowledge, in the countless world systems, in the countless mass of beings, in the destinies, wombs, destinations, and abodes,

original: ca paccakkhaṃ karontena mayā pubbeva so satto diṭṭhoti vadati.
analyzed: ca paccakkham karontena mayā pubbā iva so satto diṭṭhaḥ iti vadati
translated: I have seen that being before.

original: Goghātakoti gāvo vadhitvā aṭṭhito maṃsaṃ mocetvā vikkiṇitvā jīvikaṃ kappanakasatto.
analyzed: go ghātakaḥ iti gāvaḥ vadhitvā aṭṭhitaḥ maṃsam mocetvā vikkiṇitvā jīvikam kappanaka satto
translated: “A cow-killer” : a being who makes a living by killing cows, cutting up the meat, and selling it.

original: Tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesenāti tassa nānācetanāhi āyūhitassa aparāpariyakammassa.🔽Tatra hi yāya cetanāya narake paṭisandhi janitā, tassā vipāke parikkhīṇe avasesakammaṃ
analyzed: tassa iva kammassa vipāka avasesena ati tassa nānā cetanāhi āyūhitassa aparāpariya kammassa  tatra hi yāya cetanāya narake paṭisandhi janitā tassā vipāke parikkhīṇe avasesa kammaṃ
translated: By the remainder of the result of that same kamma: by the remainder of the result of that kamma which was accumulated by means of various kinds of consciousness.

original: vā kammanimittaṃ vā ārammaṇaṃ katvā puna petādīsu paṭisandhi nibbattati, tasmā sā
analyzed: vā kamma nimittam vā ārammaṇam katvā puna peta ādīsu paṭisandhi nibbattati tasmā sā
translated: For when the result of that consciousness by means of which rebirth-linking was effected in hell has been exhausted, then rebirth-linking occurs again in the ghost realm, etc., with a remainder of kamma or with an object as the sign of kamma as its object.

original: paṭisandhi kammasabhāgatāya ārammaṇasabhāgatāya vā “tasseva kammassa vipākāvaseso”ti
analyzed: paṭisandhi kamma sabhā gatāya ārammaṇa sabhā gatāya vā tassa iva kammassa vipāka avasesaḥ ti
translated: Therefore that rebirth-linking is called “the remainder of the result of that same kamma” either because it is of the same kind as the kamma or because it has the same object.

original: vuccati. Ayañca satto evaṃ uppanno. Tenāha – “tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesenā”ti.
analyzed: vuccati ayam ca satto evam uppanno tena āha tassa iva kammassa vipāka avasesena ati
translated: And this being was reborn in this way. Hence it was said above, “By the remainder of the result of that same kamma” .

original: Tassa kira narakā cavanakāle nimmaṃsakatānaṃ gunnaṃ aṭṭhirāsiyeva nimittaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: tassa kira narakā cavana kāle nimmaṃsaka tānam gunnam aṭṭhira asiyā iva nimittam ahosi
translated: It seems that at the time of his passing away from hell the sign of the bones of the fleshless skeletons was the object for him.

original: So paṭicchannampi taṃ kammaṃ viññūnaṃ pākaṭaṃ viya karonto aṭṭhisaṅkhalikapeto jāto. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: so paṭicchannam pi tam kammam viññūnam pākaṭam viya karontaḥ aṭṭhi saṅkhalika petaḥ jātaḥ paṭhamam
translated: And he was born with a skeleton of bones, making his past kamma manifest as if it were external and visible to the wise. First.

original: 2. Pesisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pesi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Sutta on the Skeleton

original: 203. Maṃsapesivatthusmiṃ goghātakoti gomaṃsapesiyo katvā sukkhāpetvā vallūravikkayena🔽anekāni vassāni jīvikaṃ kappesi, tenassa narakā cavanakāle maṃsapesiyeva nimittaṃ
analyzed: maṃsapesi vatthusmim go ghātako ti go maṃsa pesiyaḥ katvā sukkhāpetvā vallūra vikkayena  anekāni vassāni jīvikam kappesi tena assa narakā cavana kāle maṃsapesiyā iva nimittam
translated: In the case of the story of the man who lived on human flesh, the man who killed cows dried human flesh in the sun, and for many years made a living by selling it.🔽When he came out of hell, the first thing he saw was human flesh.

original: ahosi. So maṃsapesipeto jāto. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: ahosi saḥ maṃsa pesi petaḥ jātaḥ dutiyam
translated: In the case of the man who had been a butcher of cattle, he had dried the flesh of cattle after cutting it up into pieces, and had made a living for many years by selling it as a luxury. So when he came out of hell, the sign that appeared to him was a piece of meat. He was reborn as a ghost in a piece of meat. Second.

original: 3. Piṇḍasuttavaṇṇanā🔽204. Maṃsapiṇḍavatthusmiṃ sākuṇikoti sakuṇe gahetvā vikkiṇanakāle nippakkhacamme🔽maṃsapiṇḍamatte katvā vikkiṇanto jīvikaṃ kappesi, tenassa narakā cavanakāle maṃsapiṇḍova
analyzed: piṇḍa sutta vaṇṇanā  maṃsa piṇḍa vatthusmim sākuṇiko ti sakuṇe gahetvā vikkiṇana kāle nippakkha camme  maṃsa piṇḍa matte katvā vikkiṇantaḥ jīvikam kappesi tena assa narakā cavana kāle maṃsa piṇḍā uva
translated: . The commentary on the Piṇḍa Sutta

original: nimittaṃ ahosi. So maṃsapiṇḍapeto jāto. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: nimittam saḥ maṃsa piṇḍa petaḥ jātaḥ tatiyam
translated: In the case of the man who had been a poultry-keeper, he had made a living by catching birds and selling them. When they were dead, he had skinned them and sold the flesh as a luxury. So when he came out of hell, the sign that appeared to him was a piece of meat. He was reborn as a ghost in a piece of meat. Third.

original: 4. Nicchavisuttavaṇṇanā🔽205. Nicchavivatthusmiṃ tassa orabbhikassa eḷake vadhitvā vadhitvā niccamme katvā
analyzed: nicchavi sutta vaṇṇanā  nicchavi vatthusmim tassa orabbhikassa eḷake vadhitvā vadhitvā niccamme katvā
translated: . The commentary on the Nicchavi Sutta

original: kappitajīvikassa purimanayeneva niccammaṃ eḷakasarīraṃ nimittaṃ ahosi. So nicchavipeto jāto. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: kappita jīvikassa purima nayena iva niccammam eḷaka sarīram nimittam ahosi saḥ niccha vipetaḥ jāto catuttham
translated: In the case of the man who had been a sheep-dealer, he had killed sheep and skinned them, and had made a living by selling the skins. So the sign that appeared to him was the skin of a sheep. He was reborn as a ghost in a sheep-skin. Fourth.

original: 5. Asilomasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: asiloma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the Asilomasutta

original: 206. Asilomavatthusmiṃ so sūkariko dīgharattaṃ nivāpapuṭṭhe sūkare asinā vadhitvā
analyzed: asi loma vatthusmim saḥ sūkarikaḥ dīgharattam nivāpa puṭṭhe sūkare asinā vadhitvā
translated: In the Asiloma story, the swineherd killed pigs for a long time, stabbing them with a knife,

original: vadhitvā dīgharattaṃ jīvikaṃ kappesi, tassa ukkhittāsikabhāvova nimittaṃ ahosi. Tasmā
analyzed: vadhitvā dīgharattam jīvikam kappesi tassa ukkhitta asika bhāvaḥ uva nimittam ahosi tasmā
translated: and for a long time he made his living in this way. The fact that he had raised a knife was the sign.

original: asilomapeto jāto. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: asi loma petaḥ jātaḥ pañcamam
translated: Therefore he was reborn with bristles of iron. Fifth.

original: 6. Sattisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: satti sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Satti sutta.

original: 207. Sattilomavatthusmiṃ so māgaviko ekaṃ migañca sattiñca gahetvā vanaṃ gantvā tassa
analyzed: sattiloma vatthusmim saḥ māgavikaḥ ekam migañca sattiñca gahetvā vanam gantvā tassa
translated: In the Sattiloma story, the hunter went to the forest with a deer and a spear, and

original: migassa samīpaṃ āgatāgate mige sattiyā vijjhitvā māresi, tassa sattiyā vijjhanakabhāvoyeva
analyzed: migassa samīpam āgata āgate mige sattiyā vijjhitvā māresi tassa sattiyā
translated: whenever a deer came near, he killed it by spearing it. The fact that he had been spearing deer

original: nimittaṃ ahosi. Tasmā sattilomapeto jāto. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: nimittam ahosi tasmai satti loma petaḥ jātaḥ chaṭṭham
translated: was the sign. Therefore he was reborn with bristles of spears. Sixth.

original: 7. Usulomasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: usuloma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Usulomasutta.

original: 208. Usulomavatthusmiṃ kāraṇikoti rājāparādhike anekāhi kāraṇāhi pīḷetvā avasāne
analyzed: usuloma vatthusmim rājā aparādhike anekāhi kāraṇāhi pīḍetvā avasāne
translated: In the Usulomas story, the executioner was a man who had been punished in many ways for offending the king and was finally

original: kaṇḍena vijjhitvā māraṇakapuriso. So kira “amukasmiṃ padese viddho maratī”ti ñatvāva
analyzed: kaṇḍena vijjhitvā māraṇaka purisaḥ saḥ kira amukasmin padese viddhaḥ marati iti ñatvā ava
translated: killed by being pierced with a stake. It is said that he knew “In such and such a place, one is pierced and dies,” and

original: vijjhati. Tassevaṃ jīvikaṃ kappetvā narake uppannassa tato pakkāvasesena idhūpapattikāle
analyzed: vijjhati tassa ivam jīvikam kappetvā narake uppannassa tatas pakka avasesena idha upapatti kāle
translated: and he was pricked. When he was reborn in hell as a result of that action, the remainder of the action that had reached maturity at the time of his rebirth here was the cause

original: usunā vijjhanabhāvoyeva nimittaṃ ahosi. Tasmā usulomapeto jāto. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: usunā nimittam ahosi tasmai usu loma petaḥ jāto sattamam
translated: why the pricking with the spear was the sign for him. That is why he was born with hair like needles. The seventh sub-story of the Assalāyana Family,

original: 8. Sūcilomasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sūciloma Sutta,

original: 209. Sūcilomavatthusmiṃ sūtoti assadamako. Godamakotipi vadantiyeva. Tassa patodasūciyā vijjhanabhāvoyeva nimittaṃ ahosi. Tasmā sūcilomapeto jāto. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: sūci loma vatthusmim sūto ti assadamakaḥ godamakaḥ tipi vadantiyā iva tassa patoda sūciyā nimittam ahosi tasmā sūci loma petaḥ jātaḥ aṭṭhamam
translated: In the Sūciloma story, the “horse tamer” was a horse trainer. They also call him a “cow tamer.” The pricking with the needle was the sign for him. That is why he was born with hair like needles. The eighth sub-story of the Assalāyana Family,

original: 9. Dutiyasūcilomasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya sūciloma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Second Sūciloma Sutta,

original: 210. Dutiye sūcilomavatthusmiṃ sūcakoti pesuññakārako. So kira manusse aññamaññañca
analyzed: dutiye sūci loma vatthusmim sūcako ti pesuñña kārako so kira manusse aññam aññam ca
translated: In the second Sūciloma story, the “slanderer” was a slanderer. He is said to have

original: bhindi, rājakule ca “imassa imaṃ nāma atthi, iminā idaṃ nāma kata”nti sūcetvā sūcetvā🔽anayabyasanaṃ pāpesi. Tasmā yathā tena sūcetvā manussā bhinnā, tathā sūcīhi bhedanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: rāja kule ca imassa imam nāma atthi iminā idam nāma sūcetvā sūcetvā  anaya byasanam tasmai yathā tena sūcetvā manussāḥ bhinnāḥ tathā sūcīhi bhedana dukkham
translated: broken up people and families, and he is said to have slandered people in the royal family, saying, “So-and-so has such-and-such, and he has done such-and-such.”

original: paccanubhotuṃ kammameva nimittaṃ katvā sūcilomapeto jāto. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: paccanubhotum kammam eva nimittam katvā sūci loma petaḥ jātaḥ navamam
translated: He brought about their ruin. That is why he was born with hair like needles, so that he might experience the pain of being pricked with needles, just as he had pricked people with his words and brought about their ruin. The ninth sub-story of the Assalāyana Family,

original: 10. Kumbhaṇḍasuttavaṇṇanā🔽211. Aṇḍabhārivatthusmiṃ gāmakūṭakoti vinicchayāmacco. Tassa kammasabhāgatāya kumbhamattā
analyzed: kumbhaṇḍa sutta vaṇṇanā  aṇḍa bhāri vatthusmim gāmakūṭakaḥ ti tassa kamma sabhā gatāya kumbha mattā
translated: 10. The commentary on the Kumbhandasutta🔽In the story of the Egg-bearer, the “village-corner” was a judge. Because of the similarity of his action, his eggs were the size of large jars.

original: mahāghaṭappamāṇā aṇḍā ahesuṃ. So hi yasmā raho paṭicchanne ṭhāne lañjaṃ gahetvā kūṭavinicchayena
analyzed: mahā ghaṭa ppamāṇāḥ aṇḍāḥ ahesum saḥ hi yasmai raho paṭicchanne ṭhāne lañjam gahetvā kūṭa vinicchayena
translated: For he, having taken a bribe in secret, in a concealed place, and having made his fault obvious by a false judgment,

original: pākaṭaṃ dosaṃ karonto sāmike assāmike akāsi, tasmāssa rahassaṃ aṅgaṃ pākaṭaṃ nibbattaṃ.🔽Yasmā daṇḍaṃ paṭṭhapento paresaṃ asayhaṃ bhāraṃ āropesi, tasmāssa rahassaṃ aṅgaṃ🔽asayhabhāro hutvā nibbattaṃ. Yasmā yasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhitena samena bhavitabbaṃ, tasmiṃ
analyzed: pākaṭam dosam karontaḥ sāmike assāmike akāsi tasmā assa rahassam aṅgam pākaṭam nibbattam  yasmai daṇḍam paṭṭhapentaḥ paresam asayham bhāram āropesi tasmai assa rahassam aṅgam  asayhabhāraḥ hutvā nibbattam yasmai yasmin ṭhāne ṭhitena samena bhavitabbam tasmin
translated: made the owner not the owner.
