original: viya bhijji. Atha naṃ dantehi vijjhitvā ukkhipitvā thale chaḍḍetvā tuṭṭharavaṃ ravi.
analyzed: viya bhijji atha nam dantehi vijjhitvā ukkhipitvā thale chaḍḍetvā tuṭṭha ravam ravi
translated: like a clay pot. Then he seized her with his tusks, lifted her up, and threw her on the bank, and he trumpeted with joy.

original: Atha naṃ hatthī ito cito ca āgantvā maddiṃsu. Tassa eko aḷo paṭikkamitvā pati, taṃ
analyzed: atha nam hatthī itas citas ca āgantvā maddiṃsu tassa ekaḥ aḷaḥ paṭikkamitvā pati tam
translated: Then the elephants came from all directions and trampled her. One of her legs was broken and fell off.

original: sakko devarājā gahetvā gato.
analyzed: sakkaḥ devarājā gahetvā gataḥ
translated: Sakka, king of the gods, took it and went away with it.

original: Itaro pana aḷo vātātapena sukkhitvā pakkalākhārasavaṇṇo ahosi, so deve vuṭṭhe udakoghena
analyzed: itaraḥ pana aḷaḥ vāta ātapena sukkhitvā pakkala ākhāra sa vaṇṇaḥ ahosi saḥ deve vuṭṭhe udaka oghena
translated: The other leg dried up in the wind and sun and became as hard as a piece of wood. When the rains came,

original: vuyhanto dasabhātikānaṃ rājūnaṃ uparisote jālaṃ pasārāpetvā gaṅgāya kīḷantānaṃ āgantvā
analyzed: vuyhantaḥ dasabhātikānam rājūnam upari sote jālam gaṅgāya kīḍantānam āgantvā
translated: the water carried it down to the ten brothers, who were playing in the river. It came to the net

original: jāle laggi. Te kīḷāpariyosāne jālamhi ukkhipiyamāne taṃ disvā pucchiṃsu “kiṃ eta”nti?
analyzed: jāle te kīḷā pariyosāne jālamhi ukkhipiyamāne tam disvā pucchiṃsu kim etat ti
translated: which they had spread out, and got caught in it. When they had finished playing, they lifted up the net, and seeing it, asked, “What is this?”

original: “Kuḷīraaḷo sāmī”ti. “Na sakkā esa ābharaṇatthāya upanetuṃ, pariyonandhāpetvā bheriṃ🔽karissāmā”ti? Pariyonandhāpetvā pahariṃsu. Saddo dvādasayojanaṃ nagaraṃ avatthari.🔽Tato āhaṃsu – “na sakkā idaṃ divase divase vādetuṃ, chaṇadivasatthāya maṅgalabherī
analyzed: sāmi iti na sakkā esaḥ ābharaṇa atthāya upanetum pariyonandhāpetvā bherim  karissāma ati pariyonandhāpetvā pahariṃsu saddaḥ dvādasa yojanam nagaram avatthari  tatas āhaṃsu na sakkā idam divase divase vādetum chaṇa divasa tthāya maṅgala bherī
translated: “The king is the owner of the elephant.” “It is not possible to use it as an ornament. Let us cover it with a cloth and beat it.” They covered it with a cloth and beat it. The sound spread over the twelve-league city.

original: hotū”ti maṅgalabheriṃ akaṃsu. Tasmiṃ vādite mahājano anhāyitvā apiḷandhitvā hatthiyānādīni
analyzed: hotu uti maṅgala bherim tasmin vādite mahā janaḥ anhāyitvā a piḷandhitvā hatthi yāna ādīni
translated: Then they said, “It is not possible to beat it every day. Let it be a festive drum for the six-day festival.” They made it a festive drum. When it was beaten, the great multitude, having been excited and delighted, mounted their elephants, chariots, etc.,

original: āruyha sīghaṃ sannipatanti. Iti mahājanaṃ pakkositvā viya ānetīti ānako tvevassa nāmaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: āruyha sīgham sannipatanti iti mahā janam pakkositvā viya āneti iti ānako tvevassa nāmam ahosi
translated: and assembled quickly. Thus it brought the great multitude, as if having summoned it. Therefore its name was Ānaka.

original: Aññaṃ āṇiṃ odahiṃsūti aññaṃ suvaṇṇarajatādimayaṃ āṇiṃ ghaṭayiṃsu. Āṇisaṅghāṭova avasissīti🔽suvaṇṇādimayānaṃ āṇīnaṃ saṅghāṭamattameva avasesaṃ ahosi. Athassa dvādasayojanappamāṇo
analyzed: aññam āṇim odahiṃsu iti aññam suvaṇṇa rajata ādi mayam āṇim ghaṭayiṃsu āṇi saṅghāṭaḥ uva avasissi iti  suvaṇṇa ādi mayānam āṇīnam saṅghāṭa mattam eva avasesam ahosi athassa dvādasa yojana ppamāṇaḥ
translated: They made another Āṇi. They made another Āṇi of gold, silver, etc. Only the Āṇi-saṅghāṭa remained.

original: saddo antosālāyampi dukkhena suyyittha.
analyzed: saddaḥ antosālāyam pi dukkhena
translated: The sound of twelve leagues spread. Even in the inner apartments, it was heard with difficulty.

original: Gambhīrāti pāḷivasena gambhīrā sallasuttasadisā. Gambhīratthāti atthavasena gambhīrā🔽mahāvedallasuttasadisā. Lokuttarāti lokuttaraatthadīpakā. Suññatappaṭisaṃyuttāti🔽sattasuññatadhammamattameva pakāsakā saṃkhittasaṃyuttasadisā. Uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbanti🔽uggahetabbe ca pariyāpuṇitabbe ca. Kavikatāti kavīhi katā. Itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: gambhīrā ati pāḷi vasena gambhīrā salla sutta sadisā gambhīratthā ati attha vasena gambhīrā  mahāvedalla sutta sadisā lokuttarā ati lokuttara attha dīpakā suññata paṭisaṃyuttā ti  satta suññata dhamma mattam eva pakāsakā saṃkhitta saṃyutta sadisā uggahetabbam pariyāpuṇitabbanti  uggahetabbe ca pariyāpuṇitabbe ca kavi katā ati kavīhi katā itaram tassa iva vevacanam
translated: Deep: deep in the text, like the Sallasutta. Deep in the meaning: deep in the meaning, like the Mahavedallasutta. Supramundane: illuminating a supramundane meaning. Connected with emptiness: illuminating only the seven kinds of emptiness, like the Saṃkhittasamyutta. To be memorized and learned: to be memorized and learned. Poetry: composed by poets. The other is a synonym for that.

original: Cittakkharāti vicitraakkharā. Itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Bāhirakāti sāsanato bahibhūtā.🔽Sāvakabhāsitāti tesaṃ tesaṃ sāvakehi bhāsitā. Sussūsissantīti akkharacittatāya ceva🔽savanasampattiyā ca attamanā hutvā sāmaṇeradaharabhikkhumātugāmamahāgahapatikādayo
analyzed: cittakkharā ati vicitra akkharā itaram tassa iva vevacanam bāhirakā ati sāsanataḥ bahibhūtā  sāvaka bhāsitā ati tesam tesam sāvakehi bhāsitā sussūsissanti iti akkhara citta tāya ca iva  savana sampattiyā ca attamanāḥ hutvā sāmaṇera dahara bhikkhu mātu gāma mahā gahapatika ādayaḥ
translated: Deep: deep in the text, like the Sallasutta. Deep in the meaning: deep in the meaning, like the Mahavedallasutta. Supramundane: illuminating supramundane meanings. Connected with emptiness: illuminating the mere emptiness of beings and of ideas, like the Saṅkhepa-samyuttasutta. To be learned and mastered: to be learned and mastered. Poetry: composed by poets. The other is a synonym for that. Metre: having various syllables. The other is a synonym for that. External: outside the Dispensation. Spoken by disciples: spoken by this or that disciple. They will listen: being pleased by the memorizing and by the excellence of the hearing, the novices, the youths, the bhikkhus, the women, the great householders, etc.,

original: “esa dhammakathiko”ti sannipatitvā sotukāmā bhavissanti. Tasmāti yasmā tathāgatabhāsitā
analyzed: esa dhamma kathikaḥ ti sannipatitvā sotu kāmāḥ bhavissanti tasmā iti yasmā tathāgata bhāsitā
translated: will assemble, thinking “This is a preacher of the Dhamma,” and will wish to hear. Therefore: because of that.

original: suttantā anuggayhamānā antaradhāyanti, tasmā. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: su tantāḥ anuggayhamānāḥ antaradhāyanti tasmai sattamam
translated: and the Suttas disappeared.🔽The seventh chapter.

original: 8. Kaliṅgarasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kaliṅgara sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Kaliṅgarasutta is finished.

original: 230. Aṭṭhame kaliṅgarūpadhānāti kaliṅgaraghaṭikaṃ sīsūpadhānañceva pādūpadhānañca
analyzed: aṭṭhame kaliṅgara upadhānā ati kaliṅgara ghaṭikam sīsu upadhānam ca iva pādu upadhānam ca
translated: In the eighth sutta, “with a wooden bar as a pillow” means with a wooden bar as a pillow for the head and as a pillow for the feet.

original: katvā. Appamattāti sippuggahaṇe appamattā. Ātāpinoti uṭṭhānavīriyātāpena yuttā. Upāsanasminti🔽sippānaṃ abhiyoge ācariyānañca payirupāsane. Te kira tadā pātova uṭṭhāya sippasālaṃ🔽gacchanti, tattha sippaṃ uggahetvā sajjhāyādīhi abhiyogaṃ katvā mukhaṃ dhovitvā yāgupānāya
analyzed: katvā appamattā ati sippu gahaṇe appamattāḥ ātāpinaḥ ti uṭṭhāna vīriya ātāpena yuttāḥ upāsanasmin ti  sippānam abhiyoge te kira tadā uṭṭhāya sippa sālam  gacchanti tattha sippam uggahetvā sajjhāya ādīhi abhiyogam katvā mukham dhovitvā yāgu pānāya
translated: “Vigilant” means diligent in learning a craft. “Zealous” means devoted to the zeal of energy. “In practice” means🔽in the practice of crafts and in the service of teachers. They got up early in the morning and went to the craft school,🔽where they learned a craft and practiced it by recitation, etc. Then they washed their faces and went to drink rice porridge.

original: gacchanti. Yāguṃ pivitvā puna sippasālaṃ gantvā sippaṃ gaṇhitvā sajjhāyaṃ karontā
analyzed: gacchanti yāgum pivitvā punar sippa sālam gantvā sippam gaṇhitvā sajjhāyam karontā
translated: After drinking the porridge, they went back to the craft school and learned and practiced the craft.

original: pātarāsāya gacchanti. Katapātarāsā samānā “mā pamādena ciraṃ niddokkamanaṃ ahosī”ti
analyzed: pāta rāsāya gacchanti kata pāta rāsā samānā mā pamādena ciram niddokkamanam ahosi iti
translated: Then they went to the breakfast meal. After the breakfast meal, they thought, “Let us not sleep long and fall into negligence,”

original: khadiraghaṭikāsu sīse ca pāde ca upadahitvā thokaṃ nipajjitvā puna sippasālaṃ gantvā
analyzed: khadira ghaṭikāsu sīse ca pāde ca upadahitvā thokam nipajjitvā punar sippa sālam gantvā
translated: and they put wooden bars under their necks and under their feet. After sleeping a little, they went back to the craft school and

original: sippaṃ gahetvā sajjhāyanti. Sāyaṃ sajjhāyaṃ karontā ca gehaṃ gantvā bhuttasāyamāsā
analyzed: sippam gahetvā sajjhāyanti sāyam sajjhāyam karontā ca geham gantvā bhutta sāya māsā
translated: and they learned the texts by heart. After learning the texts by heart, they went home and ate their evening meal.

original: paṭhamayāmaṃ sajjhāyaṃ katvā sayanakāle tatheva kaliṅgaraṃ upadhānaṃ katvā sayanti.
analyzed: paṭhama yāmam sajjhāyam katvā sayana kāle tathā iva kaliṅgaram upadhānam katvā sayanti
translated: After the meal they recited the texts by heart. At bedtime they made a pillow of the same kind of bundle and went to sleep.

original: Evaṃ te akkhaṇavedhino vālavedhino ca ahesuṃ. Idaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: evam te akkhaṇa vedhinaḥ vāla vedhinaḥ ca ahesuṃ idam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: Thus they were not able to pierce the moment and pierce the hair. This is the meaning of the text.

original: Otāranti vivaraṃ. Ārammaṇanti paccayaṃ. Padhānasminti padhānabhūmiyaṃ vīriyaṃ kurumānā.
analyzed: otāranti vivaram ārammaṇanti paccayam padhānasmin ti padhāna bhūmiyam vīriyam kurumānā
translated: ‘They made a hole’: they made a gap. ‘An object’: a condition. ‘In the exercise’: while they were making effort in the exercise, i.e. in the stage of exercise.

original: Paṭhamabodhiyaṃ kira bhikkhū bhattakiccaṃ katvāva kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karonti. Tesaṃ🔽manasikarontānaṃyeva sūriyo atthaṃ gacchati. Te nhāyitvā puna caṅkamaṃ otaritvā paṭhamayāmaṃ🔽caṅkamanti. Tato “mā ciraṃ niddāyimhā”ti sarīradarathavinodanatthaṃ nipajjantā kaṭṭhakhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: paṭhama bodhiyam kira bhikkhū bhatta kiccam katvā ava kammaṭṭhānam manasi karonti tesam  manasi karontā anaṃyā iva sūriyaḥ attham gacchati te nhāyitvā puna caṅkamam otaritvā paṭhama yāmam  caṅkamanti tatas mā ciram sarīrada ratha vinodana attham nipajjantā kaṭṭhakhaṇḍam
translated: It seems that at the time of the first enlightenment the bhikkhus gave their attention to the meditation subject after doing the duties of the day.🔽While they were giving their attention to it, the sun set. They bathed and then went on to the walk and walked up and down in the first watch of the night.

original: upadahitvā nipajjanti, te puna pacchimayāme vuṭṭhāya caṅkamaṃ otaranti. Te sandhāya
analyzed: upadahitvā nipajjanti te puna pacchima yāme vuṭṭhāya caṅkamam otaranti te sandhāya
translated: Then, thinking ‘We shall not fall asleep too soon’, they lay down to ease their limbs and made a pillow of a piece of wood and lay down. They got up again in the last watch of the night and went on to the walk.

original: idaṃ vuttaṃ. Ayampi dīpo tiṇṇaṃ rājūnaṃ kāle ekaghaṇḍinigghoso ekapadhānabhūmi ahosi.
analyzed: idam vuttam ayam pi dīpo tiṇṇam rājūnam kāle eka ghaṇḍi nigghosaḥ eka padhāna bhūmi ahosi
translated: This is what was said. This island was also a single drum-beat, a single shout, a single jurisdiction in the time of the three kings.

original: Nānāmukhe pahaṭaghaṇḍi pilicchikoḷiyaṃ osarati, kalyāṇiyaṃ pahaṭaghaṇḍi nāgadīpe
analyzed: nānāmukhe pahaṭaghaṇḍi pilicchikoḷiyam osarati kalyāṇiyam pahaṭaghaṇḍi nāgadīpe
translated: When the drum was beaten at Nāṇāmukha, it was heard in Pilicchikoḷiya; when the drum was beaten at Kalyāṇī, it was heard in Nāgadīpa.

original: osarati. “Ayaṃ bhikkhu puthujjano, ayaṃ puthujjano”ti aṅguliṃ pasāretvā dassetabbo
analyzed: osarati ayam bhikkhu puthujjanaḥ ayam puthujjanaḥ ti aṅgulim pasāretvā dassetabbo
translated: “This bhikkhu is an ordinary man, this is an ordinary man,” they would point out with their fingers.

original: ahosi. Ekadivasaṃ sabbe arahantova ahesuṃ. Tasmāti yasmā kaliṅgarūpadhānānaṃ māro
analyzed: eka divasam sabbe arahanto va ahesum tasmā ati yasmā kaliṅga rūpa dhānānam māro
translated: One day they were all arahats. Therefore, since Māra did not get an opportunity to tempt the meditators on the subject of the skeleton,

original: ārammaṇaṃ na labhati, tasmā. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇam na labhati tasmai aṭṭhamam
translated: therefore. The eighth.

original: 9. Nāgasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nāga sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Ninth Story

original: 231. Navame ativelanti atikkantavelaṃ kālaṃ atikkantappamāṇaṃ kālaṃ. Kimaṅgaṃ panāhanti
analyzed: navame ativelanti atikkanta velam kālam atikkanta ppamāṇam kālam kim aṅgam pana ahanti
translated: In the ninth story, “for too long a time” means for too long a time, for too long a period of time. “What then shall I do?”

original: ahaṃ pana kiṃkāraṇā na upasaṅkamissāmi? Bhisamuḷālanti bhisañceva muḷālañca. Abbuhetvāti
analyzed: aham pana kiṃkāraṇā na upasaṅkamissāmi bhisa muḷālanti bhisam ca iva muḷālam ca abbuhetvā ati
translated: means “What reason shall I have for not going to him?” “Bhisamuḷāla” means both bhisas and muḷālas. “Having dug up”

original: uddharitvā. Bhiṅkacchāpāti hatthipotakā. Te kira abhiṇhaṃ bhiṅkārasaddaṃ karonti,
analyzed: uddharitvā hatthi potakā te kira abhiṇham bhiṅkāra saddam karonti
translated: means having taken out. “Bhiṅkacchāpas” means baby elephants. They make the sound “bhiṅkāra” frequently,🔽it seems.

original: tasmā bhiṅkacchāpāti vuccanti. Pasannākāraṃ karontīti pasannehi kattabbākāraṃ karonti,
analyzed: tasmā bhiṅkacchāpā ati vuccanti pasanna ākāram karonti iti pasannehi kattabba ākāram karonti
translated: so they are called “rattlesnake-makers.” They do the deed of the faithful: they do the deed that should be done by the faithful.

original: cattāro paccaye denti. Dhammaṃ bhāsantīti ekaṃ dve jātakāni vā suttante vā uggaṇhitvā
analyzed: cattāro paccaye denti dhammam bhāsanti iti ekam dve jātakāni vā suttante vā uggaṇhitvā
translated: They give the four requisites. They preach the Dhamma: they learn one or two Jātakas or Suttas and

original: asambhinnena sarena dhammaṃ desenti. Pasannākāraṃ karontīti tesaṃ tāya desanāya pasannā
analyzed: asambhinnena sarena dhammam desenti pasanna ākāram karonti iti tesam tāya desanāya pasannā
translated: they preach the Dhamma with an unbroken voice. They do the deed of the faithful: the faithful

original: gihī paccaye denti. Neva vaṇṇāya hoti na balāyāti neva guṇavaṇṇāya, na ñāṇabalāya
analyzed: gihī paccaye denti na iva vaṇṇāya hoti na balāya ati na iva guṇa vaṇṇāya na ñāṇa balāya
translated: give them requisites because of that preaching. It is not for the sake of beauty or strength: it is not for the sake of the beauty of virtue or the strength of knowledge.

original: hoti, guṇavaṇṇe pana parihāyante sarīravaṇṇopi sarīrabalampi parihāyati, tasmā sarīrassa
analyzed: hoti guṇa vaṇṇe pana parihāyante sarīra vaṇṇaḥ api sarīra balam api parihāyati tasmā sarīrassa
translated: But when the beauty of virtue declines, the beauty of the body and the strength of the body decline too, so it is not for the sake of the beauty

original: neva vaṇṇāya na balāya hoti. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: na iva vaṇṇāya na balāya hoti navamam
translated: or the strength of the body. The ninth.

original: 10. Biḷārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: biḷāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the tenth sutta

original: 232. Dasame sandhisamalasaṃkaṭīreti ettha sandhīti bhinnagharānaṃ sandhi, samaloti
analyzed: dasame ettha sandhi iti
translated: . In the tenth sutta, “junction, rubbish-heap, and crowded place” : the junction of broken houses is the junction;

original: gāmato gūthanikkhamanamaggo, saṃkaṭīranti saṅkāraṭṭhānaṃ. Mudumūsinti mudukaṃ mūsikaṃ.
analyzed: gāmataḥ gūtha nikkhamana maggo saṃkaṭīranti saṅkāra ṭṭhānam mudumūsinti mudukam mūsikam
translated: the road for taking out rubbish from the village is the rubbish-heap; the place for disposing of rubbish is the crowded place. A soft mouse: a soft mouse.

original: Vuṭṭhānaṃ paññāyatīti desanā paññāyati. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam paññāyati iti desanā paññāyati dasamam
translated: “The arising of it is evident” means the teaching is evident. The tenth.

original: 11. Siṅgālasuttavaṇṇanā🔽233. Ekādasame yena yena icchatīti so jarasiṅgālo icchiticchitaṭṭhāne iriyāpathakappanena
analyzed: siṅgāla sutta vaṇṇanā  ekādasame yena yena icchati iti saḥ jarasiṅgālaḥ icchiticchita ṭṭhāne iriyāpatha kappanena
translated: The commentary on the Siṅgālaka Sutta is finished.

original: sītavātūpavāyanena ca antarantarā cittassādampi labhatīti dasseti. Sakyaputtiyapaṭiññoti🔽idaṃ devadattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. So hi ettakampi cittassādaṃ anāgate attabhāve na
analyzed: ca antar antarā labhati iti dasseti sakya puttiya paṭiññā ti  idam devadattam sandhāya vuttam saḥ hi ettakam pi anāgate attabhāve na
translated: In the eleventh, “by whatever way he wishes” shows that the old jackal gets satisfaction of mind by lying down in the place he wants to lie down in and by cooling himself with the breeze.

original: labhissatīti. Ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: labhissati iti ekādasamam
translated: “He claims to be a Sakyan” is said with reference to Devadatta. For he will not get even this much satisfaction of mind in a future existence. The eleventh.

original: 12. Dutiyasiṅgālasuttavaṇṇanā🔽234. Dvādasame kataññutāti katajānanaṃ. Kataveditāti katavisesajānanaṃ. Tatridaṃ
analyzed: dutiya siṅgāla sutta vaṇṇanā  dvādasame kata ññu tā ati kata jānanam kata veditā ati kata visesa jānanam tatra idam
translated: The commentary on the second Siṅgālaka Sutta is finished.

original: jarasiṅgālassa kataññutāya vatthu – satta kira bhātaro khettaṃ kasanti. Tesaṃ sabbakaniṭṭho
analyzed: jarasiṅgālassa kataññu tāya vatthu satta kira bhātaraḥ khettam kasanti tesam
translated: In the twelfth, “grateful” means knowing what is done. “Obliging” means knowing the difference between what is done and what is not done. Here is the story of the old jackal’s gratitude. Seven brothers were ploughing a field. The youngest of them

original: Assasīti bhavissasi.🔽Aññātuñchenāti abhilakkhitesu issarajanagehesu kaṭukabhaṇḍasambhāraṃ sugandhaṃ bhojanaṃ🔽pariyesantassa uñcho ñātuñcho nāma. Gharapaṭipāṭiyā pana dvāre ṭhitena laddhaṃ missakabhojanaṃ🔽aññātuñcho nāma. Ayamidha adhippeto. Kāmesu anapekkhinanti vatthukāmakilesakāmesu
analyzed: assasi iti bhavissasi  aññātuñchena ati abhilakkhitesu issara jana gehesu kaṭuka bhaṇḍa sambhāram su gandham bhojanam  pariyesantassa uñchaḥ ñātuñchaḥ nāma ghara paṭipāṭiyā pana dvāre ṭhitena laddham missaka bhojanam  aññātuñchaḥ nāma ayam idha adhippeto kāmesu an apekkhinanti vatthu kāma kilesa kāmesu
translated: “You will be breathing in”: you will be breathing in and out.🔽“A living by gleaning”: a living by gleaning is a living by seeking for fragrant food and a store of bitter goods in the houses of the great men who are marked out. But a living by gleaning is also a living by seeking for mixed food

original: nirapekkhaṃ. Āraññiko cātiādi sabbaṃ samādānavaseneva vuttaṃ. Kāmesu ca anapekkhoti

This is what is intended here. “Without cleaving to sensual desires”: without cleaving to sensual desires as objects and sensual desires as defilements. “A forest-dweller” and so on are said according to the undertaking. “Without cleaving to sensual desires”

original: idaṃ suttaṃ devaloke accharāyo dassetvā āgatena aparabhāge kathitaṃ. Imassa kathitadivasato
analyzed: idam suttam deva loke accharāyaḥ dassetvā āgatena apara bhāge kathitam imassa kathita divasataḥ
translated: This sutta was told by the Elder Mahā Kassapa after he had returned from showing the celestial nymphs to the newly-arrived deities. It was told in the latter part of the day on which he had returned.

original: paṭṭhāya thero ghaṭento vāyamanto katipāheneva arahatte patiṭṭhāya sadevake loke🔽aggadakkhiṇeyyo jāto. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya theraḥ ghaṭentaḥ vā āyamantaḥ kati pāhena iva arahatte patiṭṭhāya sa devake loke  aggadakkhiṇeyyaḥ jātaḥ aṭṭhamam
translated: and after striving and struggling for a few days, he established himself in Arahantship. He became the most worthy of offerings in the world with its deities.🔽The eighth story.

original: 9. Tissasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tissa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the ninth story of the Mahāvagga.

original: 243. Navame dummanoti uppannadomanasso. Kasmā panāyaṃ evaṃ dukkhī dummano jātoti?
analyzed: navame dummano ti uppanna domanasso kasmā pana ayam evam dukkhī dummanaḥ jāto ti
translated: In the ninth story, “troubled” means having arisen sorrow. But why did he become so sorrowful?

original: Khattiyapabbajito hesa, tena naṃ pabbājetvā dupaṭṭasāṭakaṃ nivāsāpetvā varacīvaraṃ
analyzed: khattiya pabbajitaḥ ha isa tena nam pabbājetvā du paṭṭa sāṭakam nivāsāpetvā vara cīvaram
translated: He was a prince who had gone forth, and so they had him go forth, had him put on the two-piece robe, had him put on the best robe,

original: pārupetvā akkhīni añjetvā manosilātelena sīsaṃ makkhesuṃ. So bhikkhūsu rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pārupetvā akkhīni añjetvā manosilā telena sīsam makkhesum saḥ bhikkhūsu ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānam

original: gatesu “bhikkhunā nāma vivittokāse nisīditabba”nti ajānanto bhojanasālaṃ gantvā mahāpīṭhaṃ🔽āruhitvā nisīdi. Disāvacarā āgantukā paṃsukūlikā bhikkhū āgantvā, “imināva nīhārena
analyzed: gatesu bhikkhunā nāma vivitta ukāse nisīditabbanti a jānantaḥ bhojana sālam gantvā mahā pīṭham  āruhitvā nisīdi disāvacarā āgantukā paṃsukūlikā bhikkhū āgantvā iminā āva nīhārena
translated: he, not knowing that a monk should sit in a secluded place, went to the dining hall, climbed onto the high seat,🔽and sat down. Wandering monks who were refuse-rag wearers came and said, “We can’t see the One of Ten Powers with our limbs covered in dust and dirt. Let’s put our bundles down.”

original: rajokiṇṇehi gattehi na sakkā dasabalaṃ passituṃ. Bhaṇḍakaṃ tāva ṭhapessāmā”ti bhojanasālaṃ
analyzed: rajaḥ kiṇṇehi gattehi na sakkā dasabalam passitum bhaṇḍakam tāva ṭhapessāma ati bhojana sālam
translated: They put their bundles down in the dining hall,

original: agamaṃsu. So tesu mahātheresu āgacchantesu niccalo nisīdiyeva. Aññe bhikkhū “pādavattaṃ🔽karoma, tālavaṇṭena bījāmā”ti āpucchanti. Ayaṃ pana nisinnakova “kativassatthā”ti?
analyzed: agamaṃsu so tesu mahā theresu āgacchantesu niccalaḥ nisīdiya iva aññe bhikkhū pādavattaṃ  karoma tālavaṇṭena bījāma ti āpucchanti ayam pana nisinnakaḥ uva kati vassatthā ti
translated: and they came. But he remained silent and sat still. Other monks asked him, “Let us do the duties of seniority.🔽Let us bow down with our head at his foot.” But he remained silent and sat still. Other monks asked him, “How many years have you been a monk?”

original: Pucchitvā, “mayaṃ avassikā. Tumhe pana kativassatthā”ti? Vutte, “mayaṃ ajja pabbajitā”ti
analyzed: pucchitvā mayam avassikā tumhe pana kati vassatthā ati vutte mayam ajja pabbajitā ati
translated: He replied, “I have been a monk for one year.” They asked him, “We are novices. How many years have you been a monk?”

original: āha. Atha naṃ bhikkhū, “āvuso, adhunā chinnacūḷosi, ajjāpi te sīsamūle ūkāgandho🔽vāyatiyeva, tvaṃ nāma ettakesu vuḍḍhataresu vattaṃ āpucchantesu nissaddo niccalo
analyzed: āha atha nam bhikkhū āvuso adhunā chinna cūḷaḥ asi ajja api te sīsa mūle ūkā gandhaḥ  vāyatiyā iva tvam nāma ettakesu vuḍḍhataresu vattam āpucchantesu nissaddaḥ niccalaḥ
translated: He replied, “I was ordained today.” They asked him, “Friend, your hair is just cut. Today the smell of your head is still like that of a bird’s egg.

original: nisinno, apacitimattampi te natthi, kassa sāsane pabbajitosī”ti? Parivāretvā taṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ apacitimattam pi te natthi kassa sāsane pabbajito asi iti parivāretvā tam
translated: You are silent and sit still when other monks who are more senior than you ask you to do the duties of seniority. You have no respect at all. In whose religion did you go forth?”

analyzed: vācāsattīhi paharantā kim tvam iṇaṭṭaḥ vā bhayaṭṭaḥ vā jīvitum a sakkontaḥ pabbajito ti

analyzed: āhaṃsu saḥ ekam pi theram olokesi tena kim mama olokesi mahallaka ati vutte aññam
translated: He looked at one of the senior monks. The senior monk said, “Why do you look at me, you old man?”

original: olokesi, tenapi tatheva vutte athassa “ime maṃ parivāretvā vācāsattīhi vijjhantī”ti🔽khattiyamāno uppajji. Akkhīsu maṇivaṇṇāni assūni sañcariṃsu. Tato ne āha – “kassa
analyzed: olokesi tena api tathā iva vutte atha assa ime mama parivāretvā vācāsattīhi vijjhanti iti  uppajji akkhīsu maṇi vaṇṇāni assūni sañcariṃsu tatas ne āha kassa
translated: He looked at them, and when they spoke to him in the same way, the thought occurred to him, “They are surrounding me and pelting me with words.”🔽The thought of a warrior arose in him. original: santikaṃ āgatatthā”ti. Te “kiṃ pana tvaṃ ‘mayhaṃ santikaṃ āgatā’ti? Amhe maññasi
analyzed: santikam āgatattha ati te kim pana tvam mayham santikam āgatā ati amhe maññasi
translated: “Do you think we have come to your presence? We are the dependents of a householder’s outward form.”

original: gihibyañjanabhaṭṭhakā”ti vatvā, “sadevake loke aggapuggalassa satthu santikaṃ āgatamhā”ti🔽āhaṃsu. So “mayhaṃ bhātu santike āgatā tumhe, yadi evaṃ idāni vo āgatamaggeneva gamanaṃ
analyzed: gihi byañjana bhaṭṭhakā ati vatvā sa devake loke agga puggalassa satthu santikam āgatamha ati  āhaṃsu saḥ mayham bhātu santike āgatā tumhe yadi evam idāni vaḥ āgata maggena iva gamanam
translated: “We have come to the presence of the Teacher, the foremost person in the world with its gods.”🔽“You have come to my brother’s presence. If that is so, now I will make you go by the way you came.”

original: karissāmī”ti kujjhitvā nikkhanto antarāmagge cintesi – “mayi imināva nīhārena gate
analyzed: karissāmi iti kujjhitvā nikkhantaḥ antara āmagge cintesi mayi iminā ava nīhārena gate
translated: Angry, he went out. On the road he thought, “If I go with this burden,

analyzed: satthā ete na nīharāpessati iti dukkhī dummanaḥ assūni pavattayamānaḥ agamāsi iminā
translated: the Teacher will not have them removed.” Miserable and dejected, shedding tears, he went .

original: kāraṇena esa evaṃ jātoti.
analyzed: kāraṇena esaḥ evam jātaḥ iti
translated: This is why he was born in this way.

original: Vācāsannitodakenāti vacanapatodena. Sañjambharimakaṃsūti sañjambharitaṃ nirantaraṃ
analyzed: vācā āsannita udakena ati vacana patodena sañjambharimakaṃsu iti sañjambharitam nirantaram
translated: With the water of verbal abuse: with the whip of words. They filled him with abuse: they filled him with abuse without a break.

original: phuṭaṃ akaṃsu, upari vijjhiṃsūti vuttaṃ hoti. Vattāti pare yadicchakaṃ vadatiyeva.
analyzed: phuṭam upari vijjhiṃsu iti vuttam hoti vattā ati pare yadicchakam
translated: and they pierced him above, is what is meant. “He is a chatterer” means he talks as much as he likes.

original: No ca vacanakkhamoti paresaṃ vacanaṃ khamituṃ na sakkoti. Idāni tāva tvaṃ iminā kopena
analyzed: no ca vacana khamaḥ ti paresam vacanam khamitum na sakkoti idāni tāva tvam iminā kopena
translated: “He is not patient with speech” means he is not able to endure the speech of others. Now, first of all, you were pierced by this anger,

analyzed: iminā vutta vācā sannita udakena viddhaḥ atīte pana raṭṭhataḥ ca pabbājitaḥ ti evam vutte
translated: by this water of the words spoken. But in the past you were banished from the country.” When this was said,

analyzed: katarasmin kāle bhagavā ati bhikkhū bhagavantam yāciṃsu
translated: “In what time was the Fortunate One?” The monks asked the Fortunate One.

original: Satthā āha – atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ bārāṇasirājā rajjaṃ kāresi. Atheko jātimā, eko mātaṅgoti
analyzed: satthā āha atīte bārāṇasiyam bārāṇasi rājā rajjam kāresi atha ekaḥ jātimā ekaḥ mātaṅga iti
translated: The Teacher said: “In the past, in Bārāṇasī, the King of Bārāṇasī was ruling the country. Then two seers, one of high birth, and one a Mātaṅga,

analyzed: dve isayaḥ bārāṇasim agamaṃsu tesu jātimā puretaram gantvā kumbhakāra sālāyam nisīdi

analyzed: mātaṅgo tāpaso pacchā gantvā tattha okāsam yāci kumbhakāro attha ittha paṭhamataram

analyzed: ṭhatvā amhākam pi ācariya eka ratti vāsāya okāsam detha iti āha pavisa bho ti pavisitvā

analyzed: nisinnam bho kim gotto asi iti pucchi caṇḍāla gotto asi iti na sakkā tayā saddhim  eka ṭṭhāne nisīditum ekamantam gacchāti saḥ ca tattha iva tiṇa santhārakam pattharitvā
translated: When the other was seated, he asked him, “Sir, what is your caste?” “I am a member of the Caṇḍāla caste.” “It is not proper for me to sit in the same place with you.

analyzed: nipajji jātimā dvāram nissāya nipajji itaraḥ passā avatthāya nikkhamantaḥ tam urasmiṃ

analyzed: akkami kaḥ esaḥ iti ca vutte aham ācariya ati āha re caṇḍāla kim aññatas maggam
translated: “Who is that?” he asked. “It is I, teacher,” replied the other. “You Caṇḍāla, do you not see the road?

analyzed: na passasi atha me āgantvā akkamasi iti ācariya a disvā me akkanto asi khama mayhanti
translated: Why did you come and step on me?” “Teacher, I did not see you. I stepped on you by mistake. Forgive me.”

analyzed: saḥ mahā purise bahi nikkhante cintesi ayam paccāgacchantaḥ api itas va āgamissati iti
translated: When the Great Man went out, the other thought to himself, “When he returns, he will come by this way.”

analyzed: parivattetvā nipajji mahā purisaḥ api ācariyaḥ itas sīsam katvā nipannaḥ pāda samīpena
translated: So he turned over and lay on his back. The Great Man thought to himself, “My teacher is lying with his head in this direction. I will come back by the side of his feet.”

analyzed: gamissāmi iti pavisantaḥ punar urasmiṃ yeva akkami kaḥ esaḥ iti ca vutte aham ācariyā ati
translated: and as he entered, he trod on his chest again. “Who is that?” said the teacher. “It is I, teacher.”

original: āha. “Paṭhamaṃ tāva te ajānantena kataṃ, idāni maṃ ghaṭentova akāsi, sūriye te uggacchante
analyzed: āha paṭhamam tāva te a jānantena katam idāni mam sūriye te uggacchante

analyzed: sattadhā muddhā phalatu iti mahā purisaḥ kiñci avatvā sūriyam
translated: let your head split into seven pieces.” The Great Man said nothing, but at dawn he seized the sun,

analyzed: na assaḥ uggantum adāsi manussā ca hatthi assa ādayo ca pabujjhiṃsu
translated: and would not let it rise. Men awoke, and elephants and horses.

analyzed: manussāḥ rājakulam gantvā deva sakala nagare appabuddhaḥ nāma natthi na ca aruṇuggam
translated: The men went to the palace and said, “Your majesty, there is not a man in the whole city who is not awake, and yet the dawn

original: paññāyati, kinnu kho eta”nti? Tena hi nagaraṃ parivīmaṃsathāti. Te parivīmaṃsantā🔽kumbhakārasālāyaṃ dve tāpase disvā, “imesaṃ etaṃ kammaṃ bhavissatī”ti gantvā rañño
analyzed: paññāyati kin nu kho etat ti tena hi nagaram parivīmaṃsatha ati te parivīmaṃsantā  kumbhakāra sālāyam dve tāpase disvā imesam etam kammam bhavissati iti gantvā raññaḥ
translated: does not break. What can this mean?” “Then search the city.” They searched the city,🔽and seeing the two ascetics in the potter’s shed, said, “This must be their work.” They went and told the king,

original: ārocesuṃ. Raññā ca “pucchatha ne”ti vuttā āgantvā jātimantaṃ pucchiṃsu – “tumhehi
analyzed: ārocesum raññā ca pucchatha na iti vuttāḥ āgantvā jātimantam pucchiṃsu tumhehi

translated: “I did not do it. This young man, the ascetic with matted locks, is a magician of infinite power. Ask him.”

analyzed: te āgantvā mahā purisam pucchiṃsu tumhehi bhante andhakāram katanti āma ayam
translated: They went and asked the Great Being, “Did you do it, Reverend Sir?” “Yes, I did.”

analyzed: ācariyaḥ mam tasmai mayā katanti te gantvā raññaḥ ārocesum rājā api āgantvā
translated: “How was it done?” “This teacher of mine cursed me, and so I did it.” They went and told the king. The king came and asked the Great Being,

translated: “Did you do it, Reverend Sir?” “Yes, great king.” “Why, Reverend Sir?”

analyzed: atha nam manussāḥ na kim tvam attanaḥ ruciyā khamāpessasi iti vatvā hatthesu ca pādesu

analyzed: thera nāmaka sutta vaṇṇanā  dasame vaṇṇa vādī iti ānisaṃsa vādī yam atītam tam atīte khandha pañcake  chanda rāga pahānena tam pahīnam nāma hoti anāgatam ti anāgatam pi khandha pañcakam  tattha chanda rāga paṭinissaggena paṭinissaṭṭham nāma hoti sabbā abhibhunti sabbā khandha āyatana dhātuyo  ca tayaḥ bhave ca abhibhavitvā ṭhitam sabba vidun ti tam vutta ppakāram sabbam viditam

original: pākaṭaṃ katvā ṭhitaṃ. Sabbesu dhammesūti tesveva dhammesu taṇhādiṭṭhilepehi anupalittaṃ.🔽Sabbañjahanti tadeva sabbaṃ tattha chandarāgappahānena jahitvā ṭhitaṃ. Taṇhakkhaye
analyzed: pākaṭam katvā ṭhitam sabbesu dhammesu iti tesu eva dhammesu taṇhā diṭṭhi lepehi an upalittam 🔽sabbam jahanti tat eva sabbam tattha chanda rāga ppahānena jahitvā ṭhitam taṇhakkhaye
translated: In the tenth sutta, “one who speaks of the advantages” is one who speaks of the benefits. “What is past is abandoned”: by abandoning desire and lust for the past five aggregates, they are called “abandoned.” “What is future”: the future five aggregates are also “given up” by giving up desire and lust for them. “The conqueror of all”: he stands having conquered all the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and the three kinds of becoming. “The all-knower”: he stands having made all that is of the kind described above known and evident. “In all things”: in those same things he stands unattached by craving and views. “The renouncer of all”: having renounced all that by abandoning desire and lust for it, he stands in the destruction of craving.

original: vimuttanti taṇhakkhayasaṅkhāte nibbāne tadārammaṇāya vimuttiyā vimuttaṃ. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: vimuttanti taṇhā khaya saṅkhāte nibbāne tad ārammaṇāya vimuttiyā vimuttam dasamam
translated: Liberated: in Nibbāna, which is called the destruction of craving, and liberated by the liberation that has that as its object. The tenth.

original: 11. Mahākappinasuttavaṇṇanā

analyzed: mahā thero saḥ kira gihi kāle kukkuṭavatī nagare ti yojana satikam rajjam akāsi pacchimabhavikattā  pana tathārūpam sāsanam sotum ohita sotaḥ vicarati atha eka divasam amacca sahassa parivutaḥ

analyzed: uyyāna kīḷikam tadā ca majjhima desataḥ jaṅgha vāṇijā tam nagaram gantvā bhaṇḍam  paṭisāmetvā rājānam passissāma ati paṇṇa ākāra hatthāḥ rājakula dvāram gantvā rājā

original: mahākappino tiyojanasatikaṃ rajjaṃ pahāya amaccasahassaparivāro mama santike pabbajituṃ
analyzed: mahākappinaḥ ti yojana satikam rajjam pahāya amacca sahassa parivāraḥ mama santike pabbajitum
translated: “Mahākappina, having given up his kingdom of three hundred leagues, is coming with a retinue of a thousand ministers to go forth in my presence.”

original: āgacchatī”ti disvā, “mayā tesaṃ paccuggamanaṃ kātuṃ yutta”nti pātova sarīrapaṭijagganaṃ
analyzed: āgacchati iti disvā mayā tesam paccuggamanam kātum yuttam ti pātova sarīra paṭijagganam
translated: Having seen this, (thinking) “It is fitting that I should go forth to meet them,” he, having performed his duties in the morning,

original: katvā, bhikkhusaṅghaparivāro sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā, pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto
analyzed: katvā bhikkhu saṅgha parivāraḥ sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ
translated: having gone for alms in Sāvatthī surrounded by the Community of monks, after returning from his alms round,

original: sayameva pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā, ākāse uppatitvā candabhāgāya nadiyā tīre tesaṃ uttaraṇatitthassa
analyzed: sayam eva patta cīvaram gahetvā ākāse uppatitvā candabhāgāya nadiyā tīre tesam uttaraṇa titthassa
translated: having taken his bowl and robe by himself, having risen up into the air, on the bank of the Candabhāgā River,

original: abhimukhe ṭhāne mahānigrodharukkho atthi, tattha pallaṅkena nisīditvā parimukhaṃ🔽satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā chabbaṇṇabuddharasmiyo vissajjesi. Te tena titthena uttarantā
analyzed: abhimukhe ṭhāne mahānigrodha rukkho atthi tattha pallaṅkena nisīditvā parimukham  satim upaṭṭhapetvā chabbaṇṇa buddha rasmiyaḥ vissajjesi te tena titthena uttarantā
translated: in a place facing the landing place where they were crossing, there was a great banyan tree, having sat down cross-legged there, having established mindfulness in front of him,🔽he sent out six-coloured Buddha-rays. They, crossing over by that landing place,🔽and the six-coloured Buddha-rays running hither and thither, looking around, saw the One of Ten Powers, who was radiant like the full moon,

original: ca chabbaṇṇabuddharasmiyo ito cito ca vidhāvantiyo olokentā dasabalassa puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ
analyzed: ca chabbaṇṇa buddha rasmiyaḥ itas citas ca vidhāvantiyaḥ olokentā dasabalassa
translated: and they were filled with joy.

original: mukhaṃ disvā, “yaṃ satthāraṃ uddissa mayaṃ pabbajitā, addhā so eso”ti dassaneneva
analyzed: mukham disvā yam satthāram uddissa mayam pabbajitāḥ addhā saḥ esaḥ ti dassanena iva
translated: Seeing the Teacher, they said to themselves, “Surely he is the very man for whose sake we have gone forth.”

original: niṭṭhaṃ gantvā diṭṭhaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya onatā vandamānā āgamma satthāraṃ vandiṃsu.
analyzed: niṭṭham gantvā diṭṭha ṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya onatāḥ vandamānāḥ āgamma satthāram vandiṃsu
translated: And immediately they were convinced by the mere sight of him. They bowed low until their foreheads touched the feet of the Teacher, and then they sat down respectfully on one side.

original: Rājā gopphakesu gahetvā satthāraṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi saddhiṃ amaccasahassena.
analyzed: rājā gopphakesu gahetvā satthāram vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi saddhim amacca sahassena
translated: The king seized Gopaka by the heels, bowed low before the Teacher, and sat down respectfully on one side together with a thousand ministers.

original: Satthā tesaṃ dhammaṃ kathesi. Desanāpariyosāne sabbe arahatte patiṭṭhāya satthāraṃ
analyzed: satthā tesam dhammam kathesi desanā pariyosāne sabbe arahatte patiṭṭhāya satthāram
translated: The Teacher preached the Law. At the conclusion of the discourse all were established in Arahatship.

original: pabbajjaṃ yāciṃsu. Satthā “pubbe ime cīvaradānassa dinnattā attano cīvarāni gahetvāva
analyzed: pabbajjam yāciṃsu satthā pubbe ime cīvara dānassa dinna ttā attano cīvarāni gahetvā ava
translated: Then they asked the Teacher to admit them to the Order. The Teacher reflected, “Formerly they gave me a robe, and therefore they have come to me, taking their own robes with them.”

original: āgatā”ti suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ hatthaṃ pasāretvā, “etha bhikkhavo svākkhāto dhammo, caratha🔽brahmacariyaṃ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti āha. Sāva tesaṃ āyasmantānaṃ pabbajjā
analyzed: āgatā iti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam hattham pasāretvā etha bhikkhavaḥ su ākkhātaḥ dhammo caratha  brahmacariyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati āha sā ava tesam āyasmantānam pabbajjā
translated: And therefore he stretched forth his golden arm and said to them, “Come, monks! The Law is well preached. Follow the life of purity,

original: ca upasampadā ca ahosi, vassasaṭṭhikattherā viya satthāraṃ parivārayiṃsu.
analyzed: ca upasampadā ca ahosi vassasaṭṭhika therāḥ viya satthāram parivārayiṃsu
translated: and bring to an end the suffering of existence.” Thereupon they were admitted to the Order and received the full benefits of ordination. They surrounded the Teacher as did the monks of sixty years’ standing.

original: Anojāpi devī rathasahassaparivārā gaṅgātīraṃ patvā rañño atthāya ābhataṃ nāvaṃ vā
analyzed: anojā api devī ratha sahassa parivārā gaṅgā tīram patvā raññaḥ atthāya ābhatam nāvam vā
translated: Queen Anojā, with a retinue of a thousand chariots, went to the bank of the Ganges, and not seeing a boat or raft prepared for the king,

original: uḷumpaṃ vā adisvā attano byattatāya cintesi – “rājā saccakiriyaṃ katvā gato bhavissati,
analyzed: uḷumpam vā a disvā attanaḥ byatta tāya cintesi rājā saccakiriyam katvā gataḥ bhavissati
translated: thought to herself, “The king has gone away, having performed a sacrifice.

original: so pana satthā na kevalaṃ tesaṃyeva atthāya nibbatto, sace so satthā sammāsambuddho,
analyzed: saḥ pana satthā na kevalam tesam yeva atthāya nibbattaḥ sace saḥ satthā sammāsambuddho
translated: But that Teacher was not born for their sake only. If that Teacher is a Buddha,

original: amhākaṃ rathā mā udake nimujjiṃsū”ti udakapiṭṭhe rathe pakkhandāpesi. Rathānaṃ nemivaṭṭimattampi
analyzed: amhākam rathāḥ mā udake nimujjiṃsu iti udaka piṭṭhe rathe pakkhandāpesi rathānam nemi vaṭṭi mattam pi
translated: let not my chariots sink in the water.” And she caused the chariots to be driven out upon the water. Not even the rims of the wheels sank into the water.

original: na temi. Dutiyatatiyanadīpi teneva saccakārena uttaramānāyeva nigrodharukkhamūle
analyzed: na temi dutiya tatiya nadīpi tena iva sacca kārena uttara mānāya iva nigrodha rukkha mūle
translated: And as the second and the third rivers were crossed in the same way by the power of truth, they came to the foot of a banyan tree,

original: satthāraṃ addasa. Satthā “imāsaṃ attano sāmike passantīnaṃ chandarāgo uppajjitvā
analyzed: satthāram addasa satthā imāsam attanaḥ sāmike passantīnam chanda rāgaḥ uppajjitvā
translated: and there they saw the Teacher. The Teacher thought to himself, “If these women, while looking for their lord, should give rise to desire and passion,

original: maggaphalānaṃ antarāyaṃ kareyya, so evaṃ kātuṃ na sakkhissatī”ti yathā aññamaññe
analyzed: magga phalānam antarāyam kareyya saḥ evam kātum na sakkhissati iti yathā aññamaññe
translated: and if this should become an obstacle in the way of their attaining the Fruit of Conversion and the Fruits of the Higher Paths, it would be impossible for them to attain the Paths and the Fruits. Therefore I will so act that they shall not see one another.” And accordingly he so acted that they did not see one another.

original: na passanti, tathā akāsi. Tā sabbāpi titthato uttaritvā dasabalaṃ vanditvā nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: na passanti tathā tā sabbā api titthataḥ uttaritvā dasabalam vanditvā nisīdiṃsu
translated: All of them crossed the river, and after paying obeisance to the Ten Powered One, sat down.

original: Satthā tāsaṃ dhammaṃ kathesi, desanāpariyosāne sabbāpi sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya
analyzed: satthā tāsam dhammam kathesi desanā pariyosāne sabbā api sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya
translated: The Teacher preached the Law to them, and at the conclusion of his discourse all of them were established in the Fruit of Conversion.

original: aññamaññe passiṃsu. Satthā “uppalavaṇṇā āgacchatū”ti cintesi. Therī āgantvā sabbā
analyzed: aññamaññe passiṃsu satthā uppala vaṇṇā āgacchatu iti cintesi therī āgantvā sabbā
translated: They saw one another. The Teacher thought to himself, “Let Uppalavaṇṇā come.” The Elder Nun came, and after she had received the going forth,

original: pabbājetvā ādāya bhikkhunīnaṃ upassayaṃ gatā. Satthā bhikkhusahassaṃ gahetvā ākāsena
analyzed: pabbājetvā ādāya bhikkhunīnam upassayam gatā satthā bhikkhu sahassam gahetvā ākāsena
translated: she took them with her and went to the Convent of the Nuns. The Teacher, taking with him a thousand monks, went through the air🔽and alighted at Jetavana. With reference to this it is said:

original: jetavanaṃ agamāsi. Imaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ – “mahākappinoti evaṃ nāmako abhiññābalappatto
analyzed: jetavanam agamāsi imam sandhāya itam vuttam mahā kappinaḥ ti evam nāmakaḥ abhiññā bala ppatto
translated: “The Elder Nun named Mahākappina, who had attained the Fruit of Conversion,

original: asītimahāsāvakānaṃ abbhantaro mahāthero”ti.🔽Janetasminti janite pajāyāti attho. Ye gottapaṭisārinoti ye “mayaṃ vāseṭṭhā gotamā”ti🔽gottaṃ paṭisaranti paṭijānanti, tesaṃ khattiyo seṭṭhoti attho. Vijjācaraṇasampannoti
analyzed: asīti mahāsāvakānam abbhantaraḥ mahātheraḥ iti  janetasmin ti janite pajāya ati attho ye gotta paṭisārino ti ye mayam vāseṭṭhāḥ gotama ati  gottam paṭisaranti paṭijānanti tesam khattiyo seṭṭhaḥ ti atthaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno ti
translated: who was one of the eighty great disciples, a great Elder.”

original: aṭṭhahi vijjāhi ceva pannarasadhammabhedena caraṇena ca samannāgato. Tapatīti virocati.
analyzed: aṭṭhahi vijjāhi ca iva pannarasa dhamma bhedena caraṇena ca samannāgataḥ tapati iti virocati
translated: “In the world of men” means “in the world of those who are born.” “Those who are attached to their clan” means “those who are attached to their clan, who acknowledge their clan.” The meaning is, “Among them the Khattiya is the best.” “Possessed of knowledge and conduct” means “possessed of the eight kinds of knowledge and of conduct, which is divided into fifteen kinds.” “He shines” means “he is radiant.”

original: Jhāyī tapati brāhmaṇoti khīṇāsavabrāhmaṇo duvidhena jhānena jhāyamāno tapati virocati.
analyzed: jhāyī tapati khīṇāsava brāhmaṇaḥ duvidhena jhānena jhāyamānaḥ tapati virocati
translated: The brahmin shines who meditates: the brahmin who is an Arahant shines, glows, with the two kinds of meditation.

original: Tasmiṃ pana khaṇe kāludāyitthero duvidhena jhānena jhāyamāno avidūre nisinno hoti.
analyzed: tasmin pana khaṇe kāludāyi ttheraḥ duvidhena jhānena jhāyamānaḥ avidūre nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: At that moment the Elder Kāluḍāyī was sitting not far away meditating with the two kinds of meditation.

original: Buddho tapatīti sabbaññubuddho virocati. Sabbamaṅgalagāthā kiresā. Bhātikarājā kira
analyzed: buddhaḥ tapati iti sabbaññu buddhaḥ virocati sabba maṅgala gāthā bhātika rājā kira
translated: The Enlightened One shines: the Enlightened One who is omniscient glows, shines. This is the verse of all blessings. King Bhāti, it seems,

original: ekaṃ pūjaṃ kāretvā ācariyakaṃ āha – “tīhi ratanehi amuttaṃ ekaṃ jayamaṅgalaṃ vadathā”ti.
analyzed: ekam pūjam kāretvā ācariyakam āha tīhi ratanehi amuttam ekam jaya maṅgalam vadatha ati
translated: after making one offering, said to his chaplain, “Say a blessing with one victory in each of the three kinds of blessing.”

original: So tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ sammasitvā imaṃ gāthaṃ vadanto “divā tapati ādicco”ti🔽vatvā atthaṅgamentassa sūriyassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhi. “Rattimābhāti candimā”ti, uṭṭhahantassa
analyzed: saḥ tepiṭakam buddha vacanam sammasitvā imam gātham vadantaḥ divā tapati ādicca uti  vatvā atthaṅgamentassa sūriyassa añjalim paggaṇhi rattimā ābhāti candimā ati uṭṭhahantassa
translated: He, after pondering the Buddha’s word in the three Piṭakas, said this verse, beginning “By day the sun shines,”🔽and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the sun as it was setting. “By night the moon shines,”🔽and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the moon as it was rising. “The warrior shines in his mail,”

original: candassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhi. “Sannaddho khattiyo tapatī”ti rañño añjaliṃ paggaṇhi.
analyzed: candassa añjalim paggaṇhi sannaddhaḥ khattiyaḥ tapati iti raññaḥ añjalim paggaṇhi
translated: and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the king.

original: “Jhāyī tapati brāhmaṇo”ti bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhi. “Buddho tapati tejasā”ti
analyzed: jhāyī tapati brāhmaṇaḥ ti bhikkhu saṅghassa añjalim paggaṇhi buddhaḥ tapati tejasā ati
translated: “The brahmin shines who meditates,” and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the Community of Bhikkhus. “The Enlightened One shines in glory,”🔽and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the Enlightened One.

original: vatvā pana mahācetiyassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhi. Atha naṃ rājā “mā hatthaṃ otārehī”ti ukkhittasmiṃyeva
analyzed: vatvā pana mahā cetiyassa añjalim paggaṇhi atha nam rājā mā hattham otārehi iti ukkhittasmiṃ yeva
translated: and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the Great Shrine. Then the king said: “Do not let go your hands!”🔽

original: hatthe sahassaṃ ṭhapesi. Ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: hatthe sahassam ṭhapesi ekādasamam
translated: and he raised his clasped hands in reverential salutation to the Great Shrine. Then the king said, “Do not let go of your hand,” and he placed a thousand on the upraised hand.🔽The eleventh.

original: 12. Sahāyakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sahāyaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sahāyaka Sutta🔽The twelfth.

original: 246. Dvādasame cirarattaṃsametikāti dīgharattaṃ saṃsanditvā sametvā ṭhitaladdhino.
analyzed: dvādasame dīgharattam saṃsanditvā sametvā ṭhita laddhinaḥ
translated: “For a long time they have been in contact and agreement”: they have been in contact and agreement and have stood so for a long time, that is, for a hundred and five births.🔽For they roamed about together for a hundred and five births.

original: Te kira pañcajātisatāni ekatova vicariṃsu. Sameti nesaṃ saddhammoti idāni imesaṃ
analyzed: te kira pañca jāti satāni ekatas va vicariṃsu sameti na isam saddhammaḥ iti idāni imesam
translated: “Their true Dhamma is in contact”: now this Dhamma of the Dispensation is in contact with them,

original: ayaṃ sāsanadhammo saṃsandati sameti. Dhamme buddhappavediteti buddhena pavedite dhamme
analyzed: ayam sāsana dhammaḥ saṃsandati sameti dhamme buddha ppaveditā iti buddhena pavedite dhamme
translated: “In the Dhamma taught by the Enlightened One”: in the Dhamma taught by the Enlightened One,🔽the Dhamma of the Dispensation shines for them. The meaning is that it is well adorned.

original: etesaṃ sāsanadhammo sobhatīti attho. Suvinītā kappinenāti attano upajjhāyena ariyappavedite
analyzed: etesam sāsana dhammo sobhati iti attho su vinītā kappinena ati attanaḥ upajjhāyena ariya ppavedite
translated: “Well trained by the one of developed conduct”: well trained by his own preceptor in the Dhamma taught by the Noble Ones.

original: dhamme suṭṭhu vinītā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti. Dvādasamaṃ.
analyzed: dhamme suṭṭhu vinītā sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati dvādasamam
translated: The rest is clear throughout. The twelfth.

original: Bhikkhusaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Saṃyutta Nikāya is finished.

original: Iti sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: iti sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: Thus in the commentary on the Saṃyutta Nikāya

original: Nidānavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nidāna vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Nidāna Vagga is finished.
